column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Enjoyed this right after the tapping. Fire chief murky red brown creamy head. Piney citrus hops and malts I’m the nose. Sweet malts with a decent hop bitterness pine grapefruit body a little thin but good. 7/3/8/3/15. 3.6

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Pint draft at the brewpub (Lombard, IL). Pours a nice dark coppery red, lightly hazed, with a khaki thick moderate head that stays and laces well. Aromas are nice toasted carmel malts, light hoppy bouquet fades in and out, and some cereal graininess. Initial is a littlw lighter on the palate than expected, light carmel and toasty malts mix with light floral hoppy bitterness with a touch of citrus. Malt dominant, but fairly light and a little watery overall. Lacks flavor, lacks life! A mediocre amber.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Growler - purchased 03/24/2009. Dark burgundy, with a creamy off white head. Aroma is nutty with a roast character. Interesting flavor quite roast in character. Some spicy fruity, sort of weiss-bier notes. Medium creamy feel.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: On tap at Yorktown RB. Poured a cloudy, light walnut color, very much like Erik the Red, (but not red) which I had earlier. Had an off white head which diminished to a small ring with light lace. The aroma was roasty, with light coffee/mocha notes. The flavor added a medium hop bitterness and caramel notes as it warmed. Flavorful Bitter.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Pour is hazed warm amber with a sticky tan head...smell is lightly toasty and sweet...taste is lightly caramel sweet up front with a nice subtle citric bitterness throughout and rounding it out...

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: on tap at Rock Fest ’08. pours hazy brown-red. malty, bready, and yeasty aroma and flavor. crisp, pretty decent esb.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Mug Club Draft. Brewmaster Tim says he made the 2008 edition an "American Style" ESB because he had some Fuggles hops available. I think that’s how a lot of brewpub creations are going to be decided on for some time: "What can we make with the hops on hand?" Be that as it may, here’s a beer that pours a cloudy reddish-brown with a nice short but stiff head. I suspect Tim’s keeping the color close to the prescribed "red." Toffee malt smell punctuated by a dose of English hops and, for no reason that I can figure, a whiff of green chile pepper(?). Taste is pretty rich and hearty, with chewy but not sweet malts, settled by a punchy fresh hop taste (Tim says he also used Nugget, Centennial and Cascade). Rides the border between ESB and a "red" ale, but bitterness proves it. Very sessionable, I even enjoyed it in the chilled mug I got.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Fire Chief Ale
column5: Before this entry is summarily poo-pooed by the Powers-That-Be and relegated to the status of a duplicate addition of an already present corporate beer - - I had this at the brewpub during the course of a half hour conversation with the head brewer, Timothy Marshall. I asked, "Is this your recipe?" Tim replied, "I’ve heard this before. Let me set the record straight once and for all. NONE (his emphasis) of the Chicago area’s Rock Bottoms use ’corporate recipes.’ They’re all the creation of the individual brewers. If anyone has any questions, have them call me." Which is what I would recommend whoever verifies the beer should do, and not rely on the word of whatever serving staff person who answers the phone. Rant over... for now. The beer pours a bright copper body with a substantial head that performs some heavy lacing. The aroma is filled with caramel and sweet oranges with a touch of floral/earthy hopping. Medium bodied with a lively mouthfeel, the flavor has the addition of some peppery spiciness. It finishes on a mildly bitter, dry note. Sessionable. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Name: Lying Chaff Hefe-Weizen Date: 03/25/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub opaque dark yellow, big creamy white head, thick lace, big tart clove aroma with only a hint of fruityness and eventually some bubblegum, dry wheat flavor, nice lingering banana sweetness, starts off with a clove aroma and banana flavor and then switches back and forth creating a nice interplay, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Draught. Pours a cloudy yellow with a tall white head. The aroma has the token notes of banana, wheat, tart grassiness. I found this to be not as sweet as some others in the style with more apparent tartness. This is refreshing with a pleasing level of banana and faint spiced notes, though I think it could use a bit more character. It’s a nice drink though, especially in the brutal Hotlanta weather.

Date: 04/10/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub opaque burnt orange, big creamy off white head lasts until the first sip, lots of drippy lave, sweet malt aroma with lots of spicy esters, yeasty bready malt flavor, balanced with the spicyness, touch of sweetness rounds it out, fruity citrus orange character, a cross between a wit and a triple? Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4
tap @ now defunct brewpub on 16 Nov 2011. brown with small head. below average brown ale. malty, but thin.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Amber in color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of nut, caramel, malt, and toffee. Taste is of malt, hazelnut and caramel.

A - Pours a chestnut brown S - Toffee, caramelized brown sugar, toasted wheat bread, maple, toasted nuts. Very nice! T - Lots of nutty malt, some light sorghum, notes of caramel, vanilla, dry bread sprinkle with a dash of cocoa powder, hints of over-ripened blueberry. Finishes with nutty dry bread aftertaste. M - Medium to full bodied, adequate carbonation. Very good beer. Way better than expected. This is very rich without being sweet and heavy. Everything melds together well. A standout beer in it’s class. Serving type: bottle 05-09-2011
Pours red-brown, clear, with a tall tan head. Aroma is caramel, sweet nuts. Taste is cola, tangy caramel, sweet malt. Light hop bitter. Just OK.

Good aroma of caramel and light hops. Clear medium amber with a persistent head cover, light splashes of lace. The taste is caramel malt and hazelnut, impacted negatively through a greasy mouth-coating residue that makes it seem quite heavy. Not much going for this brew. Not recommended.

12oz bottle pours ruby red to amber with tan head of foam. The aroma offers up some sweet malts, roasted malts, sweet nuttiness and a dash of chocolate malts. Pretty nice. The taste is pretty darn sweet for the style, I think, with sweet malts, some honey like notes and then a bit of carbonation enhanced roasted malts astringent tart notes.

This brew pours a clear chestnut brown color with a medium foamy beige head that dissipates slowly to a film. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt and nuts. Light body with a sweet roasty character of malt and nuts. SLight hops in the background. The finish is short and leaves and earthy malt aftertaste. Pretty average overall.

Draught at the bar and food joint in Detroit airport. Butterscotch and caramel nose, with grains, brown sugar, and some diacetyl too. Roasty grain flavor, caramel, brown sugar, ok bitterness. Decent, but nothing special.
Very nice for style, with lots of caramel, nuts and chocolate. Brinze color and nice head.

[Bottle] Pours a very dark shade of brown with very little head. Decent looking lacing. Dusty nose of cocoa powder, earth and roasted malts. Decent roasted malt and caramel taste is followed by light vanilla and sweet nuts. Mild instant coffee and sweet rolls also in there. The finish is thin and grainy. Pretty standard.

19-Dec-09 (22-oz bottle: Purchased 09-Dec-09 for $4.99 at wineandcheeseplace.com) The nose is malty and slightly grassy, but the more prominent aromas of plastic and red apple skins linger. On the palate, caramely malts show a touch of sweetness, while the moderately bitter hops are very grassy and moderately piney. There's a bit of apple skin in the flavor too, especially in the finish. Medium in body, high in carbonation, dry and slightly chalky mouthfeel. Hazy, dark-amber body with a volcanic head that shoots up to over two inches in height before slowly settling to a quarter inch. Patchy lace initially, but it slides down the glass. Overall, this isn't an especially enjoyable beer, and between the plastic and apple skin qualities and the excessive carbonation on the pour, it seems this bottle isn't 100% healthy. A rerate should happen at some point, but I'm now two for two in saying that about Laughing Dog brews.

May be my first beer from Idaho. Definitely first beer from Laughing Dog. Been wanting to try them since I've seen it at Total Wine & More for the past year. They sold me on the label, as this really is not that good of a brew. Balance is off....over-carbonated, aroma smells like wet dog (no pun intended), etc. The appearance and hop finish on the flavor is about all going on here. For that the flavor is barely a 7. Kinda scared to try their others now for what they are charging. Why can't these brewers just bottle them in 6-packs and sell for what it's worth....$6-7 tops. To call this premium, stick a cool label on it, and sell for $5 a bomber is just a crime.

Thanks Frank. This was poured into an English pint glass. The appearance was a ruddy burnt orange almost copper color with a finger’s worth of light foamy white head. Some lace, but sliding and messy. The aroma had some biscuits, toast, sweet grain, butterscotch, caramel/toffee malts, earthy to grassy hops and a touch of dried leaves. The flavor was malty sweet like many ESB’s I have tried. Expected earthy hop to smooth malty crispness in the aftertaste. Finish was crisp and malty. The palate was roughly medium bodied with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation felt good as best as a bottled ESB can be. ABV felt as projected. Overall, I’d say this was a pretty good ESB worthy of having again if I could get it. Pass the fish n’ chips, Frank!
22 oz bottle. Poured a copper color with a frothy beige head. Taste of sweet malts, caramel and toffee. A little over carbonated, medium body. Excellent ESB!

A surprisingly on the money wan from a hit n miss Brewer. Copper color. Head sticks around. Aroma of nuts and caramel, slight earth and pine. A little toffee pine and earthy hops on the tongue. Smooth and easy.
22 oz bottle from notes. Pours a hazy amber/copper color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted malts, caramel, nutty, some earthy notes, light floral character, decent.

Shared 22 oz. bottle. As Laughing Dog CSB. Hah. Thought the CSB would stand for something similar to ESB. Not quite! Pour is hazy amber, with a thick beige head. Aroma is malty and bready. Taste is malty, bready, cloying, and sour. This is strange for an ESB, or perhaps for any beer. Not good. Didn’t finish it.

Aroma: sweetly malty with a slightly rotten note; Appearance: hazy amber with billowy white head that dissipates pretty quickly; Taste: unfortunately, it follows nose; Palate: medium body with long, sickly sweet finish; Overall: drain pour.

Big 1.5" chunky slightly tan head... looong lasting with very nice sticky lacing. Brown side of amber brew... clear... pretty. Aroma is fantastic.. toasty toffee malts and earthy hops.. fairly clean with only a touch of yeast esters. Flavor is bigboned for the style... full maltiness and bracing bitterness... fairly big spicy and grassy hops.... I would guess English style malts are used, but could easily be wrong. Lite very lite brown malt presence.. intricate... above average complexity.. Body is lite medium.. but somehow it and the carbonation pulls everything together very well with a lingering full tongue finish.
Old rating. Malty, sour, somewhat fruity and earthy. Interesting beer, didn't really get the ESB.

Clear golden, white head with good lacing. Smells like wort, a little bit of spice. The arse is moderately worty and sweet, lught but. It watery, moderate to strong bitterness with a hint if husk. Not the worst alcohol free lager.

(bottle 0,5l) Overall: Quite good for NA. Worty, but not such unpleasant as others. Aroma: Strong wort, light sweet. Appearance: Clear golden. Long lasting, white head. Taste: Wort, light sweet, medium bitter. Palate: Medium body. Astringent finish.

Bottle from ICA Maxi Eurostop outside of Örebro. Smell of wort. Sweet taste with wort, pale bread and some caramel. Light carbonation. Low bitterness. Drinkable but more like drinking light wort then finished beer.
Quite sweet, but still beer character, of a lager style. Decent low-alcohol alternative.

Nice, thick foam, golden, clear. Unpleasant note typical for low-alco beers + something sweet and malty. Taste is empty, low bitterness. The non-alcco note much less present in the taste, which is nice. Still, the beer is rather watery-sweet. Not that bad, bud i've had much better.
aromat słodowy, wygląd średni, smak pusty, ogólnie bez szału. Są lepsze piwa bezalkoholowe
Draft 500ml. Quite rich in flavor and taste. In comparison with other non-alcoholic beers, this has a closer taste to the classic pilsner.

0.5 l bottle from local 'Tesco', best before September 2018. Clear, golden amber with a medium large, frothy, almost stable, white head. Sweetish, slightly grassy-spicy aroma of grains and some straw. Just slightly sweet, moderately bitter, gently grassy-spicy taste of grains, some straw and just hints of wort, followed by a short, moderately bitter, pretty dry and slightly grassy-spicy finish. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft to average carbonation. Pretty dry NA beer, not bad.
50cl bottle. A clear dark golden beer with a huge most good lasting white head. Aroma of sweet breadish malt and grains. Taste of mid sweet grainy malt, bread, some sugar.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

This was absolutely fantabulous. Not extremely hop heavy, remains true to the style, a very nicely done American Barleywine. Rich and sweet on the palate without being cloying, brown sugar and honey notes, with some dark caramelized fruits, some candied fruit zest, but all remains in balance with the hops coming through giving some much needed bitterness. This is full bodied, but extremely well balanced and drinkable.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is malty-sweet with lots of caramel. Appearance is reddish brown with an incredibly well maintained light tan head (particularly for a barley wine). Flavor is rich with dark dried fruit and molasses; alcohol dos not come through, but is evident, which is more than I can say for the hops. Mouthfeel is full bopdied and slightly syrupy, with lots of warmth and a minor carb feel. Overall, a great example that is definitely more English than American in style, but brings out a lot of great portlike characteristics.
On Tap at the brewpub pours out brown topped with a dark tan head. A nice malt and caramel sweet aroma. A nice thick drink. pretty good.

On Tap at the brew pub. Cloudy deep redish brown. Creamy dense light brown head and fine persistant lacing. Dark malty aroma with notes of caramel and old barrels. Flavor is a strong balance of dark sweet malts and lots of bittering hops. Very thick palatte and soft carbonation. Nice big beer.

Draft: Pours a rich mahoghany color with ruby tones. Small off-white head and light lacing. The nose is citrus and malt, the taste moves into a more roasted malt with dark fruits, citrus, and caramel. Very smooth, no alcohol feel at all. Just a smooth, warming affect. Very pleasant and drinkable barleywine.

Tap: Pours a murky ebony color with light head and lacing. The nose has lots of alcohol with raisin, plum, sweet dough and lots of hops and candy. The flavor is chewy with caramel and alcohol with herbs and a light carbonation. Bitter finish but balanced. Mouthfeel is strong with a nice subtle malt presence.

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Almond Brown Ale
column5: On cask at the brewpub. Clear brown with a small tan head. Excellent lace. Sweet, nutty nose, lots of maltiness, toasty. Rich flavors of lightly toasted malt and sweet nuts. Medium creamy body. I liked this one quite a bit!

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Almond Brown Ale
column5: Cask, Very sweet malt aroma that definitely smells of what is probably some almond extract, but as I love a malt bomb I liked the aroma. The body is dark brown with a ridiculously lasting creamy tan head. The fore holds toasted malts, almond and other nuts and sweet dark fruit. As this was from a cask the head and lacing were beautiful. Easy to enjoy.

column1: Seven Bridges Toasted Almond Brown Ale
column5: Pint at the Seven Bridges Brewpub in Jacksonville. Hand pulled from cask. Rather average looking brown ale with a white head that soon fell away. Slight malty aroma. Flavor did not appeal to me at all, especially after having two other excellent beers there. Flavor was astringent malt, lacking in hops and bitterness. Last beer of the night and I didn’t even finish the glass. Subpar and not representative of the brewpubs usual standards. Really poor for an offering on cask.

Cask pint at The Red Tile, Cossington, Somerset. Pours clear pale golden with a slim with head. Aroma: biscuit malts, light honey, flowers. Taste: light sweet & bitter, lemon citrus, floral hop. Light bitter finish. Light body with low carbonation. Not a lot to it really

Tap at Hankridge Arms Taunton. Pours pale gold with no head. Very little aroma (no carbonation). Taste is lemon/citrus with decent bitterness on the front and mid palate. Texture is thin and watery. Served quite cold for am ale. Not great but might be OK on a hot day.
On tap. Pours golden orange colour with low white head, murky liquid. Medium bitterness, low sweetness, low sourness. Medium body, thick feel, high carbonization, ligth bitter finish.

Clear golden, one inch white creamy head. Stays. Honey, biscuit cake, floral & spicy notes on nose. Light to medium body. Bittersweet taste. Floral hops again. Short finish with malts & hops. Not bad.
Sample at SBWF 2016. Light fruity smell with some flowers, bread and light hops. Similar taste. Light. Clean. Not that hoppy but a very drinkable beer.
Barril, en El Cervecero. Dorada clara, aroma lupulado ligeramente herbal. Agradable en boca, suave al paladar, malteada y delicadamente lupulada. Muy bebible.

On tap at the sloop. This golden ale, is very refreshing, with a slightly bitter yet not to sweet taste. Goes beautifully with a summers day and a hard days thirst. Its taste is hard to distinguish at first, but towards the end of the pint a slight taste of nutmeg and meringue comes through. I’m not a great fan of badger’s beers but this installment isn’t too bad and is something that I could probably drink more often.
On tap at Tröls. A fine English pale ale, love the english malts that brings citrus, peach, grass and herbs with them balanced with a nice semi-sweet maltiness. Get it and try it.
Draught @ Cockney Pub. Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt, grass, herbs. Flavor is malt, little sugary, herbs, grassy hops, little butter. Medium body, soft carbonation. 240114
Cockney Pub, Aarhus, DK. Cask, 011113. Amber with small head. Aroma of fruit and malt. Flavor with spices and hop fruit

Bottle 33cl bought at Le marché de Nathalie in Bouillon 3 years ago. Pours hazy blond with a medium white head. Nose: dried fruits, floral, cheesy, malts... Taste: strong carbonation. Sweet (dried fruits) malty and floral. Some citruszeste, soap...

Bottle thnx to Beerlover_ben . Pours very clear and light blonde . Small white head . Smell is yeasty , rotten fruits . Taste is sharp , the aspects of rotten fruits is intense and joined with some sweeteners ...
Een blond biertje zonder veel smaak, ik heb er veel betere geprobeerd, teleurstellend

15/VI/14 - 33cl bottle from De Zytholoog/Bierloods (Adegem) @ home - BB: XII/12 (2014-637) Clear light blond beer, big fizzy irregular white head, unstable, dissipates rather quickly, non adhesive. Aroma: sour apples, floral, elder flowers, bit soapy, citrus, some grains. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sourish, soapy touch, spices, dry, pears, coriander, bitter. Aftertaste: very soapy, pretty bitter, some citrus, apple skin, alcohol noticeable.
Alcohol sweet aroma with sour notes, some fruit, perhaps. Head disappears quickly. Sour, tangy flavour. Soapy.
Pas de mousse, nez un peu acide, goût bizarre, pas de houblon... Pas leur meilleure, ou alors je suis tombé sur une mauvaise...

33cl @ Delirium BB 05-2010. Gusher, once again, keeps the br. Bouillon’s tradition that anything not over four years past the expiration date will gush. The brewery has some serious bottling issues. Dorée sur un profond doré foin, col blanc épais. Arôme fruité, houblonné agrumes/citronné avec ce joli bouquet de noix. En bouche, dors et déjà, cette bière est sauvée par le rajout de noix qui donne une très belle dimension au palais. Le tout se mélange bien à un profile plus centré sur le houblon, les agrumes. Malt est léger, laissant une pointe de caramel/biscuité avec ce très bon côté de noix, le tout sur une carbonnation qui donne un pétillant trop agressif et qui se retrouve dans bcp trop de leurs bières. Dommage car le produit a du potentiel.

Light yellow coloured beer with medium carbonation and a medium white head. Light malty hinted aroma with a light alcoholic yeasty touch. Full sprankling palate. Finish is light bitter sweet and yeasty hinted. Long dry hoppy finish. Not bad.

(bottle, 33cl, gushing) Cloudy, pale golden colour with a medium-sized foamy white head. Yeasty, slightly sweet grainy and wheaty malty aroma with sour-fruity notes of citrus. Bitter and slightly sour-tart flavour, medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Yeasty and slightly grainy taste with notes of wheat and citrus, accompanied by mild spicy notes; pretty dry and bitter-spicy finish. Not very attractive. 23.I.10

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, grain, toasted, lemon notes, moderate yeasty, coriander. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090403]

Pint at the Seven Bridges Brewpub in Jacksonville. Hand pulled from cask. Very dark almost black beer with a big tan head that lasted a while. Aroma of dark roasted malts. Flavor was excellent, a complex mix of sweet dark malts, roasty coffee and chocolate, subtle hints of vanilla, a good hop presence, and nicely bitter finish. Tasty and easy drinking. Similar to their Iron Horse Stout but a slight malt sweetness replaces the faint saltiness. I really enjoyed this.

Bottled - 250ml. Found by my Dad in his travels in Calais. Pours a nice gold colour with a good white head. Has a real floral aroma, with a very dry citrus taste. Just your average French beer, just about drinkable.

Bottled(250ml). -Brought by a friend from somewhere. Best before end passed on 13th of January 2007, so I’ll re-rate it as soon as (if) I found it again. Golden coloured, small white head, lively carbonation. Very dusty aroma with notes of caramel and hay.
Bottle. A very timid opening, just a hint of wheat, almost no froth and very little roundness in taste. Ok but a bit watery.

330ml botlle. Body is golden with a huge off-white head. Aroma is fruity yeast with a little hint of yeast. Flavor is fresh, relatively sweet, some malt, a certain level of sourness (recognizable from the Kvernkrnurr, but not this overwhelming). The finish has certain bitterness. Medium body and a bit watery. This beer is promising as a kind version of a German style weissbier but not to complex. At a certain level I recognize some of the “infection” acidity from Kvernknurr, but not to annoying this time. This could have something to do with this beer sampled quite fresh and this style beer could easy tolerate certain sourness at a moderate level. I want to re-rate this beer from another batch, this could be a quite interesting beer somewhere between average and complex weissbier.

330ml bottle. Hazy, dark golden body with a big, creamy off-white head. Aroma is fruity and acidic. Flavor is acidic fruity like green apples, some citric, moderate but pronounced bitterhops and yeast. Body is a bit thin. Not exactly a very complex beer, but refreshing in it’s own way and actually may be on it’s way to infection, but no clear evidence of that when sampled.

Bottle. A hazy, golden-orange beer volcano-ing out of the bottle, settling a finger-thick, diminishing off-white head. Milky sour notes in the aroma, slightly citric, with some hops, a touch of malts and some faint papery notes. Citrusy and piney hops giving some bitterness in the mouth, and also some malty sweetness. Thin to medium body. Sweet and lemon-sour finish with a pleasant bitterness. Sure going bad. Citrusy sourness and piney and bitter hops make a strange combination. The beer is still drinkable and refreshing, but I wonder how much longer that would have lasted. (081202)
Bottle. Dar golden- orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is acid, orange, citrus peel. Flavour is acid, orange citrus peel, malt, hop. Ordinary beer.

330 ml bottle, bought at Hotel Havana (which is not a hotel, but an upmarket delicatessen / grocery store in Oslo). Brew #1, BB May 2009. ABV is 4.7%. Cloudy amber to orange colour, moderate but lasting off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma, also notes of citrus and white wine vinegar. The flavour has a moderate hoppiness, but unfortunately also some vinegary notes which may mean that an infection is on its way. Dry and sourish finish.

Bottle from Hotel Havana, Oslo. Fully diminishing offwhite coarse head. Cloudy orangey-brown body. Fresh and fruity hop nose; lemon, unripe pinapple and a hint of pine, supported by a light caramellish malt scent. Taste is dry malty, has a fine bitterness, and a fruity acidity with a twist of vinegar. Medium body. Dry, almost tart fruity ending.

Bottle. Pours cloudy orange with some sediment and a tan creamy head. Interesting fruity aroma, quite sharply acidic, orange zest, but adding to that passion fruit and soothing toffee. Good bitterness, orange zest dominates, quite dry. It is miles away from an English pale ale; though containing no wheat, it certainly comes close to some saisons. Refreshing it is, anyway.

Bottle shared by GrOve. Nice, fresh, hoppy aroma with a thin malty body underneath. There is, however, some citric acid lurking underneath in this one, too, so I thing this should be drunk as fresh as possible.

Thin white head. Hazy orange body. Citric tropical fruit aroma with toffeeish malt notes and some plums. Dry citric tropical fruit taste with grapefruit notes. Aftertaste is all fruit: oranges, mango, and grapefruit. Very dry all the way through, almost a bit harsh. Very unusual, but grows on prolonged acquaintance. Nice. (Small sample from bottle, Bølgen & Moi, Oslo.)
Old rating, 0,33l bottle @ home: Aroma is fruity, hops, grain and hints of citrus. Taste is slightly dry, hops, light malts, hay. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Fair enough.

Dagens underlige. Dukket opp i en kjeller i Grebbestad. Erdet ikke en stund siden disse forsvant tenkte jeg. Joda denne hadde BB apr 09. Men måtte smake. Flott disig gylden farge med hvit skum på toppen. Lett fruktig og syrlig aroma. Ser av tidligere ratinger at den har hatt en viss sødme. Ikke mye sødme igjen her. Syrlig og fruktig med en grei malt bakgrunn. Fortsatt frisk og drikkelig tre år etter BB.

Bottled. An unclear light golden beer with a huge white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of citrus. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of lemon and spices, leading to a dry bitter finish. The body is thin. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.
Botella. Hazy golden colour with a huge white head. Bit sweet hoppy mildly fruity aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a nice bitter hoppiness with some frutiness and malt. Bitter pleasant finish.
33cl bottle slightly cloudy yellow, thick white head. sour socki’sh aroma, also some ordinary sour and some citrus. flavor is grainy grassy, hops, sort of rough compsition.

Okay... 0,33l Bottle bought at Vinmonopolet Røa, Oslo, Norway. Lovely honey golden colour, slightly hazy. White, long lasting head, BUT wayyy too much. Foams more than any belgian tripel or wheat beer I’ve ever seen. The most over carbonated beer I’ve ever seen.Tried 3 btls. All the same. Light aroma of floral and slightly lemony hops, barely noticeable light malt (some wheat?) and refined or light candi sugar (none of those are supposed to be in a pilsner, or what!?). The foam and head structure supports this theory too. Dry, acidic and foamy entrance on the palate the body is quite slim, but the creamy mousse makes the body seem bigger. Nice acid structure, though. Lemon/lime’ish, floral and Belgian blonde’ish sugar dryness and taste. Quite short aftertaste, but with a medium bitterness that lingers for sometime. All in all a bit unbalanced, certainly not a pilsner, more a bitter Belgian blonde and horribly overcarbonated and way too foamy.

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of yngwie. Hazy pale golden with a dense white head. Lightly tart fruit aroma. Medium body, lightly tart, fruity and spicy with quite some yeast. Rather bitter finish. Not completely terrible and not really a Pils. 030608

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Batch 2. It poured a murky orange colour with a medium white head. The aroma smells of hops and grass. It has a dry, spicy and fruity flavour that tastes of malts, apricot and a hint of vinegar. It reminds me of a blend of lager and an IPA. Strange but pleasant. It has a short aftertaste.

33 cl bottle - thank you yngwie. Bath # 2, best before 03/09. Slightly hazy golden color, very big and lasting white head. Aroma is hops and some citrus. Flavor is hops, malt, fruit. Fine malty and bitter finish. High carbonation. Not bad.

Bottle, brygg no 2. Label states Yme Pils, but with 5.5% ABV (sold by Vinmonopolet after all), I suppose it is the Yme Pils Spesial. Gradually, the cloudy, grapefruit-coloured beer appears under the enormous, off-white head. Decent grassy hop aroma with hints of citrus. Toffee and grass flavours as well as a hint of grapefruit with good bitterness throughout. A quite good Kellerbier it has become.
Dkkddjdjdjfjdjdjdjdjdjdjdjdjdjjddjdjdjdjdhr djdjdjdjdjfjdjdjdjdjdjdjdrjdjdjrjdjdjjddjdjrjrjfj ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cerveja agradável ao paladar. Cor muito bonita e aroma bom também Gostei bastante ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aparência marrom escura(lembra refrigerante de cola ou vermute tinto),creme bege alto e de boa duração com grande formação de bolhas,média carbonação;aroma de torrefação e caramelo;quanto ao sabor bem "suave" para o estilo(Bock),dulçor do malte torrado se sobressai,apresentando notas de chocolate e café,lúpulo e álcool são sentidos no final,bem refrescante para uma "Bock",alias lembra mais uma "Dunkel";ótima drinkability,talvez uma opção "Bock" de verão.

Aromas of toast, chocolate-covered cherries, graham cracker, cookies and cream. Brown-black, somewhat lasting beige head. Sweet, not unlike Keebler Elf chocolate-drizzled shortbread cookies, some earthiness like steeped tree bark, subtle birch beer and cream soda, soft mintiness like Pepto Bismol. Medium bodied, aftertaste is a little astringent.

Creme bonito e cafezado. Sem muita duração. Coloração marrom escura e opaca. Aroma doce de malte torrado, um pouco de cravo. Gostoso. Como outros falaram, é um pouco rala, mas o sabor é bom, caramelado, de malte torrado e doce, com um retrogosto persistente e agradável. O 5,5% de álcool mal é percebido.
Pours black. Aroma and taste are roasted malts, smokiness, and mildly sweet and then mildly bitter.
Uma bock escura de sabor leve, maltada com notas acentuadas de grãos torrados. De espuma pouco espessa.

Bock boa, da sempre confiável dado bier. Falta, porém, alguma complexidade no sabor (embora seja incomparavelmente melhor que as bocks das grandes cervejarias), bem como algum amargor. Espuma pouco densa e cor um pouco decepcionante (podia ser mais escura)

Boa formação de espuma, mas pouca persistência, líquido preto com reflexos avermelhados. Aroma de queijo inicial. Cerveja leve de corpo básico, pequeno amargor inicial, sendo que a presença de malte é bem mais sensível que a de lúpulo.
Pours an almost totally black colour with a tall head. Aroma is lightly roasted and some coffee. Taste is similar with little bitter finish. Not too bad.

Can (in NZ). Not quite black, more a dark brown. A thinnish and sweet palate, a touch of roast and caramel. If there could be such a thing as a sessionable version in this style, this would be a pretty good impression.

Dourada,límpida,boa carbonação,espuma com boa formação e duração,no aroma malte,fermento e um leve floral do lúpulo no final,sabor acompanha o aroma,maltado com leves traços de lúpulo ao fundo,refrescante,final seco.
Boa de trigo...aroma de banana...pouco cremosa...pouco amarga...coloraçao turva...refrescante
Pours a clear yellow color. Aroma and taste are lightly hoppy with a mildly bitter finish.
Outra pilsen bastante doce. Aparência sem nada de especial. Sem mais comentários.

this recipe was reformulated about 2011, they said it should now be a bohemian pilsner. In fact this is not a bohemian pilsner, but is a good lager, with a soft hoppy aroma, in the mouth is balanced with malts flavours, little bitterness.
Pours a clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma is malt with hints of grass and hops. Taste is medium sweet leading to a bitey lightly bitter finish. Not bad.

I had a tall can of this beer poured into a glass while in Rio de Janeiro. The beer had a clear gold color with a small bubbly white head that had little retention and cling. It had a grassy and grainy hops aroma with a bit of corn and adjuncts. The flavor was surprisingly bitter and grainy, and not very pleasant. It had a thin, lightly-carbonated mouthfeel without much texture.
Bottled. A yellow beer with a white head. Aroma is sweet and slightly grassy. Taste is quite simple. Malty. A little bit watery.
Uma pilsen sem-graça, lembra os maus tempos da Kaiser, com aroma que lembra enxofre. A espuma é fraca. O preço não compensa.
Típica cerveja pilsen brasileira a qual, apesar de ser "artesanal, assemelha-se muito às "de mercado". Aroma e sabor quase inexistentes. Aguada. Não perca o seu tempo. Mineral beer.
Uma cerveja de trigo batata porém honesta. Amargor suave. Aroma suave de cravo e banana.
Breja de trigo dentro da média nacional. Não possui muito corpo, mas é refrescante.
Bottle. Golden colour with a weak head. Nose is poopy, vegetal. Taste is thin, a bit bland. Faulty. The yeast is a mess here.

Liquido turvo,coloração clara,boa formação inicial de espuma,mas,que não se mantem,aroma e sabor típicos de uma weiss,porem de uma maneira bem suave(seria uma Weiss light?),é bem refrescante,talvez agrade os iniciados,bom preço é um atrativo,mas não passa de uma breja regular.
Bom exemplar de weiss nacional. Odor de baunilha e cravo, tipico de weiss de qualidade
Cor amarelo palha com turvidez. Boa formação de espuma. Tipicidade. Aroma frutado com especiarias. Boa acidez e carbonatação repetindo o aroma. Corpo médio e drinkabilidade.
Muito bonita, espuma bem formada, coloração bonita. Porém, a acidez atrapalha a cerveja. Na verdade, mata a cerveja.
Falta complexidade no sabor e no aroma (a banana e o cravo, por exemplo, muito comuns em weissbiers, não estão presentes). Boa para uma weissbier brasileira, mas longe das alemãs

Pours a cloudy yellow colour with a frothy white head. Aroma is wheaty and citric fruit. Taste is very light, refreshing of more citric fruit and wheat. Not sweet enough and a little watery but not too bad.
Bottled from dado pub. A watery weizen that’s almost more of a witte. OK but not enough heft in the hefe.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Bottle 50cl. @ 2D2Dspuma Tienda, Barcelona, Spain. A: Amber. T: Hops, malt, sweet, tropical fruits, resin.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Botella del @Lupulo feroz, Oviedo. 10/09/16 Bottled: 25/11/2015 Color amarillo oscuro, aromas caramelo, frutal. sabor dulce, final lupulado.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: En bouteille. Robe orange cuivrée. Arôme de résine et d’alcool. Gout résineux. Amertume légère et plaisante. L’alcool fait sentir sa présence. Pétillement léger en bouche.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: 18th August 2016 Bright clear amber beer, decent cream colour head. Palate is light, slightly dry and decent carbonation. Malts are sweet, some thin malt cream. Mild hop spice and pine. Smooth orange, floral orange and light orange peel. Light spicy finish. Some alcohol showing through but no heat. Drinkable but could do with more hop intensity.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: 50 cl bottle. Bottled on 25.11.2015. Pours clear dark golden color with a large white head. Aroma is sweet with mango and some orange, resinous hops, some malt and nut tones, mild pine. Malty sweet flavor with a slick palate, some resinous hops, mango, passion fruit, orange and subtle pineapple, quite juicy, also grapefruits too. Some bitterness and very faint alcohol burn on the aftertaste. Not very fresh anymore but very good still, the age can be noticed on the aroma more than on the flavor. 4414

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Flarra. Doftar milt av hav å lite trä. Omedelbart i munnen medelfyllig viss sötma. Sötman smakar Titti frutti. Hallonbåtar . Sen kommer jaaa klassiska Dipa smaker . God frisk Dipa . Dock något söt å tuttifruttig för att få topp betyg.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Le liquide est jaune orangé, mi-épais avec une carbonatation assez faible ; le nez est quant à lui dans le sucré et le fruité, laissant planer le doute sur qui, des malts ou des houblons, dominera en bouche. Au final les deux se complètent et se suivent : attaque de riches malts caramélisés pour commencer, vite tranchés secs par une amertume intense et durable. Rarement une double IPA est aussi bien équilibrée, Charlevoix a elle-même connu des ratés sur ce plan dans sa série VF, mais celle-ci touche la cible. Une des meilleures de ce côté du continent.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Achetée directement a la microbrasserie. Elle a ete brassée il y a plus de 3 mois... Vous en aviez pas de la fraiche?? Gros bof. On ne goute que l’alcool et le malt. Où est le houblon? Je ne comprends pas le rating aussi élevé...

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Où, Quand, Comment : Dégustée en fût au Saint-Bock à Montréal et titrant 8% abv (printemps 2007). Visuel : Couleur : ambrée. Apparence : claire. Arôme : Houblon fruité (agrumes, abricots), citrique et aux notes résineuses, caramel doux. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Amer de houblon fruité (abricots, pêches, agrumes), citrique, légèrement résineux et herbeux, présent toute la gorgée. Un support malté de caramel doux sucré est également présent avec quelques notes poivrées. En bouche : Corps : moyen. Effervescence : moyenne. Texture : légèrement crémeuse et aux petites notes résineuses. Finale : longue et un peu sèche, amère de houblon citrique aux notes fruitées, résineuses et herbeuses.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Amarillo Double IPA
column5: Bouteille de 500ml. 2015/11/25. Superbe robe cuivrée avec une importante couche de mousse. Une rocaille qui laisse une belle dentelle. Premier nez d’herbe, de foin coupé, de marijuana, tabac, sucre d’orge et ananas. Une bouche sur le même registre avec beaucoup d’herbe et de résine. Une certaine chaleur est présente en finale.

355ml can pours a pale straw color with a small white head that leaves no lacing behind. Aromas are light grains and mild hops. Taste is along the same lines which is typical for the style. Just another typical macro lager.
[2034-20090312] 355mL can. Veggie yeast and scratchy hay aroma. Clear, yellow body with a quick foamy white head. More veggie straw yeast in the flavour. Light body. Terrible. (w/ jerc)

2009-03-12. Yellow body with a small white head. Muted aroma, lightly grainy lightly alcoholic. Flavour is similarly muted and mild. Very light muted grains, light bitterness, light touch of alcohol. Not much going on here. Very small amount of hops? Relatively clean and inoffensive. Average to thin bodied palate. Meh. Can from NB Liquor

341 ml bottle from Moosehead cold beer store here in Dartmouth NS. First off the lable says nothing about what the beer is except "real taste and clean finish". Pours a basicly non existant head and straw colored body. Standard aroma. It has no real taste that stand out besides what I would call a discount beer aftertaste. This beer is boring and over priced. Moosehead failed this time.

Canette de 355 ml achetée chez ANBL (Dieppe, N-B). Arôme: Légère odeur de céréale et de miel. Apparence: La couleur est blonde avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréale avec une pointe fruitée. Courte durée d el’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps et la texture sont mince. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréale en arrière goût. (Rating #1479)

Can. I can’t believe I actually poured this into a glass. Very light smells of grain and sweat. Head was small, fizzy, white with no lacing and fully diminished. Color is clear gold. Flavor is lightly acidic. Palate is light and watery with a fizzy carbonation and a dry finish. Blecch.

The Aussies routinely brew beers that are halfway between regular beers abd light beers. They call them "Midstrengths" and every major brewer in Australia has at least one in their lineup. Anyway, I digress... This pours like a Corona-- pale clear straw yellow with a rich foamy white head leaving no lace. Low grainy aroma. Light watery grainy palate. The only positive thing to say is that it tasted clean (unlike the mouthful of piss Alpine Max I tried yesterday), but otherwise pretty featureless and lacking in character.
A bit of a livened up light beer. Pours straw yellow and has some light malt notes. You actually get a light hit of hops on th finish. It is better than miller lite.

I was surprised - there was a bit of taste to this stuff. barely, but I did notice something. However, I am keeping the low rating for the television commercial which proudly proclaims: "Half way between a lager and a light beer". Half way between a lager and pure spring water would have been a more appropriate advertising campaign.

355 ml can from New Brunswick Liquor Corporation on King Street, Saint John, New Brunswick (May 2007), served right out of the fridge and defiling my Christoffel glass in the process. Ha! Halfway between light and "regular" beer. What the hell. Anyway, there’s a big frothy, fizzy head that dies away very quickly atop the pale, you-could-read-through-it-clear cidery body.....aroma is not unpleasant, what there is of it, barely distinguishable mild adjuncty graininess....on the tongue, well, it’s cold, that’s about all I can say about that. There is a bit of a metallic character at the finish that’s not so pleasant but otherwise there’s really nothing I can grasp, just an extremely faint corn sugar - dry stale bready quality....carbonation is low, mouthfeel is syrupy yet very thin at the same time. About as "good" as the Cold-Filtered Light I had a couple of days ago.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Bottle conditioned and nicely done by an experienced brewery. Typical Hampshire chocolate malt flavours. Nice. I have a real soft spot for Hampshire - their beers are always very tasty and very drinkable.

Bottle. Amber with an off-white foam. Aromas are nutty and earthy with toffee and chocolate malts. Wheat with some citrus. Flavours are toffee and weetabix malts with citrus and wheat. Clean hops with a woody finish.
Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Sweet toffeish bitter with appley fruit. A little toastyness provides a boost in the middle but this seems overly sweet and stodgy in the finish.
Tap - small foamy head, pale straw color, light and sweet malt/corn like aroma and flavor, mild hop balance, crisp finish, ok overall ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample at the brewry. Clear golden with just a little off white foam. Aroma is spicy. As is the flavor. Earth and grain with a little corn. Noble hops are nice. A little honey. Bitterness is pleasant. A much better Pilsner than what is often brewed in the US.
This is a great example of how an unfiltered/non-pasteurized Bohemian style lager should be. It’s clean, crisp with a great hop finish. I could drink this all day.
On tap at rock island location, pours a hazy yellow with a thin head, aroma had a slight kick of corn and not much else, flavor has a corn front end with a sweet finish, boring, meh.
On tap at the brewpub in a pint glass. Sour corn flavor with a slight hoppy bitterness, but not enough.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was dark gold with a dense, bright white head. The aroma was grainy with some bread crust. There was also some hints of the spicy Saaz with green bell pepper. The taste was fairly sweet with some cake donus. There was also carrots and peanut shells. Decent.

Looks like this brewery is starting to et into the lagering game. Lightly hazed golden color with a full white head. Small lines of lace. Light noble hops, with a touch of grass. Mild pale malt drift around in the background. Light pale malt sweetness in the front followed by a light zip of zest. Finish is crisp and light. Perhaps a touch acidic, but a nice domestic pils.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden color. Head was thin and white. There wasn’t much lace on the glass at the end. Pretty standard pilsener. Light noble hop aroma complimented by a tocuh of cereal grain. Slightly sweet on the tongue. Honey touched malty cereal grain dominated the flavor with only a bit of hop in the background.
another solid beer from bent river.....straight forward, mild hops, very quenching.....i knew i wasn’t drinking watered down crap, but it didn’t over power and distract me from my burger

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: ABR 2007. Brown body. Grains and light rye in the nose. Malty body with faint rye and a little hop finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: On draught at the ABR 07 in Minneapolis, MN. Pours a semi-clear brownish amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that dissipates clean. Aroma of multi-grain malt, a touch of lime zest and some apples. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a very dry multi-grain and flowery hop flavor. Finish is dry, a litle gritty and some metalic aftertaste.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: nice beer, cooler name. nice and ark farily strong dont recall exact notes but a nice beer and would try again for sure!

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: Glad this was already listed on here...i had no clue what style it was. Digging the name. Farily dark, nice malt base to it. I liked it. Enjoyed at Arborfest

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: Gitchee Gumee Brewfest: Dark Brown Color with No Head. Subtle Malt/Rye Aroma. Dry Rye and Malt Flavors...Clean and Grainy Tasting...Lightly Dry and Sweet Ending. Medium Bodied. Nice Offering from Rock Bottom.

column1: Rock Bottom Minneapolis R T Ryebock
column5: Named for Minneapolis mayor R. T. Rybak. Dark mahogany hue, with bright-ish burgundy highlights. Smaller head from this pour than I got at the pub yesterday, (but this growler has been waiting in the fridge since then...the RB growlers tend that way, in my experience.) Aroma: malty sweet, hints of chocolate, toast, cherries, & tobacco. Slightly smoky. Quite nice. Tasty right from the start, a copious helping of delicious malty flavor, and sublimely smooth. Grapes and other dark fruit are here, met with a grainy texture, that plays well off the tongue, Continues solid, smooth, and intriquingly delicious. I’ll be enjoying the remains of this growler and checking in for a few more pints before this disappears.
Hand pump at the brewery. Pours a clear yet dark amber (ruby red hue) with a small off white head. Aroma of light citrus, malt and red wine. Taste of light citrus, faint malt and wine. Watery.
Draft at Brewpub. As JRedmond discribed it so elequently it is a mix of ales together in a cask. Rather offensive brew with notes of biscuit and hop spice. Very disappointing. 2.55

Draft at the brewpub. Described by the waitress as a mix of a bunch of different beers, although she wasn’t told which ones. It pours a clear darkish brown body with some head. Aroma is malty and bready. The taste is clearly complex but mildly offensive.

Tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in 2007. This was specially brewed to commemorate Jack Drew, a real ale stalwart who worked hard behind the PBF scene - nice way to be remembered eh. Cask, Handpump dispense. Ruby black in colour with a thin creamy buff head. Whiff of wood smoke in the pleasant aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Dark malts give a full roasted grain flavour with hints of burnt maltloaf and raisin fruit. Pleasant hop bite in the aftertaste and onto a dry woody finish. Tastes like an old ale. Good stuff.
Nice ruby colour, with a light malt fruit nose, and a deep rich fruit flavour with a little hoppyness in its finish.
Malty, toffee, horrible, not my scene, typicle, arran.......................

Date: 04/28/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, Dark Lord Day, 2007 opaque orange, wispy off white head, sweet fruity aroma wist a nice spicy character, creamy body, lots of spicy flavor, light fruity character, nice complexity, touch of funk adds to the complexity Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
On tap @ the brewpub. Golden and orange in colour with a medium sized off-white head. Dry and fruity with notes of spices, herbs and also some sweetness.

Growler pour @ DLD 4/28. Pours cloudy orange/copper color with a small white head. The aroma had notes of citrus, corriander, grass, and some funk. The flavor consisted of more citrus, spices, sweet malt, and an acid tartness. Medium mouthfeel, smooth drinking. Not my favorite, but worth one sample.

From a growler at DL Day: Pours a surprisingly deep amber with reddish highlights and a small head which left just a hint of film on the glassware. The aroma has notes of coriander, rosemary, ginger ale, biscuity malts, toffee, apple, pear, and a hint of brett like funk. The taste mostly followed suit with a spicy character over a layer of acidic fruit and malty base. Bready and slightly gummy finish. The mouth feel is smooth and soft. Okay at best but worth the try.

Sampler at Clybourn. Quite a change from the reds, weizens and bitters I’ve been sampling tonight (June 6). Brown pour with rosy highlights. Nice brettish smell—if you like that sort of thing. Tart taste that more likely from warm fermenting. Tongue tingling and dry, with a melange of spices, though my impression is more of cherries and sour apple.

Date: 4/28/2007 Event: DarkLord Day 2007 Location: Three Floyds Brewing Co. Parking Lot Serving: Sampled from a growler. Tasting Notes Aroma: Slight funk and grassy notes. Appearance: Hazy/cloudy honey color, almost opaque. Flavor: Fruity and somewhat malty with a slight corriander spice to it and a hint of tartness. Palate: Average. Overall: Okay, but again nothing special. I’m glad Goose Island is constantly trying to make new beers, but they need to work a bit more at it. Many of the brewpub beers that I have had, including this one, turn out to be only marginally better than average...

(Tap) Pours a muddled amber color with a foamy white head. Aroma includes ginger, bread, and other spices. The taste features quite a bit of sweet malt, with some caramel and toffee noticeable. Otherwise, some hints of grass impart a dry bitterness near the end. Certainly an interesting beer, with a lot going on in it.

Draught. At the Clybourn brewpub. Slight hazy amber with a small off-white head. Fairly wan sweet caramel malt aroma, weak contributions from soft spices and yeast. Tasted a bit beefier (served too cold for the aroma?), coriander and other spices, yeast and sweet malt which seemed a touch lactic in the finish. Average body, mild carbonation, slightly bitter and, oddly, acidic - it was okay, not a home run though.
Pours a hazy copper color with a white head. Aroma is musty, banana, clove, and slightly bready. Flavor is malty, musty, and some clove.

I don’t comprehend why this is a "new" Saison from Goose Island merely because it has differing ingredients from past versions and is aged somewhat differently. After all, it is just another Saison, overly chilled, poured into a tulip glass, isn’t it? So much for this week’s commentary on Wild Blossom’s Sweet Desire 2005... This is a fine entry into the Saison category by GI. It’s a hazy amber/gold with a modest white head that does some spotty lacing as you drink. The aroma (once it warmed) is sharp and pungent, somewhat funky, with citrus zest, newly mown grasses, and wildflowers. Medium bodied, it’s somewhat bitter with grass and fruit rinds, has a splash of pale malt, a touch of coriander (can’t taste the ginger), and watered down citrus juice. It finishes on a bitterly refreshing note. Not bad. Goose Island - Clybourn, Chicago, IL
7/18/2010. From bottle. Very nice DIPA and too bad it’s no longer available. Amber color with a white head. Caramel, hops, malt and floral aromas. Very nice balance and hoppy finish.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Dense beige head. Aroma: caramel, pine, flowers, light soap. Flavour: Herbs, light soap, pine, caramel, sweetness, medium to full bodied. Ends on a medium somewhat grapy bitterness. Nice

Bottle at yespr. Cloudy red-brown coloured with a medium sized beige head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits and burnt sugar. Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits and burnt sugar with notes of hops. Sweet and hoppy finish.

Purchased time ago at Chevy Chase in Washington DC, vintage 2007, 5 years old Dark brown color; small creamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, roasted nuts, light vanilla. Good body strength, with sweet rich flavor of caramel, malt, some chocolate; the oxidisation is almost absent; it has a good bitterness level. Very good.

Bottled. An unclear dark red beer with dark a yellowish head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, roasted malt, and over ripe fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, over ripe friuts, and roasted malt, leading to a dry finish. Thanks fiiulijn for sharing.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of fiulijn. Pours a hazy orangey brown with a creamy and lacing beige head. Nutty aroma, burned caramel, oxidized. Rich body, nutty and toffeeish, overripe fruit, again oxidized. Some warming alcohol and hops, but no crisp hop character. More of a British Barley Wine. 160912

22 fl oz bottle, #0847. Pours hazy orange with a small tan head. Aroma is cheesy, solid hoppy, pine and caramelish. Light oxidised. Dense hoppy, pine and bitter. Herbal, solid malty and caramelish, light alcohol presence. Bitter and dense malty finish.

19th May 2010 Cloudy brown beer. No head. Silky palate which is a little soft but with a carbonated bite. Toffee caramel malt with an aged malt chocolate aspect. Fresh hops integrate well. Pine and a little grapefruit. Finishes soft and with mild bitterness. Very drinkable indeed. Another very decent beer from this brewery.

Thanks to someone for sharing this at the May Freetail bottle release. The beer pours a dark copper color with a small white head. The aroma has a lot of resin from the hops, but I also get some brown sugar notes. Not quite what I expected since the beer smells more like a hoppy American Barleywine than a Double IPA. The flavor is more of the same. There is a lot of toffee and caramel as well as some bitter pine notes and some brown sugar. The alcohol is definitely noticeable, giving the beer a barleywine-like flavor. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. The beer is still good, but with the age it now has on it, it is not really an IPA at this point.

Bottle thanks to Butters. 0271 of 2008 which from the description I’m assuming is a 2008 vintage. Pours a hazy brown-red-orange with a dark beige head. It took a vigorous pour but did produce a lasting finger of foam. The aroma is big, like a foot away from the glass big. Lots of caramel, toffee, fruity, apple, then some citrusy hops, and a twinge of alcohol. Taste is very spicy bitter, lots of fruity malt, apple, toffee, a touch of age, oxidation and alcohol in the finish. Very americanbarleywineish at this point.
gusto deciso e agrumato nel giusto dosaggio , anche l' amaro non troppo pronunciato, insomma la birra che piace anche a chi non piacciono le IPA strong quelle con IBU sopra 75
330ml bottle back in 2013. This was a classic. I don’t mind the newer version by any stretch, but it lacks the depth and complexity of the original version and all it’s grapefruit goodness.
Aromas cítricos y resinosos Aspecto ligeramente turbio espuma persistente En boca refrescante naranja y mandarina Final amargo cítrico suave ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dirty beigie with a smallish, dense head. Vanilla, bitterness and summer fruits on the nose. Bitter and zesty, but not overpowering, malt sweetness also showing through.

Aroma: lightly soapy, lightly fruity, grapefruit notes Appearance: cloudy yellow, off white fluffy head, no lacing Flavour: lightly crystal, loads of hop bitterness Palate: thin to medium, fizzy finishes very hoppy bitter
Prima IPA, de nieuwe trend in NL. Leuk dat ze deze ook bij AH verkopen. Ruikt kruidig en smaakt lekker vol. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
De mis primeras ipas no está nada mal . Toques cítricos y frutales sin ser demasiado amarga
indemodable, la biere qui a remis l'ipa au gout du jour. je la deguste aujourd'hui avec plaisir malgres la chute de la boite qui m'a oblige a la boire quasi sans la deguster

geel met oranje glans, minimale witte kraag aroma: lekkere frisse ipa hoppigheid, citrus, grapefruit, frisse dennennaalden, gras smaken:redelijk zoet, redelijk bitter, dennennaalden, citrus, mooi hoppig, fruit, smaken zijn goed gebalanceerd. matig tot redelijke body, nagenoeg hetzelfde als de 'nieuwe'

Pivo u flaši. Brewdog PUNK IPA 2017 Ovo je možda najveće razočaranje na koje sam zasada naišao u svijetu Craft pivarstva ! PUNK IPA je jedno od najlegendarnijih piva u svijetu Craft pivarstva. Nekoliko Craftera sa kojima sam razgovarao naveli su baš "tu" pivu kao jedan od razloga ili čak glavni razlog što su se počeli baviti Craft pivarstvom. To je pivo fine arome tropskog voća i hmelja , krasnog isto takvog "izbalansiranog" okusa sa ne previše gorčine i lagane slatkoće. Ovo šta sam pio na ljeto 2017 je za 30% slabijeg okusa od pive koju sam pio 2016. , i nisam jedini koji je to primijetio ! Jedva čekam sa prođe godina dana od toga pa da vidim da li su prošle godine imali lošu "šaržu". Inače ovo pivo za mene kad je u pravom izdanju ima ocjenu 3.8/5

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: 31st May 2010 Muddy brown beer. Short lived creamy tan head. Softish palate. Rich malt, tastes a little aged with a little chocolate. Seamless light tangy orange hops. Smooth and very drinkable malty beer and another winner from Alewerks!

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Bottle shared by Dak. Amber pour with a foamy head. Aroma is caramel, honey, raisins, citrus hops, brown sugar and wood.Sweet fruity flavor with a nice bitter hoppy finish. Good stuff!

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Courtesy of ksurkin. Pours dark ruby red with tan head. The aroma is smooth sweet inviting goodness with a mix of pine, sweet ripe cherry yumminess, chewy malts and concentrated plum juice. The taste is rich and yummy with pine hops, ripe cherries, sweet malts, more pine hip resiny-ness, plums and sugar stewed raisins. Wow! Love it!

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: bottle 1452/2007 by way of dakine on 3/21/10. cloudy brick reddish tinted brown with a thin tan head. the nose is quite vinous.... seems a bit barrel aged since it is very spicy and peppery... also, notes of brown sugar, vanilla and malt. the palate is fairly dry especially given the abv%... it tastes mostly how it smells and contains even more of the peppery spice that the aroma. medium bodied with a touch of bitterness. 7/3/7/3/15/3.5

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Thanks to IBrew2or3 for the share. Pours dark amber with creamy tan head. Nose is malt, cherry, caramel, some pine, brown sugar/ molasses, and bitterness. Flavor is lots of cherry and fruit with caramel, malt, and pine. Medium body with lingering caramel and bitter. Medium bodied with lingering caramel and bitterness. I can understand the ASA distinction, but it does have many qualities of a barleywine.

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Bomber # 1452/2007 shared by Daknole at Hellbilly’s Shootout in Sosco Tasting. Pours cloudy amber with a thin tan head. The nose is sweet fruits, molasses and brown sugar. The taste is pretty much the same with some vanilla extract added. Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel. Decent stuff – thanks Dakine!

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Bottle shared by Daknole @ Hellbilly’s. Thanks DAK!!! Not a huge fan of this one...chestnut brew with a light tan head. Dark fruit, brown sugar, and tons of pepper...a bit much, really. Kind of boring.

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Amber pour. Light head. Aroma is honey, raisins, citrus hops, brown sugar, oak and caramel. Citrus hops, brown sugar, honey, light oak and some fruity esthers. Nice.

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: bottle shared by the illustrious daknole keeper of the beerhood in the year of 2010 before our lord hallowed be thy name.

column1: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale
column5: Bomber-pours a clear deep amber with a modest lasting head. Aroma is sweet, ok grassy and good citrus hops,caramel earthy and spiced, quite a bit of phenolics and some nutty toffee malts. Flavor is a big sharp dark crystal malt backbone, gets a bit harsh and earthy, burnt toffee, caramel, nuts slight chocolate and burnt paper- overall a bit messy and the malts are a bit too overdone and harsh. Eh.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Direktlieferung von BrewDog). Dunkelbraun mit viel Schaum im Glas. Dominierende Malznoten. Es gibt Besseres.
Pours brown with a creamy head. Aroma is malty. Pretty boring amber beer. Some malt flavour but not much else.

330ml bottle from Brewdog.com (£1.29 approx): Opening very well, this beer got off to an excellent start thanks to how good the nose was when it came through with tonnes of caramel malts & sweetness, some toffees backing them up as well. Things changed after that though, the taste being an altogether different affair with less sweetness & caramel but a lot more bitterness & earthy flavours which weren’t too my liking after the great opening to the beer. Throughout it remained an enjoyable beer but sadly the change of direction wasn’t completely to my liking & I feel like I would have liked this one more had the caramel flavours continued throughout; nice stuff but nowhere near as good as the brewery’s 5 A.M. Saint for me I’m afraid.

Appearance- dark brown and opaque, a one-finger beige head which hangs around. Aroma- hops, brown bread, malt, toffee, hints of chocolate. Taste- caramel malt, underlying hop bitterness, slightly sweet in places, dark fruit, biscuity malt, fruitcake. Smooth mouthfeel.
Bottle from brewdog online shop, revival pack. Amber coulour, hoppy, refreshing. Not to my taste

Bottle at home from BewDog online. Anniversary reissue. Chestnut brown colour with s tan head. Aroma has plums, stewed fruit and dried fruit. Taste light bitter to mid bitter, slight dryness to finish. Medium body.

Bottle. Pours medium amber brown, opaque with a red hue. Tan head subsiding quick. Scent is medium strong notes of caramel Mali, amber Ale yeast. Taste is consistent. Finish is light and frothy. Great.

Aroma 7/20, Appearance 4/5, Taste 7/20, Palate 3/5, Overall 14/20. Comments: 330ml bottle from Brewdog online. Pours a reddish brown colour with a creamy foam head leaving lots of lacing. Nose of malt, bready, fruity hop. Taste is malty, boiled sweets, blackcurrant note, and fruity hop bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry bitter finish. Quite drinkable.
Fra keg på Brewdog Shepherds Bush London 4 Mai 17. Mørk amber. Filmskum langs glasset. Aroma av mørk frukt & litt malt. Smaken søt kjeks & plommer. Tørr bæraktig avslutning. God!

Bouteille achetée chez BrewDog - De couleur brune rubis, avec une belle mousse fauve qui dure et colle - Au nez des arômes malté, caramel, biscuit, café, des houblons résineux, floraux et légèrement agrumes - En bouche toujours bien malté qui tend un peu sur les fruits rouges, toujours ces notes de caramel et de café, les houblons sont toujours bien présent, floraux et légèrement agrumes - Corp moyen, amertume moyenne, carbonation correcte, lisse et souple, final amère herbacé et café - Simple mais une belle réinterprétation du style, plus sur le brun que l’ambré

Butelka: 269 CABB 26/05/20 Kolor czarny, nieco przeblyskuje na brzegach, piana brązowa, drobna, powoli redukuje do cienkiej i trwalej tafli, lekko zdobi szkło. Aromat czekolada, nuty kawy i likierowe. Wytrawne, wyraźnie palone i przyjemnie goryczkowe. Nasycenie niskie, pasujące. Proste i dobre.
Utseende sort med beige skum. Aroma røster malt kaffe sjokolade. Smak mørk sjokolade kaffe lakris røster malt noe vanilje og humle. Smaksrik og kraftig. Smakt Juli 13

Smell - strong, dark chocolate roast, little tingling sensation. Foam - medium think to think, soft, constant chocolate bitterness for tongue, low if any carbonation. Taste - quite strong bitterness, witch chocolate tones and alcohol tones. Later gets a bit better. Also some sweetness, bit too much bitterness with alcohol tones for me. Will not buy again. So reducing overall score a bit.

Wrzucone do piwnicy dnia 31.10.2015. Piana beżowa, opadając zdobi szkło. Aromat niezbyt intensywny, troszkę czekolady, trochę owocków z utlenienia, jakieś takie kwaskowo-drożdżowe klimaty poza tym. A, no i leciutki zmywacz do paznokci. W smaku raczej wodniste, kwaskowe, niewiele ciała. Na plus solidna, palona goryczka. Dość wysokie wysycenie. Lipa, kiepsko się zestarzało.

Tap at Brewdog Tallinn. Black colour, beige creamy head. Aroma is roasty, coffee, bit ashy. Taste of coffee, very dark chocolate, roasty. Hops in aftertaste. Almost full body, but still very easily drinkable, smooth carbonation. Very creamy texture. Quite well covered alcohol. Nice stout, roasty and hoppy.

Keg, BD Lothian Road. Nitro version. This is as smooth and creamy as an impy stout could get. Darkest brown, lively creamy tan head. Loads of toast and roast all round, a little bit of booze heat. Yummy.

Creamy beige head, very black body. Strong aroma of coffee and motor oil in balance, some licorice. Flavour is good greasy roasted barley with dark roasted espresso, soya sauce, sea salt. A good drinkable heavy stout.
Black color with small brown head. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Bittersweet chocolate and light malty bitter taste. Quite good, but it needs to be more complex.

Flasche 0,33l: Schwarz, kräftige Trübung, mäßig stabiler feinporiger brauner Schaum; sehr süße Nase, kräftige dunkle Süße, dunkle eingelegte Früchte, Vanille, getrocknete Feigen/Datteln, Malz, kräftig Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, kräftige Röstaromen, dunkle Schokolade, Kaffee; würziger Körper, kräftige dunkle Süße, dunkle getrocknete/eingelegte Früchte, Röstmalz, kräftig Malzzucker, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, kräftige Röstaromen, Tabak, Vanille, dunkle Schokolade; angenehmer würzig-süßer Nachgang mit kräftigen Röstaromen
Dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma is rich molasses and chocolate, hint of vanilla. Taste is a little bitter, molasses and cocoa, touch of black licorice.

12oz Draft at Amherst Brewing Company. This is the first time that I have seen this one anywhere. The pour is cloudy dark yellow with a quickly disappearing 1/2 inch head. The aroma is full of yeast and bananas. The first sip is buttery smooth with yeasty bread and subtle fruit flavors. The finish was more butter and bananas. This lacked the carbonation and peppery flavors of La Fin Du Monde. It was more smooth and balanced like the St. Bernardus triple. The 8% abv that the chalkboard sign stated was completely undetected. I have always liked this local brewery and this is a great attempt at a Belgian from them. Cheers.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: "the vanilla that’s present in the aroma is nearly too much in the flavor, but it makes for an easy drinking enjoyable brew. i must say, though, i was hoping for more from this one."

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: Had this on tap at Brew it up! Color is black. Heavy frothy head and very smooth flavor. Has a hint of vanilla with a heavy malt flavor.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: Draft. A pitch black beer with a lazing brown head. The aroma has strong notes of vanilla and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of vanilla, roasted malt - a bit too much vanilla for my liking. The finish is dry and roasted.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Pours black with a medium brown head. Nose of vanilla, maple and hershey’s syrup. Flavor starts with vanilla, then moves to chocolate. Those two flavors stay with you to the end. Nice beer and while it’s sweet, it’s not overly sweet compared to others of the same style. Best beer of the 16 I tried here.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: Dark brown with a nice foamy tan head and good lace. The aroma is full of vanilla. Some roast and dark malt. Sweet vanilla dominates beer, perhaps a little butter, some light roast. Kind of tasted like root beer. Smooth creamy body, light lingering roast.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: On tap. Pours black and opaque with a light brown head. Intense aroma of vanilla sugar that pretty much overpowers the hard roasted malts. Medium body, sweet notes of vanilla sugar. Good, malty bitter finish. 130709

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours pitch black with a dense, creamy, lacing and tan head. Aroma is solid vanilla and roasted malt. Vanilla and chocolate malt flavoured. Solid vanilla flavoured into a mild roasted lingering finish. Too much vanilla for my liking.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: On tap at the brewery. This dark brown ale poured with a rich beige head and a strong vanilla aroma. The flavor is all abouit vanilla, but there is a hint of roasted malt and a slight hop bitterness.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: ~Pours black with creamy tan head. ~Roasted malt scent with vanilla extract syrup. ~Clean roasted malt flavor with some mild vanilla. ~Smooth creamy feel, mild bitter finish. ~Just like their Macs Dry Stout, but the vanilla makes it a tad better.

column1: Brew It Up! Vanilla Cream Stout
column5: Pours a very dark brown colour, almost black. Great roasted malt character, thick and creamy with a nice sized brown head. A a very rich yet silky stout- this was like a meal in a glass.
Draught. This is a seriously bitter DIPA - grass clippings, grapefruit, and resin.
On tap at brewpub. Pours copper with thin white head. Bubblegum, fruit, citrus, something else I can’t quite place. Moderately bitter and sweet. Crisp and a bit acidic. Interesting aromas.

On tap at the source. Comes to the table a deep orange amber color with a thinnish white head that dissipates quickly to a small cap on top. Smells of bitter resin, grapefruit, apricots and a hint of ethanol and bready malt. The flavor starts off with a solid shot of bitter pine and resin with some citrus fruit in the mix as well. There’s a hint of bready and caramel malt as well as a healthy shot of alcohol before a long lingering bitter resinous finish. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet bitter resinous mouthfeel. This is a solid DIPA, it made for a really nice after dinner drink.

Draft from Martha’s. Unclear Amber in color. Nice white head with decent spider-web lace. Nose is a mix of citrus and pine. Taste is much the same, good amount of pine needles and resin bitterness. Medium body, toward the lighter side of meduim body. Slightly lingering bitterness. Well made.
Draught at the brewery. Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Smells of grapefruit, some floral notes. Tastes resiny and sweet with a bitter finish.

Growler. Pours a deep amber color with a 1/2" off white head. Massive hop aroma with a hint of background malt. Heavy, sticky palate with low carbonation. The hop bitterness practicly bites you on the tongue. Huge hop based flavor as you would expect as well as a sweet malt undertone. Also, some secondary fruit flavor. This was one enjoyable brew. The Dr is in.

on tap-pours a rich light tan head that laces and amber color. Aroma is nice citrus-grapefruit, secondary sweet medium malt. Taste is nice citrus-grapefruit/pine hops with some bitter, secondary sweet medium malt. Slightly slick.

[growler] Rich amber in color, with a coarse white head. Aroma is powerful, dense hops. Resinous, hops flavors are as strong as the aroma, with more fruit (peach, mango and pineapple) showing through. The malt really seems to take the backseat, allowing the hops to really dominate. Long, piney hop finish balances perfectly with alcohol warmth.

growler shared at the CL RB gathering, thanks dirtymike for this one. Relatively clear orange with some reddish highlights. Aroma has alot of citrus and pine, fresh resiny hops- citrus is slightly sweet and has alot of mango character. Taste also has a ton of hop character- sticky resiny citrus, mango, and pine. Full bodied, but not overpowering. Finishes hoppy, resinous and bitter. Carbonation was a tad low, but didn’t even make much of a difference. Excellent IIPA.

Growler supplied by hophead75 (thanks!): Amber colored beer with lots of clarity and an off white film for head. The aroma is strikingly hoppy. Oily resins shoot out at you. Piney, grapefruit, nice. The flavor is ultimate hop oils. It tastes like hop extracts with a drop of malt in the body. Has an extreme pineyness and a perfumy character. Could be a bit more balanced in my opinion. Would improve significantly with age.
Lidt skuffende. Foirventningerne var for store. Stadig velsmagende, men særdeles ordinær.
Rødgylden kær skum råhvid Citrus grape bær korn malt Bitter modrate sød modrate Oile blød @home

Tap at bierbier, helsinki. Clear deep golden color, white head. Aroma has caramel malts, hint of honey, some citrusy hops. Sweet caramel malty body, smooth bitterness, some honey, citrus notes from hops. Little bit british style ipa i think.

Copenhagen 24/9 2017. 50 cl bottle from SuperBrugsen. Drawing of some very shiny Indian temple on the label. It seems that the name of the beer is written in Braille as well. Nice touch. Very foamy when I pour it. Pours hazy opaque amber with humongous head. Settles as 3-4 cm thick head of fluffy foam. Massive lacing. Aroma is fruity and sweetish. Peach and canned pears. Light citric notes. Medium carbonation and medium thick palate. Flavor is medium sweet followed by stronger bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter and finish semi dry. Good balance without being very exciting. Not very IPA'ish - but a nice brew.
An okay IPA. Give you a hoppy feeling. But still reminds you more of an am. pale ale.
Amber hazy IPA with white head. Citrus, piney and sweet malty aromas . Light sweet and medium bitter taste.

A lightly hazed golden amber ipa with orange hues, and a thick frothy lacing mocha head. In aroma, sweet caramel malt with loads of citrusy, pink grapefruit pulp, resinous and piney hops, light mineral notes, pleasant. In mouth, a nice roasted caramel malt with resinous floral hops, grapefruit pulp, light tropical fruits, very nice. Bièropholie imports.

A danish, foggy, amber IPA with extremely high white head (chilled, 9 months before BBD, even after pouring 1/3 of the beer the foam keeps running up the bottle, infected in my oppinion). Aroma is hops, pine, citrus, fresh fruit, caramel, malt. Taste is bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma; hops, spruce, peaches, pale malts, grapefruit. Look; off white good head, about clear deep golden body. Taste; resin, hops, spruce, grapefruit, pale malts, alco note - leading to a finish with peely hops. Feel; strong. Overall; an IPA stronger than 6.5 is noticeable. [50cl.btl 7.3% BB.08.04.2017]
Extremely over carbonated. Aroma is sweet, malty and slightly floral. Tastewise too much malt and too little hops. Too fizzy as well. Not impressed.
Nose is mediumheavy dry hops, blackcurrant, feel is medium, carb is mediumheavy, taste is heavy hops, corn, leaves, little leather
Tap @ the brewery ( DØE meeting ) Pours amber with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grassy and fruity hops. Taste is floral and fruity hops, grapefruit, pine. Medium body, soft carbonation. 150611
(Bottle 15/6-2011) Low head, weak hoppy aroma. Below average pale ale.
Hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, fruity and light hoppy - flowers. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and bitter finish. 130510

50cl bottle from Vinoble-favrskov foamed over slightly when i opened it. clear golden, huge offwhite head. aroma is very flowery, hoppy, hoppy-herbal, hoppy-bitter. quite hoppy, but not very intense, not much of a malty aroma but a little. perhaps a hint of honey? flavor is herbal-grassy-hoppy (not grassy and herbal in a bad way - i think it’s the hops), spicy, malty. sort of like an english pale ale. Some delicate bitterness like in an english bitter. sweet malts, but much in the background. You could probably drink a lot of this. Flavorfull for a 4.7% beer.
Clear amber of color with a white head. An aroma of malt, citrus, hops and spice. A flavor of malt, hops, spice and grapefruits.
50 cl bottle. Slightly unclear golden amber colour. Big head. Hoppy aroma. Low carbonation.

Cask at Horsens Beerfestival. Hazy reddish orange body with a medium off-whitehead. Aroma is moderate malty with a hint of fruit, caramel and hops. Flavor is rather straight forward malt, caramel and hops in a balanced and pleasant way. Nice session ale.

Coppery colored with hazy appearance. Lots of yeast floating in glass. Huge yellow head. Rich aroma with hops dominating, slight burnt rubber with fruity touch. Medium bodied. Flavor is also finely hopped with dry touch, aftertaste lasts as dry one, slight burnt rubber also here. Fine PA, aroma is still more PA than flavor.
