Botltle. Very aggressive high fluffy and lasting white head. Clear amber body. Fruity and pretty hoppy aroma, a bit sharp and metallic hops bitterness dominates the flavor. Low carbonation, short bitter and dry aftertaste.

Bierhalle Manufaktura Łódź , Barwa ciemno-miedziana, piana obfita, trwała. Aromat średnio-intensywny, słodowy: karmel, palony karmel, razowe pieczywo, biszkopty. W smaku lekko słodkie, gładkie i pełne. Słodowe: palony karmel, chleb razowy, biszkopty, z przyjemnym wytrawnym finiszem.
Chlebek, ciasteczka, karmel. Ładnie ukryty alkohol. Średnio pełne, słodkawe. Średnia goryczka, umiarkowane wysycenie. Przyjemne.
Murky brownish amber pour with a white head. Hop aroma with a hint of caramel and the taste is malty but fruity.
Cask at the Nags Head, Reading. Slightly hazy amber with a thin white head; sour apple aroma; caramel and orange fruit flavours; short, dry, burnt caramel finish.

Cask gravity at Red Lion, Snargate. Slight haze on an amber/red beer, disappearing head. Herby hoppy aroma with some grapefruit. Reasonable juicy malts in mouth. Tingly, zesty herby citrus hop finish. Very drinkable bitter with an attack of herby grapefruit hop.

Cask (gravity) @ The 17th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium amber orange colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sour malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration, bright - pale raisin. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20110429]

Cask-conditioned at the Dog Inn, Ewyas Harold, Herefordshire 25/04/2011. Deep amber with a frothy, off-white head. Citrus hop and marmalade aroma with some sweetish malts. Decent, biscuit malt flavours with more fruit, and a hoppy, bitter finish. Good stuff.
Cask conditioned at The Wellington, Birmingham. Amber to gold with white head. A fairly standard best bitter lacking a little flavour but reasonable maltiness, thin on the palate. Average.
Cask gravity at George, Bethersden. Sherberty hop aroma, standard bitter in mouth, some spice/herb/sherbert hop on end. Fresh tasting and I rather liked it.
Cask @ Boot Inn, Burnley. Golden with a small frothy head. There’s definitely some pear that’s evident in both aroma and taste. It’s still more of an ale than a perry though!

First tasted this in the Hogshead, Paisley in April 2000. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear golden amber in colour with a thin white head. Slight hint of pear and floral hops in the short aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a juicy fruity flavour of pears, kiwi, melon and lychees. Dusty floral hop resins give a tart metallic flavour to the aftertaste. Finish is bitter sweet and has an alcoholic warmth to it. A typical English ESB.
Cask from the Bitter End, Bromley. Amber pour with a white head. Sweet fruity nose of apricot, peach and pear. Fruit laden flavours of pear, baked apple, peach and light malts. Fruity, bitter finish.

Cask gravity at George, Bethersden. Straw coloured with bubbly white head. Slightly sweet golden ale. Bit sickly. Hop is citrusy and pleasing, but the pale malts are a bit sickly. I mean it’s fine and in decent condition. Sub Hop Back Summer Lightning.

Ich fand dieses Bier nicht übel. Es hatte einen schönen, vollen Körper und einen hefig-getreidigen Charakter. Auch wenn es nicht allzu aromatisch rüberkommt, so macht es das für mich fein süffig und gemütlich.
Aroma 4. Appearance 3. Taste 6. Palate 3. Overall 11. Malt and hops aroma. Malt, grass, and slightly sweet taste.

Пиво золотистого цвета с белой очень нестабильной пеной которая в мгновение ока превратилась тонкую пенную шнуровку по краю бокала и очень быстро пропала. В аромате немного яблочных эфиров, легкий солодовый аромат и аромат кукурузы. Вкус солодовый с хлебом, легкой сладостью и небольшой тонкой горечью. Очень слабое пиво...

Blind test - 25 koncerniaków. Wygląd: Barwa złota, klarowna z niska białą pianą, zbudowaną z średnich pęcherzyków, redukuje się w mgnieniu oka do małego pierścienia, nie pozostawiając lacingu. Aromat: Słaby, trochę jabłkowych estrów, nuta pieprzowych fenoli, lekka słodowość chlebowa i diacetyl. W tle nuta utlenienia. Smak: Ciut lepiej, słodowość chlebowa z nutami estrów jabłkowych. W ustach półsłodkie, treściwość średnioniska, wysycenie niskie. Goryczki brak. Finisz półsłodki, estrów jabłkowych. Ogólnie taki super light Tripel, który został mocno rozwodniony. Pomimo, że nie stylowo, to miła odmiana od przykrych wad "poprzedników".
Čapované v Karcme Hajduk Polsko Niedzica. Aj napriek vysokému alkoholu letne osviežujúce. Horkosť úmerná, odhadujem IBU okolo 30. Silná dochuť sladu. Tu ho čapovali dobre.
Gulbrun klar med lavt hvitt skum. Lukter malt og korn. Lett. Vannete, noe bitterhet. Kort
malts, alcohol, corn, golden, clear, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, lively carbonation, poor beer

Jasnozłote, klarowne piwo o dość obfitej pianie, która zdobi szkło i pozostaje do końca w formie pierścionka przy brzegu szkła. Aromat i smak nikły słodowy. Goryczka niska. Ogólnie zwykły, koncernowy lager bez smaku i goryczki, ale też bez wad.
Piwo o barwie jasnej z średnią pianą, która stopniowo opada. W aromacie słód i Dms. W smaku troszkę lepiej jak w aromacie z wyczuciem chmieli.

Lane. O ku*wa. Nie spodziewałem się, że korpolager może być aż tak chu*owy. Nie spodziewałem się, że różnica między kraftem, a dawno nie pitymi "normalnymi" jest aż taka... Zapach sztucznego miodu z dodatkiem pietruszki nie był najgorszym co mogło mnie spotkać. Smak wody rozrobionej 1:1 z syropem glukozowo-fruktozowym był gorszy. Słodsze to niż Milky Moon. Never again.

Cask handpull at Penderels Oak, JDW, Holborn. Copper colour with thin lasting white head. Coppery, some red berry fruit. Lacks malt fullness. Certainly has fruity presence. Bit over teh top. Earthy bitter and syrupy fruit. It’s a fruity bitter.
Cask @ Standing order (JDW), Soton. Full fruity malts in a creamy body with a mild hoppy finish. Not really my thing but pleasant enough.

Cask at Wetherspoons, Milton Keynes. Amber with a small white head. Served at the right temperature but with too much fizz. Pleasant fruit and hop aroma. Ashy taste with the merest hint of sweetness and a mid bitter finish. It’s all right, but it’s not the best of B & T.
A Mes rate: Cask from ’Spoons @ Baker Street. Nice amber colour but with no head at all. Mellow grapefruit aroma. Hoppy flavour with some dusty tobacco and a long citric finish.

Thanks to hopdog for picking up this growler... Appears a dark brown with a small, light tan head that slowly fades into a small collar. Streaky spots of lacing are left around the glass. Smell is of cocoa, cloves, bubblegum, banana, and caramel with some tart wheat notes. Taste mimics the aromas with a mix of Bavarian yeast flavors playing along the palate. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with some astringency, citrus, and grapefruit, along with caramel, grass, and cocoa lingering.

Sampled from Growler picked up at the Brew Pub. Poured a deeper and muddy brownish color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas of wheatiness, light chocolate and some bananas and cloves in the background. Tastes of wheat, light chocolate, bananas, and spices. Tart wheat finish.

Thanks to hopdog for bringing this back from his annual trip out to Wisconsin. Poured from a growler with a medium off white bubbly head, deep brown with amber highlights. Aroma of toasted malts, hints of caramel, some wheat, some light coffee, light alcohol and chocolate. Flavor is a bit earthy, some chocolate, lightly roasted malts, light banana, some bitterness, kind of dry. A decent beer but a little different for the style.

This looks like a cola with a pale tan ring in lieu of a head. The aroma is quite faint. Even my girlfriend, whose nose is much younger than mine, could barely pick it up. Seems like some dark caramel and, if you inhale heavily with your mouth open over the glass, a touch of old bananas. The mouthfeel is a bit harsh for the style. Tastes like dark malt, some cocoa, black pepper, and near the finish, a hit of banana. Odd. Flatlanders Restaurant & Brewery, Lincolnshire, IL

Poured a deeper, hazy reddish-brown with a short white head and nice lacing. Aroma picked up sweet banana initially along with chocolates and bubble gum.. really enjoyed it!.. a pinch of cocoa and some darker spices emerge with warmth. Flavor had semi-sweet chocolate, banana, and darker spices at the core, surrounded by tangy, tart wheat notes.. dark, sweet finish with some peppery spices.. very good! Medium-bodied with an almost creamy middle.. grainy tart notes extend outward. Quite a tasty brew!
Bottle from Philippe. Pours dark ruby some frothy head minimal lacing. Notes of cherry pie, tart cherries, some lemon. Taste medium tart light sweet. Medium acidic body lively carbonation.
Grapefruit and some cherry. Lot of acidity, probably a little too much for my liking. Deep Ruby red pour with decent head and living champagne type look. Bottle.
Pink/red appearance. Aroma is tart and cherry. Flavour is tart, cherry, bitter and dry.

Barwa niczym sok z wiśni, piana różowa, która utrzymuje się kilka minut. W aromacie stajenka, siano, wiśnie. W smaku dominuje kwaśna wiśnia, a sam kwas jest na wysokim poziomie. Bardzo lekkie i wyraźne piwo.

Bottle. 2016 date on it. Bought from a supermarket in Brussels. Took it down the byo kebab shop. Purple. Medium haze. Super dense, lasting, pink head. Nose has funk. Cherry stone. Cardboard. Taste is tart and lightly sour. Some cherry sweetness. Light to medium body. Foamy carbonation. Tart, light sharp finish. Barring the cardboard this was great.

Flaska från Belgiuminabox. Rödvinsfärgad med medelhögt rosa skum. Syrlig körsbärsdoft med kärnor, mandelkakor. Bådes ÖT och rejält syrlig. Lite mycket kolsyra i början men fina smaker av körsbär med kärnkaraktär. Gott!

Aroma: tart cherry, funky notes, some lemon zest Appearance: clear dark red-brown color with a two-finger light red head Taste: tart cherry, little bit ripe peach, funky notes, some.lemon zest, medium sourness, medium-high sweetness, very low bitterness Palate: medium-low body, medium-high carbonation, comfortable astringency, very little alcohol sensation Overall: The aroma and taste are nice but little bit low in complexity. Drinkability is really nice.

The colour is like a raspberry kompot, pink foam disappeared very quickly. Smells like a champagne, little bit of cherry and a bit of brett. Sour in flavour, also acerb and a bit bitter. After a while there is less champagne and more of brett smell.
Bottle. Pours hazy deep red, medium fizzy pink head, minimal lacing. Aroma is tart cherry, mineral, lemon, funk, sock. Flavor is medium tart, light oleds funk. Medium body.
Lambic type aroma, spontaneous fermented, cherries, weak biscuits. Full red body. Sour and fruity taste, no sugar or sweetness. Enjoyable, almost too sour, quite nice lambic.
Can 500ml (Rema Kirkenes, 4,5% - no premium) Clear golden colour, small white head. Grainy, metallic aroma. Light-bodied. Crisp, grainy, sweet cereal malty. Typical industrial lager.
50cl can. Vasa, Norski tasting 2019. Poured light golden color. Light sweet malty aroma. Simple, light, watery. Mild sweetness, some hay. Clean.
Une pils simple avec un nez marqué par le coté malté et une bouche ronde sur une pointe de sucrosité. Agréable sans plus
Aroma of malt, fruits, hay and grass. Golden with a white head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with average carbonation. Overall an OK Pilsener, but rather boring.
Easily drinkable lager brewed on elements of wheat malt to provide a premium taste and a good foam.

Solid white head, golden color and nice stream of co2. A bit closed sromas containing malty sweetnes, a little hops. Nice medium- fill average length. Malty sweetnes in the start followed by light citrus and bitternes towards the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Mack Fatøl Premium Pilsener 44324 Lukt: Syrlig humle og malt. Utseende: Gyllen. Skum/kullsyre: Dekkende skum, heng langs kant. Smak: Humle og malt. Hvor: Kjøpt@Spar, Bryne, Nydt@Hjemme. Medium: Boks@500ml, ABV@4,5%, Når@24.12.2017
From can at Vaaland Bryghus with BG and JFE 27.10.17. Clear golden. Diminishing white head. Aroma and taste of boiled vegetables, wet cardboard and wet grass. Some bitterness.
50cl burk från djoeye. Gyllende kropp med ett fint vitt skum som försvinner fort. Lite gröna äpplen i doften. Mjuk och len med en viss beska.

Modest off white head, clear golden body. Aroma has apple, fruity wort, bready grain juice. Tastes caramel, grass, apple, tart bread, sweet grains - leading to a malty finish, but with hops too. Normal on palate. Not bad. But not too many of this. [50cl.can abv4.5% BB29JUL17 Mack Fatøl]...

The Chop House has some decent variety, but I found them all pretty boring. That being said, the Saison was easily the best offering. Light and hazy, no head. Scent of corn and wheat. Tastes a little sour and complexe, corn and wheat. Refreshing.

Clear pale yellow small white head. Fruity aroma. Taste is honey malts all the way with a touch of caramel, and citrus, orange and coriander. Floral hops, weak belgian funk bite to it but it was still there. This was an awesome beer to sit on their patio with it being 88 degrees outside, very easy to drink, very refreshing, and it may not have been made by a monk but it was still well made and was awesome with the food.
By far the brewery’s best option that I’ve tried; very sour, citrussy with fresh herbal and coriander notes. Slightly thin profile (it’s pretty translucent) and weak, but not bad considering.

Poured a clear golden amber with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of bread, earthiness and light grapefruit. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, earthiness, grapefruit and light pine with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

Draft at GABF. They must have their shit together now. Pours a nice and attractive orange-gold with a fluffy white head. Nose is fresh and popping with citrus and some resiny pine. Nothing outstanding, but still nice. On tasting, firm malt backbone supports the big bitterness and nice combo of pine & citrus. Clean and refreshing and finishes quite dry. Really nice.

Tap at the brewery. Pale golden amber pour. Very worty aroma with some DMS character as well. Flavour is incredibly watery and underhopped. It’s got less hop aroma/flavour than the pale ale, which was itself underhopped. As it warms up it starts to taste like they brewed it with water that had previously been used to cook carrots and rutabegas. Gak.
tap @ the ChopHouse - truly one of the worst IPAs I’ve ever tasted. Old vegetables and cheese. Arouma is deceptively normal. Finishes astringent and blechy.

On tap at the District ChopHouse in Cleveland on our way to RBSG. Pours a mostly clear, just barely hazed golden yellow amber with a medium sized white head. Caramel and vegetables. Sort of like a turnip flavored sweet tart. Quite unpleasant. Tastes like vegetables and sadness.
Parmesan cheese. Time to taste it. Wow, this is truly one of the worst things I’ve ever put in my mouth. How does this even happen? Incredible. I revel in its crappiness.
Nice IPA. Great hop profile producing a citrus aroma and flavors. Cloudy with medium carbonation. Average for an IPA
Golden and reddish colour with slight lacing. Minimal scent, a little hoppy, but pretty weak for an IPA. Sweet tasting with a slight bitter finish.
Light amber in appearance with a bit of lacing. A bit spicy and hoppy in the nose, but not befitting a true IPA. Not very well distinguished from their APA, and in fact has less hopping.

Cask@lychgatetavern, wolverhampton. Chestnut colour, large creamy head with strong lacing. Looks good. Aroma is very faint caramel. Taste is mild grapefruit, dark fruits and a little caramel. Full bodied and smooth. An excellent beer.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Merchants Inn Rugby. A chestnut brown coloured beer. The aroma is dry with malty touches. The taste is full and fruity. Some raisins. Malty and a little nutty. Pretty decent.
Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford in 2015. Clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma of pine, caramel and grain. Flavour was grainy, with some hop resin and a bit thin at the end.

I had one of these the other day and judging by other peoples remarks I must have got a super fresh one because it was lovely! Possibly the best beer I've had in the last 4 months! It was fresh and hoppy with a lovely level of English bitterness rounded off with a fruity floral aroma. Top pint - cheers.

September 17, 2017 - at Wetherspoons (Victoria Station) - handpull cask. Hazy amber-gold, no head. Bog-standard semi-sweet slightly twiggy bitter with some unpleasant but not nasty overtones (a generous 6-). Taste is grainy and sharp, with a weird mineral/sulphur thing ... infected? I will assume it's the water. Still, sticky, somewhat harsh in the taste and linger - not horrible but not very good at all.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear deep golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of butterscotch, some toasted grain, a hint of citrus and subtle sulphur. Taste of butterscotch, some toasted grain, slight caramel, a little grass, a hint of fruit and subtle sulphur. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, sulphuric, butterscotch bitterness in the finish. An plod school, golden bitter. Few off flavours biit not offputting.

Cask a the company inn. Pours golden with white foam top. Aroma has herbs, leaves, resinous, qualities . Taste is medium sweet to sour. Palate is medium bodied with sticky feel soft carbonation and a sour coating to the tongue. If this is what you look for in a beer it's widely available.
Clear pale gold small head on Cask @The Malt Shovel Sharp taste tart grapefruit biscuity Malt. Not a favourite but make up your own mind......
Cask @ Manchester & County, Manchester. Golden with a thin head. It's a fuller-bodied ale with a berry-fruit nose. Has a light bitter finish.

On tap at The University Club, Oxford. Pours a clear and thin orange gold with a thin white head. Aroma: Very mild malt and pine notes. Has a funky unpleasant smell, like a cheap lager. Taste: Sweet malt, caramel, citrus, peach flavours. Unusually sweet for an IPA. Medium body. Low carbonation, a bit too flat if anything. A pleasant flavour balance at first, but I couldn't drink a second of this. A bit unbalanced.
Cask@Crosse Keys - Amber pour small white head. Furity and toasted sweet malty with some toffee, caramel, grapefruit and orange citrus fruity notes, hoppy bitter finish.
From cask at Wetherspoon, Cross Keys, London. An amber coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flabour of malt, hops, caramel, bitterness and biscuit.
Cask. A golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, alcohol, and grain, as well as an odd note of vitamins.

Cask (handpump) @ Harlequin, 108 Nursery Street, Sheffield, South Yorkshire England S3 8GG. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus, peppery. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, peppery notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100118]
Cask. Clear golden with a creamy white head. Discreetly fruity nose. Medium body, lightly sweet malt and fruit, a little yeast and phenols before a lightly bitter finish. 180110
Cask Handpump at the Harlequin, Sheffield 16/01/2010 Fruit and hop aromas. Clear golden coloured hoppy and fruity with a hint of dryness and citrus flavour in a bitter malt finish.

Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Straw with a thin white rim. Peachy apricot aroma swamped with booze. Sicky, vegetal and a bit wrong. Fibrous apple peel fruit cocktail yeastiness, grassy hop, white white booziness, soggy biscuit afters. Too still and heady with not enough hops for me. Their Festival Ale at 3.8% was drenched with lip-smacking hoppage compared to this. Weird one.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag ONails, Bristol 8/12/08. Pale gold with a moderate white head. Light aroma of hay, caramel and a hint of grassy hop. Flavour was sweetish, with a touch of citrus hop and a short, bitter finish. A bit subdued.

Cask at the Broadway Cinema, Nottingham. It’s a light golden coloured beer with aroma and flavour of hops and some citrus fruit. I enjoyed drinking it but it pales in comparison to Jaipur or Goose Island IPA.

Clear dark golden pour topped by a lasting off-white 1cm cover. Indeed a rather hoppy ale, but full-on goldings which limits it to very floral, earthy aromas. Mineral saltiness also chimes in and the ending result make the beer quite predictable. Still tasty and drinkable, well-bodied and finely drying out.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark gold. Spicy and citric hop aroma. Fruity taste of peach and pear, with some bitterness. Rather good.
Cask@The Criterion, Leicester. Golden beer with a light head. The aroma is caramel and dry, and the flavour is syrupy, malty and dry. Overall an average beer.

I often have a stout as a nightcap when out drinking, so I know a good one from a bad one. This is not, in my opinion, a good one. It looked like a stout should at first: black, but with a small white head which didn’t hang round long. Tasted watery and weak, a little bitter chocolate and malt came through towards the end of the pint (as its temp raised to room temp), otherwise not a lot of flavour. No mouthfeel to talk of, as I have already said, it is watery and weak. This was drank last night in one of my favorite Real Ale pubs, my last note on it from last night reads ’Very Poor’.
Cask Handpump from the Festival Bar at the Cricket Club, Barnton 23/11/2007 Roast aroma. White head. Amber coloured and a littly hoppy with a crisp bitter and dry chocolaty roast finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Alexandra Arms Rugby. A black coloured stout with an off-white head and some lacing. The aroma is initially slightly tainted by diacetyl, but then it’s smooths out to have a lactic quality and a malty base. The taste is nice and chocolatey. Some sweet maltiness. A tasty well flavoured stout.

column1: Mickey Finns ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: Nice session ale. It pours a deep brownish red body with a creamy beige head that engages in some intricate lacing. The aroma is sweet and grainy with light fruits and a mild earthy bitterness. It tastes sweet and malty, a touch grainy, with a peppery spiciness and and earthy/herbal bitterness that makes it a good thrist quencher. Mickey Finn’s Brewery, Libertyville, IL

column1: Mickey Finns ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: Poured a clear, dark coppery-brown with a medium cap of creamy beige head and thorough lacing. Sweet aroma with chocolate malts, cereal, and herbal notes representin’.. enjoyable components, but tough to grasp. Flavor had a heavy emphasis on toasted cereal grains.. semi-sweet chocolate with rye-like spicage.. mild herbal bitterness rides through the finish. Little less than medium-bodied.. middle was slightly grainy. OK feel, and a tasty brew!

Cask (handpump) @ Salmon, 19 Butt Close Lane, Leicester, Leicestershire, England LE1 4QA. [ As Kendricks Webb Ellis ]. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, fruity malt, pale malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20160221]
Cask barley mow Leicester. Golden colour thin white head lacing. Aroma is fruity taste is fruity citrus ok hops dry bitter finish. Medium body. Average golden ale.

(Rating originally entered 23/03/2009, moved over from Webb Ellis Ale). Cask, The Crown, Nuneaton. Mildly irked these beers were wrongly aliased in 2012 and my re-rate of this beer has been deleted, along with my score for this and Webb Ellis Ale. Shit happens. (These words relate to a beer consumed in March 2009, itself almost certainly a different recipe to the Wood Farm beer now labelled ’Webb Ellis’)....Resolving straw domed with loose sudsy white. Delicate flowery lemony hop mousse, dashes of mandarin and America. Amarillo? Long sweet vanilla malt afters with alcohol splashes. Sits nicely alongside the JHB- similarly pale citrus refreshment with a squirt less lemon cleaning product. Very fine sessions. Shades of Ufford. Soft alpha creaminess, fresh and good. Surprising, so much so I saw about 4 of them off in rapid succession- virtually unheard of these days. Earlier Rating: 9/24/2012 Total Score: 3.1
Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Gold with slight head. Smooth, thin malty beer, quite grainy, corn like, some bitterness but quite indistinct. Bready, yeasty finish. Quite dull.
Golden and smooth ale with a creamy head. Both malty and hoppy in character.

Cask, Criterion, Leicester. Pale gold with a white foam. Aromas are hay and citrus with fresh grapefruit and some grassy notes. Flavours are sweet biscuit and lemon with dry and grapefruit hops on the finish.
Cask in the market porter. Alround rating: Pale british malt, lemon and other citrusy characters, acidity somes in from the hop too, grassy and a bit overly dry. But good.
Cask at the Dolphin Inn, Derby. Straw with a white head; citrus aroma; clean citrus flavour with lots of tart and bitter hops behind it; long lasting bitter finish. Very drinkable.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Alexandra Arms Rugby. A golden coloured beer with a tiny pillow of white head. The aroma is nice with a decent amount of lemony hoppiness. Pretty subtle. The taste is nicely hoppy too with a good body and more lemony flavours. Smooth, mellow and very drinkable.

Frischer aber zielstrebig malzig-würziger Antrunk, etwas süß. Vollmundig, etwas cremig-malzig werdend, sehr süffig. Die zentrale Malznote wird noch etwas kräftiger, im Abgang kommt eine leicht säuerliche Note hinzu. Etwas schokoladig. Empfehlenswert! Test vom 24.4.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 8,12,13,12,-,13 - 12,15

On tap at the pub next to the brewery: Slightly hazy, copper coloured, firm off-white head, sweet honey, "green" wort and barnyard in the nose; quite strong sweetish flavour, light to medium bodied, fizzy MF; "greenish", unripe wort, again in the finish with, maybe, some liquorice and a homeopathic dose of bitterness in the aftertaste. Hardly drinkable crap...........

(on tap at the Bärenkuhle, next to the brewery, where it is offered as “Bärensaft”) Hazy, bright amber coloured hue with a small but persistent foamy off-white head. Slightly dusty, sweet and quite “greenish” toasty malt aroma with liquorice and light hoppy notes. Sweet flavour with a faint bitterness, light bodied with a fizzy carbonation. Toast-malty, worty taste with liquorice and notes of hay; sweetish malt-accented, worty finish with shy herbal notes in the aftertaste. Drinkable but unrefined brew that lacks balance and maturation.

The beer pours a hazy copper color with a light tan head. The smell is roasted malt, mild caramel. The taste is toasted malt, caramel, bread ending fruity and dry with some licorice on the aftertaste. The body is light+ with soft carbonation. A nice dunkel.

On tap at the brewpub. Nice amber-chestnut brown and cloudy in the glass. The beer starts malty. Slightly sweetish, very mild and highly drinkable. Nice smooth yeastiness, very smooth. Hints of brown chocolate and caramel. Not too dry, hints of wood/earth. The aftertaste is long, fresh-smooth, nice chocolate-soft, yeasty. Great!
On tap at the Brewpub. Trübes braunes Bier mit schöner beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell. Geschmack röstmalzig, Karamell, würzig, fruchtig.

Süßlich-malziger Antrunk mit deutlich fruchtigem Einfluss. Hefiger werdend, das Malz nimmt nur spärlich zu, im Abgang kräftiger, insgesamt mild und mittel-intensiv. Vor dem Abgang wird es kurz wässrig, dann wird das Bier deutlich würziger und entspricht nun mehr einem Dunklen als zuvor. Test vom 24.4.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 12,10,11,11,-,11 - 10,94

On tap at the brewpub: Cloudy, brownish, sweet-malty, worty nose with a tinge of hops; very sweet flavour, almost cloying,a bit sticky, light to medium bodied; short "green" fruity-sweet finish, with - at least - some bitterness in the aftertaste. Typical german Hausbrauerei stuff of limited quality......

(draught at the brewpub) Cloudy, light-brown colour with a medium-sized, slightly off-white foam. Sweetish, yeasty moderately toasty malt aroma, slightly greenish with a rather unbalanced herbal hoppy blend. Sweet, slightly biter flavour, light to medium bodied with a well-carbonated mf. Toast-malty, slightly yeasty and fruity taste; sweetish and a bit worty, subtle fruity (pears) finish. Pretty drinkable although it lacks maturation.

Hopfig-grasiger Antrunk, leicht getreidig, etwas herb werdend. Erfrischend, im Verlauf herber, mittel-intensiv, kurzer Abgang, der von eine grasigen Hopfigkeit angeführt wird, zudem leicht süß. Test vom 12.5.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 11,11,11,12,-,11 - 11,15

Draught at the brewpub: Slightly hazy, quite firm mid-sized stable head, sweet-malt, grassy hops and a tinge of berries in the nose; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, soft MF; lingering, soft-bitter tail with hops sticking to the togue. a decently crafted beer, excellent by german Hausbrauerei standards.........

(draught at the brewpub) Hazy, pale golden colour with a medium-sized, slowly lacing foamy white head. Slightly sweet and strawy, herbal hops-accented aroma with a minimal greenish yeasty touch. Solid malty base with balanced herbal touch from the beginning. With a moderate yeasty note; quite dry, almost lingering bitter hoppy finish with a soft malty sweetness in the aftertaste. Hearty Zwickel-Pils. Good.

On tap at JH. Pours a mostly clear gold with a thin-moderate white head that faded to a film after a few sips and left spotty lace. The aroma is very light malt and not too much us else going on. The flavor is a stronger dose of malt along with some lager yeast and bread. A bit of light fruit emerges towards the finish. Mild bitterness. A solid, if unexciting beer.

Tap at JH. Aroma of bready malt, sweet light fruits/citrus notes, and a bit of a metallic edge. Flavor quite fruity and refreshing, but that metallic character and a mild astringency is distracting. Good potential here...

On tap at JH. Pours a clear, light orange with a small white head. Aroma of sweet fruits and a touch of citrus. Flavor of light wheat malt and some light fruits in the finish. Crisp with a solid palate. Very easy drinking and quite enjoyable to drink. A winner! 7/4/7/4/15 (3.7/5)
Pale golden/amber colour, slightly cloudy with a thin head. Sweet pale malt. Light apple and pear with a touch of honeyish sweetness. Freshly malty with a light soapiness. It’s okay.

Translucent yellow body, with a decent, bright-white head. Great, strong malty aroma, blended well with a rich hop balance. Crisp and clean, very refreshing to drink. Pleasant, malty finish makes this an enjoyable brew.

Clear golden out of the tap, with a slight copper tint, and a small, but lasting head - aroma of honey, cane sugar, light floral touches - the flavor, at first, seems a bit too bitter, but the rather high sweetness compensates for this somewhat - honey sweetness is the most apparent characteristic - there are some floral and herbal flavors that don’t quite mix with the bitter/hop profile as well as they could, sometimes making the beer taste soapy - more honey, and a bit of lavender in the finish - not their best, but a decent effort.

Tap. Dark orange, very hazy body. Small white head. Aroma is typical barleywine, sugary and malty. Taste is sugar, pineapple, and not surprisingly oxidation. Alcohol tastes about 9%, well covered. Nice earthy, mild bittering hops in the finish but oxidation still looms. Texture is slightly sticky. This is supposedly 12 years old. I think they should have opened it 10 years ago.

Enjoyed at the Brewpub. Pours a clean amber colour with a light beige head and good creamy lacing. Aromas of caramel malts and some grassy hops. The taste is quite hoppy, grassy over the caramel malts. Some nice roasted malts appear later. At first, seems pretty bitter for an Imperial IPA, but just less sweet than most of this style and grassier. Quite inviting with some darker malts.
Old bottle at a bottleshare: pours copper with a white head. Aroma is piny and malty with some caramels. Taste is bitter and malty. Light bodied. Lingering hoppy aftertaste. Ok.

Bière orangée à tendance cuivrée, plutôt limpide, effervescence moyenne-bonne, et surmontée d’un col beige moyennement large et bien dense, mousseux et persistant. Arômes principalement maltés, pain légèrement grillé, pâtisserie, et tout de même pas de sucres mi-foncés, mélange de sucre d’orge, réglisse rouge, caramel et cassonade. Effluves plutôt pâteux, fruits rouge, baies, pâte à fruits… Derrière ces odeurs maltées, on décèle également les arômes d’un houblon qui semble surtout floral, ainsi qu’une certaine dose d’alcool. Nez moyennement agréable et complexe présentant toutefois une bonne intensité. En bouche, pétillement moyen-faible sur la langue, onctuosité tout de même intéressante au palais, belle rondeur, c’est soyeux et velouté. Au goût, pain légèrement grillé, gros grain brut qui manque de raffinement, sucré au goût plutôt générique malgré une petite tendance sucre d’orge et/ou caramel, houblon floral, alcool, et même caoutchouc par moment… Bière céréalière, sucrée et plutôt grossière, avec un alcool un peu mal supporté, et une finale à l’amertume de faible à modérée. Bonne intensité en bouche, mais goût plutôt ordinaire et complexité assez faible. Aussi, c’est assez loin de l’idée qu’on se fait habituellement d’une IPA Impériale. Tout juste une bonne bière, sans plus…

750ml bottle. Clear copper with a foamy off-white head. Flavors are toasted cereals, caramel and alcohol with earthy and fruity notes. Medium body, soft carbonation, slick texture. Cloying sweet, boozy as hell, unnoticeable hops...this is disastrous.

Let this one sit for about a year, and am pleased with outcome. The nose is a soft malt and caramel mixture. The initial taste has a relatively sweet blend of toffee, malt and caramel. Dark fruit - dates, blackberries and figs - soon enter the mix with a slight bitter overlay finishes it off. I agree there is little bitterness expected of an imperial IPA, but as a barleywine/IPA hybrid, its a smooth, tasty sipper.

Bière relativement mince, limpide, rougeoyante avec un tout petit peu de mousse ; en nez c’est très malté, on sent du caramel, des sucres divers et un peu de houblons. D’une rondeur extrême en bouche, elle laisse finalement, après de longues secondes, pointer quelque houblon en fin de vague. Trop simple, trop retenue, trop sucrée et trop maltée, elle accomplit l’exploit d’être tout ce qu’une IPA impériale ne doit pas être, tout en étant plutôt agréable au goût. Dichotomie au final pas très payante pour le Lièvre, et par ricochet pour le goûteur appauvri de 11 dollars aussi.

Dark copper pour, small white head. Aroma is sweet, syrupy malts, caramel, and pine resin hops, and some herbal grasses. Mouth feel is a little viscous, carb is very soft. The finish is medium to high bitter, with a sweet, papery malt finish, with some light pine hops. Pretty bad dipa.

Couleur ambrée avec un léger col mousseux. Nez de caramel et de vieux houblons herbeux. En bouche beaucoup de caramel, houblons herbeux, une touche métallique et une moyenne amertume, sur quelques fruits amère qui ne son pas frais. Une des pires IPA impériale que j’ai pris, a coté du style et on dirait que la bouteille avait 1 ans, mais si je regarde la date elle avait seulement 1 mois... Décevant!
bouteille de 750 ml d’ambrée. arome léger de pamplemousse et de céréale. au gout petite amertume mais pas trop intense pour une ipa un peu sucré pour balancer l’amertume

1 L growler. Bottling date is October 2011...oops. Pours a clear reddish amber with a short lived white head. Aroma is caramel and hops. Flavor is malt, caramel, fruity notes. Finish is very metallic. Lingering cola flavor. Syrupy mouthfeel. Average carbonation. It was probably WAY too old...Don’t worry, I used it for cooking ribs instead of letting it go to waste.

Bottle from Tokyu store, next to Kamakura station. Pours creamy golden, little on the darker side. White bubbly foam. Nose has grain, wet cardboard, some malty fruitiness. Tastes lightly bitter, relatively creamy, some biscuits, medium body. Bitterness is quite crisp, not completely balanced but drinks OK. Simple and decent beer, was good with some food.

From notes: bottle bought in Kamakura in May 2008, enjoyed August 2008. Orange color. Small head. Aroma’s: malty, caramel malts. Retronasal it’s caramel, light fruity and sweetish. Flavor: light to moderate sweet, caramel, later a hint of bitterness. Light bodied. A bit dry finish with light bitterness.
0.33 l bottle @ beer stand in Enoshima, Japan. Looks like pale lager, but taste is quite hoppy for a Japanese beer. Oh, this is a Kölsch? Quite refreshing during a very hot summer day on the seaside.

Bottle shared with Kanagawa friends. Light iyokan and mikan notes. Medium to medium-heavy body with average carbonation. Sweet on the palate, mikan, orange and bread. Finish has some light bitterness. Meh.

Bottle. Aroma is biscuit malty, little bit of citrus hops. Taste has the similar light citrus thing, but is pretty sweet too. Feels pretty heavy which I wasn’t really expecting given it’s a kolsch. Something a bit alcoholic about it. Not really for me I guess.
Mild citrus, floral aroma. Sweet malt flavor, orange, bittersweet finish. Little hoppy local ale, had low expectations but fairly drinkable actually.

Bottle brought back from a friend’s trip to Japan: What a heavy little bottle! Crisply carbonated, pours a dark golden color with a bubbly white head. Mild aroma is mostly malt, light florals, and grassey. Nice body, thick and silky mouthful. Flavor is rather mild, but a pleasant herbal/grassy blend with the overal maltiness of the brew. Picking up a little grain. Finished a little watery.
Bottle. Golden colour. Malty aroma. Some grassy hop flavours, otherwise quite malty. An industrial lager disguised as ji-biru. Points deducted.
Grainy hay, light honey, slight grassy herbyness, and a touch of caramel. Grain, soft caramel, faint earthy herbs, and a touch of sweetness.

Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a decent white head that dissapears quickly. Aroma is malt, light citrus hops, fruit, and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is muted. Fruit, malt, and some hops. Medium, creamy body. Solid, but nothing exceptional.

I +/- 10 yrs old. /I Fast gone white head over terracotta to red/pink coloured beer, clear, almost no carbonation. End of bottle is muddy. Very spicy, pharmaceutical, faintly fruity. Pharmaceutical flavour - which is logical seen its ingredients as galanga, grains of paradise, etc. Undercarbonated; oxydated if really very mildly for its age. Seen its age, pretty satisfying. But it remains a glorified homebrew. I Thanks to Stef! /I

75 cl bottle, bought in Grobbendonk. Orange golden color. Slightly hoppy, soapy aroma. Sweetish flavor, perfumed. Some hopbitterness with orangy esters. Anis and flowers. Slightly yeasty aftertaste. The beer is nothing special tastewise, but clean and reasonably well made.

On tap at Greenwich Union. Black with brown edges and tan head. Lots of dry roasted malt on aroma. Quite harshly dry and maybe overly roasted. Unsubtle. Lots of dry bitter dark choc. Espresso coffee beans. Very drinkable though. Finish has more lengthy choc/coffee. Decent

Cask handpull at County Hotel, JDW, Ashford. Brewed especially for JDW according to the pump clip. Hazy amber colour with thin beige head. Some caramel on aroma, tangy hops on finish. Hops are fun on a standard bitter.
Absolutely excellent! Irish brown ale style, with honey notes and citrussy hops.

Bottle, source not recorded. Poured amber with an average sized off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, hops and fruit. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Malty, slightly bready finish.

Bottle. Orangey Amber in colour. Malty; toasty malts; caramel. Fruity; citrus-orange. Hoppy; grassy and spicy hops. Sweetish malty fruity throughout. Dry slightly bitter malty finish. OK. Drinkable. (2008)

500ml bottle: Pours a clear golden with minimal white head. Aromas of honey, bread and fruit. A bitter beer which is nicely balanced by the malt. Medium body, medium light carbonation. Overall a nice ale.
Bottle from Spar, Hawes and Morrisons, Cowgate, Newcastle. Bright gold in colour with a thin white head. It has a marzipan and pineapple flavour with melon and a zesty slight sulphur finish. Ok.
Butelka 500 ml. Miedziany kolor piana niska biala. W zapachu chmielowe ziemiste orzechowe. W smaku chmielowe goryczkowe - rodzynki palony chleb orzechy. Niezle
Bottle from Asda, deep hold colour with a thinly head. Aroma is light but has marmalade. Taste light sweet.

500 ml bottle. Soft sweet malt smell with notes of caramel. Ugly white top with dark amber color. Waterish bitter taste with great ending! Not enough substance with this beer, but definetly great ending, could hve more power in it, but is not that bad to complain.
Bottle from Tesco; clear golden amber pour with a frothy white head, aroma marmalade and some pale malts, taste has tangerine, some caramel, some fruits, bitter finish, serviceable.

Bottle shared with JMD at HNB 25.05.15. Golden. Off-white head and lacing. Moderate aroma of English hops, Sevilla orange marmelade and fresh grass. Similar taste, with evident bitterness. An excellent session beer!

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: On tap @ Clybourn. Orange-red pour with a light tan head. Aroma of earthy hops, caramel malt and light citrus. Flavors of citusy hops, toasted caramel malt and a bit of lemon. Medium body, crisp/sweet/bright with an earthy/bright/toasty finish.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: On tap at Clybourn on 6/20/07: Pours a transparent copper orange with a thin coating of white head. Sweet toasty grainy caramel malty aroma has a touch of citrusy hops. Body starts with nice lightly sugary sweet caramel malt balanced with good earthy noble hops toward a drier, crisp finish.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: Name: Pennant Race Red Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Clybourne hazy red, wispy head, light sweet caramel malt aroma, well balanced tasty caramel malt flavor with earthy hops, nice bready biscuit character, just a touch of sweetness, light bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: (Jun 07) Tap at Clybourn, MBA pint glass: Slightly hazy reddish brown with a nice long lasting creamy head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of apricot, berries, apple esters along with grainy and caramel malt, slight grassy hops. Very floral and fruity indeed. The taste has a malty and fruity overtone with an earthy and herbal backbone. A weird plastic finish did cause some concern. The mouth feel is lively yet soft, chalky dryness in the finish. Okay beer but the flavor did not match the aroma, quaffable.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: On tap @ Clybourn: Clear light amber in color with a white head. Aroma, caramel and pale malts, some earthy notes. Flavor, caramel some sweet notes, toasted malts, and some earthiness to it on the end.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: From the tap this poured a dirty red body with a modest white head. The aroma had some caramel, orchard fruits, and a slight earthiness to it. Not a bad malty flavor with some fruit tossed in. The hoppy bitterness balances it out smoothly and lingers into the finish. Goose Island - Clybourn, Chicago, IL

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: Sampler. Seems to have migrated to the Clybourn location once the Cubs were out of the pennant race as of June. Looks liike the Rotweizen I just had, minus the murk and the weizen. Smell is actually a little less robust, too. Much clearer reddish brown color. Simply a hearty, lightly malted ale with a hidden hop burn at finish.Cask pour. The cask version, available 6/6, shows a stiffer foamy head. Still has a nice effervescence, with a much more prominent malt character.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: Draft at Wrigleyville. Had this brew after freezing and leaving early from a mid-May Cubs-Sox game. A good session ale, although not quite as good as Wrigley Red which was pouring at the same time.

column1: Goose Island Pennant Race Red Ale
column5: Poured a murky reddish-brown with a well-retained short white head. Aroma picked up dusty biscuity notes with hints of dark fruit and some dry herbal notes.. came across as a cheap amber. Flavor was of artificially-sweetened, lightly-toasted caramel with faint dark fruit and light herbal bitterness.. uptick of dark fruit again at the finish. Lighter-bodied with noticeable effort to be non-offensive in all facets… certainly sessionable.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Pours a transparent orange bronze with a well-lacing wispy white froth of head. Aroma of fresh citrusy grapefruity hops and mild caramel. Starts with a light crystal malty sweetness and good fresh bittering and flavor hoppy balance. A nice IPA.
Your basic brewpub chain IPA: plenty of hops, very drinkable, goes with a burger. It doesn’t amaze, but it’s not bad.

Name: Tribulation India Pale Ale Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Chicago cloudy orange, big off white head, heavy lace, huge citrus hop aroma with sweet caramel malt makes the definitave sugar covered grapefruit, wonderful rich citrus hop flavor perfectly balanced by the sweet caramel malt, follows the aroma perfectly, Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

Rating #1044, Special thanks to Cornfield for bringing this growler to the Chicago Area May Gathering held in Champaign (Road Trip). Drank at Radio Maria. Hazy golden copper with a medium sized off white creamy head that is quickly discipating. Nose is fruity with ome alcohol and somewhat estery kind of like fruit loops. Taste is loaded with pine, sap and grains. More piney and cleaner. Very good stuff.

This has a cloudy amber/orange body with a decent beige head. This has a tropical fruit aroma along with some hits of grapefruit and grass. There’s a soft caramel sweetness at the base, but it’s full of a fruity, hoppy bitterness. The only flaw that I’m finding is that the bitterness seems to end too quickly in the finish. Otherwise a dandy drink. Rock Bottom Chicago, Chicago, IL

One-finger tan head, cloudy bronze-pumpkin color. Sweet, fruity/cat urine/pine/grapefruit/pineapple aroma. Candied orange grapefruit flavor, pretty sweet, medium-heavy hops (for the style.) Finishes strongly in the back palate. Burps pinecones. Good. Second Winston trip.

Draught at the brewpub. Poured a very cloudy orange with one finger of ivory head and good lacing. The aroma is sticky grapefruit, sugar, and some pine. The flavor is lots of grapefruit, some grass, light caramel, and bready tones throughout. It finishes with fruity hops and some alcohol. Pretty tasty.

According to beer nerd Shawn (smhncabot), it is too watery. I guess that was the element that I missed in the beer. Otherwise, a good beer. Nice aroma, but the finish and the body are lacking. Just not a complete IPA.

Poured hazy medium golden with a short cap of creamy off-white head. Lots of pineapple and interesting spices in the aroma.. some sweet toffee sugars beneath.. floral shows as it warms up.. nice. The flavor had a great blend of pineapple and floral hoppage paired with dry English toffee sweetness… lots of enjoyable lingering bitterness along with toffee at the finish. Medium-bodied with med-high bitterness at the edges and at the dry and refreshing finish. Good stuff!
Draft at SIB07. Bits of roasted hop on aroma. Hints of bitter citrus hops, floral notes, and a decent malt backbone. Decent.

On tap at Walking Man. Like the name. Reddish brown in color. Aroma was fruity and earthy. I wonder what the alcohol percentage is. Flavor was solid; fruity and earthy, with some brown malt elements. Fairly dry to me.
Draft @ the brewpub. Very nice and smooth. Full flavored. Billed as an imperial brown by the brewery.
How can Stevenson produce such a solid brewery which continually turns out amazing beers. Labeled as an Imperial Brown, very full malt and toasted taste. High ABV, lends a nice little kick.

Draught. Called an Imperial Brown. Not much aroma, some caramel, some malt. Full malty flavour with caramel, toasted sugar and cream. Lingering malt and sugar finish. Again Worth a special trip, no. Worth drinking if you find it, yes.
(Old rating discovered in a dusty pile of forgotten notes.) Pours coppery dark amber with an off-white head. Medium body and carbonation. Flowery hop aroma, nutty biscuit taste.

6/30/07 On draught at the Seattle International Beerfest with BrewDad. Aroma is light roast and fruity hop flora forward. Appearance is dark brown, cloudy. Flavor is roast forward, bitter, with low hop citrus character. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with some carb bite. Overall, a bit woody, which normally I wouldn’t object to, but just doesn’t work for this beer.

PIB... Clear, reddish brown color with a frothy head. Sweet aroma of berries and malt. Flavors of hops followed by bitter malt and tart fruit and accented barley. Pretty smooth finish considering the complexity of this brew. It’s beers like this that make Walking Man such an awesome brewery.

An excellent double brown ale from Walking Man. Very rich and roasty caramel malt flavors. Doesn’t go for that cereal tasting malt approach, but more like caramel and chocolate, with an earthy rum-cake flavor. Well balanced witha solid hopping. I’m not sure how strong this beer was, but it went down very easy.

[Taster – Seattle International Beerfest] Wow what a name for a beer. Interesting beer flavor an Imperial Brown. Brown in color with a strong Belgian aroma. Deep in alcohol flavor with a deep porter tendencies. But felt like a strong ale also. Has some strong herbal flavor that where very nice. This was a good drinking beer.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Sampled at Latona in Seattle, WA--Poured a ruddy, rich amber body with a medium beige head. Bold hops stickiness and caramel malts. Grainy, dry and sweet. Unbalanced, but better than any other beers I’ve had from this brewery.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Draught at Brouwer’s Café: Dark amber, heavy reddish hues, moderate to large light bege head, hazy, superb lacing. &nbsp Geeze, this beer is quite thick and hazy. &nbsp Somewhat assertive hop nose, grainy malts. &nbsp Seems like it might be a little astringent. &nbsp Fairly strong hop bitterness, mild malt presense, a little grainy and astringent. &nbsp A bit rough on the back side, but otherwise it is quite filling. &nbsp Fairly full bodied and mouthfeel. &nbsp Good cross between an Amber and an IPA, just a little more astringent bitterness than I perfer. &nbsp Still better than I was expecting.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Name: Balls to the Whalstrom Date: 10/13/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, GABF hazy amber, frothy beige head, sweet caramel malt aroma with lots of citrus and earthy hops, rich caramel malt flavor, lots of earthyness keeps it dry, long bitter finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: GABF 2007: Poured a hazy copper color with an off-white head. The hoppy aroma was sweaty and dirty. Some caramel and cereal malt notes. The flavor was bitter from the front to the back and matched the aroma.. Large dry bitter finish. Light body.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: GCBF sample. Called "Balls to the Wahlstrom, Hop Bomb" as a nod to the BA Bros. (I guess). Dark orange. Minimal head. Enjoyable malt and hoppy nose. Dry light malt body with mouth drying hops. Doesn’t turn out quiet as well as expected.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Orange brown with no head. Big grapefruit nose some malt. Yep it’s hoppy. Grapefruit and a bitter finish. This beer is really all about the hop. Damn tasty.GCBF.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Somewhat murky reddish/light brown colour. Big, fresh amarillo nose, like a mountain spring, with some toasty malts in there as well. Really fresh, pithy hops. Dry as a bone. Some malts crackling in there - crystal, Munich and yes they are crackling fresh. Nonetheless, this really is hoppy, like chewing on amarillo.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: (on tap at Brouwers) This is on the border of IIPA & american strong, but I see it more as the latter due to color & hoppage. deep amber bordering on ruby tones, pleasant head. a little weight in the mouth but not slippery, enough carbonation. I’d like more of this. the hops are very vocal but balanced away from harshness; the malt is robust baramel, with a sting of roasted & a smoked undercurrent.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: (Draught) Sampled at the Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 7th, 2007. Citrus hops. Very strong orange flavour - almost too overpowering and sweet.

column1: Water Street Balls to the Wall
column5: Cloudy orange-maroon firestorm with a light hop nose and a mild hop flavor that is lush and full in mouthfeel.

Sampled from a growler @ DLD 4/28/2007. Pours a clear dark golden color with a medium off white head. The aroma was citrus and weak caramel malts. The flavor was much like the aroma: light sweet caramel malt and citrus. The body was a bit thin and the finish was on the dry side. Overall, not bad, very drinkable.

I’m not a huge fan of the American hops in lagers. The dry straw malt can never match up to or balance the citrus and pine harshness of American hops. This beer is no exception. It’s good when paired with the pizza, but on it’s on the flavors clash a bit to me.

Date: 4/28/2007 Event: DarkLord Day 2007 Location: Three Floyds Brewing Co. Parking Lot Serving: Sampled from a growler. Tasting Notes Aroma: Light caramel malt and citrus. Appearance: Clear golden color with a beige frothy crown. Flavor: Light caramel malt and juicy citrus. Hints of rye characteristics in the dry and spicy finish (although there probably isn’t any rye in this beer). Palate: Average palate; a little watery here and there. Overall: Very easy to drink. Better than most Heller Bock/Maibock brews...

On tap at the brew pub, poured a slightly hazy gold color with a thick white head. Aromas of sweet malts and a bit of bready yeast. Nice flavor, good caramel sweetness with a bitter undertone. Slick mouthfeel and a sweet fininsh. Another nice beer from Rocky River.

column1: The Brewery at Lake Tahoe Nut Brown Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: "decent aroma, and i agree that this is one of their better beers. unfortunately that’s pretty much saying it doesn’t suck, but it’s not worth a trip there. totally let down by this brewery. 10-2010-can’t even say that anymore. 1 dimensional, barely brown (dark tan?) and weak."

column1: The Brewery at Lake Tahoe Nut Brown Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: 3oz sample. One of 7 samples tasted while having dinner at the brewpub. I found all 7 to be average or below average with no real standouts. (actual tasting was on 2/15)

column1: The Brewery at Lake Tahoe Nut Brown Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Not much aroma. A pretty nice brown to me because despite the name, it isn’t all that nutty. A bit thin in the finish, but quite drinkable.

column1: The Brewery at Lake Tahoe Nut Brown Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Their best made beer IMO. Perhaps it was the freshest since it’s a seasonal beer? Maybe the others weren’t up to par? At any rate, this was a pretty good brown ale. A dark brown appearance, clear with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma was caramel, buttered pecans, molasses with a toasted bread character too. Mouthfeel was on the thin side. Flavor was clean, malty with a strong molasses sweetness that was pretty overpowering. This was their best creation. Now if they could pull up the rest of their beers we might be talking something good here.
Cask at The Market Porter. Black with a beige little froth. Coffee and earthy aromas and flavours, some smoked meat. Different, slightly smoked porter.
Cask, The Ale Wagon, Leicester. Near black with a small head. Aromas are smoky, earthy roast malts with soft berries. Flavours are smooth coffee and chocolate malts with berries and soft spices. OK.
Cask@Ale Wagon, Leicester. Black beer with a strongish head. The aroma is herbal and malty, and the flavour is herbal, malty and lightly dry. Overall a nice beer.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Ale Wagon Leicester. A black coloured beer with ah decent off-white head. The aroma is chocolatey and malty but there’s a hint of sourness which does transgress to the taste, but doesn’t spoil the nice chocolate malts too much. Reasonable enough.

On tap at the brewery. Clear, light gold appearance with a patchy white head. Aroma and flavor of bread, light spice, citrus fruit and light bitter hops. Crisp and easy to drink. A little bland and boring overall.

ON tap at the brewpub. Pours golden with a long lasting white head and soda-like carbonation. Aroma is of biscuit and wheat malts and hints of lemon. Body is medium and smooth. Taste is wheat malt and some citrus notes. Almost no finish. Just a step above of macro brew.

The mountains of Colorado harbor many niches, nooks and crannies, within which lie a bounty of hidden mines, towns and even the occasional bakery (Silver Plume). Glenwood Springs is not what you’d call a quaint mountain town, exactly, but it’s not a global tourism destination either. Home to a therapeutic hot springs, it sees its fair share of visitors, and those who do go get a chance to visit the local brewpub: Glenwood Canyon Brewing Company. It is by no means an infamous brewery, or a landmark in craft beer, but it provides better beer to a town with one foot still in the past, and that makes it all the more charming. My family and I ordered a sampler to get a well rounded taste of the offerings, and I came away reasonably impressed, considering my expectations. The American Wheat appeared early on in the sampler, providing a welcome therapy after the depressing efforts of the Glenwood Canyon Brewing Honey Lager. I’m doubtful that a wheat really belongs in a restaurant context. Wheat beers, whether Witbiers or American are exceptional by themselves, isolated, with the drinker’s palate dedicated entirely to the beer. The subtle spices and flavor configurations can only be appreciated without sauces, syrups and seasonings disturbing the precarious silence that a wheat beer demands. Perhaps a salad or a fish dish might be appropriate, but there are too few places at the dining table where a wheat beer can find the proper care and treatment it requires. This American wheat was actually a pre-prandial arrangement, but it’s still coupled to the restaurant that supports the next door brewery, no doubt spoiled by many diners who used it to wash down a rack of intensely flavored ribs. The Sunlight American wheat was a very golden yellow hue, with nary a floating particle in sight, nor any head to speak of. Still, vapor exuded from the half-dollar sized top, pleasant with hints of lemon, but countered by a Frankenstein skunk-flower blend that is more confusing than ill tasting. The taste ditches the bewildering aroma, glazing the tongue with a moderately sweet flavor of refined sugar and the slightest hint of coriander, besides the assumed generic wheatiness. If you can get past the confusing vapors, then you’ll find a solid American wheat with enough to please and no forays into the kinds of excess that harms many American wheats.

column1: Glenwood Canyon Rock Garden Biere de Garde
column5: The mountains of Colorado harbor many niches, nooks and crannies, within which lie a bounty of hidden mines, towns and even the occasional bakery (Silver Plume). Glenwood Springs is not what you’d call a quaint mountain town, exactly, but it’s not a global tourism destination either. Home to a therapeutic hot springs, it sees its fair share of visitors, and those who do go get a chance to visit the local brewpub: Glenwood Canyon Brewing Company. It is by no means an infamous brewery, or a landmark in craft beer, but it provides better beer to a town with one foot still in the past, and that makes it all the more charming. My family and I ordered a sampler to get a well rounded taste of the offerings, and I came away reasonably impressed, considering my expectations. The Biere de Garde came somewhere around the middle, striking a balance between the light-bodied lagers and pale ales, and the ruddier stout. The name provided no information about the beer’s flavor, aroma, or even its categorical style, so, with a completely mysterious jar of beer in front of me I took a plunge. Evidently, what I had thought was a mystery had turned out to be a familiar friend. The Biere de Garde, for all its veiled, incognito efforts and foreign titling was remarkably similar to New Belgium’s Fat Tire. The body of the beer is a mix of deep and light colors, synthesizing a deep dandelion color, clear and lucid, and a great cream colored head. The aroma, unlike any other beer in the sampler, had a very aged, mature feel to it. It was funky and cheesy, as any good cheese monger’s shop should be, but also skunky, suggesting it had suffered some UV abuse. The aroma is reflected in the taste where the skunkiness prevails over the gourmet flavors. Some of the skunk taste is hidden with an interesting combo of pistachio, peanuts, caramel and brown sugar, though it persists much to the detriment of the brew. A week later I called the brewer to ask what the style was, since it had reminded me of Fat Tire, and he told me it was a “French Farmhouse Ale”, while Fat Tire is classified as an Amber Ale. I know that classifying beers can often mislead, but the Biere de Garde and Fat Tire are very similar in taste, especially with the nutty and skunky flavors dominating the palate. Still, it was a reasonable beer, and was a big hit with the family. We took home a growler that evening and played a rousing pirate board game with it, calling out for hotel glasses of grog and growing ever merrier with each pour and each sunken pewter ship.

(300 ml bottle from Swedish Systembolaget) Imported to Sweden by Akebono Unlimited. Clear pear color. A bit rancid butter mixed with wood scent. Some fresh pear after a while. Strong vinous buttery taste with some dry wood. Smooth mouthfeel with a fiery alcohol aftertaste. Some pear peals taste as well.

Very woody aroma with lesser hints of maple syrup. Opaque brown, thin head. Maple syrup is much more distinct on the palate. Chocolate syrup is also present. Alcohol is not noticeable, but there is a whiskey note. Holds up surprisingly well after 4 years. I was very fortunate to find this bottle. Not much in the way of hops, but after all this time, I wasn’t expecting any. I usually prefer a hoppier brown, but this was quite good.

Bottle. Pours a murky hazed deep amber brown with a thin head- low carb. Aroma is vege, dms, solvent, light dusty caramel malt, burnt toffee, biscuit, sharp edges turn to a grapeskin, and sour wine. Flavor is more tart notes, vegetal, tannic, grapeskin, moderately sweet brown sugar, then turns tart again with an ashy note and astringent finish. Blech.

Received this in a trade with edmedina. Man, I was really hoping for a good beer here on this one. I was let down. Appearance- Nice dark, amber brown with little to no head and no lacing. Smell-A nice nutty and sweet aroma. Nice hints of roasted malts and caramel. Taste- Horrible! There is this bad sour taste that just ruins this beer. Ugh, this beer became a drain pour. Mouthfeel- Medium body with very little carbonation. Overall- A HUGE disappointment! I really hope the beer went bad and this taste wasn’t intentional. Started off great but then went south! I don’t even think the Jamestown colonists would have consumed this swill.
Deep amber with light tan head and lace. Brown sugar, dough, and a hint of abv on the nose. Roasted malt, sweet malt flavor and a malt bitter finish. Medium bodied but really foamy in the mouth.
Dark brown, frothy beige head. Aroma is slightly funky- molasses, lemon, berry, honey. Taste is bad sweet, lemon, charred biscuit. A little acidic.

Pours a lasting ring of beige head with a copper-brown body. Aromas of brown sugar, roasted, band-aids. Flavor is roasted, toasted, brown sugar, infection. Sour, metallic, wrong. Let me down big time. Was really hoping this beer was gonna be good and right. Thanks Butters!

bottle poured a dark brown in color with a thin head. aroma has dark malts, earth, and some over ripe dark fruit. mouth feel is really thick and light on the carbonation. flavor is richly malted, bitter nuts, and some funk. has not aged so gracefully.

This smelled really like a nice brown ale, roasty, nutty, cool! Unfortunately the taste was sour but not in a good way. I don;t know if this was intentionally sour or not but it does not work for this beer. Sadly, this beer ended up as a drain pour as I could not drink it. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 06-21-2008 01:57:36

22oz from Once Upon a Vine, Richmond. Nice dark brown pour, almost mahogany with bits of amber in there. Minimal carb, almost looks soupy once it’s in the glass. I was all keyed up for something malty and nutty, but I got a dank, vegetal funk instead. I’m not talking oud bruin, and happy dank. I’m talking infected. Mild yeasty notes are detectable if you’re looking for something palatable and somewhat to style. But there’s some serious oxidation going on to top off the likely infection. Shame, as other ratings seem to suggest the ale is - when healthy - exactly what I’d hoped for and expected. As is: drainpour.

Bottle in trade from Butters. Tall tan head that floats over a clear dark brown body. Coffee dark chocolate malt aroma. Tastes like your typical brown ale with a slightly sour/bitter note in the finish. I would probably pass on this one next time.
June 2010. Sampled at the brewery. Orange/amber color with a white head. Caramel, citrus and malty aromas. Flavors of grass, hops, malt, and tropical fruit. Not bad.

Pours with a small head. Medium lacing on the glass. Orange - copper color (clear). Slightly malty and some nutty flavors, with a touch of clove. This is an English IPA, but the hops are stronger than usual of this type (in a good way) Nice clean finish. Nice surprise :-)

Rating #37 for 2012 5/17/12 Wabi Sabi Petersburg VA. Draft served cold from a Shaker. Very refreshing and crisp aroma of extremely citrusy hops, some wheat, and spice. Copper color 1/2 inch tan head thick wispy lacing. Sweet for an IPA light to medium hop flavor light citrus and vanilla in the finish. Light to medium carbonation finishes a bit dry. Not bad at all would love to try froma bottle
Tap at BP Old Towne. Big soapy, pine, orange, grapefruit hop tones. Clean golden malt body. Rather straightforward IPA, but really well executed. Mellow tropical fruit tones.
Moderate hop aroma. Hazy orange color with a large white head. Light sweet beginning with a resin hop bitter finish
Tap. Not my fave IPA- prefer hop bombs. Golden with thin white head nice lacing. Had trouble with nose- peaches, vanilla, and citrus? Not too sweet, not too bitter. Light.

This 22 oz bottle was courtesy of Strykzone. Pours a color between orange and amber with a good sized light-beige head that left good lacing rings. Nose shows some nice ripe fruit, such as pear and grapefruit. Body is medium and the mouthfeel is creamy any easy to swallow. The flavor is well balanced between the caramel malts and some floral and citrus hops tastes and nice bitterness. The finish is bitter and flavorful. A very well crafted and easy drinking IPA.
Pours hazy copper orange with a nice white head. Aroma is of hops, pine and caramel. Has a pretty mediocre taste, nothing special. Some hops, pine, resin and caramel. Definitely worth the $4, though.

Bomber bought in Harrisonburg, Va. Clear and copper colored. A soapy off white head lasts nicely and leaves sticky lacing. The nose is hard to find and is mostly caramel. The flavor begins with burnt sugary notes and some soggy hops are in there, too. A slow start. The hops grow with warmer temperatures and things smooth out and balance is much better. . They are citrus and floral with some moderate bitterness. The caramel is creamy and brown sugar is tasted. The finish was worth the ride.

Bottle. Pours a pale amber golden color with a longlasting off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma with hints of citrus. Sweetish malty hoppy bitter flavor with some soapy hints. Hasa fruity malty hoppy bitter citrus finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pours gold with a white head. Smells fruity with some toasted malt hints. Tastes breaddy and sweet with a crisp finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle with MaltDawg on 08/16/2008 or sometime shortly afterward since these ratings were lost for a half a year. Clear copper amber body with a small off-white head. Grassy, slightly vegetal aroma. Sweet floral an caramel flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Poured mediun light amber color. Hop nose, with some maltiness. Descent head with little lacing. Same malt-hop flavorness....Not a huge fan of organic beers, but descent.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Nice amber color and a fast fading head. The bottle has an abstract dot on it. Mellow aroma that is floral with a little earthy yeast. This is a mildly sweet ale that is not forceful, but is mild and well balanced with some light, perky hops. A tasty organic brew.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12oz. Bottle: Faint aroma of toasted malts, citrus hops and caramel. Poured orange/amber in color with a small, off-white head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer. Clear. Not sparkling. Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Tastes of toasted malts, caramel, hops, brown sugar, and slight citrus. Medium body. Average texture. Average carbonation. Sweet, toasted malt, brown sugar finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle in NYC. Glowing dark gold. Soft, fruity, well balanced beer. Sweet and sour cherries, fine dryness.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: (Bottle). Faint caramel malt aroma. Orange-copper color, tiny off-white head. Flavor seems like an attempt at maltiness and caramel, but really there’s not much of anything. Mostly cardboardy and watery. I like their Black Lager, but this one’s quite bad.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: A single sixer of 12 oz bottles found at local Kroger. Slight aroma of pale malt with a touch of earthy hops and a hint of something vegetal. Clear amber golden with a small white head. Flavor of caramelized malt and sweet tea like hop notes. Medium body with a fairly dry finish. Okay amber ale.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Pours a hazy orange-copper with a big, mostly-lasting, fluffy off-white head. Decent aroma, slightly sweet, of caramel malt, more hops then expected, some fruit and light toastiness. Light, hoppy, fruity flavour, a touch watery, backed by lightly toasted caramel malt and a light bitter finish. Easy to drink. The aftertaste got just a tad iffy after a while though. Medium bodied. Though not amazing or anything this is still much better then I expected and I would easily drink it again.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle sampled at NFB&WF ’08 at Martha Clara Vineyards. Pours a clear amber. Mild aroma of malt. The flavor starts out with some caramel malt, and is followed by light hops bitterness. Not a bad beer, its just that the flavors kind of lurk in the background and never seem to make a real appearance.
Bottle courtesy of Eepiest. From memory. Nice brown, pretty up the middle, picked up a little molasses with age, still not very sweet though. Legend Brewing is the shit.

Dark brown body with a small tan head. The nose is toffee, molasses, raisins and plums. The flavor is fairly dry with light roast, chocolate, molasses and raisins. Medium body is soft with light carbonation.

22 oz bottle, cellared 6 months. Dark amber brown with a lively, but settling beige head. Nose is wild grapes and mocha, a little dusty. Medium light with mild fizzy carb. Taste is coffee and burnt brown sugar. Finishes with plum and a citric tang.

Bottle, clear dark brown with a light brown head. Light cocoa, caramel in the nose. Flavor has notes of light chocolate, a little toffee and earthy British hops with moderate bitterness level. Watery body with moderate carbonation.

22oz bottle, courtesy of jasonp. Thanks, Jason! Pours an oily, dark cola color; off-white head with patchy lacing. Nougat and sticky dried fruits in the aroma; some coffee. Medium mouthfeel: coffee and nougat; slightly watery, with a decently chewy malt core; messy and kind of weird, honestly. Medium, nougat and instant coffee finish.

Poured from a 22 oz. Transparent and reddish sienna brown pour. Aroma suggests wheat biscuits, chocolate, wild rice, and molasses. Tinny hints of maple and caramelized sugar wander in. Taste is of tepid malts, being strangely clean, lightly fruity and generically dull. Wood, honey, maple, and vanilla in that usual montage of dark malt sweetness. Thin palate lacks any kind of liveliness or rich bombast; it couldn’t serve as a refreshing session or as contemplative sipper. Something so uninspired can hardly be expected to inspire. Thanks for sharing, Jason!

Appears a dark brown with a light tan head that slowly fades out. Scattered lacing is left around the glass. Smell is of roasted nuts, toffee, cream, cocoa, light buttercream, and gentle smoke. Taste is of the aromas with a decent mix in a different but enjoyable flavor. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy, smooth, sugary with mild cocoa bitterness hitting the tongue on the swallow.
Dark brown, nearly black. Rich malty aroma. Strong maltyness that fills the mouth. Roasted, creamy mild body.

Date: 05/23/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting clear dark red, dense creamy beige head, drippy lace, sweet milk chocolate aroma, creamy body, rich chocolate flavor, nice butterscotch sweetness blends well with the chocolate, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Poured a clear deep brown color with a large beige head. The aroma was soapy and floral with mild diacetyl notes. The flavor was lightly malty with a citrus hopmiddle and a roasty finish. Mildly bitter with a semi-dry finish. Light to medium bodied.
Little flat, but another decent addition from this local brewer. A bit of a bitter from a nice finish.
Bottle: Another of these weird beer mixed drinks, can´t taste any beer at all, only tomato juice. Food Pairing: Bloody Mary.

Poured pale yellow with a small, quickly fading head. Another new Guatemalan beer and another bad one. Tequila infused, even has the salt. Hard to descibe. Bad from start to finish. This has to be one of the worst brews ever produced.

column1: Brew It Up! Belgian Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Served overly chilled. Light caramel aroma. Amber color with fine white head. Starts with belgian candy flavoring, a bit of spice. A light bitter in the finish balances the sweetness a bit. Tastes like a light Belgian dubble? Less yeast and spice than a Belgian. Pretty good stuff. Might be better at a warmer temperature.

Candy sweet nose initially with a lightly buttered toast note behind it. A subtly not malt slickness to the palate with a focus on malt toastiness, a hint of roast and a tad bit of slick butter. Decent but not a style I care for.

355ml bottle. Amber pour, large offwhite head. ARoma is hoppier than expected, some tropical fruit and citrus, some caramel and dried fruit. Falvor is both earthy and hopppy. This is actually pretty good. HErbal, piney hops, ,caramel, pretzel, supremely dry, spices even the lightest roast/smoke. Complex. A winner in a mundane category.

On tap at Emmett’s, pours a clear amber with an egg shelled colored head and some spotty lacing in the glass, the aroma actually had a nice hop touch to it with the sweetness following, the flavor has a hoppy and fruity front end with a sweeter finish of caramel and malt, hoppier than I expected, pleasantly surprised.
12 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and pine. Taste is malts and caramel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ruby red color with off white head. Caramel malt and piney hop aroma. Citrus and piney hop flavors balanced by caramel sweetness. Chewy, medium bodied, medium-high carbonation, great mouthfeel. Finishes semi-sweet to dry with a nice hop bitterness to balance out the malty sweetness. Unique, but appropriate style characteristics.
translucent bright amber pour with a thin tan head. bready caramel malt aroma with some piney hops coming through. malt forward flavor with a dry, slightly bitter hop finish.
Had this on draft at uncommon ground. Cloudy red pour. White head. Malty and bitter finish. Smooth and hoppy upfront. I like
On tap at Goose Island 25th Anniversary Event. Citrus hops and a bit of bready malt. Mild toast and caramel.

Brewhaha. Poued reddish amber color with a decent off-white head. Decent amount of hoppy aroma which is promising. On the lighter side of medium bodied. Decent balance with a decidedly hoppy finish. Fair to decent beer.
Aroma is malts and light but crisp hops. The flavor is fruit, mildly sweet malts, light citrus and a bitter finish.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Very dark red brown. Thick cream head. Flavour is hard to place - almost scotch. nice.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: 330ml bottle. Dark red in colour,with a small beige head. Nice dark malt flavours with a sweet aftertaste.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: 330ml bottle. This limited release porter carries a big fluffy tan head that is made up of big and little bubbles. Dark brown in the glass with very strong honey aroma. Reminds me of when you open a jar of honey and that big sweet aroma wafts out.
