The sweetness carries over to the flavour and if you closed your eyes you would swear you had a piece of fresh honeycomb in your mouth. Full flavoured and carries the alcohol well. Dry on the palate with an aftertaste that fills the mouth and goes on and on. Sometimes you come across a beer that you wished you bought more than one of, this is one such beer.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Pours dark brown, almost black, with a large, off-white head. Nose shows honey, grainy malt, and some soft roasted malt. Flavours have a little more impact in the way of roasted malt, with some coffee hints showing up, and more honey is present. Unfortunately there’s also a huge grainy, cardboard character and overt alcohol which ruins it. Carbonation is much too high.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Bottle. Dark red brown with a beige head that fades but laces nicely. Aroma of (tea-tree?) honey, raisins, burnt sugar, candied ginger, vanilla, angelica. Silky texture. Alcohol completely hidden. Taste has some dark malts but is mainly about fruity and herbal/ spicy honey. Modest sweetness, interesting herbal and slightly astringent finish. Good match for hard cheese - would pair very well with Pecorino Toscano. Unusual and good.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Bottle 330ml. Delicious beer. Aromas of honey, alcohol, and liquorice. Taste is sweet, with bitter notes, and long length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Dark brown, with a thin white head.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Bottle. Pours dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of honey, chocolate, plum and alcohol. The flavour is sweet honey/toffeeish malt, chocolate and a peppery taste presumably parted from the alcohol. A strange mix to be honest and at no point is the beer intriguing to drink, but having said that I like the innovation of the brewers to try something different. Very sweet finish. It’s really not that bad just rough around the edges.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Bottle. Pours dark clear ruby brown with a short light tan head. Aroma is of cocoa, caramel, malt and honey. Flavour has very little distinct honey but you can tell its there from the slight influence it has on other flavours: malt, chocolate and coffee notes all have a slight twist from the honey. Quite light for a porter, this is still an ok beer but it seems like it could have been a fair bit better.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: Creamy thin head good carbonation red brown ale.Aroma caramel honey toffee walnut chocolate.Flavour soapy like but not harmful it,s the honey mixing with the other flavours of chocolate toffee caramel nuttyness,gives it a creamyness like texture that is not hard to take,finish mild bitter creamy nutty flavour.

column1: Red Duck Limited Release Queen Bee Honey Porter
column5: This got a bit better as it warmed. Dark brown body with a ruby tinge and a short head. Sweet malty aroma with hints of raisins and probably some honey. Smooth taste, don’t notice the alcohol, not big flavours but don’t expect that with a porter.
Poured from bottle thanks ClarkVV 2007 vintage hazy gold color with a thin fizzy white head. Aroma is dried fruit and honey. Taste is pale malt with notes of clove spice and apricots.

750 ml bottle, thanks to ClarkVV on this bottle. About a 2007 vintage... Mildly hazy gold color with particles floating around the liquid. Aroma is honey, mild dried fruits. Maybe mild sugar. Flavor is a pale malt base with mild spice, clove and like apricot. Body is pretty decent. Pretty much spot on for the style. Nice.

2007 bottle randomly acquired at Downtown Liquors, drunk 11/28/15. Honey, cork, plastic, mandarin, alcohol. Hmmm, quite mellow. The flavor is sweet, with 8 year old carb that is obviously low. Oxidation is mild with lots of honey and citrus. Pretty tough to drink, though not sure how this could have been any better young. Incredibly sweet as it progresses.

750ml bottle from 2007 shared by ClarkVv. Thanks, Clark. Pours copper with an off white head. Aroma is fruity esters, honey, biscuits. Flavor is honey, clove, fruity esters. This is really holding up well. Nice and soft and smooth.

Light yellow with a bit of a white head. Smell is honey and spices. Something about this is off to me. I like it sort of but I can pinpoint the off flavor. Maybe it’s just the lime leafs... like I need citrus or I need more tea or something in this. IDK.

75CL from Clark, A very light orange color with a 3 finger head. Fully carbed for a 2007 beer. Aroma is super cheesy, very yeasty with a little bit of citrus. Well, it’s certainly old. You get a ton of oxidation, cheese, lemon meringue and old shoe. Believe it or not, this is still drinkable but lots of oxidation.

Bottle at Haket during Ölets Dag 2015. Hazy golden beer with a small but kinda lasting offwhite head. Malty fruity aroma, caramel, figs, raisins, grapes, bready notes, some spices. Fruity malty aroma, dusty, some wood, citrus, still some hops, raisins, figs, warming alcohol, caramel notes. Fruity yeasty caramel finish with warming alcohol. Very good.
Rating #1070, flaske fra Netto i Nysted Ret sød tripel, som dog stadig bevarer en flot blomsterprofil og en vis humlebitterhed. Tyk og god.
0,75l bottle @ Pikkulintu. Pours murky golden with a medium head. Aroma is malts, yeast and lime. Flavor is malts, yeast, lime and hops. Interesting if nothing else. Great!

750ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki) Bottled 2007, BB 2010, Drunk 2014 Simple fruity aromas, some interesting esters. Magical taste - I was literally like a sow with pheremones sprayed in front of her snout as soon as it got some in my mouth. Fruity, banana, orange. Gentle malts, sweetish and so mellow. A genuine 9/11 of wow, I’m flattened. Sweetish full paalte, nice carbonation stops it from being sticky. Marvelous full waves of esters through the back of the mouth. Later the aroma loses the aged aspects and becomes more mellow after the yeaster end of bottle is poured in. Better without yeast, only 8 in taste now. 0lfabrikken - we miss you!
Updating old records. From bottle in shaker. OK but could use a bit more of the Sauvin hops

Dourada escura,translúcida,espuma fina cremosa,no aroma,malte e um leve frutado;na boca,malte,caramelo,notas cítricas com amargor moderado finalizando,carbonatação e corpo médio(a)/baixo(a),álcool bem inserido,boa drinkability. Pale Ale australiana,produzida na Bélgica,classificada como estilo americano,mas ao meu ver esta mais para uma bitter inglesa,mostrou qualidades razoáveis,vale a prova.
Aroma delicioso intenso e cítrico. Âmbar e translúcida. Creme branco fino. Cítrica ácida e média densidade. Amargor baixo. E no final. Um pouco de acidez excedida no final
Aroma discreto. Cor dourada e espuma branca. Sabor um pouco maltado com suavidade em seu paladar.

Poured a head of medium-high density which left a fine lace. Woody, toffee aroma with bread, caramel and some dried fruit flavours. Some musty staleness which may reflect the bottle’s age. Overall an easy drinking pale ale with some interesting notes.
bottle. pale amber with small head. caramel malt. light spice and yeast. not very good, but clearly an old bottle.
Beautiful honey aroma with some floral notes. Clear amber colour with no head. Nice honey flavour up front with mild bitter hop finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottled@EBF2008 (backlog). Pale amber colour with a small white head. Aroma is fruits, toffee and some nectary notes. Flavour is tropical fruits, wood, toffee, herbs and some mild grassy and bready notes.
Pours nearly clear amber with a short, off-white head. Scent is fruit, malt. Taste is slightly bready, overripe sweet fruit. Grassy hop bitter. Fairly decent.

A good looking clear golden amber with a 1/2" head and swirls of lace. Sweet caramel malt carries all the way to the finish where light carbonation provides most of the bittering. A decent big box brewery offering, but not enough taste or complexity to merit a big rating. Best for a night at the bar with your mates.
Bottle. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, cellar, dried fruit, caramel. Flavour is malt, caramel, dried fruits, cellar. Medium body. OK beer.
33cl bottle. white head. Nice dark colour. A pretty decent double. Nice aftertaste

Bottle 330ml. @ home. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, berry, chocolate notes, light to moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, caramel, brown sugar, plum - raisin, chocolate notes, light coffee dusty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100825]

Bottled, 330ml at Lemmy’s, Leiden. Dark Chestnut with cream head. Right in to a dry nutty beer, a fair amount of CO2, but decent roasty notes and a good amount of bitterness. Lemmy’s had all 3 Leidsch beers but I was running late for the train so just went for this. Decent.
Bought at ABCBeers in the Hague. Amber brown body with little head. Sweet and roasty nose. Taste of malts, caramel & lots of toffee. Quite creamy & refreshing.

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, amber beer with a decent beige head. Cellar, dried fruits and a touch of caramel in the aroma. A bit papery mouthfeel, medium bodied, with flavors of cellar, caramel and dried fruits. Cellar and dried fruits in the finish. A decent dubbel, but there’s lots of beers better than this one. 100522

Bottle@Home. Strong aroma, quite malty, mainly licorice and laurel. Dark brown colour, beige good head, good lace. Sweet, nice bitterness, very malty, loads of licorice, hint of laurel, other spices as well. Medium to full bodied. Flavourful, balanced but maybe a bit over the edge with the licorice.

33cl Bottle at homebrewing clubhouse. Clear reddish brown colour, light beige head. Aroma of burnt sugar and roasted malts. Flavour is light sweet, roasted malts, burnt brown sugar, some bitter chocolate. Light bitter finish. Medium bodied, soft mouthfeel. OK.

Bottle 33 cl. Pors a dark brown with a small off-white head and an aroma of caramelly malts, yeast and liquorice. The taste is a bit sour or an abbey dubbel, but apart from that it’s a pretty dubbel. Nothing t write home about.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Amber brown body with healthy head. Sweet and roasty nose. Taste of malts, caramel, and lots of toffee. Quite creamy and refreshing. Licorice references well-spotted.

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Tres bonne scotch ale. J ai meme eu l honneur d en faire des degustation lorsque je travaillais a la Duchesse d Aiguillon! Saveurs de caramel, fruits confits/foncers/caramelisers et un peu de fumer. Encore un peu jeune lorsque deguster, mais d ici quelques mois, elle devrais etre un delice. Very good scotch ale. I had the honor of promoting it when I was working at the Duchesse d Aiguillon. Caramel, candied/dark/caramelized fruits and slight smokey notes. Still young when tasted, will need maturation.

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Brown bottle, 500 ml, purchased at Dépanneur La duchesse d’Aiguillon, savoured on October 29 2008; eye: mahogany, opaque, nice café au lait head, average effervescence, lacing; nose: caramel malt, scotch, dark fruits, light smoke, vanilla, light wood, light hops; mouth: malt, caramel, wood, light smoke, dark fruits, light peat, finale in malt with a good presence of scotch, mildly sweet, medium body, sticky texture, not much carbonation; overall: quite likable FRANÇAIS Bouteille brune, 500 ml, meilleure avant juin 2010, achetée chez Dépanneur La duchesse d’Aiguillon, savourée le 29 octobre 2008; œil : acajou, opaque, belle mousse café au lait, effervescence moyenne, dentelle; nez : malt caramel, scotch, fruits foncés, léger fumé, vanille, léger boisé, léger houblon; bouche : malt, caramel, boisé, léger fumé, fruits foncés, léger tourbe, finale en malt avec une bonne présence de scotch, moyennement sucrée, corps moyen, texture collante, peu carbonatée; en résumé : bien aimé

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: A deep dark mahoganny brown ale with a thick moka head. A nice molasse aroma with plums and hops, treacle, burned sugars, not buttery or cloying. In mouth, a good sweet brown sugar malt, amber maple syrup, woody, with loads of nutty and light alcohol. Rich and woody. Bought at Jovi, Gatineau for 3.99$. No label, just a sticker....thanks Pascal!

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Biere du dep d’Aiguillon. Scotch ale qui fait la job sans trop de prétention. Bien balancé entre le sucré, l’alchol et l’amertume. Excellent!

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: bouteille brune de 500ml, vendu 4,59$ chez Lavigne, mon exemplaire a 8% alc./vol. bière brune opaque, la mousse disparait très vite, nez sucré de pomme verte, envahissant. la première gorgé est très bien, ensuite l’alcool se fait sentir, très agréable, ronde. succès pour AMB.

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Bouteille 500 ml. Vieillie environ 1 an. La bière est de couleur rouge-rubis avec des reflets brun- bourgogne. La mousse quant à elle est modeste mais dure tout au long de la dégustation. Au nez, une attaque d’arômes percute notre sens de l’odorat. Le caramel au beurre, le caramel brulé, les noix grillés, les dattes, les figues, les pruneaux,l’alcool, le toffee et le moût de raisin s’entremêlent pour créer une expérience inoubliable. En bouche la bière est d’une rondeur fort appréciable et nous confies des flaveurs de caramel au beurre, de chocolat, de noisettes grillés, de malt fumé, de vanille et de raisin confîts. Le tout se termine par une amertume qui s’estompe plus ou moins rapidement tout dépendant de la température. De plus, une légère touche d’alcool est présente. WoW

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Bouteille 500ml. De couleur rubis brune foncée et voilée.Nez de caramel moyennement rôti et aux notes terreuses, légèrement fruité (léger de cerises, notes de raisins et de dates) et de houblon herbeux avec des notes de pain et de chocolat noir. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse et aux notes sirupeuses. Goût légèrement fruité (dates, léger de raisins, traces de cerises) accompagné de petites notes de tabac (quelques traces fumées) lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté du genre caramel moyennement rôti (traces brûlées) et sucré avec des notes terreuses ainsi qu’un léger goût de chocolat noir et des notes de pain puis en finale l’on retrouve un goût moyennement amer de houblon herbeux accompagné d’un léger goût d’alcool doux et réchauffant. Post-goût moyen-long aux petites notes sèches, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux, de rôti, léger de chocolat noir avec des notes d’alcool et de fruits (moût de raisins).

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Bottle (500ml) shared with and courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy dark ruby with an average size diminishing tan head. Nice aroma of lightly burnt caramel, toasted sweet malt, smoke, floral hops and brown sugar. Flavour of burnt caramel, faint tobacco, floral hops, chocolate, some alcohol and a bitter, slightly alcoholic finish -- not bad at all. Medium bodied. This is quite good, a nice version of the style.

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Bottle (500ml). Shared with blankboy, my bottle via trade with Viper666. Hazy and very deep ruby, average off-white head. Aroma - very nice - thick sweet malt, noticeable herbal hops, some alcohol and wood resin. Taste is more hoppy/bitter and alcoholic, less malt up-front, bitter finish, a hint of chocolate. Thick, mildly boozy, longish bitter finish, well balanced, maybe a touch boozier than I’d like. Well done.

column1: Au Maître Brasseur Duchesse DAiguillon Scotch Ale
column5: Almost clear dark ruby body with a small but long-lasting tan head. Thick caramel on toasted bread. Rich body. Some tobacco. A few roasted nuts. Some grassy hops. Rather earthy, not the “cleanest” scotch-ale and that’s alright like that. Faithful to the scotch ale style, it doesn’t sleep around with IPAs.
Unclear, red colored, almost no pink head. Tart fruity, raspberries, woody, funky, sour lemony moderate+ sourness, dry finish. Medium- bodied, soft to flat carbonation, bit oily.
On cask at Moeder Lambic. Pours a hazy ruby with medium pink white head. The aroma is raspberry and funk. Slick body, tart berry, light funk, loving these Moeder exclusives.
Edwin Z. is drinking a Cuvée Moeder Lambic (Framboise) by Brasserie Cantillon at Moeder Lambic Fontainas Thin, sweet, framboise all over, light funky, nice

Draft @ Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussel. Slightly hazy cassis, bubbly pinkish head. Cassis without carbonation, raspberry, blackberries, woody tannin tard and dry, medium-high acidity, faint funk. Medium body, almost without carbonation.
Fat moeder Lambic, Bryssel. Snygg klarröd vätska. Tydlig smak och doft av hallon. Krämig och fruktig med frisk syra.
Draught at Moeder Lambic Fontainas 2019-06-27 Brussels AR: sour citric, Framboos AP: red glowing, pinkish head F: sour Frambozenlambik, tart, citrus

On cask at Moeder Fontainas during TDG week. Pours a pinkish red color with low/medium carbonation and pink top. Noted are raspberry jam, acidic funk, wet earth, blanket, and misc loon bugs. Light to medium in body. Excellent.

Cask at Moeder. A hazed bright pink plum coloured pour with a Rocky pink head. Aroma holds loads of tangy woody raspberry, red berry light acid.. Palate is soft fluffy carbonation, medium acid, spicy finish. Flavour is composed of semi sweet tangy raspberry, woody, strawberry, airy, woody raspberry pips, acid builds in the finish. Nice fruit character.
Fat på Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Varmrosa färg med lite krämig skumpuck. Mjuk och krämig i munnen för att vara en lambic. Bärig med massor av syrliga och söta saftiga hallon. Fantastiskt!.
Fat på Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Varmrosa färg med lite krämig skumpuck. Mjuk och krämig i munnen för att vara en lambic. Bärig med massor av syrliga och söta saftiga hallon. Mycket mycket gott.

On draft @ brewery. Pours black with tan head. Nice aroma of sweet malt, chocolate malts and some faint smokiness. Full flavor that starts some what sweet with malts, molasses and hints of alcohol. There’s also some mild smokiness and roasted to burnt malts that join in near midway. Nice porter with plenty of interest.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Light chocolate aroma. Black body with a thin head. Medium palate. Flavor is chocolate malt with a dose of bitterness as well. Enjoyable.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: C-Bus 7 Bottle shared by crizay: Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma, some chocolate, and roasted malts, dry and earthy. Flavor, smooth roasted malts, coffee, and some chocolate. Some roasted bitterness. Solid.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Oily black pour, thin looking body. Light brown head has well retained compacted bubbles. Aroma is a good balance of chocolate and roastiness, some coffee. Further nosing indicates more chocolate than roasted malts, minute hoppiness and off smells of acrid smoke and pineapple. Flavor is not very good, unbalanced and unexpected. Coffee grounds are dominant now, grainy to a point of annoyance. Too much bitterness in the finish is not akin to a fresh, highly hopped imperial stout of recollection, but rather a poor malt extraction. Thin mouthfeel doesn’t help this beers’ cause. A phenolic, cluttered oddity.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Sampled at the O-Town throwdown thanks to Crizay. Dark pour with light brown head. Black patent burnt malt aroma with malted milk shake and kind of vanilla notes. The flavor doesn’t divulge its imperial nature. Seems awfully drinkable. Burnt malts start things off with malts sweetness close behind. The finish is pure burnt even charred malts.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Thanx to Crizay for sending this down for the O Town throwdown.the nose on this was that hoppy dirt aroma.I am not sure I detected the bologna Fantomas was raving about.I sniffed this several times and told him I didn’t get that.Lots of hops and coffee with slight chocolate.Easy drinking not too heavy.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Smells like ring bologna. If you don’t believe me, buy some. Smell it. No doubt, though, that it’s the hops giving it that smoky paprika aroma. Stark imbalance between the hops and the malts with the former dominating the later. Whatever roasted coffee, chocolate flavor is here is playing second fiddle. Tastes more like a dark DIPA. But the bitterness does play well with its supporting cast.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Thanks to Crizay for shipping this to Dragonstout for the O-Town Throw Down. The body is deep black and holds a finger sized, compact tan head which is lasting. The aroma is massive coffee and cream with chocolate and fudge brownie notes. It isn’t very Imperial in the burnt/roasted malt parts of the aroma and actually smells a bit like an amped up sweet stout. Smells very good though. Fore is again chocolate, coffee, cream with some vanilla, esspresso, fudge and a very silky mouthfeel that makes me suspect it may have a little oatmeal in it. The finish gets much more roasty and bitter than the aroma or fist sip would indicate. Finishes quite nicely.

column1: The Brew Kettle Rich's All-Grain Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle... O-Town Throwdown... This beer rocks!... Pitch black ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. Chocolate and big-time coffee in the aroma. Some oxidation in the flavor, but mainly sweet chocolate and burnt, bitter coffee grounds. Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and feather-soft carbonation. Finishes chocolaty sweet, then charred and bitter. Thanks to crizay for shipping this world class brew down for The Throwdown!
Bottle from Cyprus. No head. Color is pale yellow. Aroma and taste are apples, sugar and alcohol. Semi dry.

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow color with virtually none head. Aroma is sweet apple, green apples, sour appels. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20081121]
Bottle. Pale deep yellow colour. Aplle bit rubber aroma. Sweet apple soda flavour. Sweet appleish finish. Drinkable cider.
Bottle, 5%. Very pale colour, almost water. Sweetish apple flavour. Not like Swedish crap cider, but a little too sweet. Good citric notes, though, making it tolerable.

50 cL bottle, courtesy of pinball. Pours pale yellow to colourless. Sweet and citric aroma. Sweet and citric flavoured with a crisp apple flavour. Light acidic to citric finish. Clean and crips, quite simple.
very very light yellow, no head. aroma is apple, not much else, slight vinagre. a bit too sweet imo. but okay.

Cider apple aroma with some champagne like hints. Champagne like appearance, highly carbonated. Slightly sour apple flavour with some peppery and spicey notes. Has a dry and tart finish, not a bad cider.
Bottle from Morrisons. Aroma is cider apples, hints at swet apple syrup and spice. Taste is similar over cabonated, alright but still alot better out there.

Very pale straw in colour, it IS slightly sparkling....on the verge of being flat actually. Has a light appley nose, and a light appley flavour. Quite dry, with a fresh zippy acidity. Hey! this is ok! I’m pleasantly surprised.
Very pale gold. Sweet fruit aroma. Very sweet taste. Nothing much else. Oddly I quite enjoyed it, being in the mood for something sweet and fizzy. But next time I’ll have a Pimm’s instead.

On tap at the brewpub in Little Rock, AR. Pours a deeper brown colored body with a ruby hue. Finger-width, creamy, light brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is clean, medium sweet toffee with a light brown sugar, some earth, touches of honey, a few darker fruit esters, and a touch of roast. Flavor is similar. Clean, medium sweet toffee and caramel with a very light bread. Some fruity esters in the middle with an earthy balance as well as touches of honey and brown sugar before this finishes dry, earthy and grassy, lightly bitter, and faintly roasted with a balancing, light malt sweetness and fruity ester. Lengthy aftertaste following a smooth, medium-light body and a medium-light carbonation. Overall, a pretty decent Scotch Ale. Not the biggest in body or overly robust, but balanced and flavorful. Good beer.
Copper pour with watery off white head and lace. Roasted malt, toffee, and earthy hops. Flavor mirrors aroma. Light bodied and tad fizzy. A bready like flavor on the finish as well.
on tap at the brewery pours light brown with a medium off white head. Aroma is toffee, brown sugar, esters. Flavor is rich toffee and creamy malt body, oats, maple syrup and a nice grassy finish.
on tap-pours an off white head and hazy copper color. Aroma is medium malt-peat/toffee. Taste is medium malt-peat/toffee, some fruit, herbal hops.
Dark copper brown with a fizzy off white head. Sweet malt and cereal grain aroma and taste with some molasses notes.
Tap at the brewpub. The look is a red color, clear, with an ok beige colored head. The smell is peat, malts, sweet, and ok. The taste is sweet, peat, caramel, malts, and ok.
Solid beer, ive got a growler of it and damn is it tasty. Very thick and malty, lots of caramel and really thick texture to it. Im a huge fan, not alot of hops so that is as nice and unique change.

(draught at the brewpub) no description - simply written up as "Vino’s Scotch Ale" on the whiteboard. I saw "Kiltlifter" on a hand lettered label stuck to the tap (May have been "Kelly’s Kiltlifter, but I wasn’t sure). Nice medium brown, small head but nice lace. Very mild malt aroma. Flavor is sweet malt, a hint of caramel.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: Clear light golden color/ white head. Classic corn, bready yeast, pale malt aromas. Light bodied with a soft mouthfeel. Decent lagered, yeasty bready pale malt flavors with some corn flakes--

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Nose of light banana and citrus. Clear yellow with a medium glass lacing white head. Flavor is light banana, wheaty bread, and a hint of lemon.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: Tap. Pretty much your standard light lager, pale yellow, fluffy white head. Nose is mostly corn and cereal grain, slightly bitter finish, very crisp.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: On tap at LJ RB, a few nights ago. Pale yellow color. Aroma was decently sweet, with alot of grain and corn aromas. Flavor was very similar. Probably average to above average in terms of taste, but what is that really saying. Decent, but will not be having again any time soon.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: Date: 12/03/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, La Jolla clear pale yellow, frothy white head, thick lace, sweet cereal aroma, sweet sugar coated cereal flavor, light balancing bitterness leads to a light bitter finish, Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *+/4

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom. Malty aroma, very bready taste, watery palate, and a crisp, clean, but bland tasting finish.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Great White American Light
column5: Draft at Brewery. Very light and pale lagery. Defintely the attempt to satisfy the average beer drinker. More hops presence than a common BMC beer. Crisp and refreshing, just not exciting.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Espresso Stout
column5: On cask (firkin) at the brewpub. Nose of coffee and chocolate. Black with a medium tan head. Flavor is coffee, caramel, and chocolate.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Espresso Stout
column5: On tap at La Jolla location. Color was dark brwon to black with a slightly dark tan head. Aroma of coffee grinds, roasted malt, cocoa, caramel and vanilla. Really nice aroma. Flavor was really good for a coffee stout. Heavy on the espress/coffee with vanilla, cocoa and roasted malt providing some nice balance. REally surprised with this one.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Espresso Stout
column5: Cask at San Diego Brewers Guild Festival 2008. An overpowering espresso nose. Flavors leave a lot to be desired unfortunately. If they were half as good as the smell this beer would be off the charts.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Espresso Stout
column5: On cask at the brewery. Lots of espresso aromas coming off this very black pour with a very fine tan head. Flavors fell off a bit. Watery roasty coffee with some chcolate, but not a lot. Creamy finish. Not bad

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla White Hot Maibock
column5: On draft at the brewpub. Amberish-light brown. Carmel malt with some spiceness. A bit thin and watery. a nice little seasonal from RB.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla White Hot Maibock
column5: Draft at the Brewery. Malty sweet aromas off this brownish yellow pour with a nice head. Spiciness and more malty sweetness of the flavor. Some sugar cookie in the finish. Pretty tasty

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: Draft. Copper beer with an off-white head. Grapefruit aroma. Caramel flavor with grapefruit and some pine. Medium body. Light bitterness for an IPA. Light grapefruit lingers with some caramel malt.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: ON tap at RB La Jolla. Color was auburn or a dark amber with a small head. Aroma of rye bread, caramel and flowers. Flavor had a lot of rye and earthy flavors. A bit watery overall. Floral finish. It was a bit harsh on the palate occasionally, but nothing too detracting. Not the best IPA I have had from them, but I really like this location. Not resting on any laurels.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: An amazing IPA at Rock Bottom. Initially smells only of the strong bitter hops, but after drinking off the top layer (and probably desensitizing to the hops) it smells and tastes like liquid rye bread, including the cumin twang every now and then. Deep amber color adds to the fun.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: On tap @ at La Jolla location - Pours a cloudy amber color with a thin off white head. Nice lacing. Has a floral and citrus hop aroma. Flavor is citrus hops and rye malt. Has a lingering rye aftertaste. Medium body. A good beer.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: Pint glass in at Warrenville, IL location. Thick amber in color, more opaque than anything. Thick head. Blent of bready (rye) and mildly hoppy in mouth, but weak for a "pale."

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: 4 oz sample at the Warrenville, IL location. This selection is not listed on the Warrenville list, but it has the same name as this, will have to do. Medium amber color, slightly hazy with a thick white head. Nose is slightly citrus and piney with a hint of maltiness underneath. Not hoppy enough. Medium bodied with a dry finish. Pretty good, but like all of the Rock Bottom beers I have tasted, it is too soft.

column1: Rock Bottom La Jolla Catcher in the Rye P A
column5: Draft at the brewery. Lots of citrus hops and some pine coming off this golden orange brew. Decent head that lasted for a while. Flavors were more citrus and pine. Nice malt balance too. Not bad.

column1: Rocky River Monkey Off My Bock
column5: 4/28/07: MRAF ’07 – Cask. Large grainy nose. Light orange-gold body. Flavors include grass, floral and a touch of lemon.

column1: Rocky River Monkey Off My Bock
column5: Cask version at Barley’s 5th Annual Mini RAF (04/28/07): A not-so-subtle jab at former Blue Jackets GM Doug MacLean. Orange color with a medium rocky light beige head that lasts awhile. Spotty lacing. Toasted malt aroma. Medium, smooth body with a sweet fruit and malt flavor. Lightly bitter hops are present as well. The finish is slick and sweet malt followed by a touch of hops. Slightly above average when it’s all said and done.

column1: Rocky River Monkey Off My Bock
column5: Had at Barley’s Mini Real Ale Fest 2007! I had this today at the Ale Fest but can find no other info about it. Sorry. Not sure if it goes by another name or not, but this is what the sign said. It was pretty good. Taste was sweet malts and caramel. Slight hop finish. Dont remember much else about it unfortunately! One of 14 beers tried today and the only one by Rocky River I believe!
Like the Wheat, no aroma, and very little flavor. Sampled at the Albany, OR brewpub.

Slightly hazy roasted orange color. A little roasted nuttiness on the nose. Good bitterness on the middle and sides of the palate. Nuttiness comes through on the palate as well. A little of for the style due to the roasted note.
Sample tasting at the brewery: Pours cloudy and orange. Arom a is mellow malt with light resinous hops. Taste is malty and bitter. Malt overloads everything else. Kind of plain, a basic amber ale.
Very light aroma of caramel and not much else very light body got the style. Finish is very light with not enough hops and a strange iced tea finish.
Not heavily hopped. But rich in flavour withal. Coppery body with white head. Malt and hops in proper proportion. Finish lasts a long time.

Pale amber color with a finger of thick white head that left some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel malts and citrus and earthy hops. Taste is caramel malty sweetness with some citrus and earthy hop bitterness that lingers nicely on the palate. Medium body and soft carbonation. A very nice bitter that was tasty and enjoyable.
I had an IPA right before this so it might have thrown me off a bit, but I was underwhelmed by this one. No depth at all.

Imperial pint in a dimpled mugs at "f/stop Fitzegeralds" bar in Salem. $4.00 Nice copper coloured ale with a off white inch high head that sticks. Good English hop profile for a while then the usual PNW takes over..strong malty caramel. Nice tasty yet balanced beer..gret hop profile balanced by a chewy maltiness. Very nice on the tongue ..complex yet goes smooth. Overall a very drinkable well made PNW ESB..

Malty graininess on the nose with a tinge of sweetness. A hazy amber glass with a one finger white head. A bit of sweetness starts, eithe rfrom crystal malt or English hops. Finish is dry and clean as expected. Hop flavor emerges on the mid-palate and is medium spicy/floral. Light in body and quaffable. A fine bitter; crispness keeps you coming back for more.

Name: River Dog ESB Date: September 25, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, wispy beige head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet caramel malt aroma, light earthyness Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice caramel sweetness, light bready character, good solid earthy bitterness that lasts right through a long bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ** /4

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Pours clear orange amber with a three finger, off white head. Aroma is light tropical fruit and wheat. Taste is light passion fruit and light caramel, moving to wheat. Finish is wheat. An OK wheat beer.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: An orange beer, a head is small and blond. Aroma has sweet fruitness, banana, mustyness. Taste has also sweet fruitness, some sourness fo wheat. Medium bodied. Not freshness at all.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 18-Jun-07 (12 oz bottle: Purchased 15-Jun-07 for at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) One of my favorite fruits is the passion fruit, especially when you buy it fresh off the tree at a market in the Caribbean and have them cut it open for you so you can eat it right there on the spot. So in 1996, when I spent several days in Hawaii, I fell in love with this local beer called "Lilikoi Wheat." Now here it is 11 years later and this Kona beer is finally available on the mainland as a seasonal. And I'm sad to say that my impression is much less favorable this time around. On the nose, this beer smells like your standard American Wheat beer, but the tart fruitiness of passion fruit is almost able to offset the cheap wheat aroma and provide at least some level of enjoyment for fans of this fruit, though the underlying American Wheat aroma is still what registers the most. Each sip begins with a similar balance of gently tart passion fruit and wheat beer flavor, but the fruit fades in the evolution for a "cheap beer" finish and a pretty awful after taste. Dark straw in color and fairly clear in appearance. The small, white head fully dissolves fairly quickly. Body is predictably light as is usual for the style, and carbonation is medium. While the fruit is still in play, the mouthfeel is fairly refreshing, but the finish and after taste lead to staleness on the palate. So after such fond memories, this has been a disappointment, so either I didn't know any better back then (likely), or this just isn't as good as it used to be. I guess the plan should be, drink it cold and drink it fast.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Very nice wheat beer. Smooth with a European beer feel to it. Well balanced with slight tropical notes to finish

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Pretty non descript appearance. Gold body with a thin white head. Very faint passion fruit nose. Flavor is slightly bitter with a macro beerish flavor. Inoffensive. Not my favorite from the mixed pack that I purchased.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at a beerfest. Lots of bloody Mary's and other beer here. Not sure what else to write to get to 75.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Fionn Whitehead on top of a clear yellow body. It smells of the passion fruit is made with with a hint of sweet malts underneath. It's full of flavors yet nothing is overpowering. The Malt the Hops the yeast the fruit all exist within perfect balance and Harmony. This is among my most favorite beers. I do remember when it was unfiltered though.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 355ml bottle into pint glass. Golden beer, slightly hazy, thin white head which disappears. Medium carbonation. Nose of grain, dry fruit and dark caramel. Good body, smooth texture. Caramel sweetness is followed late on with light fruit. Only a hint of passionfruit but it is there (right at the end). Super easy-drinking.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 330ml bottle. Light amber with slight head. Slight phenolic, slight bitterness with dryish finish. Average.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: pours clear gold with a smallish white head. aroma of floral and light skunk. Fruity semi-sweet taste. Fairly quick finish. ok.

Hazy/cloudy, unfiltered, golden yellow body with a lush head. This ESB has more flavor and alcohol than is typical, I think, but it is still a good session beer and easy to drink. Full finish - caramle-maltiness, sweet, roasty finish balanced by a refreshing dose of hops. The flavor is hoppy as a good American beer will be, and I wouldn’t consider this typically English, as they claimed at the brewery, but it is tasty and nice overall.

Cloudy golden out of the tap, with a soft, pillowy head - grainy, bready malts in the aroma, with more of an american hop aroma than a british, which is fine with me - a slighthard water, mineral quality in the flavor makes it seem authentic regardless of the more american-ish hop profile - medium, crisp, fresh hop flavors are balanced well with a slighty dry, biscuity malt flavor - I could drink this one all day long.
draft. orangeish amber with a thin head. Really decent NW IPA. Citrus and pine. blah, blah. A nice beer.

Taster - Calapooia Brewing Co. - Albany, OR Aroma – Strong hops aroma. Appearance – Amber in color, Thin head and clear. Flavor – Good strong hops flavor with a nice malt backing. Has a semi fruitiness to the flavor. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, good texture with a dry finish. Overall – One of the better beers for the day .This was a very good PAC NW IPA.

On tap at Calapooia in Albany, Oregon--Poured a orange-sienna body with a wispy, beige, filmy head. Nose of fruity, citrusy grapefruit hops and sticky malts. Grainy and spicy. Big earthy, piny, resinous finish. Yum!

Tap... Poured an unfiltered burnt orange with a thin white head. I typically like the look of unfiltered beers, but the head diminished so quickly to nothing I had to rate its appearance lower. Sharp, hop and grain aroma. Great texture in the mouth and a punch of hops with a very earthy/piney presence. Tasted great.
on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow/gold color. Aroma is mild citrus hops, yeast?, secondary medium malt. Taste is citrus hops/grapefruit/flat hops-some bitter, secondary medium malt.

On tap at the brewpub. I think it might just be me, but Chinook hops smell like cat pee, and this was loaded with them. Pours light orange with a soft white head. Heavy citrus grapefruit hop flavor finishing more towards the pine side. I liked the flavor of the IPA, but the chinook aroma just bugs me.

This draft brew from the Oregon Brewers festival poured a small sized head of medium sized brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a transparent softly carbonated orange brown colored body. The aroma was malty musty and dirty sock. The Mouth feel was crisp and clean with a lingering piney hoppy aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of piney hops. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Amber with not much head - bad pour at the Oregon Brewers Festival. Bread and pine and a little citrus. Medium body with a creamy texture and an astrigent finish. Nice beer with good balance, very drinkable.

Sampled at the 2007 Blooms & Brews Fest at the Oregon Gardens. Pours a hazy amber with a nice white head. Nose is citrusy. Taste is hoppy grapefruit and a little pine. Finish/aftertaste have a lingering hop bitterness that is a bit metallic. Carbonation is moderate, body is medium.

Stopped at this nice little brewpub in long island. Unable to get good tasting notes because had to catch the ferry. Staff was very nice and the beers was enjoyable. Very nice food too. Would like to stop back sometime and get proper rating but numerical score will have to do now for the flight we got.

Growler. Poured a slightly hazed deep orange-copper color with a medium off-white head. The aroma starts off phenolic and then shows some banana underneath. Even some minty notes. Toasted bread malt makes the base of the aroma. Sweet malt thats gets some spice in the middle through the long sweet finish. Light to medium body. Odd finish that makes my tongue twist.

I think that "Notalush’s" rating hits the nail pretty squarely on the head when he says that it is out of balance. The spice was in generous proportions which, to me, made it a very interesting brew. In this year’s batch the alcohol is covered up much better with orange citrus and coriander flavors. Another improvement is that it no longer has the sticky sweetness described. Don’t misunderstand, it is still sweet, just no where nears what I would describe as over-sweet. This is not like any other Brickhouse beer, so if you haven’t liked them in the past don’t count this one out.

Not your typical belgian strong ale - clear golden with a copper tint - sweet aroma, with a lot of spice, bracing you for what’s to come - the alcohol is a bit evident at first, but a heaping helping of spices helps cover it up quickly - coriander, and some nutmeg? are strongest - light banana and clove coupled with a touch of phenolics - strong belgian sugar sweetness makes the beer a bit too sweet, and makes it a little sticky - a little out of balance, but still quite nice.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: En fût sur place, rue Sherbrooke. Un liquide dorée avec une mousse blanche. Un nez de fruits tropicaux, de malt blonds, de pain et de houblons résineux. Une bouche intense légèrement marquée par l’alcool, les fruits exotiques, la résine de pin. Finale longue et mordante qui en fait une bière qui est difficile à boire.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at l’Isle de Garde. Clear bright orangey-golden with a medium white head, good retention, leaving good lacing. Aroma is of melons, resinous hops, caramel, floral notes and mangoes. Taste is of caramel (not overwhelming, just as a good malt backbone), resin, floral presence, moderate fruitiness and some bitterness. Medium body. Moderate-medium carbonation. A bit oily mouthfeel. The finish is where it’s less interesting as the resinous bitterness lingers quite a bit. Good oily and resinous IIPA but it could use some refinement and work on the balance.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: 2016 Anniversaire. Glass @premise. Aroma: piney, grapefruits, lots of bread mixed with cat pee. App: clear golden, small white head, good lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, medium sweetness, moderate lingering bitter finish. Overall: on the sweet side (again), too malted too. Ok.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: En fût au Brouhaha. Liquide profondément doré, translucide, filtré et clair, surmonté d’une mousse qui tient bien la route. Nez caractérisé par des fleurs, de la sueur, des houblons trop résineux et un malt fermenté. C’est très puissant. Intéressant mais surtout puissant. En bouche le liquide est huileux, visqueux. Une quantité importante d’alcool me picote et me chauffe la langue alors que la résine de ces houblons floraux me cole au palais. Amertume coupée par tout ce sucre (et cet alcool), cette bière est pour moi trop intense dans toutes sortes de directions et manque de fini. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: on tap at isle de garde, mtl. hazy golden with a very nice off-white head offering good retention and lacing. overripened mangoes, dense caramel - annoying; hearty berries, sweetness - wort; clean yeast action. moderate carbonation, medium body - oily; hot, sweet and unbalanced piney-citrusy finish. seemed close to cactus’s tenth anniversary. melon and caramel resinous stuff. o-k.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Où, Quand, Comment : Dégustée en fût sur place sous le nom « Imperial IPA 1er anniversaire »(printemps 2007). Visuel : Couleur : ambrée. Apparence : semi-voilée. Arôme : Houblon résineux, moyennement citrique, légèrement herbeux et fruité (agrumes), caramel sucré, notes de menthe. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Amer de houblon résineux, citrique, légèrement herbeux et aux notes fruitées présent toute la gorgée. Un support malté appréciable de caramel sucré est également présent avec quelques notes boisées et terreuses. En bouche : Corps : moyen-rond. Effervescence : moyenne. Texture : moyennement huileuse. Finale : longue et amère de houblon résineux, citrique aux notes terreuses et herbeuses ainsi qu’avec des traces d’alcool.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: (On tap at downtown brewpub, 2014 version, May 25 2014) Poured a orange-copper colour with a small white head, slight lace. Hoppy aroma, grapefruit, lemon, some sweet tropical fruit, a bit herbal/wet pine, some caramel malt and alcohol. On the palate the toffee/caramel malt sweetness was more pronounced, grapefruit rind, orange, lemon, some "green" hop quality, fairly bitter towards the finish, some alcohol heat as well, still fairly dry aftertaste. Mouthfeel medium-full, oily, fairly soft carb. Good stuff, but on the sweeter, maltier, boozier side of the DIPA spectrum and so not a perfect beer. A little brash.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Another huge beer. Grapefruit and lemon coconut aroma. Huge beer. Had this on draft at the Benelux brewery in Montreal. Flight pour

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: ** 2014 - 8e Anniversaire ** Cuivrée, pas trop voilée, un joli collet de mousse beige laisse une dentelle gigantesque sur les parois du verre. Un bouquet presque exclusivement constitué de houblons fruités et herbacés nous laisse croire qu’on aura droit à une bombe houblonnée. En bouche par contre, c’est assez bien dosé, une petite présence maltée venant adoucir l’amertume puissante de la bière. Le citron, le pamplemousse et les autres agrumes rendent cette bière très désaltérante, quoique j’aurais aimé que ce soit plus aromatique qu’amer.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Je me faisais a croire que je sentais l’arome de la biere...je trouve qu’elle ressemble a la devil dancer de founders mais en moins boozy. C’est bon mais un peu inegal. J’aurais aimé plus de saveurs de houblon. De toute facon on s’entend que se faire comparer a founders, y’a pire que ca dans la vie
Clear amber color. Decent off-white head. Sweet caramel aroma with some sour. Tastes quite plain with some cloying sweetness, but it could be worse.

I paid $2.99 for a six pack of GLASS bottles in West Allis, Wisconsin. Deep malt, caramel. and brisket aroma (yes, BRISKET!). Nice deep, golden color with a creamy, beige head that last longer than others have said it does. Leaves a gorgeous lacing on the glass. Bourbon whiskey/caramel flavor with too quick a finish. EXTRA (yes, I intended ALL large case letters) thick, caramel consistency feel on the tongue, palate, and throat. You can taste the texture of this brew in your olfactory, I shit you not!!! An OUTSTANDING beer at ANY price!!! But...did I mention I got it for $2.99 for six 12 ounce bottles? Rock-’ N-Roll, my friends! Rock-’N-Roll!!!

Very surprised by the lack of skunk, considering the clear bottle. Pours a clear amber with quickfading white head. Interesting flavor, i suppose that comes form the sour mashing? A little grainy in the finish. Cheap and interesting, worth a try, but not gonna be a regular in my fridge.

Pours a three finger white head that fades quickly to a thin layer, leaving some lace. Clear amber color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Malty nose. Flavor is sweet bourbon and caramel, unusual lager, hops are in the background. Label has this brewed by the Naked Lion Brewing Co and their web site is nakedlion.com. $1.50 for a 12oz clear bottle from Manchester Wine and Liquors Manchester, CT
Pours like copper. The sour mash is definitely noticeable. Good strength at a good price. If you can find it give it a try.

Pours a clear copper colour with a medium sized white off white head. Aroma is a little nutty, with strong malt aroma as well. Flavor is semi-sweet with a full mouthfeel. Decent, but nothing incredible.
Clear 12oz bottle. Poured a medium golden color with a small sized head. Aromas of wet grass, earthy, and vegatables. Tastes of caramel, lightly bready, and a trace of brown sugar.

Apple cider with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, toffee and toasted malt. Flavors include fruit, toffee, toasted malt and nuts. A shade astringent and the flavors are a bit weak but a lot better than expected considering the packaging it came in.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear copper-gold with a white head that quickly recedes to a thin film that leaves a little lacing. The aroma is pretty subdued - metallic malts, maybe a little vegetables. Some sweet sugary malts come out as it warms. The flavor is sweet malts with some sugary candy with a bit of bitterness to finish. Sour mash comes out some as it warms. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with sharp carbonation. Overall, a small step above macros - nothing too exciting.
Single from Woodman’s Oak Creek. Good body thick malty taste and feel. light brown sugar, dark corn syrup which was surprising given the look of the beer.

Date: 07/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy gold, fine white head, drippy lace, sweet fruity Belgian candy aroma, lots of sweet estery malt flavor, nice fruity character, warming, light spicyness is the only balance for the sweetness yet it is not overly sweet, hint of light bitterness in the finish, the spicey character grows as it warms and provides wonderful character Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

Draught @ Brewpub: This one poured a cloudy, straw yellow color with a very small white head. The aroma is milder. It contained notes of fruits, yeast and breadiness. I was hoping the aroma would pick up as it warmed, but it stayed kind of light. The taste was good. It was somewhat bready and slightly sweet. There were some fruits evident, noteable slight pineapple and banana. Also a slightly peppery finish. Nice.

Sampled on draft this beer poured a hazy vibrant golden color with a small white head. The aroma was sweet, tangy, yeasty and lightly fruity. The flavor was thick sweet sugar with a nice plum fruity element and a long, tangy, sugary finish.

Don’t look at my numbers, this is a great beer for the style, I just don’t care for high alky brews. Ubiquitous pale yellow american lager color with a slight haze. The aroma of this is quite scary, strong and sweet. You know by smell you are going to get a big alky taste bud impact. The initial kick is hard, sweet and laid back all at the same time if that is possible. The developement of flavors is complex. Alky impact, then that numbs up the taste buds for the sweetness. Hides the initial alky bite quite well. A few of these and you will not pass a DUI checkpoint. I feel my head getting dizzy already. This is a very refined brew that deserves accolades. Continuing thru the session, the alcohol bite builds. Barely any carbonation. Fruity hints thoughout. After a while, the alky effect begins to take over. Very strong malty alky finish. Borders on uncivilized! Not quite as refined as Grimbergen Blonde or Chimay Blanche (White) but certainly on par with great beers like Tripel Karmeliet, Allagash Tripel Reserve and Victory Golden Monkey.
Aroma: yeast, alcohol, and grains Appearance: murky yellow, small white head, lacing Flavor: candy sugar, alcohol, grains, and yeast Palate: smooth, bubbly, yeasty-grainy aftertaste, crispness

Draft. Murky yellow lemon color. Sweet candy sugar and lemon nose, heavy sugary citrus smell and flavor. Yeast character is quite light, but overall it’s very good. Full of sweetness but then with a little bite of lemon juice and fluffy yogurt yeast flavor. Finish is lightly spicy and peppery, syrupy and sweet fruit and lemons and light yeast. For a second it even resembled a witbier. Good stuff.

From draught at Marzoni’s, then again from growler I brought home. Sweet honey and heather, some bubblegum and cotton candy. Light graininess and a bit of Belgian yeast funk. Some bit of jasmine or other greenery in there that I can’t quite decipher. Mild coriander. Cloudy golden pale, like a creamy butterscotch color, with mild foamy lacing head. Medium bodied with medium-soft carbonation. Alcohol warming, for sure. Starts sweet with honey and grain, cotton candy or candi sugar, melon. Yeasty chalky bitterness with some citrus rind and Beeman’s gum. Light herbal/orange oil bitterness at the finish with mild chalky after. Finish is just a tad too sweet buy in no way cloying. Very nice sipping tripel.
Aroma: initial sulphur, hop & a touch of malt Appearance: clear yellow, tiny flat head Flavour: crystal malt, some flavour hop Palate: medium finishes sweet malt
Bottle enjoyed during a holiday in Australia. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. Tasting notes not kept, just rating.

Clara,límpida,brilhante,espuma cremosa mediana;aroma maltado,acrescido de um suave floral;sabor maltado,"crocante",com notas amanteigadas e um leve amargor finalizando,refrescante,boa carbonatação,baixo corpo. Cerveja regular,não entusiasma e nem decepciona.
Pours clear light amber with medium white head. Nose is cereals. Aromas are caramel malts, grass and a hint of honey. Light body, average carbonation. Slightly bitter finish. Refrshing.
Bottle. Non descript but drinkable at a barbie. I don't understand why they make it in Belgium ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice light honey aroma. Cloudy pale golden colour with good head. Light honey flavour with little to no aftertaste. Light refreshing body with low carbonation.

Hazy golden with a edge of head and littles spots of lace. The taste is mostly caramel malt with carbonation bittering moving in near the finish, but giving way to caramel again in the finish. As a mass produced brew, not so bad, but don’t bring out the good stuff.
330ml Bottle. I’m just updating my records. A good average lager and refreshing.
A nice slightly-fruity aroma. Orangeish color. This is pretty good. Light, some orange, but a good fruitiness to it. Could drink more of this.
Pale malty lager with grainy character and little detectable hops other than some citrus/lemon notes, very thin and no memorable finish.

Sampler @ 4 Queens, Vegas. pours dark brown, beige head. Aroma is malty, gingery, cookie like. Taste, came out tasting like gingerbread, lots of malts, caramel and dark fruits with a good cookie dough like finish. Taste made up for the uninteresting aroma.
Tap @ Four Queens. Served a dark amber color in my glass. Lightly malty aroma. Fairly sweet with some lightly roasted qualities. Seemed like a regular bock, couldn’t tell that it was a weizen.

750ml bottle pours out amber brown color topped with a fizzy head. Nose is nice funky notes some cherries a little basement notes and a cork. Taste is more of the nice funky dusty notes and a light fruit note.
Barnyard, crabapple aromas. Appearance cloudy just like apple cider in color. Almost no head light carboinnation. tastes of barnyard and granny smith sour apples and yeast. Refreshing bier de garde.

Tasted the 2006 version on 4/18/15. This great beer still tastes remarkably fresh despite it’s age. It is holding up extremely well and aging very slowly. I found it sitting on the shelf in the store. Compared to the 2013 it is still very acidic with just a hint of increased malt in the background. Carbonation is light to moderate, unchanged compared to the 2013, just perfect for this beer. Aroma: Lovely balsamic vinegar blended with apple cider, vanilla, with a hint of leather, cherries and peaches in the background. No hint of hop bitterness. It has subtle but noticeable barnyard funk, hay and aged cheese along with the bread on dough. The taste parallels the aroma; it is incredibly complex and well balanced despite the high acidity. The mouth feel is delightfully velvety and viscous, but not syrupy. This beer tastes like a super concentrated, super complex great OUDE GEUZE. It is fascinating and absolutely delicious. It is built to age well for a long, long time. Be forewarned; This unusual beer will not appeal to everyone. I consider this an ’extreme on the edge beer’. If you don’t like complex sour beers with funk, this is not for you. I rate this and the 2011, 2012, 2013 (and all the Grand Cru versions) 100+.
750ml bottle. Sampled with Jerome. Wow an amazing red sour, peppery tannic qualities but sournes sand funk, cherry skins, tart fruit, acidicty.

Bottle thanks to Tom. Pours a murky brown with paperthin beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is funk and sour fruit. Thin mouth with cherry skin, oak, light funk, lingering tartness, good.
Bottle pours a murky toilet brown with no chunks. Aroma is caramel, leather, basement, and tart cherries. Flavor is acidic tart. Tasty.
Bottle. Pours murky chestnut, small off white head, good lacing. Aroma is funky basement, oxidized sugars, mushroom. Flavor is light sweet, light tart, light funk. Medium body, good carb.

Bottle, shared with friends on game night. Murky orange amber, minimal head formation. Musty, yeasty aroma, light acetic sourness. Mouthfeel is tampered by low carbonation, but the flavours are nice enough: unripened berries, caramel, yoghurty lactic sourness, musty cork.

Tasted on 10/7/14 with the Savages from a capped 750mL bottle sent to me as an awesome extra in a trade. Pours muddy brown orange with an average tan head that leaves thick lace. The nose is vinous, super sour, nice caramel malt, and super funky. The flavor is a bit maltier and oaky, with the sourness coming through a bit less vinous, but very balanced. The body is full with just under average carbonation and a long, nicely sour and caramel malt finish.

750ml bottle pours semi-clear ruby blood red with small finger of head. Nose is tart musty dark cherry, damp tree bark, molasses, brown sugar. Taste is tart sweet dark fruits, cherry, berries, red grape, musty wet wood. Finish is semi sweet tart mildly acidic fruit, faint metallic coppery note which eventually fades as it warms, woody funk, vinous fruit.

This one has been in the cellar for a couple years. Probably courtesy of wombat23 since that’s where most of my BFM Stock came from, and there’s no German labeling. Virtually black with a creamy beige head that lingers. Vanilla and chocolate aroma. Fairly straightforward. Taste is mildly sweet up front and nuanced—full of vanilla, black tea, herbs and chocolate. The finish is more peppery than bitter, although a mild bitterness is present. Big thick body that covers the alcohol completely. Delicious.

En fût à L'Autre Oeil (Gatineau, QC). Robe noire, opaque et coiffée d'un bon col beige et mousseux. Arôme malté et agrémenté de nuances de cacao et de céréales rôties. En bouche, la base maltée est appuyée par des notes de cacao, de poivre et de pruneaux. Au nez comme en bouche, l'alcool reste discret. Finale modérément réconfortante. Pas mal.
Brownish with foamy head. Mixed flavour with fresh hop bitterness and dark malts. Rather gassy and maybe overly hopped for the style.
(∞-herbal, µ-poivré noir, bouche moussue, malt grillé, µ-genièvre, pas extrême, pas vraiment is, pas élégante, strange)

De Labirratorium. Version de 2018. En copa Teku. Viendo The Society 1x05. Curiosa impy, con un toque acido que lejos de estropearla le da personalidad. Suave en boca, con abv bien oculto y amargor tipo black ipa.

Robe noire, très fine mousse. L'attaque est légèrement acidulée, puis vient une certaine douceur, il y a beaucoup de saveurs qui se mélangent mais l'ensemble reste peu torréfié pour le style. Pas mauvais mais ce n'est pas le type de RIS que j'affectionne le plus, ça manque de densité et de puissance.
Tap (Riga Pours 2019). Black color. Medium size, beige head, stays. Sweet, malty, honey, woody in aroma and in taste. Dry black tea in aftertaste. Solid brew.
Tap at the Riga Pours 2019. Pours black. Aroma and flavor are sweet, bitter, roast, malt, coffee. Overall: very good.
Bue avec Laura et Frank au Bierrevier à Basel. Bière noire au nez café choco. Bouche vineuse. Pruneaux et maderisation. Pas mal du tout
Keg @Riga Pours festival 2019. Sample. Dark brown colored brew. Thick white head. Nutty roasty notes, nice bretta funkyness. Peppery, nutty flavors, balancing funk. Long sweet finish. Solid

beerdays 2008, solothurn middle yellow coloue no much head not bad carbonated in mouth smells of malty-sweetness and some hops, but not very much tasts of malt hops and hidden citrus aftertaste is almoust missing, perhaps a hidden bittersweetness

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - clear and bright golden colour, little stable foam; almost nothing in the nose except some cabbage; creamy mouthfeel, medium-bodied, sweet and no bitterness; elusive finish with a hint of aromatic hops - no character

Bottle. A deep and dark brown with a tight beigr foamy head. A cola-like caramal aroma. A full mouthfeel, roasted malt on the palate, and a herbal hoppiness coming through with the swallow. A dry finish. Well balanced.

A really good porter style. Lots of coffee and roast aroma which flows onto the palate, very smooth and creamy too. A combo of choc. chit malt and roast malt with fuggles the main hop variety. On tap at the Greenock Tavern

750 ml bottle, RBNAG07. Yellowish amber colour. Cloudy. Almost no head. Earthy aroma with notes of dried apricots. Thick body. Papery malt flavours. Somewhat refrshing citrus flavours. Very reminiscent of a saison. Farmhouse ale character. Slightly funky. Interesting.

Bottle. 75cl corked. (RBNAG 07) Poured a hazy, orange-golden with a minimal, off-white head. Sourish, fruity aroma. The flavor is sour as well, too sour I think, and it also has fruityness and some sweetness. Thin mouthfeel, slightly astringent. I’m used to a little sourish touch in the beers from Fuglebjerggaard, but this was too sour, and far from the best they’ve made. (071103)

750ml bottle @ RBNAG’07. Hazy orange body with a nice dense off-white head. Aroma is a bit fusty or cellar characterized, not unpleasant. Flavor is quite mild, a bit sour, certain bitterness and very refreshing. As many of the beers from Fuglebjerggaard, this reminds me of some kind of farmer ale (saison?). I’m getting used to these flavors, and am enjoying them, but this body is a bit too watery and thin. A really quaffable refresher, but not the best from this interesting brewery.
Bottle at RBNAG 07. Unclear golden / orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is yeast, fruit, sour. Flavour is yeast, sweet, sour, sugar, apple. Nice beer.

Cloudy orange- golden color. Low near-white head. Unrefined but pleasant aroma of sour/acific fruits and berries, cellar, herbs, sweetish malts and chalky hops. Nice sour/acidic, light fruity and herbal taste. Notes of earth and stable. Tasty, challenging and exciting. (Bottle @ RBNAG’07)
Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. Hazy golden colour. Unusual rustic aroma, farmhouse, basement. I like it! Sourish and sweetish flavour, notes of farmhouse.
75 cl bottle. Cloudy yellow/orange color, no head. Acidic/citric, honey, malt. Raw, bur not bad. (RBNAG’07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)

Thin white head. Hazy opaque yellow body. Thin acidic barnyard aroma with grainy notes. Thin sharpish taste is bth acidic and sweetish with vinegar notes. Very thin mouthfeel. A bit grassy. No aftertaste. Unpleasant. (0.75l bottle at RBNAG’07.)
Bottle. Hazy orange. Yeasty and fruitish aroma. Sweet malty and fruitish flavour with some spices and yeast. Boring.
Bottle. Muddy golden coloured with no head. Fruity aroma of yeast and spices. Swwte spicy flavour of yeast and berries with notes of fruits.
Bottle. Dark golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, yeast. Flavour is fruit, malt, candis sugar, yeast, citrus, spices. Interesting and nice beer.

Bottle, 75cl corked. Clear, golden pour, with a small, beige head. Fruity, yeasty, spiced and slightly malty aroma. The flavor is not that interesting, but still nice, with yeast, some citrus, a little spiced note, malt and grain. A bit dusty, fruity finish with spices and some yeast. Quite fizzy mouthfeel. Quite lovely, one of the best from Fuglebjerggaard so far, but I seem to like them better than most people. (070705)
750 ml bottle. Golden body with a big white head. Aroma is slightly sweet malt, yeast, spices and bitterhops. Flavor is fruity, yeast, sweet and hoppy. Complex, refreshing and delicious.

Bottled. Deep golden colour. The aroma is a bit sweet with yeast, spices and malt. The flavour is malty and yeasty, bit sweet with spices and hops. One of the brews that are drinkable from this very small micro brewery.

Københavnske Øldage 07. Bottle. Golden beer with an aroma that has notes of yeast and coriander. The flavour is fruity and wheaty with notes of yeast and coriander and sweetness. The finish is slightly bitter. 2172

CBF07 sample from 75 cL bottle. Pours clear orange. No head. Aroma is citric/sour and malty with a touch of yeast. Mouthfeel is carbonated. Flavour is malty and slight sour, some hops bitterness. Finish is short malty.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours an almost clear, pale amber golden with an off-white head. Sweetish, citric nose with a whiff of yeast. Medium body with sweetish fruit notes, some maltiness and yeast. A whiff of diacetyl. But actually a very classical and straight - albeit a bit thin - Belgian Blonde. 290407
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a small white head. Sweet malty, fruity, citrus, yeast aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.

Bottled. Dark golden coloured. Unclear. Small off white head. Fruits, yeast, earht and light sourness in the aroma. Flavour as well has light yeasty notes, some sweetness and spice. Fruits and sourness are notable. Is medium bodied. Is sweetish and light bitter in the end.

Bottled. An unclear orange-brown beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of burnt plastic malt and some fruit, especially oranges - reminds me of a poorly made Eastern European beer. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of fruit, but also with an annoying light acidity.

Bottle (0,75 l) Golden, cloudy, stable, almost creamy off-white head; fruity-wheaty nose (oranges) with a tinge of yeast and turpentine; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, a bit fizzy; a light tartness shows up in the sweetish-fruity finish. Not a necessary summer-beer............

(75cl bottle) Cloudy, pale golden colour with a medium-sized, slightly off-white frothy head. Dusty, slightly sweet and grainy malty nose with a shy touch of citrus. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied, slightly fizzy mouthfeel. Yeasty, soft grainy, moderately fruity (citrus) taste, quite dry, yeasty- and slightly hop bitter finish. Not very balanced but surely refreshing in the summer (12.03.08).

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body:   Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4     Pale Yellow(1)->Copper(5) : 2     Still(1)->Volcanic Sparkling(5) : 2 Head:   None(1)->Large(5) : 1     Lasting: 1     Lacing : 1 Aroma: Intensity : 3   Yeast : 3   Bread : XX   Dough : 3   Esters : XX   Phenols : 3   Dusty : XX   Spicy : XX   Apple : XX   Banana : 2   Tropical Fruits : 2   Brett : XX   Barnyard : XX   Leather : XX   Wood : XX   Vinous : XX   Cheese : 2   DMS : XX   Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX Malt : 3   Pilsner : 3   Pale : XX   Vienna : XX   Biscuity : XX   Toasty : XX   Hay : XX   Caramel : XX   Honey : 3   Cereals : XX   Grainy : XX   Wheat : 2 Hops : 1   Noble(1)->American(5) : 1   Leafy : XX   Perfume : XX   Orange : 2   Floral : 1   Lemon/Lime : XX   Herbal : XX   Grassy : XX   Piney : XX Notes : Pepper : 2   Cloves : XX   Coriander : XX   Ginger : XX   Orange : XX   Earth : XX   Vanilla : XX   Oxidation : XX   Bubblegum : 3 Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4   Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3   Sourness : XX   Acetic : XX   Lactic : XX   Bitterness : 1   Farmy : XX   Complex : XX   Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2   Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 1   Clean : XX   Sharp : XX   Watery : XX   Oily : XX   Chalk : XX   Astringent : XX   Alcohol : XX   Mineral : XX Comments: A ridiculously bland, lifeless saison with little texture nor hops, but lots of spicy yeast. Also headless which is something I quite dislike and overly phenolic - reaching medicinal grandeur.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is acid, fruit, yeast. flavour is fruit, yeast, hay, malt., spices. Nice beer.

Bottle, 75cl corked. Golden, almost clear, with a white diminishing head. The nose has some acidity, spicyness, grass and hay. The flavor is much the same, but is more on the malty side. Medium body. Really pleasant in the hot summer evening and hot, smoked salmon to eat. (070608)
Cloudy golden colour with a small white head. Sweet fruity and yeasty citric aroma. Malty sweet flavor with notes of frui and vague hints of some spices.

750ml bottle. Golden, slightly hazy body with a small white head. Aroma has a pleasant sourness, reminds me of farmer ale. Flavor is fruity, spicy and malt. A really refreshing treat, like this a lot.
Bottle. Hazy golden. Grainy caramellic, fruity and yeasty aroma. the flavour is sweet and grainy and yeasty with some burned malt and plastic.
Københavnske Øldage 07. Bottle. Golden and the aroma has notes of fruits, yeast and straw. The flavour is sweetish with notes of fruit, a touch of honey, straw, mould and very little citrus. 2173

CBF07 sample from 75 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow. Aroma is vaguely sour into slight chemical. Almost no carbonation. Flavour is vague malty with a tart citric note. Flavour is not really bad, just off. Finish is soft malty to dry.

Bottle. Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is chocolate, hop, coffee, roasted, malt. Flavour is roasted, malt, hop, coffee, chocolate. Not the best one from these brewer, but still a nice beer.

750 ml bottle. Golden reddish body with a thin beige head. Aroma is cocoa, hops, roasted malt and rubber. Flavor is a bit sour bitter and something between malt and something artificial. A strange beer and a bit disappointing compared with other experimental quality beers I have tasted from this exiting brewery.

Bottle, 75cl corked. Almost clear, reddish brown pour with a nice, beige head on top. Chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt and coffee in the aroma, as well as something reminding me of the white inner peal from citrus fruits. Some sourness in the aroma, but mostly dark flavors like roasted malt, chocolate and last but not least, coffee. Not much hoppy bitterness. Slightly soapy and effervescent mouthfeel, and a coffee-ish finish. I like it, but not sure how much I really like it. It has the typical sour touch that the beers from Fuglebjerggaard usually has, maybe it would have been better without. (071228)
75 cl bottle, at Yngwie´s xmas-tasting. Dark brown/reddish color. Disappering beige head. Strange taste of rubber. rostaed malt, fruits/berries, some sourness and bitterness. Well...
Black colour with a small light brown head. Light roasted malty aroma with a vague liqourice note. Sweet and light roasted flavor with a light acidic note in a dry finish.
Bottle.Cloudy deep brown colour. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and liquorice. The flavour is a bit flat with roasted malt, caramel, liquorice, bit of coffee and bit burned in the finish.

On Tap at Köbenhavnske Öldager 2007: Black colour, and brown head. Aroma of hops,citrus, and malts who is unbalanced! . I Think, I have to re rate this after a while, for give it a new chance. Flavor is coffe,dark chcoclate, and sour!(?)+ almost the same as the aroma.thin body body, short finish

Københavnske Øldage 07. Bottle. Black/brow with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, a bit of caramel and is slightly burnt. The flavour has sweetness, notes of roasted malt, caramel and then comes sweet coffee and a hint of cocoa along. The body is light, and it’s a porter, that cannot scare anyone off. 2174

CBF07 sample from 75 cL bottle. Pours muddy brown with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee and a sour note. Flavour is slight malty and sour, a slight sweetness. Finish is vague. I assume black magic about this one was gone long ago, not good.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Hazy brown / black color with a average fizzy fair lacing mostly diminishing off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, sourness, light coffee grounds ! Flavor is moderate sweet , moderate to heavy acidic and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. Not good :-((

Bottled. An unclear orange-brown beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is very smoked with light notes of bacon and an acidic edge from the smoked malt, as well as a note of caramel. The flavor is sweet smokey giving it notes of tar and rope, leading to a dry smokey finish.

Cloudy amber color. Very nice smoked aroma. The smoked flavor is excellent, it would be better with a stronger body, with more malt. The final is quite long, but also here the malt is missing. Pleasant. Thanks Jacob for bringing this back, at the price that only a few know you had to pay.
Bottle. Hazy orange coloured with a beige head. The aroma is dominated by smoke with notes of burnt wood. Very smoky flavour of caramel, hops and burnt wood.
Bottle. Hazy orange colour with a beige head. Smoked aroma and a smoaked eal taste. Medium body with a smoked finish. To smoked for my taste.

Sample from 50 cL bottle. Pours deep orange to brown. Aroma is a lovely smoke note. Flavour is dry and smoked. Light feel but the flavour fills it all. Good soft smoke finish. "Too simple", lacks some complexity, but a refreshing smoked beer.
Bottle. Cloudy orange-brown colour. Very smoky aroma, bit spiced. Flavour is smoked, bit sour, yeasty, malty and sweet. Smoky sweetish finish.
Muddy amber colour with a beige head. Toasted malty aroma with meat notes and hints of wood. Malty, smoky flavor with fruity notes. Light dry and smoky finish.
Bottle. Small beige head. Spar lacing. Hazy amber color. Moderated smoke, wood, caramel. Medium bodied. Flavor was light sweet. Finish was sweet with a lingering smoky feel.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of Hildigöltur. Very hazy, orange amber with a beige head. Distinct, baconish smoke aroma. Medium-bodied with sweetish caramel notes and then again distinct bacon in the flavour. Some acidity - almost no bitterness. Quite yummy. 230407

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: Malt hop boring not very exciting. Not much thin head. At the brewery no nose ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: On tap at the Moline location, pours a clear amber red with a thin head, the aroma is of sweet malt and caramel at first with hops coming through as well, the flavor has a decent amount of hops at first with a finish of malt and sweetness, pretty middle of the road.

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: Slight esters and metals on the nose with the same on the flavor with a surprisingly nice hoppy kick.

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: Ruby umber color with a smallish off-white head. Caramel and toast lead the way in scent with some dry floral hops in the background. To me this had all the makings of a simple red ale. Not that simple is bad, but sometimes simplicity is needed when making a somewhat simple brew. Light malt and again some floral hops. American/irish red ale mix. This is one of those simple brews that I could spend a session with and not get tired of. Basic and simple is sometimes nice.

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
column5: from a growler at a friends house on the 4th of July. reddish - mahogany in color with a decent head and lacing. caramel malts dominate the aroma and flavor, but with a fair amount of citrus and some flowery hops. seemed more like a toned down marzen than an amber.

column1: Bent River ReplicAle American Red Ale
