column5: Draft at the brewpub. I also had Flossmoor Station’s version of this earlier in the day. Poured a slightly hazy orange-red color. Head was thin, off white, and left some decent lace behind. Aroma was very similar to the Flossmoor version; malty caramel and flowery/citrusy hops. Dry on the tongue with a dominant spicy malt flavor, but less intense grapefruity hop taste than the Flossmoor version. There was some pleasant light hop bitterness at the end.

Bottled. An unclear orange beer with a huge white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of citrus. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, but also a slight acidic touch, leading to a dry bitter finish with the notes of straw carrying thru.
Muddy blond color. Light aroma of wheat and buckwheat. Some weizen flavor, light citrus and spicy touch. Not bad, but too simple.
Bottle. Muddy yellow colour with a white head. Dusty, malty aroma and a sweet malty, wheat, yeasty taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with particles. Weak sourish wheaty and malty aroma. Flavour is rather thin, sweet, wheaty and yeasty, bit sour, malty and grainy. Weak dry finish.
Cloudy pale yellow colour with a white head. Malty, citric aroma with a light fruity note. Malty, sweet flavor with an acidic and dry finish.
Sample from 50 cL bottle. Pours unclear yellow. White head. Aroma is slight citric wheat. Flavour is soft wheat but also slight sour. Watery finish.

Bottle. Average white fizzy head that mostly diminished. Spar lacing. Cloudy orange color. Wheat, citrus, grain, hay. Light bodied with an average carbonation. Flavor was malt sweetness and hint of acidic. Sweet finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) I was a bit confused by this one: being completely cloudy, yet called a Hell - and then from a Weizenbierbrauerei. What to make of it? Anyways, as said the beer pours a cloudy golden with basically no head. Tart malt aroma. Medium body with some malt and a degree of acidity. The finish is dry. 230407

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Hazy amber/gold pour. Aromas of bread, flower and citrus. Body was medium with some hop, spice and biscut tastes. It was ok.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pours copper with a white head. Smells citrussy and sweet. Tastes citrussy and peppery with a lightly bitter finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle that was never poured in a glass, drinks like a lame caramel bodied ipa with not enough IBU’s to put forth anything i enjoy in an IPA. Simple and sessionable i suppose.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a modest off-white head. Aroma of strawberries, candied fruits, citrus hops, and caramel malt. Nice, fresh grapefruit hops in the body with good crisp caramel malt for balancing. Bitter, clean grapefruit aftertaste. A very good IPA. Can’t really find this stuff anymore...too bad.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Hazy dark gold color with a small fluffy head. Bitter, light citrusy hop flavor. Faint malty sweetness. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Nothing too out of the box.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy orangish gold wth small slightly off white head. Crisp citrus hoppy nose. Light maltiness with a somewhat bitter citrus hop finish. Medium body. Not bad, though I’d echo the comments that it lacks the punchiness of good IPAs.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: (Bottle). Citrus aroma. Cloudy yellow-orange color, with off-white head. Flavor is refreshingly citrus, mostly orange and lemon. Limited bitterness. Pleasant, but very mild for an IPA.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: on tap at Magic Hat- rating based upon a few samples. Almost clear golden in color with orange highlights. Aroma: mild to moderate orange/grapefruit with a very light touch of malt in the back. Taste is a light to moderate amount of citrus hops, on a light to medium pale malt body. Very straightforward and easy drinking for an IPA. Clean flavor profile. Bitterness is light to moderate in the finish. Not bad for an APA but not as assertive as I like IPA’s.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: [1604-20080816] 355mL bottle. Light sweet fruit aroma has a bit of hops and grains. Clear, light orange brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Bit of sweet fruit hops and a bit of hoppy bitterness in the flavour. Medium body. Not bad, fairly fresh. (@ Cole’s IPA Festival; Buffalo, NY)

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 2008-08-16. Dark yellow not quite orange body, with a small white head. Mild grainy aroma, touches of straw and hops. (5+) Low level citrus hops in the flavour, light astringency, mild grainy undertones. Average palate. An adequeate pale ale, a poor IPA. Bottle, Coles IPA Festival, Buffalo

Sweetish aroma, fruits, caramel, molasses. Deep black color; you only get slight fringes of dark ruby around the edges with a backlight. Tall, thick, creamy, dark tan head with moderate-to-short retention; its down to a 1/8 inch after 5 minutes, leaving no lacing. (But disconnected spotty lacing as you drink.) Eventually, the head completely disappears and the sides of the glass are completely clean. Moderate body and feel, smooth. Initial taste is an interweaved complex of malt flavors: bread, sweet molasses and caramel, plums, fruit, chocolate liqueur, dry roasted malts, playing back and forth. Semi-sweet in the beginning, with no bittering initially. It becomes somewhat bitter, starting in the middle and carrying on into the finish and aftertaste. It remains semi-sweet through the middle, but ends semi-dry in the finish. Very slight alcohol presence on the roof of the mouth. Some sweetness returns in the aftertaste. The complexity and interplay of the flavors, sweet-to-dry-to-sweet, and balancing bitterness is just great.

Brunatne. Nieprzeniknione dla światła. Jasno brązowej piany całe mnóstwo. Syczy jak kłębowisko węży. Redukuje się. Prawie bez koronkowania i nie znikając do końca. Został atol. Nikły aromat czekolady i kawy. Średnie do niskiego nasycenie. Gładkie, słodkie, palone. W smaku prym wiedzie czekolada. Jest i kawowa kwaskowość. Niska goryczka. A posmak zdecydowanie – jednak umiarkowanie - palony. Są i owoce: śliwka i wiśnia. Jak na świeżynkę całkiem ułożony egzemplarz. Jedynie może bąbelków za dużo.
Well-made smooth beer, creamy almost, not stout or roast bitterness, just clean. My only knock is that it’s a little muddled, a big mix of random flavors. Jabeerwocky warsaw

Degu rok po dacie przydatności. Barwa podręcznikowa - czarny brąz, z nieśmiałymi rubinowymi refleksami. Piana niska, średniej struktury, dość szybko znika. Aromat średnio złożony, na czele gorzka czekolada, ziarna kakaowca, dalej kawa, palone słody, delikatnie wyczuwalny tost, biszkopt, toffi. W smaku również średnio: słodka kawa zbożowa, ciasto czekoladowe, delikatna kwaskowość palonych słodów i tak samo delikatna ich gorycz. Pozostawia wrażenie nieco rozwodnionego i mało alkoholowego portera, aczkolwiek gładkiego i z ułożonym smakiem. Brakuje mi tu zdecydowanego ciężaru gatunku i smaku rozbudowanego o owocowy susz. Cena do jakości bardzo dobra, ale leżakowanie nie przyniosło efektu "wow".
Trochę takie oleiste, z resztą jak dobry porter. Barwa czarna, w smaku i aromacie kawa i śliwka. Piana szybko opada i zabarwiona na brązowo

Bottle, from Malt & Mold. Pours dark brown with faint ruby highlights, large spongy tan head, mocha-faint rum aroma, adequate carbonation, medium sweet mocha taste with coffee bitterness, faint alcohol undertones, smooth body, long finish. Well balanced and well covered ABV.

The Aromas are dark malt, roast, cocoa, some black patent and a bit of Funk. Flavors are like nose, mildly sweet up front with some carbonation to balance and some metallic minerals in the Finish. Little sign of the strength. Good body, nice beer.

aromat: pupernikiel, palone slody, kawa zbożowa kolor: czrne piana szybko zanikajaca, brązowawa Smak i odczucie w ustach: pełne, wysycone średnio słodkie, karmelowe, czekolada; finiszu robi się bardziej wytrawne, na pierwszy plan wychodzi kawa i czekolada. Posmak delikatnie palony, intensywnie kawowy Alkohol jest niewyczuwalny, podobnie jak goryczka.
.5l bottle from Boise Co-op. Dark brown pour, beige head dissipates to flat. Roasty, woody aroma, dark chocolate. Taste reveals more chocolate, mild sweetness. A bit sticky at the finish.

Warka do 02.12.2019 Wygląd: ciemnobrunatne, nieprzejrzyste, piana bardzo szybko opada ( prawie jak na coli ) Aromat: estry, czerwone owoce, kawa, trochę czekolady i karmelu Smak i odczucie w ustach: pełne, wysycone średnio mimo niezbyt ostrożnego nalewania. Ściągające w lekko winny sposób, słodkie, karmelowe. Na finiszu robi się bardziej wytrawne, na pierwszy plan wychodzi kawa i czekolada. Posmak delikatnie palony, intensywnie kawowy, będący największą zaletą tej warki. Alkohol jest niewyczuwalny, podobnie jak goryczka.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Pours a light amber color, small head. Aroma of caramel, bread. Taste is medium sweet, medium body.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Ins Glas ergießt sich ein rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, süß, fruchtig, Karamell. Geschmack röstmalzig, stark fruchtig süß, Karamell, schokoladig, leicht alkoholisch.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Takie srednie piwo lekko slodowe, bez chmielu, ze srednia piana ale mimo nawet trwala. Ciemno zloty kolor, wiec jasny doppelbock, ja wole zdecydowanie ciemniejsze wersje.Nieczytelna ciemna etykieta tylko jednostronna i za to takze dostal sie minusik.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Schöne orange-braune Farbe. Der Geruch ist sehr schön angenehm süßlich-malzig. Der Antrunk ist muffig-säuerlich, zum Hauptteil wird das Ganze merkwürdig-muffig mit einer zwar malzig-süßlichen, aber auch sehr muffig-herben Note. Zum Nachgeschmack verfliegt diese muffig-erdige Herbe aber auch wieder ziemlich schnell. Insgesamt ein sehr merkwürdiges Bier. Dazu auch noch relativ wässrig, von den 7,5% schmeckt man überhaupt nichts. Waldboden mit Salzwasser. Ganz komische Aromenkombination. --> Sehr interessantes Bier, aber überhaupt nicht mein Geschmack! Trotzdem vielen Dank an wastl für dieses Bier! Test vom 22.2.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,5,9,4,11,5 - 6,45

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: #701 Ein ziemlich derber Doppelbock, der zwischen süß und bitter hin und her schwankt. Insgesamt durchaus trinkbar, aber Genuß will sich nicht einstellen, schade. Test vom 1.3.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,9,9,9,9 - 9,00

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 500ml bottle. Clear deep orangey-golden colour with small macropore white head. Intense caramel malt aroma, sweet and slightly alcoholic. Taste is sweet, caramel, inharmonic bitter hop note. Disappointing.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Hellmalziger, daneben muffig-süßer Antrunk. Im Mittelteil werden alkoholische Noten offensichtlich, die sich zusammen mit dem muffigen Aroma störend auswirken. Penetrant, klebrig, getreidig-malzig. Dazu etwas säuerlich. Im Abgang alkoholisch, muffig, disharmonisch, modrig.Wenig würzig. 7/6/6/7/8/6

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Im Geruch süß-malzig und marginal röstig. Süßlicher Antrunk. Dann noch süßer und malzig. Mittig wird die Malzigkeit durch marzipan- und honigartige Töne begleitet. Im Abschied leicht ölig wirkend und ein wenig alkoholisch nachbrennend. Schweres Bockbier und nicht so leicht trinkbar. Hat jedoch geschmackliche Qualitäten.Test vom 22.12.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Reddish golden brown color with a little foam and less carbonation. The smell is minimal alcoholic, alsomalty sweet and spicy. Starts strongly aromatic and subtly sweet, slightly alcoholic. The finish shows spicy aromas, little alcoholic, still pleasantly malty sweet.

column2: Höchstadt an der Aisch, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle looks good, the beer in the glass zippy, fine creamy head. Starts very strong, a bit soapy-alcoholic, very dry and metallically. Finish unbalanced, still dry and somehow hard. Should be more spicy. Not good.
0,5 l bottle from kappldav123. Thanks a lot! Clear golden, small head. Low grain and hop on the nose. Taste is grainy with malt, some sweetness, very low hopy for a Pilsener. Doesn´t hurt.

Bottle. Light golden, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish aroma, faint bread and butter with light herbal hoppyness. Body is light to medium, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, light herbal hoppyness. Finish is average, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish, faint metal with light herbal hoppyness. Lightly grainy pils, could use more bitterness. Nothing wrong - nothing special.

Statt einer Wanderung zur Luisenburg wenigstens ein Luisenburg-Pils ... - Vom Faß in den Ratsstuben, Wunsiedel. - Sattes Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase nur milder, leicht zitroniger Hopfen. - Antrunk mild zitronig hopfenherb mit feiner Kräuternote, sehr gediegen und rund. Zart hellmalziger Körper. Mild rezent, weich, zart mineralisch. Im Abgang mild zitronenschalige Hopfenherbe. - Mild aber gediegen gehopftes, rundes Pilsener mit feinem Malzkörper. (Verkostung: 11.9.2016.)
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, malty, modest dry. Grasy-spicy. Finish could be more balanced, some metalically-dry notes. Boring malty. Okay.
Short fluffy white head. Opaque pale yellow color. Small aroma of lactic acid. Also a bit acidic in the taste. Small maltiness and bitterness.

50cl bottle. Pours clear pale golden colour with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of bitter mild floral hops, grains, pale malt. Taste of bitter floral hops, some metallic bitterness, grains.
Getreidig hopfiger, dazu mild süßer Beginn. Deutliche, noch steigende Herbe, grasig bitter. Spritzig herb bitterer Mittelteil und Nachgeschmack, hell, harmonisch. 9/11/10/9/7/9
Pours a golden colour. The flavour is grainy with some flowery hop notes. O.K.

bottle from Edeka Marktredwitz. Clear pale yellow with a tall white head. Green and fresh hjop aroma. Light and elegant malty flavours support fragrant grassy hops. Lingering hoppy finish. Good example of the style.
Not a good Pilsner. Very light color, non existant aroma and an odd undefinable aftertaste.

From growler at DLD: Pours a deep brown with ruby highlights. The aroma has your standard BA vapours of vanilla, oak and booze along with syrupy maple and brown sugar characteristics. Some chocolate, grassy and aromatic hops, and a hint of pipe tobacco on the nose as well. The taste is surprising on that sweet as I feared because of the cleaning effect of the bourbon. You get a lot of sugary sweetness and husky malt tones at first but then the alcohol come a calling a takes over in a brash manner. In the end it the BA nature became a bit too much but I still enjoy the sample I did receive. The mouth feel is wonderfully lush and oily, mildly carbonated and a warming brew. Would like a set down with a full pint a see if that would be even a better experience.

DLD. If you didn’t get this, you really missed out. Deep brown body. The aroma was a nice mix of brown sugar, toffee, caramel, and bourbon. Taste follwed the aroma exactly, and was very, very enjoyable. I hope they bottle this one.

well...this is odd...had this on tap at the brewery and it doesnt resemble that of any of the other ratings..initially i was served a backwoods bastard and was told it was this beer, then asked for another sample of it from a different bartender, and alas i was given the bourbon maple porter...it was dark amber/brown body with no head..aroma large in sweet bourbon and nothing else....ditto on the flavor..it was missing all porter characterisitics and had no maple to speak of...i guess i better go again to try, but this was more of a bourbon malt beer than a porter...
How is the entire columbus crew the first to rate this. DLD also. Poured dark brown with a light colored head. Aroma of light bourbon and chocolate. Pretty good malty aroma. Real tastey beer.
Growler @ DLD: Poured dark brown with a khaki head. Aroma had some maple, brown sugar, caramel. Flavor, caramel, some alcohol, bourbon. Great stuff.

Sampled from growler @ DLD ’07-Nice chocolate and bourbon aroma.Pours black with a medium tan head.Very smooth chocolate with some bourbon/alcohol dominate the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a very smooth alcohol finish.

Dammit Scott!! You beat me to another beer, and my rating is once again similar to yours!!! Sampled from a growler. The nose was immense amounts of bourbon and lots and lots of maple that worked really well within this beer. Very thick on the palate which I didnt really expect with a porter, but it was fantastic stuff! Not really sure on the alcohol percentage of this one but it was certainly noticeable but all the while it still went down very smoothly. Highly enjoyable stuff and a beer that I didnt know even existed let alone did I think I would get to try it. Thanks to who ever brought this to DLD. Truly appreciated!!

Growler sampled at DLD - Pours dark brown with a short offwhite head. Aromas of maple bourbon and oak blended with a good chocolate and coffee base. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, and a good amount of maple. Light hints of bourbon accent this as well with some oak. Good medium body and a very smooth palate. This was fantastic!
draft at Coles, medium bodied black pour. roasted malts, touch of chocolate malts. solid flavor . Good porter

On tap at the brewery. While tasting the porter my brother found out our host was Tim Herzog, who my brother went to High School with for 4 years. Also my friend Steve was there and he lived on the same street as Tim growing up. We had a good time talking about the old days and enjoying beer. Oh, it was black with a small head. Medium body with a pleasant maltiness and a hint of chocolate and coffee. Great.

(cask @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Dark black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma is heavy malt and roasted notes with a lot of dark fruit and a light touch of oak and wine. Flavor is dark and earthy. Lots of plum and oak notes mix with heavily roasted malts and some light chocolate at the end. Creamy and bitter all at the same time.
Cask @ goodbar. Very dark brown, just a little light. Light tan head, nose is cocoa, malt, toffee, caramel. Flavor is toffee, ink, molasses, dark fruits, light coffee. A bit cloying.

On cask at Goodbar, Buffalo. Very dark brown, small bubbly white head. Nice subtle roast and chocolate aroma. Good cask roasty taste, very sessionable. Light body, a true session cask porter without really knocking it out of the park. I liked it more than the other guys I guess, and hey, we helped the good people of Buffalo celebrate their sabres victory, so maybe it gets a point for that :)

Cask at Mr. Goodbar, Buffalo, NY. Pours a very dark brown with a small diminishing tan head. Very mild aroma of lightly roasted malt with a hint of coffee. Slightly watery flavour of lightly roasted malt, some caramel and hints of chocolate and coffee. Body’s pretty thin. Disappointing, this needs more taste and character, as it is it’s just O.K.

Cask. At Goodbar in Buffalo NY. NOT their Imperial Porter, this is a new beer, recently launched. Poured typical dark brown, small cask off-white head. Mild aroma, sweet light chocolate malt, a hint of cola syrup, very mild floral hops. The taste ... pretty weak, really, tries to be roasty, and mostly succeeds, but I kept getting watered-down syrup - on cask it was certainly easy to drink, perhaps too much so, no real finish to it. Very weak body, mild astringency which faded instantly, fairly still - drinkable, but I was frankly disappointed.
Hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is wheat, lime and light banana.
Ordinær witbier - sikkert drukket på den forkerte årstid. Frisk øl uden megen bitterhed og aroma.
Smagt 12-11-2016 i Lynge, Danmark. Serveret fra flaske. Gul, tåget øl uden skum. Duften er metallisk, syrlig og lys humlet. Smagen lidt for sprittet, metallisk og bitter.

Bottle. Pours clear golden with tiny white head. Aroma is flour, banana, lemon, groundcherries and chalk. Taste is medium sweet, faint bitter and light acidic. Body is watery with faint carbonation. Finish is a bit short and mostly sweet with notes that follow the nose.

33 cl bottle@home in tall glass@approx 6 degrees. Pours hazy yellow with one finger white head with decent retention. Malty aroma with orange and coriander notes. Sweetish, dry taste again with malt, orange and coriander. Medium/low carbonation and somewhat thin on the palate. Short, pleasant aftertaste where a little more bitterness kicks in. Refreshing wit.

Small head during pour, immediately vanishes. Hazy yellow body. Chlorinated oranges aroma with spicy notes. Dry-sweet mealy fruity taste with orangey notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, mealy mouthfeel. Dryish mealy orangey aftertaste with spicy coriander notes. It’s not bad, just slightly strange, although the aroma had me really worried for a moment. (0.33l bottle, from Føtex Frederikshavn. Drunk on the BB-date.)

A danish, golden, unfiltered Witbier with very low, white head and with lemon peel. Aroma is fresh fruit, banana, yeast, light malt, white raisins. Taste is bitter sweet, pearly. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle@strandby. Very haze muddy golden. Faint white bread. One finger foam. Low bitterness. Some undefined fruity flavours. Compared to Belgium bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Løkken By Camping, Denmark. Pours hazy golden with little white head. Aroma of oranges, bananas, some sulfur. Tastes pretty bitter with some sweetness, dry mouth feel. Refreshing summer beer, but not the best wit I’ve tasted.

04-MAY-2016, bottle @home, from Føtex as Løkken Witbier. Very pale yellow with a short, very quickly dissappearing white head. Nice aroma of lemon and herbs. Taste the same with sweet malt and wheat. Not very bitter. Very thin body. Short finish. Refreshing.

Appearance: dark amber color. Little head, yellowish and some lasting. Aroma: very unpleasant lactic, rancid and plastic smells. Very infected. Flavour: acid, rancid, plastic and like fuel. Palate: ? Undrinkable. This is a "Bottled-Infection"
Amber color, with a yellowish foam. The aroma to me remembers a disturbed fruit. My fear becomes reality when, proving it. is a bad beer. I will return to try in another opportunity.

Has a reddish color, amber. The head is very white and persistent. The aroma is exquisite, raspberries. (The aroma is of an intense freshness). The flavor is balanced, surprisingly. Is well malty, but the raspberry is persistent, very well. The best mixing (raddler) that I have tried of the Chilean beer of microbreweries.

Appearance: amber reddish color. Medium head, ivory color, consistent and persistent. This beer could be very beautiful without the curds of yeast presents. Aroma: very intensive in fresh raspberry, some citric and sweet tones of others berries. Malty and nice yeasty. Flavor: good balance of the raspberries citric and sweets, sickly sweet. Fresh yeasty, with reminiscences of raspberries cake. Persistent fruitiness and refreshing sourness. Palate: light body, watery texture and little carbonation. A nice surprise, refreshing citric-fruitiness, balanced beer. Advisable.

Pours a deep dark brown color. Head is medium, off-white and creamy. It diminishes slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is malty, toasted. There are notes of cocoa, bitter chocolate, nutella and capuccino coffee. I noticed also a perfumey hint that detracts from the overall profile and makes the smell feel a little unclean. Flavor is affected by a sour-ish sign of infection. Underneath the lemony and grassy hitns there is some cocoa and chocolate mousse. Could be OK, but not in this state. Medium mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Finish is long and chocolatey. Decent aftertaste. Need a good bottle to rerate but it seems this one has batch problems.
The aroma is strong, probably a bit mellow. Has a rather dark foam, with very little cord. In the palate is very wrong. (I will try again).

Appearance: dark brown color. Medium head, beige and persistent. Aroma: roast malts, candy, some chocolate and milk with coffee. Very yeasty. A rare plastic smells. Flavor: disappointingly (I had high expectations in this beer) and unfortunately, existing infection problems. Some toasty malty and chocolate taste. Excessive yeasty. Palate: medium body; light to medium carbonation.

Large beautiful creamy foam. Lovely malty with lots of fruit. Creamy mouth feeling with good fruity taste of raisin, prune and light citrus. Gentle malty sweetness holder for an appropriate hoppy and lingering aftertaste takes over.

Bottle 500ml as "Børglum Kloster Abbedens Dubbel" @ home Pours hazy deep amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and hint of alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long malty, caramel and dried fruity finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

courtesy of Antonio Rey; under the name of Borglund Kloster - hazy ruby-brown beer with no head retention; toasted aroma of cola and hazelnuts; notes of candied fruits; pretty sweet and full-bodied; long malty finish with notes of ripe bananas and cola again; some residual sweetness

Bottle (label Børglum Kloster Abbedens Dubbel") from BarleyWine, CPH - dark reddish brown pour with almost no head at all. Sweet fruity and malty number, sweet yeasty, some dried fruit, caramel, slight spice. Ok.

0,5 l bottle at Rold Storkro. Beer labelled as Rold Storkrro 50 år 2008. ABV is 7,9 %. Hazy deep ruby mahogany body with no head. Dates, raisin and rock sugar on the nose. Full bodied, sweet and light alco warm with wooden and light nutty notes. Smoothish with a dry finish.

Som Børglum Kloster Abbedens Dubbel, flaske delt med Ovesen en vakker høstsøndag med aktivitetsdag på Holmen: en meget bra dubbel i typeriktig stil&smak. Saftig, og med lang ettersmak. En behagelig overraskelse som gjør at jeg vil prøve flere fra Søgaard.
Dufter vinagtig lidt syrlig, farve mørk brun uklar, vandet, megen malt smag, sød ikke min type Free Føroyar!!!

Bottle as "Børglum Kloster Abbedens Dubbel", 7.9%. Dark brown with tiny beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, yeast, dark fruits and chocolate. Flavour is malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruits, chocolate, medium sweet and a little bitter.
bread, cereal, brown, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, fizzy, light bitter finish.
Tap at DØE. Hazy brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, spice, malt and fruit.

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. Another pleasant beer from this upstart brewery in the middle of nowhere. Clean clear crisp and flawless. Why can’t all light beers be this good? This could be my highest rating of all time for a light beer.

Sample at the Parkville Microbrewers Festival. Pours yellow with some white head. Very light spicy rye and nobel hop aroma. Very light on the rye flavor as well. Thin and dry. Would be nice on a 150 degree day.

Review: 500ml blue can of Excelsior Lager: 4.0% vol. Can find it with 4.1% to 3.9 % in strength, depending on the region. Coming in a pretty cool looking logo of a Knight’s sword, in a nice blue can. Aroma is pretty shit, in fact it smells a bit like shit, had the aroma of a fart! Lagery smell, and very metallic on the nose. Not great! Looks good on pour, a nice frothy white head, nice and creamy, and a golden coloured beer on show. Not bad. Head maintains well, and some good lacing apparent. Get a lot in the can. Bit of an off taste found initially, not great at all………. Overall, it is a bit tasteless, and any taste you do get is bittersweet and lacking in flavouring. Second can, it improved a little, and was slightly easier to drink, a bit smoother and nicer on the old stomach, but still lacking any real depth to the beer. Malty and a little hoppy, but overall not a nice beer at all. Very forgetful and not worth trying again, cheap as it is and all………..

Can, 4-pack found at me local Lidl. Pours with foamy enough head and a yellow liquid, small bubbles. Smells of soft garbage cabbage. Flavour is slight grains and sugar with a medium finish. Given how cheap this is, I don't think it's bad at all.
50cl can from LIDL. Thick creamy white head. Clear golden pour. Watery. Not much to it.

An inexpensive lager at Lidl, it’s not particularly nice to drink on its own. Overly fizzy and with very little taste. However, its lack of richness and relatively high carbonation does mean that it makes for a lovely light shandy for a summer afternoon when you want to take it easy, so it is worth picking up a few of these on the cheap to keep in the cupboard with some nice lemonade in time for when summertime comes around.
Can 0.44l at home, Vantaa. Enjoyed straight from the can. Aromas and flavours: Sweetness, syrup, grain and malts. Very bad bulk lager.
Pours clear yellow with a large and foamy head. Malty aroma. Taste is mild with sweetish maltiness. Very little hops. Watery and tasteless overall. (440ml can, bb 05/2018)
0,44l can. Pours golden with quickly diminishing head. Some metallic notes and a hint of hops with malt. Had worse I guess.
Pale golden colour, medium-sized head. Sweetish, grainy malts. Some metallic notes. Light bodied, quite carbonated.

can, lidl (4%, made in france- version). pale golden, clear. dull weak pale malty nose, wheaty bland, thin. light metallics. light bodied, pale malty, very weakly flavoured, watery thin. clean, but probably the weakest flavoured beer in a while.

0.44 l can from Lidl Ojamo, Lohja. Appearance is golden, clear and with a big head. Well, I didn’t expect much of this and I wasn’t disappointed. Taste is on the sweet side of lagers. Includes some kind of sugared colour or something. It is drinkable if you are very thirsty, but I’d prefer more hops and malts. Made in France.
Actually scratch 317. Good beer, enjoyable and lighter. Would buy another case, and could drink throughout the day. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at campground brewdown. Pours gold with a white head. Pretty well oxidized at this point (obviously) with some faint sweet apple notes, and off yeasty notes as well. Honestly, for a 7 year old beer of this style, I expected way worse.

*First and foremost, this review is for how this is drinking right now, not in the past. My scores reflect the last time I had it but didn’t review it.* Big thanks to John for bringing this one to Campground Brewdown this year. Never thought I would have the chance to try it after so long a time. A - Pours pale yellow with a decent one finger tall white head, quickly dissipating to a light film, leaving small rings of lace on the sides of the glass. S - This one just plain smells old. Plenty of oxidation, stale bread, died up yeast, bubblegum, apples and some sugary sweetness. T - Starts off with some green apple skins and wet cardboard oxidation slowly being joined by the pale malt, bubblegum, old yeast and some light sweetness. Finish is a touch sweet with more oxidation. M - Medium-Light body with high carbonation. Prickly, sweet feel. The bottle sounded like a gun went off when it was opened. O - I knew going into this that this one was long gone so I was expecting all of this. If you still have one of these it is for pure novelty at this point.

A: The beer pours a very hazy golden orange color with a large white head. S: Butterscotch and cardboard are prominent, which is disappointing but not necessarily surprising. Toffee and caramel sweetness with a little bit of bready. Strangely, there is a strong Cracker Jack aroma. T: A very strange fruity flavor that I can’t quite describe. Cardboard oxidation, toffee, butterscotch, honey, and some more Of the Cracker Jack character. M: Medium in body with a fairly high level of carbonation. O: I was happy to try this just because of what it is in terms of the series, but it’s really not worth drinking.

Bottle thanks to Derek!.. I’ve now managed to track down the first 25 of these! Poured hazy peach with a short, swirly cap of whitish head. The aroma picked up soft, buttery notes and pale malts with early-stage composted grass around.. sweet overall, and age definitely showed. The flavor found honey and bready malts at the core (again showing age, but pleasant).. dry black pepper, earthy notes, and a touch of grass around.. finished with a lemon-peppery twang over honeyed bread. Light-medium bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. sweet complexion, but it dried out on the edges.. past its prime, but still a tasty and interesting brew.
Poured yellow with a white head. Aroma of fruit. Some fruit flavors. Light bodied. Little bit hops.
Bottle. Pours a pale golden body with a white head. Grainy malt body some light citrus and hints of grape juice. Lightly earthy with a hint of spice. Decent.

7-27-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to DIM, we believe Cloudy dull dirty yellow with a thin and short lived white film of a head. Smell is very doughy with a faint splash of citris - very faint. Flavor is light malt and mostly dough but there is that light citris backdrop there as well. Drinkable, but not superb.

Bottle in trade from a forgotten source. Possibly DIM? Thanks though! Pours a nice hazy light orangish yellow color with a small white head. Smell is lightly hoppy and with sweet tea like maltiness. Taste is fruity with lightly bittering hops and a touch of a yeasty flavor. Unique tart and citrusy flavor with a touch too light sweetness. Pretty interesting beer.

Wow. I was expecting a boring beer here, but this was outstanding (especially for this style!). Aroma was fruity hops and pretty strong. Pour was murky light gold with a one finger white head. Taste was very sweet in the front. Sugar and fruit mostly. The hops balance the sweetness, but after the swallow the cheeks are almost numb. Don’t know why but there is a crisp aftertaste that tastes like Juicy Fruit gum. Very nice.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: My Bottom Line: An enticing wooden, spicy hop character evolves into an assertive earthy, herbal finish. This drinkable Double IPA is a hop feast, no doubt about that, and should satisfy those looking for a high-alpha fix. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam seeps into the hazy peach blond. -The aroma isn’t overblown, and that soaring bitterness could not have been predicted. -Sandy dryness and tame biscuity maltiness work well together. -As you can imagine, maltiness is only here to support the hop flurry. -After their lackluster Barley Wine, I admit I was surprised by the high flavor content and complex hoppiness in this one. On tap at Tap NY.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: This Imperial Pale ale has a huge amount of hops. The beer pours deep brown and the nose offers a deep hops aroma. The mouthfeel and palate is dense with a carmel like hops flavor. The beer finishes long and with a balanced bitter.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: on tap-pours an off white head that laces and black color with red tint. Aroma is mild dark malt-chocolate. Taste is lemony, chocolate-dark malt, faint hops bite. Medium body.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Rating 1055. Had on tap at the brewery in Hilton Head Island South Carolina. Clear with no head. Flat. No rim. Faint malts in the nose. Taste is weakly faint and soft. Slight smoke (only way that I was convinced that it WAS a porter) and cream. Drinkable at best.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft pint at the brewpub; Darkest shade of brown there is, with a thin tan head. I swear this has a raspberry aroma and there’s a bit of this in the flavor, too. Wasn’t advertised as a raspberry porter, so don’t know if it was my imagination or not ... (#2820, 4/22/2007)

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Found out of bottle from a variety pack. Nice appealing brown pour and odd copper smell. It has flavor but not good ones. The first part is like sucking on a bad penny with an aftertaste of charcoal.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: 5 week old can A: Clear dark reddish brown pour with 1/2" of bubbly tan foam that held the ring and cap. S: Bitter chocolate and faint roast coffee. T: Follows the nose with roasty chocolate, coffee and a nice woody bitterness. But where's the caramel? M: Smooth and thin texture, light carbonation and sticky finish. O: Pretty good if not very complex.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Bottle from Sam's Quik Shop. Pours brown with a small head. Aroma is chocolate, cocoa, roasted nuts. Flavor is cocoa, roasted nuts, coffee, something else.... Simple, but decent.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Dark brown pour with moderate tan head and lacing. Aroma is acetone, licorice, and ground coffee. Taste is much more pleasant, some coffee and a tiny bit of chocolate, something else I can't figure out. Finish is pretty clean.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Bottle from Harris Teeter in Asheville, CA. Aroma is soupy roasted barley soup, vegetal hops, okra. Taste is soupy, grainy and vegetal with some tang in the finish. A very tangy but Randy Porter if Randy Porter were what you thought it was.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: This beer is a clear brown color with a medium light beige head that dissipates quickly to an outer ring. Short strings of lace. Roast malt, chocolate and slight hops in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of chocolate malt, nuts and mild hops. The finish is sweet with a short malty aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Not bad, a bit thin in body, but overall a good representation of the style. Certainly malt forward, subtle bready and fruity notes. Nice.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Aromas of caramel, toast. Dark Brown with good head. Flavors of dark caramel, toast and sweet malt. Very balanced but simple.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: Poured a deep brown. Mild head. Pretty nutty. Some toffee. An ok brown nothing spectacular.

column1: Big Boss Bad Penny Brown Ale
column5: This one is good and has some punchy malt flavors. I’ve certainly had worse brown ales. The aroma could be a little more pungent, but still it has plenty of that brand cereal notes with a sweet underbelly. Taste follows with lots of cereal, brand flakes, toasted bread, toasted malt, grains and faint leather with a smooth sweet sugary character in the background. Finish is slighly sticky and malt...pretty much what you’d expect.

column1: Old Market Atheneas Maple Vanilla Stout
column5: Name: Maple Vanilla Stout Date: September 22, 2009 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewpub Appearance: black, fine beige head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, lots of vanilla sweetness, notable maple sweetness Body: creamy nitro body Flavor: sweet roasted flavor, lots of the vanilla, touch of maple, dark chocolate bitterness adds balance, light espresso, roasted finish Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *** /4

column1: Old Market Atheneas Maple Vanilla Stout
column5: On tap at the Old Market Portland OR. Pours out black topped with a tan head. A nice coffee and vanilla on this one. Tast of roast and sweet vanilla pretty good.

column1: Old Market Atheneas Maple Vanilla Stout
column5: Clear very dk vrown with redish edges. small light tan head. Big vanilla and choc0olate roasted aromq. Mild roasted and bitter choc flavor wwith a quite thin almost watery palate. Intereting attempt but it downst qiite come off.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Une bière noire, aux reflets bruns, avec deux bons doigts de carbonatation qui s'estompe rapidement toutefois. Au nez, une fumée assez présente, un peu de sirop d'érable ainsi qu'une touche de pain brûlé. En bouche, c'est pas aussi lourd que je l'avais imaginé avec un corps assez mince somme toute. Le côté fumé est léger, ne prend pas trop de place avec une sensation d'eau d'érable également. C'est assez facile à boire mais très simple au final.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Où, Quand, Comment : Dégustée en fût sur place sous le nom « Double à l’Érable » (printemps 2007). Visuel : Couleur : ambrée-foncée. Apparence : semi-voilée. Arôme : Grains de malt, caramel sucré, notes fruitées et de sirop d’érable. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Léger goût de levures fruitées (mûres?). Une dominante maltée de caramel doux est également présente avec des notes de sirop d’érable, de houblon herbeux ainsi que quelques traces fumées. En bouche : Corps : moyen. Effervescence : moyenne-douce. Texture : légèrement sirupeuse aux petites notes huileuses. Finale : moyenne, composée d’un léger résiduel sucré avec quelques notes de houblon herbeux.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a reddish brown color with a small white head. The aroma is spicy notes, some heavy sugary sweetness. This is brewed with Maple Syrup and it certainly shows, some sugary sweetness, spices, like a Belgian Amber.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: A nice reddish amber ale with a thick creamy light moka head. Fruity esters melding with maple in aroma. In mouth, a nice caramel malt, with fruity notes, woody maple, a very nice ale. Medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, April 24 2009.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Pours a copper color with a thin white head. Strong aroma of maple syrup with some malt. The maple is a bit less intense in the falvor and the malt is a bit more present. The palate is medium and oily. The maple is very present, but as a dubbel, it’s not great.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: My Bottom Line: Authentic maple syrup sweetness and wooden character is swept into slender toasted maltiness until clean hop bitterness tactfully closes each sip. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circles the clear brownish copper. -The flavor profile is not as sweet as the had announced, and drinkability is enhanced. -The body is leaner than I would’ve expected from a maple-flavored Dubbel. -The Dubbel character is overtaken by the maple and so the beer becomes a decent maple-flavored ale, more than anything else. On tap at the brewpub.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: En fût. Verre de dégustation à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur de céréales… aucune présence d’érable au nez. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée foncée. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel très doux avec une très légère pointe d’érable. Courte durée de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est mince avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de sirop d’érable en arrière goût. (Rating #1011)

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Dark(5) : 3 &nbsp Ruby : 2 &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 2 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: XX &nbsp Lacing : XX Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 4 &nbsp Bread : XX &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Esters : XX &nbsp Banana : 3 &nbsp Phenols : 4 &nbsp Leather : XX &nbsp Perfume : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : 3 Malt : XX &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Toast : XX &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Toffee : XX &nbsp Maple : 4 &nbsp Molasses : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Candy : XX &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : 4 &nbsp Fruits : XX &nbsp Chocolate : XX &nbsp Coffee : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : XX &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Dates : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX &nbsp Plums : 2 &nbsp Figs : XX Hops : 1 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Cloves : 2 &nbsp Smoke : 1 &nbsp Pepper : XX &nbsp Ginger : XX &nbsp Peach/Pear/Apricot : XX &nbsp Candi Sugar : XX &nbsp Anise : XX &nbsp Vinous : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 4 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Bitterness : XX &nbsp Complex : 1 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 2 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 3 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : 3 &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: An interesting experiment, but the maple’s fermentation seems once again difficult to control. Rather woolly, ropey yeast finish and a generally stagnant sweetness.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Dark brown color, with a creamy beige head, yeasty nose, with notes of wineyness, faint toasted malt, some acidic berries fruitiness, not sweet maple accent in the aroma, follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, fruity winey, sourness character, hint of sweet toasted malt, no maple syrup flavor here, with some pruney, date, and raisiny notes, with a faint floral hop, leading towards a fruity, malty alcoholic finish. This beer needs some works.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: (Batch brewed for 1rst anniversary 28 april 2007). Clear ruby body topped by a small beige head. Strong aroma of wet earthy. Not much of the advertised maple on the nose. In the mouth things get worse. The beer has a somewhat lactic taste, borderline yogurt. That lactic taste really doesn’t sit well with the other flavours which include watery caramel, nutty/earthy malts and a little fruity touch of berries. Weird and not very pleasant mix here. The expected maple flavour really takes the back-seat (which is not a bad thing to me). The hops are there but can’t seem to find a way to express themselves. Carbonation is a lot of soft small bubbles and is appropriate here. Overall I was left with a “wet cloth” feeling. A big disappointment considering how good the beers from this brewpub have been lately. Something went wrong. Ha well, accidents happen. I even owe my being born to one.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Où, Quand, Comment : Dégustée en fût sur place (printemps 2007). Visuel : Couleur : dorée. Apparence : claire. Arôme : Levures fruitées (agrumes) et épicées (poivre doux), grains de malt sucrés, léger houblon herbeux. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Goût de levures fruitées (agrumes, traces d’abricots) et épicées (poivre doux, traces de coriandre). Un support de grains de malt sucrés est également présent avec des notes de miel et de pain ainsi qu’une légère amertume de houblon herbeux. En bouche : Corps : moyen. Effervescence : moyenne. Texture : légèrement crémeuse. Finale : moyenne et un peu sèche, composée d’une légère amertume de houblon herbeux avec des traces d’alcool.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: on draft at brewery, this one actually took a set to stop tasting like pennies. It got strong wheaty flavors, and some alcohol. its a triple...

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Un ballon sur place bien assis sur la merveilleuse terrasse. Bière blonde dorée passablement foncée. Un nez sucré avec des esters fruitées agréables mais tout de suite anéantit par des effluves d’alcool. La bouche est aussi sucrée avec de l’alcool. Somme toute un produit intéressant mais un peu trop marqué par l’alcool et le sucre.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Tap at Brenelux. Pours a almost clear deep golden with thin lasting white head. Aroma is fruity esters, light perfume, sweet candy sugar, apple, phenolic and lemon. Flavor is light cracker, pils malt, honey sweetness, apple cider, peach, pear, fragrant, fruity, with tangy sweetness, peppery phenols and floral rose petal- triple karmeliet-like- slight dms and corn comes through as it warms. Ok.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Dégusté avec french tickler le 7 juin 2007. On Tap Yellow amber poor with nice lacing... Aromas of bubble gum, mellon, very hoppy... Reminds me of a little rhubarb and raspberry tart. Flavors of creamy caramel with a spicy peppery aftertaste. Dry finish, creamy and slightly oily. Good overall.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Yeast, malt and pear aroma, golden, pours a small off-white head. Good malt taste, some yeast is noted. Medium bodied, some spice and a fine tongue tingle. Good.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at Benelux. The color is honey with a small off white head and nice lace. The taste is of spicies and fruits.The hops are very present in the overall taste and aroma. All in all a good Abbey triple.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Draught. Clear orange body with a small white head. The aroma is fruity consisting of pears, faint spice, and oranges. Toasted grain flavour along with a good level of hop bitterness. Not a whole lot of fruit character but otherwise pretty decent. Sampled at the brewpub on June 1, 2007.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Triple d’Été: Fruity esters and nutty, lightly grainy malts are joined by light notes of alcohol. Clear golden body is topped by a low but lasting white head that covers the sides of the glass with fine lacing. Fruity esters are joined by clean fresh malt flavour and surprising bitterness. Plenty of grassy hop character. Medium body with initially refreshing moderate carbonation that s somewhat short-lived. Sampled on tap at the brewpub.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at brewpub. Clear, golden clear ale with small fizzy rocky top. Grainy, wheat like aroma. Pleasant fruity clean nose. Fruity, clean grainy character. Gentle, potency well hidden. Silky smooth finish with light bitterness to it. Reminded me a bit of old school of Unibroue.
Draught at the Parkville festival. Pours a dense brown color with a thick tan head. Medium-bodied with a big malty flavor, slightly sweet flavor balance.

On tap at the 2007 Parkville Microbrew Festival. Pours a dark brown color with mahogany highlights. Has a dense, large, thick beige head with good lacing. The aroma is like unattenuated malt in the hydrometer. Sugary sweet and almost bock-like in some ways. It’s like this is not fully fermented. Some toasted malt flavors are here like a burned marshmellow at the campsite. I am strangely attracted to this.

Sample at the Parkville Microbrewers Festival. Tawny color with a light tan head. Not much to speak of in the aroma, but the flavor is chocolaty and ripe with rye flavor. Fairly rich on the palate. Nice beer.

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - hazy pale golden colour with a little stable foam; very flowery hoppy nose with a touch of peanuts, medium to full-bodied with a fair but not overwhelming hoppiness; dry and very bitter floral finish - hoppy and balanced, a good one

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - hazy dark amber colour with a solid creamy beige head leaving a superb lacing; fruity hoppy nose with a nutty touch; creamy palate and medium to full-bodied; low carbonation, some sweetness and a late bitterness, a note of alcohol in the aftertaste; the finish is a bit sweeties-like with notes of pear - balanced and with lot of subtility

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - very dark black colour, no foam; deep and at the same time subtle aroma of chocolate and milk coffee; quite toasty; low carbonation; the light to medium body is well maintained until the end; some bitterness; long finish of cocoa and moderately dry - another masterpiece from BeSte
Bottle from McScrooges. Orangey yellow, fluffy foam. Smells green bready and toasty. Taste is hay and pepper, then a vegetal green pepper flavor that seems out of place.

Bottle, 7%abv; golden with small white head; aroma is smokey, fatty, cellar and herbal; taste is smoke and fat, nice sweetness, herbal bitterness, some phenolic notes, funk and cellar, low bitter finish; texture is oily with low to medium carbonation and a medium body; nice and drinkable, hiding 7% well

Visual: (cellared for 5 years). Pours toffee brown with lots of suspended sediment, barely any head, thin ring with very thin layer of retention, a mix of fast and slow loose scatter streams. Nose: pukey, soft funk'd malt, lime oil (lvl-6)-pungency Attack: thicker-dull CO2, sour-funk malt impression Mid-palate: subuded & controlled short pukey-sour, honey barley malt, (lvl-4-sweetness) Finish: elderflower, lime oil & peel bitter, stealth lingering bitter hops Summary: Unlike any other saison I've had, this one is pukey-sour but is particularly engaging because of it. Also unique about this is the lime flavour as opposed to the usual banana-wheat malt in a saison. Very smooth and palatable, excellent to whet the appetite.

Bottle from my somewhat secret euro santa, cheer anstei! Pours a hazy bright yellow with a white head. Really good farmhouse nose with barnyard stuff, wet straw but also grass and citrus, as well as some overripe sweet apples. If I stick my nose deep into the glass and inhale I get some feces, so I stopped doing that and just enjoy the beer with less intense inhalation. Taste is refreshing, with lemon juice, gooseberries, grass, pepper, white bread, some pineapple. Quite tart, quite sweet with a good bitterness to keep things in check. Zesty lemon and peppery finish, if a bit short. Like!

Bottle from boxbeers.dk (7% ABV). Pours yellow-golden coloured with a big white head. Aroma has lots of hops, tropical fruits. Flavour is grassy and fruity hops. Aftertaste is mainly grassy and barnyardy.

(Bottle) Golden colour with big, frothy, white head, leaving traces of lacing. Fruity, hoppy nose with grass, citrus, spicy yeast, herbs and lots of fresh perfumy hops. Malty, hoppy taste with notes of citrus, grass, spicy/estery yeast, bread, herbs and a balanced citric bitterness in a finish with fresh hops. More than medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Tasty and really well balanced with lots of fresh hops, still not overly bitter. Well made, and very nice.

Intense barnyard, rotting cheese, grain malts, dusty straw, light citrus fruits. Almost clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More bitter citrus fruits, zesty, light acidity, barnyard, grain malts, yeast, bread dough, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Interesting Saison, quite strong, nice citrus fruits. Bottle from Beers’n’More, Zurich.

Bottle. Pours hazy pale yellow with a small, staying creamy white head. Aroma has sweet malts, esters, hoppy citrus, grapefruit, lemongrass. Medium carbonation, fine dry and quite creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has initial tartness, light lactic, solid hops, grapefruit, citrus. Lingering bitterness.

Many thanks for this beer to CH-303. Bottle 33cl and it is 7% ABV (Version with Yakima Hops). Sour, hops, Sour, hops, Sour, Hops, Sour and hops. I’m forget about something??? Yes This...beer is strong sour and perfectly and powerfull hoppy Ale:) Wonderfull hops aroma, taste like lime, fresh yellow citrus and strong sourly lemon juice, like a wild yeast sediment. Big and strong foam, absolutly dry, no sugary. I’m love it. Smells like fresh green apple. Thanks for this great sour saison ale Asbjorn.

Bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, corn starch), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, apricot), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of lemon taffy, plastic, pear syrup. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, slightly unclean/plastic. Medium body, velvety/watery/oily texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. If not for the plastic-and-taffy odor and aftertaste, this could be pretty nice. It could use more finishing bitterness as well. Cleaner fermentation (presumably) would probably take this to mid/upper 3s territory.

A dark brown stout with a thin off white head. A rather bizarre aroma of meat paté, cheese and thyme, odd and unpleasant. In mouth, not so bad, with a rather herbal chocolate malt and some bitter root. Medium bodied. A rather weird stout. Tasted at Mondiale 2007.

sampled at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - very dark brown colour with a little beige/brown head; nougat and alcohol, toasted with peppery notes; low carbonation and slightly oily; medium to full malt body; very bitter with notes of alcohol, coffee and chocolate; dry - very good

Courtesy of Philippe (Bov) Cloudy amber color, very lively beer, big steady head. The aroma is delicate, spicy. Good malt flavor, dry, spicy, with a positive presence of Belgian yeast and with a strong bitterness. Very good.

Bottled, thanks Bov! Cloudy golden, rich airy head. Funky orangey wheat malt a<roma. Sweetish and lively with freshly mown grass, winegum and spices. Vinous and concentrated. rather low bitterness. Really good!

Pours a hazy bronze, very lively, big puffy head. Amazingly complex spicy nose, black pepper, aniseed, licorice, coriander, citrus and more... although no spices are used. Clearly a result of the warm-ish fermentation with a saison yeast. Same spicy, peppery palate, with sizeable fruitiness and a nice hoppy edge, lingering, complex, crisp finish. Definitely more complex than its Saison Houblon stablemate, and truly unexpected in the Swiss landscape.

Bottled, thanks omhper! Pours out in a cloudy dark yellow colour with a rich eruptive white foam. Dry and fresh fruity aroma of lemon, hay, cumin, herbs, cinnamon, funk and oranges. Medium-bodied with touches of lemon, cumin,, coriander, yeast, pepper and lavendel. Dryish and fresh finish of yeast, pale biscuity malts, orange-peels and herbs. Another nice beer from Trios Dames!

Golden, huge rocky head. Malty nose with yeast, spicess and hay-like hops. Some citric wheat and light smokiness even. Flavor yeasty and spicy, wheat malt and bitter hops in the dry, a bit chalky finish. Hint of warming alcohol. Medium bodied, quite light palate. Nice spicy saison.

Bottled Orange color with floating yeast particles, huge cloudy white head - very lively beer. Spicey, peppery, almost glueish aroma - typical saison. Dry, fizzy carbonation, peppery with some fruity sweetness. Spicey aftertaste. Solid saison. Excellent brewery!

Bottled (thanks Bov!). Golden colour, huge foamy white head. Aroma is very fruity, spicy and mildly yeasty. Also some mild sourness and earthyness is lurking in there. Flavour is very fruity, mildly herbal and some earthy and yeastyness. Wellbalanced and nice session beer. Seems to be a very solid brewer.

Pours a cloudy peachy color with a thick, frothy, offwhite head. Attractive aroma of yeast, spices and fruits. Good flavor of yeast, spices and fruits with a dry finish. The body is medium with a creamy texture and lively carbonation.

Bottle Mondial. Sour fruit aroma, mildly farmyard, dark hazy brown, small off-white head. Starts with a very malty taste, fruit, some yeast qualities. Mildly acidic, dry and yet refreshing. Very good. My first saison from Switzerland.

Cloudy dark golden body with a large white head. Lush body with a mouthfeel that is full yet silky. Just enough lightly roasted malts with a light touch of caramel but as expected the main attraction is the wild fruity yeast with its citrus, banana and bubble gum flavours. Lots of bubbles yet never aggressive. Refreshing light tartness. This is not an intense beer, it is rather a highly drinkable Saison that you just cannot get tired of. A full bottle would have been more appropriated than my generous 6oz tasting sample. Excellent session Saison from a country where they call swiss cheese… well… cheese.

sampled at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - clear amber-red colour with almost no foam; phenolic with notes of honey; full-bodied and slightly oily, low carbonation, lively palate, bitter; some alcohol notes in a long honeyish, caramelish aftertaste

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - hazy golden-orange colour with a solid, stable white foam, nice lacing; fresh aromatic hoppiness with notes of corn and butter in the background; medium-bodied, nice balance and a soft regular palate; lively, long moderately fruity finish

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - slightly hazy amber colour, little stable beige foam; aroma of caramel and butter; medium to full-bodied; sweet with a moderate bitterness, some residual sugars; long and lively fruity finish

hazy yellow-orange with a head whio lets a white rim when dissappearing smells yeasty,banana tasts much of bananas,yeasty some sweetness aftertaste bananas and yeast too bittersweetish has not much other smells and tasts than the banana (where is the clove?)

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - cloudy dark orange colour, little chaotic foam formed of big bubbles; aroma of very matured bananas, sweet and medium-bodied with a rather low carbonation; long and cloying banana finish with some residual sugars

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - very dark brown colour with a little dark beige foam; slightly toasty with light notes of ginger and cookie maltiness; good carbonation and a regular medium to full malt body; decent bitterness, dry malty finish with notes of licorice

PET-bottle, thanks Bov! (5.7%) Cloudy amber, rich head. Aroma of banana and slight citrus. Caramelly and mid sweet with above medium body andsoft mouthfeel. Lots of ripe banana wrapped in cushiony caramel. No bitterness.

draught at the Solothurner Biertage - cloudy dark amber-orange colour, little white foam; aroma of matured banana, oily and full-bodied, sweet with a high carbonation, some late tart acidity, the finish is rather dry with notes of alcohol and banana - achieving some balance

draught at the Solothurner Biertage 2007 - hazy golden-amber colour with a little stable foam and a nice lace; aroma of hemp and honey, creamy and medium-bodied; quite low carbonation; residual sugars in a light hempy finish - subtle but not very interesting

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: My Bottom Line: Vanilla-laced roastiness evolves proficiently on the palate, developing fruitiness and sturdy bitterness. This low-gravity Imperial Stout is a fine introduction to the potential power of this style. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam covers the brown-sleeved blackness. -Grapey esters are perceived in the nose. -The roastiness is king here, reigning through flavor profile and remaining quite healthily in the aftertaste. -The important carbonation stays comfortable at all times. -Some supporting hops are muddled in the intense finishing roastiness. -This wasn’t served on nitro, which is a plus. On tap at the brewpub.

Draft sample at brewpub, clear pale-golden color with white head. Aroma notes of light pale malt sweetness and faint fruitiness. Taste adds some cereal and grass hop bitterness. Light body, moderate carbonation, crisp with clean finish. Very well made craft kolsch, solid.

Light passing through the gold color topped with a heady 2 finger foam. Aroma of bananas, cloves. Cucumbers, hops, lemon, peppercorns, pine. Earthy and natural it is a great session beer. Front Street represent!

From draft sampler at the brewpub on August 7, 2013 under the name "Front Street Coastal Kolsch" . Clear light yellow color, moderate bittersweet aroma, somewhat creamy texture, moderate bittersweet flavor with a bitter bite at the end. A not bad hot weather cooler.

Draught in a flight at the brewpub under the name "Coastal Kolsch." Poured very clear and golden with almost no head on it. Nose had a lot of corn with some grains coming off it. Taste was actually quite crisp and nicely dry. Good drink.

Served in a tasting glass. Pours a clear golden color with minimal white head. Little aroma of fruits and some light malt. Interesting malt bitterness with some fruity notes to it. Mouthfeel is light but decent carbonation. Decent not great.
No Head, light golden color, bitting and bit too flavorful for this light style. Plenty of delicates fruits though.
On tap. Clear golden pour with a thin white head. Scent is grains. Taste is grassy and tart.

Served on draft at the brewpub. Listed under the "Coastal Kolsch" name. Pours a clear golden color with a thin white head. Poor head retention. Aroma of cereal grains with a faintly sweet finish. The taste is tart grains, green apple and grass. Medium bodied, low carbonation.

Mug at the brewery. Pours a light gold. Aroma is soft and a little fruity, surprisingly. A dash of papery hops is here. Flavor is super light but has that mild fruitiness like apples, some hops. This is a light beer for sure, but it’s clean and refreshing at least.

This is a popular beer at Front Street. The beer poured a clear yellow. It is a light bodied beer. The draft had nice head . The wheat malt gives it a unique taste. It is good everyday beer. Nothing special.

Good refreshing brew for a hot day. It pours a slightly hazy yellow with a short-lived fizzy head. The aroma is sweet, bready, and worty with a nicely balancing grassy bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. The balance experienced by the nose con tinues into the mouth, a touch of earthiness being added to the hops. Nice. Dark Lord Day 2007 at Three Floyds, Munster, IN, 4/28/2007.

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: On draft at the brewery 6/21/09. Light gold, grapfruit hops. Interesting light sweetness up front, then slow bitterness. Simple and very sessionable.

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: Tap @ Brewery: Clear gold, light head and lacing. Nose of light hops and pale malt, fragrant hoppy notes. Nice malt base and an explosive hoppy flavor. A decent light to medium body and clean. Spot on pilsner with the right amount of hops and not TOO much bitterness. Not traditional per se, but good!

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Crystal clear medium gold. Thin white rim. Mild biscuity nose. Medium, slightly still and watery. Apricotty finish, presumably from the hops. A little bit of flavor. Listed on the beer menu at the brewpub as a golden ale, not a pils. Quite a difference.

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: Correction: THis beer is not a Pilsner. The Golddigger is Silver City’s Golden Ale. Not a lager. Anyhow, It poured a very pils-esque body with a creamy white head. Biscuity, crisp but with less of the lager skunkiness as the kellerbier. Sessionable as hell!

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: On Tap at BrewPub. Pours out a light yellow. Topped with a white head. A nice little hop aroma for a pilsener. Not to bad o ya but not to great.

column1: Silver City Gold Digger Golden Ale
column5: Tap - Brewery A deep golden yellow color. This was the least of my favorite beers at this visit. The beer was light in flavor missing some key malts and was just lacking in flavor. Might be this was a fast batch and they just needed to go to tap before its time. Better luck next time.
Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Has strong hints of hops. Also has a creamy lactose taste from begining to end. Finishes smooth at first then has a small bitter bite in the end.
Pours a opaque dark brown with a beige head. Has hints of caramel, brown sugar, and hops. Finishes medium bodied with a smooth bitter taste from start to finish.
Pyha - den var ikke god. Vandet og bitter smag. Den vil jeg holde mig langt fra... Ikke i nærheden af de oplevelser, som Samsø Bryghus ellers kan byde på...
Deep amber colour with an off white head. Malty, fruity and light caramel sweet aroma. Malty, bready flavor with a light alcohol sweet note.

Bottle. Copper-orange, clear body, with a beige head. The aroma is mostly sour and acidic, but there’s some apricot and caramel in the background. The flavor is also mostly sour, but it is slightly roasted as well. Thin to medium body, quite astringent. Sour finish with some fruits in the background. Why do they keep on tormenting us with these shitty beers? (070627)
Bottle. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, apricot. flavour is sour, fruit, apricot, caramel. Light infected beer.
Bottle. Hazy orange coloured with an off white head. Acidic aroma of fruits and vegetables. Acidic flavour of fruits with notes of caramel.

Bottled. An unclear amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of burnt caramel and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of burnt plastic combined wiht a light acidity and very light notes of cherries.

(Bottle 50 cl) Bottle # 98 of 590. Hazy, orangey brown with an off-white head. Lightly tart caramel aroma. Medium body with sweetish caramel and then a lightly tart finish. A classical infected Samsø - again. 290407
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a off-white head. Plastic, light sour, berries aroma and taste. Medium body with a light sour finish.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Loads of plastic, some sweetness and some berries in the aroma. Flavour is quite sweet and is dominated by some infected burned berries. Sounds good? Well it isn’t! Is quite thin bodied. Is grapish and sour in the end. These beers are totally not good. One could wonder who buys these beers apart from beerchaser and beercolecters. The only good thing about this beer is, that the brewer has turned 50. One could wish, that he will go into ealy retirement at about 60, leaving us with only 10 years of pain.

Bottle. Average fizzy beige head that mostly diminished. Spar lacing. Hazy mahogany color. Aroma was fruit, caramel and light berry notes. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation. Flavor was sweet with some sour notes?. Finish was sweet with again some sour notes?
Hazy amber colour with an off white head. Malty, light caramel and fruity sweet aroma with a vague hoppy note. Malty, sweet flavor with caramel and fruity notes. Light dry and hoppy finish.

Bottle. Golden-orange, a bit unclear pour, with a nice, off-white head. That was the nice thing about the beer. It has the typical infected Samsø house character, quite fruity-acidic and sour, with a little touch of caramel. Sour and acidic flavor, astringent mouthfeel, and a finish with some hops. I am pretty amazed with the fact that the beers just continue to flow out of the brewery in this condition. Can’t someone teach them some QC? (070625)
Bottle. Amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sour, caramel, malt. Flavour is sour, caramel, malt, hop, fruit. Ordinary beer, but lightly infected.
Bottle. Cloudy amber coloured with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, fruits and hops. Flavour of fruits, caramel, spices and hops.

Bottled. An unclear orange beer with a light orange head. The aroma is of burnt malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of burnt plastic mixing in with notes of caramel, and the body is thin.

(Bottle 50 cl) Hazy, amber golden with an off-white head. Sourish caramel aroma. Medium body with notes of caramel and a fruity tartness. Classical Samsø = lightly infected. Also has a buttery note. 290407
Bottle. Muddy orange colour with a medium off-white head. Dusty malt, light caramel, plastic aroma and a sweet dusty light caramel malt taste. Medium body with a light dry finish.

Bottle. Average fizzy white head that mostly lasted. Fair lacing. Hazy amber color. Aroma was honey, caramel and fruit. Something synthetic in the aroma, maybe with masberg calls burned plastic. Light bodied with somewhat of a thin texture. Flavor was light sweet with what appears to be light sour notes as well? Sweet and again light sour finish.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Light burnt plastic aroma, which seems to be quite normal for this brewery. Has light fruity notes. Flavour of fruits and sweetness. Again the plastic is notable. Light bodied. The plastic follow thru the beer all to the end. This IMO is light infected. Read the description. Its hillarious. "He was allowed to use the few products left in the store, and it became a Wiener"!!!

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Sampled at the brewery. Pours a lightly hazed golden amber with a thin-moderate linen white head. Pleasant aroma of citrus along with some notes of sweet malt. The flavor begins with some lightly sweet malt followed by some grassy hops. Mild-moderate hops bitterness at the finish. Medium bodied. This is a nice solid English IPA.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Good but not outstanding IPA has a nice bitterness to the flavor but this beer is what it is and is nothing to write home about

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Small growler fill from the fine folks at Chatham. Pours a hazy medium brown. Still, no head. Caramel and old hops, cheesy and weird. Somewhat gross potpourri flavors, and stale cheese curls. Skunky, empty, bitter. Had to spit this one out.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: A very fine IPA right here. Fairly well balanced with a strong kick of hops at the tail end. Pretty bitter, medium body, leaves a bit of an aftertaste. Not mindblowing, but very solid, I’d look for it again.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: growler-pours a light tan ring for a head and amber/copper color. Aroma is earthy/funky. Taste is smoke, light/medium malt-caramel, earthy hops. Interesting, smoky/English IPA. Will look for this again as the brewery seasons.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: growler courtesy of jcwattsrugger. Pours copper with thin white head. Aroma is hoppy, thin lemongrass nose. Flavor, had some light smoke elements, malts, some citrus hops with a bitter finish and some spicy hops. Overall finish had notes of oxidation.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Growler courtesy of jcwattsrugger. Pours clear copper with gold edges and thin white head. The aroma is malt sweet with a bit of roast moving into spicy, earthy and a bit grassy. The flavor is sweet with malts, bitter hops from a thick layer of spicy and earthy hop leafs. It picks up a pleasing modest level of malty sweetness into the finish.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Amber with no head to speak of. Little to no aroma. Tastes old, oxidized, dirty and there is no carbonation. Slight hop/astringent aftertaste.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: Tried at NY TAP festival. Not a big IPA in any sense of the word, but cleanly made, and satisfying. If you have friends that you’re trying to get on the IPA bandwagon, this is a good entry-level ale.

column1: Chatham India Pale Ale (2012 and earlier)
column5: On tap @ Coles in Buffalo NY. Not a bad IPA but seems a tad jumbeled & not very balanced. The elements for a good IPA are there but IMO just needs some more trial & error. Pours a slightly murky amber orange. Aroma is caramel malts sweetness with some hop aroma in the background. Taste has nice hop bitterness upfront followed by some maltiness that could use some more cohesion.I expect that this will get better as the brewery grows

Poured into a becher pint glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt orange to amber color with a sly crispy looking ruddy lace after a thin white foamy head dissipated. The aroma held a semi-burnt sly caramel to bready malt, slightly grassy in the hoppiness, somewhat bitter and pushing the hops to be forward but mostly staying in the background. The flavor lends to the hand of semi-sweet to a crisp subtle bitter. Keeping that malt mainly wanting a sly sweet, but really bready. Aftertaste of some nuts and caramel and toffee. Crisp sweet to toasty and roasty sort of finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Moderate carbonation. Overall, good amber ale for the most part that I could come back to.
Draft at dive 75. Pours a deep dark amber color. Light on the palate. Easy drinking malty flavor.

Sample at the brewery. Pours a hazy medium amber with a moderate off-white head. Mild aroma of caramel and malt. The flavor is caramel and malt. Mild-moderate bitterness at the finish. Medium bodied. Nice solid ale.

Small growler fill from the fine folks at Chatham. Pours a hazy brown with a thin white head. Empty mostly with a light malt and a very small touch of hops. Thin and malty. Decent. Malty bitterness on the end, tastes a bit old, but drinkable.

Woo hoo, 1st rater! Growler from Spotty Dog. Pours a very murky, deep dark amber color, almost dark red cherry colored. Cannot see through it. Thats basically where my appeal ended with this beer. It was not bad, no off flavors, no faults. My issue is it was just bland and blasé. The OG seemed to be a bit high and masked the hops and yet the malts come off watery as well. I could see this beer getting better as the brewers keep messing around with it.

Poured into a nonic pint glass, the appearance was a dark brown color with a finger’s worth of creamy colored head. Sly messy lacing. The aroma had some sweet to roasty coffee almost espresso bean-esque quality. Subtle vanilla wafers. Robust cocoa beans trickle in. The flavor blends all of the previously mentioned aromas together with a nice semi-earthy backup. Crisp wafers-ish to coffee roastiness hits the aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt good. Overall, very nicely done porter that I would have again.
This is a damn perfect porter. Sad to hear they are resting it until the fall, I’m grabbing every can I see to enjoy for as long as I can.
Draft at Aroma Thyme. Super Porter! Roasty malts, a bit of hop nip, espresso, some marshmallow sweetness. Wasnt expecting it to be this good - cheers, Chatham.
Pours cola brown with creamy off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and milk. Roasted malt flavor with milk chocolate backbone and hint of coffee. Really great porter.

Roasted malt aroma with a slight sweetness. Taste is roasted malt and almost has a milk stout smoothness. Very full flavored, nice stout. It is really good. No smokey flavors really just roasted malt and seems like lactose is in there. Full flavored, smooth, easy drinking Porter with lots of body. I really like this one!! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
