While every brewery is trying to re-invent the wheel, Chatham Brewing tends to stick to classic styles brewed using traditional recipes. Their porter is a good example of this: a solid, to-spec, porter that has plenty of flavor and is easy to drink. That’s what I consider a good beer. I poured a 16oz growler into a tulip glass. Appearance: Pitch black in color with just the faintest brownish/red highlights. Pours to a two-finger, brown, frothy head which retains and laces well. Smell: Sweet dark malts with notes of toast, milk chocolate and dairy. Taste: Porters aren’t intended to be exploding with flavor, they’re meant to be flavorful, easy-drinking beers, and that’s what you get with Chatham Porter. Up front there’s a sweetness derived from the dark malt; notes of milk chocolate, cherry, and a sweetness akin to lactose (though this is not brewed with lactose sugar as far as I know). It has almost a cola flavor, as well (Dr. Pepper to be exact). The roasted malt comes alive on the back end, while the hops lurk in the background throughout. An interesting, classic palette anyone can enjoy. Drinkability: Weighing in at 6% ABV, Chatham Porter is a little heavy for the style. Though it’s in no way a thick, heavy beer per se. The mouthfeel is thinner than you’d think, with a silky texture and ridiculously smooth finish. There’s a mild dry aftertaste from the dark malt, though it’s easily tolerated. A versatile palette – this beer will pair with a savory meal or dessert (or as dessert).
Draft at dive 75 NYC. Pours a dark black color with a malty easy drinking texture. Lighter them it looks. I enjoyed it

A - Pours a pretty dark black color with a finger of frothy tan-brown head. The head faded down to a ring around the glass lacing nicely. S - Aroma is a blend of roasted chocolate and coffee scents. A tiny bit of smoke and hop are also in noticeable in the background. T - Starts off with some roasted malt flavor and some sweet chocolate. Through the middle some deeper and richer coffee and chocolate flavors come through. The finish is a mix of roasted chocolate and coffee with just a hint of hops that lingers nicely. M - Medium bodied with moderate-low carbonation. Feels smooth and a touch creamy. Finish a touch dry and fairly clean which is very nice. D - Very drinkable. Nice coffee and chocolate flavors throughout. Well balanced and just enough creaminess. Really nice lingering flavors after the finish.

Tap at Dive Bar. Poured a deep dark brown with a bug beige head. Nose is light with roasted malts and chocolate ringing through. A nice medium bodied porter. Nice chocolate notes with nice malt backbone. Solid and easy to drink. Had it right after an anchor porter and it really held up well. Nice brew
Smells great - roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste is similar, but it has a fairly light body for a porter. Taste fades away pretty quickly. Not bad, but not the best.

column1: Ohyama (Big Mountain) Tokubetsu Junmai Nigori Sake
column5: 500mL bottle shared at Oishii in Boston, on 4/21/07 Very interesting appearance; it’s not all that cloudy and dosent show a thick, white, milky sediment, but rather a very finely ground up residue, leading to a more diaphanous robe of opal. Still some clarity on the edges, actually. Very light film of bubbles on the surface and excellent legs left behind. Semi-sweet nose is more spicy and citric than I have ever seen from a nigori. Not all the rich, chewy coconut/pina-colada notes (though inevitably, there is still some of it). Perfume and passion fruit, with a dry, almost tangerine-like fruitiness and lemon seed acidity. Soft vanilla blossom and very minimal honey notes arrive on the finish, which is dotted with white pepper and carries a good strength to it. Alcohol very well masked for its strength (listed between 14 and 14.9%). Very refined and has completely redefined the style for me. It seems a nigori dosent have to be blatant or forceful in its display of unfiltered qualities and this one is very close to any other high quality, filtered sake. The flavor follows suit, with a soft mouthfeel, that, importantly, isnt thick and chewy, but rather more fluid and full. Pineapple, tangerine, passion fruit and light melon sit on the palate, with some light vanilla and moderate acidity for a finish. Surprisingly floral and delicate for its unfiltered nature. Very well concealed alcohol. Delicious stuff.

Bottled. Clear pale golden colour, medium white head, fair durablity. Malty aromas with some bread and herbal hops. Taste of breadcrumb, honey and grassy hop bitterness. Light body, moderate carbonation, crispy texture, decent bitter finish. Not bad.
# 429; 9/2016. Nepříliš povedený český ležák. Vůně i chuť zvláštně kvasnicová, sklepová. Chuť plnější, kořenitá, mírně sladová a maltózová. V dochuti navíc zeleninové tóny.
4 days after 'best before'. Golden colour, rocky head that does not stay too long. Aroma is lots of malt, grassy hops. Medium bitterness, a bit harsh, medium sweetness. Decent.
0.5 l bottle and tap as well. Pours deep golden with minimal head. A: sweet malty T: low crispy, almost to caramely, medium body, minimal bitterness,
Ocena z pamięci w celu uzupełnienia profilu. Degustacja przed założeniem konta na RateBeer.
Vycap dá Vinci. Vôňa chmelova leziakova. Farba zlatista. Chuť leziakova chmelova.

On tap at Prague Beer Museum. Shared with Marko! Clear pale golden, small lasting off-white head. Strong aroma breaking through, like candy, green apple and butter combined. Aroma is grainy, green apple again, astringent. Light body, dry finish, some carbonation. Not very good.

Tap at Prague Beer Museum with Hrabren. Full golden body, clear white head. White bread, doughy aroma, vague diacetyl maybe, not brilliant. White bread dough, mildly sweetish and smooth, lean body, herbal hops mildly there, mildly corky. Quite drying finish.
Slušný ležák s typickým karamelovým aromatem, příjemnou sladovou chutí s hořkostí chmelů, vyšším řízem, středním tělem a klasickou ležáckou pěnou.
Maślane, do tego mocno słodowe, podparte solidną "żatecką" goryczką. Wad nie stwierdzono, pije się świetnie.

750mL Bottle. Thanks for sharing, Chas! Dry, peppery aroma backed with a little reduced apple juice and lots of minerals. Flavors quickly open with a whole lot of natural apple funk. Earth, white pepper, dust, ethyl acetate, and other wooly creatures. There’s a light snap of acidity and a good sparkle. Personally, I don’t care for the taste of apples fermented with their own yeast, as it gets a little too tape and foot tasting, but I appreciate the quality of this one and the underlying apples. I think it’s a good example of a rustic, mousy natural cider.
From notes. Gold. White soda-like carbonation. Nice balance of acid, sweet, and musty earth. Crisp, dry finish. Medium body, slightly juicy, slightly soda-like. Nice cider.
Thanx to Cheeseman for sharing this.Poured like apple juice with a nice apple sweetness nose.Flavor was ceisp apple juice that was we crbonated.This inised off slightly art.
Deep gold with a quickly dissapating white head. Aroma is sweet red apples with a light tartness. Taste is reasonably tart, with light apple and heavy carbonation.

750ml bottle from Porterhouse; Nose of dark red apples with a light tart note; clear dark gold with a huge four finger head that quickly disapates to a quarter inch then lasts; flavor is tart apples with an acidic note; very dry and tart.
Yellow with a slight chill haze. Fresh, appley nose with a slight leathery accent. Bone dry, with a faint fruitiness.

shared by thecheeseman: pours a great filtered apple juice colour with a very small white head. aroma is a fantastic clear cider aroam good floral aroma almost like smelling fresh apple blossom and some vanilla. flavour is very upfront with a good clean apple, some acidity that plays on the tongue very good dry finish, great palate. thanks cheesman

Courtesy TheCheeseMan. Clear light yellow color, loose white foam top. Crisp, fresh cut apples, light spice, slight alcohol. Refreshing light taste, lasting crisp, tart finish. Alcohol very well-hidden.

Merritt Island Throwdown, thanks CheeseMan! Warm honey color with nice foamy white head. Astringent nose of apple brandy, chardonnay, biscuity. Fizzy, thin palate. Dry apple skin and seed flavors. Nice tartness.

Maybe my cider-philia is getting the better of me. Pours a crystalline golden yellow, with a steady bead coming forth. The aroma is sweet apples, yeast, floral notes. The flavor is glorious, crisp, acidic and direct. The apples are the star here, but this cider finishes very dry, with the essence of green apples, hitting you at the end. Amazingly, the 10% alcohol is virtually non-existent in the flavor, this is an awesome cider.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle shared by Tmoney99, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are citrus, pale and sweet malts.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: Draft - pours orange white head - nose/taste of pine, orange peel, sweet caramel - med body

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: Draft - Nondescript hops and sweetness. Clearish gold with a rich white head. Sweet and malty with sticky citrus hops.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Rooster Fish. Amazing aroma of tropical fruit. Awesome. Taste is rich with resin, fruit, pine, with a good bittersweet balance. Very good. Right up my alley.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: From bomber bottle, 8% ABV listed. Burnt orange pour with semi-creamy khaki colored head and lacing. Hop oils/resin in the nose, along with some pine and grapefruit pith. Sweetish malt backbone helps balance everything out. Very enjoyable.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: A hazed reddish amber DIPA with a thick frothy mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity caramel malt with grassy hops, light vinous character, nice. In mouth, oxidized vinous malt with treacle, light surranated hops, light mineral notes, OK but tired.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: Found some old rating notes from TapNY 2013 that somehow never got entered. (I’m keeping this a little shorter than my normal rating style to help catch-up my backlog a little faster.) I thought this was a pretty nice DIPA. It has a plenty of hop bitterness. Fruity hops. Some caramel malt flavors are here too. Pretty nice mouthfeel as well.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: It is rare that I try a IIPA that I dislike... This came close. Mostly sweet big malt and bitter finish. I didn’t get a very powerful aroma or hop flavor. I wish there was more here, I really wanted to like it.

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: Draft @ J. Ryan’s. red color with great head retention. Nose is light citrus hops and caramel malt. Taste is a strong amount of pine hops with caramel backbone with a hint of Earthy malt. Body is medium with a moderate lingering bitterness. More like a standard IPA, then DIPA. Ok

column1: Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA
column2: Watkins Glen, New York, United States
column5: I poured a 22oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 4/13/13 making it less than three weeks old. Appearance: Extremely hazy but translucent shade of burnt umber/dark orange/cherry red. Forms a small, off-white, foamy head which leaves some lacing and never completely evaporates. Smell: Extremely earthy aroma of tree bark, pine cones and grass but also a subtle fruit juice concentrate scent as well. Taste: I hate to criticize an up-and-coming brewery since we beer nerds are supposed to support the little guys, but if a beer is not good I’m not going to lie about it. And while Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA is far from abysmal, the fact remains it’s just not a good beer. The reason this beer fails for me is twofold: a complete lack of hops; and a base malt flavor of burnt peanut brittle. Though it’s quite hoppy to the nose, there’s little actual bitterness to be found here. This is especially disappointing considering the label indicates an IBU rating of "100+". There’s a mild sweetness throughout the first half of the palette. It’s a general earthy flavor but without anything particularly distinctive. The finish imparts an off taste akin to licking a pine cone. Sure, some hops can have a piney taste to them, but this doesn’t seem right. The aftertaste is akin to burnt sugar, or maybe even sorghum. I don’t really know what this beer is supposed to be, but basing an entire DIPA around the Warrior hop doesn’t seem to work. Drinkability: Though I didn’t much care for the taste, I have to admit Rooster Fish Hop Warrior Imperial IPA was surprisingly drinkable at first. The body seems to be undercarbonated, creating for a thin, slightly flat mouthfeel. This makes it easy to drink, but once it warms the aftertaste becomes dry and bitter. At 8% ABV it’s inefficient, though I could probably throw back the entire bottle myself easily.

0,33l Flasche. Bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Riecht brotig malzig mit einer Note nach Citrus. Im Geschmack angenehm malzig mit einer Note nach Caramel. Im Nachgeschmack kommt ein wenig erfrischende Citrusfrucht durch. LECKER!!
* Old rating, 0,33l bottle, best before 03.2011. Malzig-süßliches Bier. Erstaunlich vollmundig für die 4,4%. Leicht herb-würzig im Nachgeschmack, mild-weich. Lecker!
0,33 l swing top bottle BB 01/2014 Dark golden color ,clear, frothy, white foam, bread, cereal, citrus, herbs, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation,
Fløska. Clear amber. Sweet caramel malty grainy aroma. Thin mouthfeel. Sweet caramel grainy flavour with malt and grass.

Clear amber with a large off white head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, caramel and breadish notes. Sweet flavour had toasted malt, caramel, nuts, grassy hops and breadish notes. Finished dry and bitter.

33 cL bottle, courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is flat malty, light roasted and slight grassy. Sweet and flat malty flavoured. Subdued bitter and roasted finish with a vague bitterness.

It’s dark golden with a huge, creamy head. While still cold it’s rather fruity hoppy, but quickly it becomes more malty and has hints of candy sugar. The flavor is moderately sweet with notes of malt, candy sugar, light fruity hops and citrus in the slightly dry finish.

Bottle 33cl. w. swing top. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, sweet, honey ! light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, and a light dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090626]

Bottle, 4.4%. Malty aroma, seems a little oxidized. Clear dark golden colour. The flavour is quite malty, a little caramelly, perhaps from oxidation. Not a problem, though. Medium bitterness with an unexpected baking yeast finish.

Bottle. Thanks pivnizub. Spicy honey aroma. Dark hazy amber, golden cream. Grainy, light papery malt base, a few spicy toasted and herbal edges - somewhat in a mismatch. Fairly dry finish, medium body,. Light aromatic hops retronasal.

Cloudy Amber Color with Brown Hues. White Skin. Subtle Aroma. Clean Malts, Very Mild, Light Hop Bitterness. Musty Dry Malt Aftertaste. Basically a Mild with a Pinch of Hop Flavor. Very Smooth with Nice Flavor but Subtle Malt Taste.

Light Amber Color with White Ring. Subtle Malt Aroma. Clean and Malty. Similiar to Free Democracy Ale, but With Hints of Spice...Pepper Notably. Like a Pepper Flavored Vodka Was Added. Nice and Light..Very Little Yeast Notes. Nice Light Drinker.

Gold Color with Off White Head. Subtle Malt Aroma. Taste is a Nice Light Beer Balance. Crisp Taste, Light Bodied... Sweet Musty Malts, Some Sweet Grain, Crisp Clean Aftertaste. Really Solid Summer Brew.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: Some honey and orange and some other sweetness. Some odd bitterness. Different and not in a great way. Better warm.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: Draft. light orange white head. disapointing robotrip overripe fruit. mild wood. eh.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: Draft at HDG for daze of the Devil II. Pours a hazy orange with a small off white head. Aromas of grains, and bread with a very light touch of hops. Flavors of citrus, alcohol and bread. Man do I like good barley wines, to bad this isn’t one.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: Poured a murky brown gold color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of light floral hops, pils malt, some pine, citrus, toffee, and a bit of toasted dough. Taste was woody, with some vanilla, honey, light cherry, and alcohol in the finish.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Hop Devil Grill. Admittedly it wasn’t a fantastic or authentic version of the style; however I found it pretty tasty. Flavor had some interesting elements to it. Some sweetness and honey. Pretty decent version.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: On tap at HDG. Gold with decent head retention. Flavor is on the fruity side with some pineapple and a strong medicinal flavor. My barleywine blows this away. Seriously, I hear this guy can really brew, so I hope the dubbel is much better.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: Tap at Hop Devil Grill. Pale amber-orange beer with no head. Chewy and sweet on the aroma with loads of orange blossom honey and some citrus fruitiness. Extremely sweet and cloying with loads of orange peel and honey. It’s really more like a sweet mead than a barely wine but not a great example of either. Fatty and underattenuated. Bleh.

column2: Lake Placid, New York, United States
column5: My Bottom Line: Humble base malt flavors are swimming in alcohol, as scattered hop vests are thrown around to attempt salvaging them. This is a cleanly-brewed, but highly soporific blond Barley Wine. Further Personal Perceptions: -There is no foam to be seen atop the hazy blond. -This is nearly scentless, aside from some honey and alcohol sharpness. -Another Great Adirondack strong ale I just can’t get into. -Some citrusy, wooden hop presence appears when looked for. -It definitely lacks malt development and hop definition to be worthy of a thumbs up within this broad style. -Some milkiness is found in the nose. On tap at Tap NY.

Appearance: light golden, clear, a lot of carbonation, two fingers creamy and dense white head. Aroma: malt, alcohol, marc, cereals. Hints of detergent and wet cardboard. Taste: sweetish, sweet malt, bread, traces fof honey. Very subtile alcohol taste. Aftertaste: weak, sweetish, cereals, alcohol, bread, yeast.
Bottle from my mom as a gift from her holiday in Nepal. Golden color, white head. Malty, Grassy, bit à bad strong lager
Bottle. Slightly hazy golden color with a thin off-white head. Mild aroma of malt water. Sweet, malty taste. Sticky feel. Medium body.
Country #74: Golden beer, small head. Aroma is malt, grain, sweet. Taste is the same, refreshing and not that pad, standard pale lager.
Aroma is quite malty. Taste is largely sweet malt with some vegetal notes. We’re just here for the tick, kids.

Bottle 33cl. @restaurant Annapurna, Castricum, poured into Nepal Ice lager glass. Clear pale golden, small frothy wite head, mostly diminishing, light lacing; aroma malty, grainy; taste medium sweet and light bitter, light malty, bit hoppy; sweetbitter aftertaste, spicy hints; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation; not bad.

Bottle at the Nepalese joint next to Bungalow. Pale gold with a tall, airy head, high carbonation. Light citrus nose, plain malts. sweet and malty, approaching an Export in style. Low hops, some lemon and grass. Nothing special, but not bad.
Bottle at my local Nepalese place. Corn and syrup on the nose. Sweet and slightly grainy on the palate. Sweet and kind of plastic-like on the finish. Yuck.

330 ML bottle My bottle is 5% ABV Clear straw yellow. Bright white head that had to be worked. Otherwise a thin collar. Some lacing strips. Nose is sweet grain, sweet corn, lots of sugar, kid of cidery in a way. Not very hopeful on this with the nose. Taste is really sweet. Sweet stewed corn and stalks, sweet grain, some green apple, wet sugary lettuce. Some apple cider notes. Not good at all based on that fault. Slick and sweet in mouth. Goes down like a lump. Not good at all.

330ml bottle into glass. Sweet malt nose. Slightly cloudy yellow with the odd bubble. Two finger white head. Chalky flat mouthfeel. Sweet bubblegum finish, some pepper lurking. A bit of tin late on. Strange mixture of flavours. Not to be repeated.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: This is quite possible one of the worst barleywines I have had. sweet and metallic with a lot of odd bitterness and dirt. Wet dog and rotting moss.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: This didnt really taste like a true Barley Wine when I had it. Wasn’t on the menu anymore, but they had it. Odd color for a barley wine as well.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: complex, layered. drnks like a wine. a little highb in alcahol content, hot

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: My Bottom Line: This hop-happy Barley Wine lathers the tongue with leafy and earthy hop flavors which lead to a sharp and slightly astringent finishing bitterness. The thin body points towards an Imperial Pale Ale, or something of the sort, but its unidirectionality and lack of malt depth remain its downfall for me. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam protects the cloudy pale orange hues. -Wet leaves and citrus fruit tickle the nose. -The prickly carbonation is too strong for the feeble maltiness. -Tasted blind, one could think this were a monstrously hopped APA. -Alcohol was shy, but present. -Their Imperial IPA was so much better that day. On tap at Tap NY.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Fles 65cl thuis. Waterig, vreemd soort kruidig bittertje, beetje grassig/hooi. (4-2014).

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: bottle @ home gold clear, minimal white head cereals, corn, watery, some corn and sweet malts, light hoppyness

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: 650ml bottle [Thanks Steffi!]. Clear, yellow-ish, deep golden colour with small to average, thick, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Grainy, minimally bready and strawy aroma, a dusty touc, hints of banana peel. Taste is minimally sweet grainy and strawy, hints of banana peel and dried banana, grassy hoppy overtones; fades to a slightly watery and minimally metallic finish.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: from iiinee. bottled 650ml. after christmas finnish craft water tastes more than this. like nothing.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Cudów się nie spodziewałem, ale w sumie nie było tak źle ;) Bursztynowy kolor, z ładną, puszystą białą pianą! Aromat mocno słodowy, z lekkim karmelem i metaliczną końcówką. W smaku - typowy lager i to nie taki najgorszy! Oprócz lekkiego metalu, nie dostrzegłem poważniejszych wad. Dość neutralny w smaku, właściwie bez goryczki, za to lekko słodkawy. Nie ma powodów do wstydu!

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Snagged a 650ml bottle of this in Kathmandu. Pours a clear gold with lots of creamy, lacing, white head. Nose has a lot of apple cider, lemon, grass, some a little bit of white flour. Flavor is a little better, more apple cider, grass, straw, mild grain. Watery finish.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Bottle 650ml @ My parents Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, floral, caramel and a faint hint of butterscotch. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is light to medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Tasted on our trip to Nepal. Didnt realize beers would be 750ml, so this will be a good night. This has more flavor than the gorkha but I definitely prefer the gorkha. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: Bu lors d’un voyage a Kathmandou. Bière pale dorée, très légère mousse. Nez malté et céréales. Gout malté doux en fin de bouche. C apasse.

column1: Everest Premium Lager Special Limited Edition
column5: For me the best popular Nepali lager. Has some notes of typical Nepali spice, which makes it different.
water.... well w/ some terrible taste in it I’m not sure what lingonberry is supposed to be but if it’s bad this has it.
Pale yellow color with faint lingonberry in the nose. Crisp bready body with no lingonberry taste in the beer. On tap at the Eau Clair location

Fresh, on tap at the Eau Claire, WI brewpub location. Pours a pale light yellowish gold with a lot of carbonation and a small fast dissolving white head. Some spotty lacing. This beverage does not have the deep red color of real linonberries but may have just the juice and no skins added. Very faint aroma of light corn/barley malt, some citrus, and a hint of tart Regal variety lingonberries. Taste is light, a little watery, crisp and very carbonated. Finish is a bit watery and soft white bready. Could use a little more Lingonberry tartness but a nice 105 + degree lawnmower beer.
On tap at the Chetek location. Light coppor color with faint hop nose. Crisp flavor with light malts and very faint hops; watery.

On tap at both Chetek and Eau Claire, WI brewpub locations. Pours a light penny copper brew with a barely thin white head. Hardly any lacing. Aroma is a clean glass, maybe a hint of malt but no hops. Nothing more. Darn, we tried to get a whiff of something of ten to eleven minutes of trying. We even tried it outside on the Chetek tavern porch to get something. We could smell only the white pines off Pokegama Lake but no hops in the beer. We simply gave up. Taste is highly carbonated, very watery and a little malt taste. Finish is clean with nothing to remember the beer by. Nice try but hopefully next year’s batch could maybe have some hops added.

On tap at The Winking Judge in Hamilton,ON- Pale sparkling gold with a frothy white cap. Good creamy lace. The aroma is fruity and lightly laced with grass and malts with herbal nuances. Tastes like sweet malty candy with good fruit and hops bitterness towards the end. Hay and lemon dominate the finish. This is very light and also quite drinkable and refreshing. Well crafted.

TFOB 2007. Draft. Pale yellow with a small white head. Sweet, lightly yeasty aroma with muted grains. Sweet pale malt. Pleasant moderate bitterness with a light sweet fruitiness. Average palate. Fairly mainstream but well executed. Drinkable. 5-6/3/6/3/13

Draught sample at TFOB 2007. Light golden with a small white head. Aroma of bready malt and herbal hops. Crisp body, balanced flavour. Not much else to be said - just a well-made lager that doesn’t have a lot of character, but is refreshing enough to earn a pass.

Sampled at the Kitchener Craft Beer show. Taps a very pale golden colour, with little head. The aroma is a tad malty, some grassiness and bread. The taste is the same, a little grassy, but actually decent. I liked this one a lot more than the Confederation Ale. Yet the ale is so much more widely distributed, go figure.

on tap: A very nice crisp tasting lager. Beautiful golden colour with a white head that leaves behind lacing. Nice hops/malty aroma. Easy drinking with a wonderful balance of fine malts and hops. A good one.

On tap at the brewery A clear deep gold colored lager with a decent 2 finger tight pored cap that lasts and laces. Aromas of fresh bisquits and a floral-citrus tone from the Yakima valley hops Lovely smooth feel in the front with ample carapils malts to chew on, nice balance with the herbal-citrusy hops ...finishes clean with a biscuity snap and a nice hop bite. A very staple lager of the old pre-prohibition Canadian style. When fresh this is far better than Creemore....more malts more smooth finish...this is much like a smooth malty steam beer.

Had on Tap at Witlock’s on the beachs. Nice cleean crisp beer, very easy drinking but i actually enjoy this more then the ale. again a golden straw color, nice amount of white head with some lacing. slightly sweet flavour with some decent hops for the style. nice and refreshing

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: What I had was just labeled amber ale. This was the closest beer buddy would give me. It was a decent but basic Amber ale ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 5/11/2016. Pours clear medium orange/amber/light copper color with a 2 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, honey, brown sugar, toasted bread, light nuttiness, light citrus/apple fruitiness, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Okay aromas with some dark/bready malt, honey, and light earthy hop/fruity yeast notes; with decent strength. Taste of caramel, honey, brown sugar, toasted bread, light nuttiness, light citrus/apple fruitiness, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Minimal herbal/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel. honey, brown sugar, toasted bread, light nuttiness, herbal, grass, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Solid robustness and complexity of dark/bready malt, honey, and light earthy hop/fruity yeast flavors; with zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Minimal dryness. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and moderately creamy/bready/grainy mouthfeel that is good. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 5.5%. Slight diacetyl presence. Overall this is an okay amber ale. Decent robustness and complexity of dark/bready malt, honey, and light earthy hop/fruity yeast flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. This was pretty bland and needed more hop presence; but was fairly tasty and enjoyable otherwise.

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: Bottle. Clear copper color with a thin white head that quickly dissipated. Aroma was light malt with a strong caramel taste. A little metallic on the backend.

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours a clear copper color with fair head. Aroma of caramel, bit of grain and malt. Taste of caramel, honey and malt sweetness. Mild bitterness and a sweet finish. Moderate body, smooth and candy sweetness. Nice if you are into bubblegum.

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: I’ve never had a beer quite like this. I expected mild maltiness, but got medicinal and metallic.

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: Poured into a perfect pint. Says "ale with honey added" on label, so this might be a different listing. 3.25 A: Clear dark orange color. Two fingers of frothy off-white head. Retention is a touch below average and a short ring of lacing is left. 2.5 S: Light toastiness. Bland overall with a noticeable adjunct aroma hinting at rice. A touch of honey comes through, but only because the rest of the nose is so anemic. 2.0 T: Man this is bad. It’s has that sickening adjunct sweetness that I will never get used to. The residual honey only bolsters this flavor. Again light toastiness and maybe a touch of graininesss. 2.5 M: Lighter body. Too much carbonation. Could be creaminess. Finish leaves a horrible sweet aftertaste. 1.75 D: This beer is ass. Don’t buy it. Avoid it at all costs. ★ 792 characters DavoleBomb, Aug 18, 2013

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: Upon pouring this beer, I immediately knew I was in trouble. It just SOUNDED like it was going to be a crappy beer. The "head" was fizzing rapidly, as if it couldn’t wait to disappear as quickly as possible. It was reminiscent of finding that 2-liter bottle of cola that’s been sitting in your fridge for weeks because no one wanted the last half glass of flat soda pop. I got screwed when I wanted a frothy beverage then, and I got screwed now with this sorry excuse for an amber ale. The carbonation evanesced faster than the talent level of a Miami Marlins roster after winning the World Series. The aroma was no better. It smelled like your hand after holding a pocketful of arcade tokens. As for the taste--does "fallacy" count as a taste? Besides being flat and listless, this "copper" colored ale tasted like it was brewed with pre-1982 pennies. I’ve never actually drank anything brewed with pre-1982 pennies (or post- for that matter), but I think I accurately likened the taste. This beer is brewed in Rochester, New York. I was in Georgia when I found it. It was probably delivered via backroads in an open bed truck, with the sun pounding away at the uncovered bottles the entire time. This entire Tap Room No. 21 series should be put in a crate Raiders-of-the-Lost-Ark-style--not because it’s a relic, but because it should be hidden away so the general public never sees it again.

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: Not a good Amber. Has a medicine aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Tap Room No. 21 Moe's Backroom Amber Ale
column5: 12 oz.bottle into pint glass. Pours clear. Toasted and malty aroma. Taste sweet. Average beer.

On tap at the Blue Moon McMenamins. Pours dark mahogany with a strong tan head. Very sweet aroma and flavor with a bit of hops to try to balance, but stayed sweet through the finish. Although you could taste the alcohol, it wasn’t overpowering, only minor excess alochol hints in the finish. Caramel flavors mixed with a light toasted bready flavor combine with citrus hops.

Cloudy amber pour with a thin offwhite head. Nice aroma of citrusy, resinous hops. Good flavor of citrusy, resinous hops with a bitter finish. The body is light to medium and slightly liquorous while the carbonation is moderate. Nicely done.

Very dark copper, hazy. A lacy off-white ring does not show much endurance over the liquid. Coniferous, piney pungent hops are the first noticeable aspects as you plunge your nose into the glass. The first sip therefore surprises with its important toasty maltiness that serves as the foundation. Lightly bready as well, but really focused on toast malt flavours. The hop importance grows and grows by the sip, reaching out towards earthiness and saltiness in the hoppy finale. Certainly not refreshing, but a pleasant hop discourse.

En fût. Verre de 20 oz dégusté au Broadway (Shawinigan, QC). Arôme: Odeur d’houblons résineux avec une pointe de pamplemousse. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’houblons résineux avec une pointe de caramel. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère amertume en arrière goût. (Rating #2013)

My Bottom Line: Resinous hops readily bloom onto the chocolate and caramel maltiness of this levelled Double IPA, an inspiring landscape which rolls away into the sustained bitterness of verdant greenery and its fresh earth. Further Personal Perceptions: -A slice of foam decorates the dark orange-red. -The soft tingling of carbonation is perfect for the suave body. -The hoppiness is redolent of Cascade and Simcoe varieties. -The flavor profile is balanced in its intensity. -Strawberries seem to grow from the caramel malt base and the chosen yeast. On tap at Broadway Pub, Shawinigan.
Aroma:Pine and grapefruit hops... apperance:Clear orange amber,good head.. Flavor:strong bitterness,grapefruit and pine,light caramel...

Cask (as Davenport Kerfuffle)@Beerd, Bristol. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, floral, wooden and a bit herbal. Flavour is fruity, nectary, tropical fruity and also has soem sweet maltyness.
Cask at the Assembly Rooms (JDW), Solihull as Davenports Kerfuffle at 4.7% ABV. Amber with a dense cream head; weak honey aroma; some citrus flavour and a wheaty body; lacking finish. Not good.
[CASK: Smugglers Den, Morecambe, Lancs 09/09/06] A deliciouse ale, very good taste and a real treat. Very pleasant and a good % to top it all off. Nice, Very Nice! Highly recommended.

It poured a clear yellow color with a small white head. The aroma was of straw, bread, spicy hops and light citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. The taste was of straw, bread, earthiness and spicy hops with a crisp dry finish.
Clear dark straw. Smooth. Slight creamy. Pretty light with a nice hint of lasting bitter.
Pours gold with a decent white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavor is nice and malty with a dry hoppy finish. The best of their beers that I tried.
A very decent pilsner. A nice floral hoppy beer. Definitely their best beer. Much better unfiltered.

Easily the best offering from this brewer. Poured gold with a small head, great lacing on the glass. Aroma is initially floral hops, caramel malts, and a very slight citric hint. Flavor is also very floral, bitter rose hearts and mild cereal malts balance elegantly. Mouthfeel is quite full for the style, almost chewy. This may be the best example of this style I have ever had. Brilliant!

On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. Good Lord that’s an interesting Impy. Pours black with a yellow-ivory beige head. The solid creamy head leaves awesome lacing behind. Has a real smokestack aroma of roasted chocolate and lots of smoke. Chewey, thick palate. This beer really masks its high alcohol. This is tight, solid, and smooth.

Sampled at the Parkville Microbrewers Festival. Poured opaque black with a some light brown head. Both the aroma and flavor were like a cup of coffee with a decent amount of creamer in it. It drank pretty rich, and I didn’t think there was too much hop character. It was a nice beer, but it drank too much like a sweet/cream stout to rate among the good Imperial Stouts.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Bottled, 355ml from Beermerchants of Kent aged 3 years. Hazy gold with white head. There is quite an aggressive hopping to this from the off, resinous, sharp and full. Bitter orange, pithy citrus notes, assertive and bittering throughout. Sweaty, fleshy fruit notes. Decent and interesting beer.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Originally rated on 12/5/2009. Greeted by a nice citrus aroma as i opened the bottle,it pours a deep burnt cooper body with a thick massive head that left plenty of good lace. Aroma of pineapple, grapefruit, floral notes with a slight earthy hint. Flavor was a bitter blast with malts showing in the aftertaste, the taste was a little disappointing considering the nice aroma. Medium body and smooth going down, with a decent balance. Overall it was a fairly good beer.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Pours a deep dark orangish amber color. Aromas of big hop action, sweet malts, and more hops. Flavor has some bready maltsy tastes with nice grapefruit and floral hop taste.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: 12 oz bottle picked up at Blue Max in Burnsville, MN. Disappointed because this one has a best by date 06-12-15 and I missed it when purchased. Poured into Belgian snifter glass. Deep brandy, reddish orange color with a healthy off-white head. Nose is a little bit malty and caramel-like with a little bit of a pine hop resin undertone. Guessing this one was brighter and hoppier when fresh. Taste has a healthy dose of sweetness with citrus (mango, orange) coming through. Much more malty and bready than anticipated once again probably from the aging of the beer in the bottle. Alcohol is relatively well-hidden. Finish feels a little bit like a pine household cleaner. I’m going to try a fresher one and re-rate this one if applicable.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: 12 oz bottle. Pours a dark orange color and topped by a thick layer of off white foam that shows good retention. As the foam settles thick rings of lace coat the glass. The aroma shows note of citrus and pine hops, orange and grapefruit, and a toaster caramel and toffee malt base. The flavor follows with the orange and grapefruit citrus up front to go with the caramel and toffee malts. Citrus and pine hops provide ample bitterness with a hint of resin on the back end. Medium plus body and smooth with ample carbonation that leads to a bitter sweet finish. Solid and well balanced double ipa that doesn’t get overly sweet or bitter and the alcohol is well hidden.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Backlog from lost & found notes: The head on this was massive, it just wouldn’t quit. Hoppay aroma with flowers, grass, citrus and pine up front. Taste is pineapple, resins, mango but also a touch of yeast. Some alcohol in there also. I’m gonna find myself a fresher version and re-rate it, as I believe that there’s something fishy with this one, even if it was more than drinkable.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: First taste of Double-Wide had an over the top bitterness dominated by Magnum hops. Like the thick pillow of foam, the bitterness ’calmed down’ as I sampled. Strong resiny pine hops dominate. Citrus and caramel flavors were given a backseat. I enjoyed this offering from the ’new’ Boulevard, unsure if what I liked was what they intended beer drinkers to like.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Single bottle from HyVee, Ankeny, IA, March 2015. "Best by 06/12/15." Big grassy hop smell right under the cap. Foamy pour, slightly orange over a fine amber beer body. Unabashedly strong in alcohol, since I pick that up even before the hop load. And then there are the hops. Not as strong in any one hop character, but a combination of pine and resin, grassy fresh hop bitterness. I don’t catch all the fruits mentioned in the description, but I don’t have to. Actually has some balance for a Double IPA, and I hope I’m rating this higher than, say, a 90 Minute.

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: Poured from the bottle of a four pack, chunky dark orange with a big foamy white collar. Lots of hops in this double wide with some citrus, got the peach and apricot flavors mostly in the 3rd and 4th beer, but the part that impressed me most was that it has a whirlpool where hops are added. I only wonder if my palate is pedestrian, because I walk around the neighborhood quite a bit (usually drunk).

column1: Boulevard Smokestack Series: Double Wide I.P.A.
column5: (Bottle) Reddish amber colour with rocky, beige head, leaving traces of lacing. Malty, fruity nose with notes of citrus, caramel, orange peel, treacle-toffee, black-currant and pink grapefruit. Malty, fruity, hoppy taste with caramel, treacle-toffee, black-currant, citrus peel, grapefruit, lychee and a generous resiny/citric bitterness in the finish. Almost full body, with a certain sweetness. Solid and well made DIPA. Despite it’s strength and bitterness it’s not aggressive, instead it’s very well balanced. Another great beer from Boulevard. Excellent stuff!

Draught at the brewpub. Pours on the red side of black with lacy beige head. The aroma is roasty coffee and some toasted nuts. The flavor is dark-roast coffee with some grainy off notes. The finish is dry and slightly tannic. Noble effort, but not so great.

Draught. Fine black pour with some rubies on the edges and a nice tan head. The aroma is musty with a surprising hop character. I don’t mean like an IPA or anything, but there is a bit of pleasing brightness going on. Also scents of tree back, earth, coffee, and butter are noted. hm. Pretty tasty at first with adequate roast and a good chocolaty flavor. The finish is drying with acidic notes. Some diacetyl starts to come out but not too bad. It makes it tastes like cheap chocolate cake a little bit. It gets a little tougher toward the end of the glass as the buttery stickiness starts to accumulate. Still, not horrible, just not the best beer from this brewer.
Brown ale coloration. No read head. Sweet malty character. Sweet aroma. carbonated strong ale.

Draft at Shelbyville Road. Poured hazy copper with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus and sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Heavy bittersweet flavor with a heavy smooth bittersweet and small alcohol burn finish of long duration. A very good beer.

Pours dark golden amber with a mostly receding head. Aroma of grapefruit, sweet cookie and citrus, and mild note of earthy toffee. Taste is tangy and citric with earthy malt notes. Mouthfeel is full bodied and resinous with lush carbonation. Pretty nice IPA from the BBC.

clear orangish amber with a great white head that lasts forever and leaves great lacing. funky earthy caramel aroma with some juicy orange notes. nice balanced bittersweet orange light pine and caramel flavor with some light nutty notes. very nice. bitter finish. medium body. lively carbonation. probably the best beer i have seen come from BBC yet! very well done! This needs to be brewed all the time!

Draught at the brewpub. Pours copper with tight ivory head. The aroma is American hops, citrus, muffin-y malt, and some floral notes. The flavor is dry, citrus hops up front along with some earthy bitterness and burnt toast. Slight maltiness works its way into the middle before a dry, botanical finish with only some faint hints of alcohol and a hint of sugary sweetness.

draught. Pours a cloudy, hazy copper with a fluffy white head. The aroma is fully floral and honey sweet. It’s not too sharp, but delicate in its intricacies with suggestions of green peppers, fresh cut grass, herbal tea. Hey, this stuff is pretty tasty. It’s really clean which as we know, can be tough to pull off in this style. I’ve had a few other hoppy brews from here that haven’t been great, but this was really enjoyable. There is a strong green tea flavor with honey and a fruit bouquet like apples, grapefruit. The finish is plenty drying with pinier characteristics. Excellent balance all around and adequate cajones to boot. Mouthfeel is just slightly sticky and still enjoyable as I slurp down the last of the glass. It reminds me of a U.K. IPA in the malt department, but more of a U.S. hop profile. Nice work!

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Tap, gold pour, white head, nose is chai, taste is chai, interesting tea plus beer here

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: July 29th, 2014 - As I stood at the counter at Central Coast Brewing, an excited young man came up and straddled the seat to my left. As I waited, he eagerly ordered several bottles of the Chai Ale to go, and as I looked around, it seemed to my slightly tipsy eye that the Cream Ale’s logo and color scheme was the plurality eye-candy in the brewpub. This, then, appeared to be Central Coast’s poster brew, and I was excited to see why. A veritable sachet of spices lies in the aroma: clove, all-spice, cinnamon, brown sugar, and everything that makes chai chai. It smells intensely of chai, and could easily be mistaken for any other kind of chai themed beverage. As for the taste, the chai tastes are subtler. The blonde ale base takes the beginning, and then the chai swells up slowly until it dominates the aftertaste. The brew is spicy, and on a thinnish palate, it has a refreshing effect, but the tastes are...strange. I like chai, and I like beer, but while the two together are novel, it’s not something I’d be champing at the bit to get a second serving of. If you’re hunting new and quirky combinations and additions to your brews, though, this is a must try.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Bottle from backlog. Pours clear amber with a small fizzy off-white head that dissipates pretty quickly leaving some residual and lacing. Aroma is grain, spices, cinnamon, clove. Flavor is light sweet, burst of lemon, clove, bit of lemony tartness. Medium body, interesting, not necessarily good.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Pours a clear deep golden color with nearly no head at all. A white ring forms and clings to the edge of the glass where it joins with the beer. A very faint aroma of tart pear emerges from the glass. Mouthfeel is wet and smooth, yielding to some carbonation scrub, and finishing a little powdery. Very mild, blended flavors. Mild clove is noted. Lightly sweet and just as lightly tart. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy aroma. Fruity malty spicy creamy flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy creamy finish.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Clear golden pour with a white head. Slight tartness up front, but otherwise nice spice notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. Some bready sweetness, water, and a grassy undertone. The flavor is a bit watery, tart, and grassy. Some good spice flavors of cinnamon and nutmeg, but overall unimpressive.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery with my bro-in-law Mike. Great off-the-radar brewery. Was told by bartender this was their blonde ale with chai added during fermentation Nice cinnamin chai flavor. Creamy and light.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Bomber poured into a pint glass. Gold with a heart of orange and a fizzy cola-like off-white head. Aroma is sweet with obvious chai spices, vanilla, hay, candied citrus. Flavor is sweet as well, with a round honey malt base and a restrained chai spiciness that surprisingly doesn’t become overwhelming. At first the beer is on the cloying side but with a little warmth, some mild tea tannins come out and dry the palate without being too astringent. I wasn’t expecting much here but this beer is completely fine. The only flaw is it’s sweet and fizzy.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Bottle from Henry’s: Poured a sparkling golden liquid and had a fizzy short lived formation of foam. As for the aroma, I can definitely pick up on the scents of cream, green herbs, spices, and perhaps a light background of tea. The flavor is just as rewarding as the nose led me to believe because of the touches of herbs, tea, and spicing as well as a delicate usage of cream flavoring. Certainly creative and different cream recipe than made for an interesting drink since I usually don’t fancy cream ales unless their really dark in complexion.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Draught at the brewery. A beer clothed in controversy, and possibly rightly so. Takes more of a sweet chai line than spicy, though the spice is there in a rounder, sweeter way, like a starbucks chai with plenty of sugar. But I like starbucks chai; much better than their coffee. Basic blond/cream ale base with light hops but a little more malt sweetness to carry the tea. Nice stuff.
golden, no foam, weak wheaty aroma; medium sweetness, lightly bitter and sour; light body, thin feel, almost flat, moderately long bittersweet finish; Overall: rather weak

Piana mierna opada po chwili klarowne kolor ciemny prześwitujący, nasycenie niskie. Czuć moc piwa lekkie rozgrzewające uczucie bez natarczywego alkoholu. lekka owocowość i drożdże. Dobry koźlak ale nic szczególnego.

Backlog. Wygląd: ciemny z rubinowymi przebłyskami. Bez piany. Zapach: palone słody i czerwono-owocowe akcenty. Smak: złożony: początek słodkoowocowy, słodkosłodowy, lekkaorzeźwiająca w porównaniu ze słodowością goryczka, wyraźne palone słody pozostające w średnim finiszu. Posmak zostaje na długo, a na języku zostają chmielowe akcenty z tych ziemistych.
Many thanks to kevnic2008 for sharing! Pours hazy orange brown colour with a small off-white head. Aroma of sweet dark malt, spices. Taste of sourish fruits, dark malt, caramel, not good!
Many thanks for this beer to Grzesiek79. Pours chestnut colour with a mid-sized off-white head. Malty nose. Flavours of malt, caramel and toffee fudge. Sour!

W aromacie leciutki ciemny słód, taki w stronę czeskiego tmavego, czekolada z orzechami, karmel, chyba tez lekkie żelazo, niezbyt intensywnie, nie przekonująco. W smaku wytrawne, ponownie dunkelowa nuta czekolady z orzechami, jednak na niskim poziomie intensywności, zaskakująco płaskie, goryczka niska, ale cierpka, ciut odsłodowa. Męczące, niezbyt udane.
Piłem chyba zepsute. Kwaśne, w tle kiszona kapusta. Barwa ciemna, bardzo mocnej herbaty. Piana biała, szybko opada.

Piana skąpa, nawet jak a wymuszaną. Po rozpadzie pozostaje niewielka warstewka. Barwa ciemna miedziana, lekko zmętniona. Aromat słodowy, lekko kwaskowy, owocowy, melanoidynowy, chmielu brak. Lekko siarką zalatuje W smaku podobnie, słodki, melanoidynowy, opiekany, Wysycenie niskie, półpełne, goryczki praktycznie brak.

Chwalony ciągle przeze mnie Haust, tym razem się nie popisał. Ciemny Bock zwyczajnie mi nie smakował. Niewielka i krótkotrwała piana nie miała tu akurat znaczenia. Aromat wypadł dość słabo i mało intensywnie. Niby jest paloność, chmiel, ale gdzieś w głębi coś nieprzyjemnego. Podobnie w smaku. Nie mogłem pozbyć się wrażenia czegoś starego, zepsutego. Trochę nazbyt wyraźny alkohol, lekka kwaskowość i wodnistość. Coś poszło nie tak. Zdarza się...
Color, dark brown/black, ruby reflexes aroma/taste, toast roast malts, earth, caramel low bitterness, poor foam thin body

Warka 28.06.2014. Kolor ciemnobordowy, lekko zmetnione. Piana srednia, powoli opada, zostawia gruba obraczke i nie oblepia szkla. Aromat zdominowany przez bardzo intensywna kiszona kapuste, gdzies z tylu ledwie przebija karmel, diacetyl, palone slody i ziolowo-kwiatowy chmiel. W smaku polwytrawne, intensywnie karmelowe, zbozowe i lekko palone, charakterystycznie sliskie i mleczne (diacetyl), dosc mocno kwasne. Krotko mowiac - zakazenie. Goryczka calkiem konkretna, ziolowa, trawiasta, kwiatowa i ziemista, lekko sciagajaca. Finisz alkoholowo-kwasny. Wysycenie wysokie.
Piwo po terminie ważnośc,i mętne, Czuć słodowość chlebową goryczka słaba, lekki kwasek piwo ok ale bez rewelacji.
Very weak malty aroma. Small head disappearing to thin layer. Cloudy golden body. Very pleasant floral hoppy bitterness in taste with appropriate malty background.

Butelka. Barwa pomarańczowa, zmętnione. Piana słaba, opada w zaskakująco szybkim tempie do zera. W aromacie DMS i lekka słodowość. W smaku kwaskowe (!) i poza tym puste. Pilsowe nuty chmielowe wyczułem w przedostatnim łyku, mocno się skupiając. Wysycenie niskie, goryczki całkowity brak. W kategorii pils to porażka, w innej ujdzie, bo wypiło się szybko - pewnie na letnie ugaszenie pragnienia by się nadało.

Draught Aroma-bread, grass, apple Appearance- amber, clear,white foam Taste-light sweetness, light bitterness, light sourness Palate-medium body, sticky, average carbonation, abrupt finish Overall-refreshing Earlier Rating: 9/1/2013 Total Score: 3.7 Bottle (filled by bartender in my presence) Aroma- bread, grass, Appearance- golden color, white foam, Taste- medium bitterness, Palate- light body, lively carbonation, long bitter finish Overall- very refreshing, good pilsener, perfect with pork chop
Sample @ PiwPaw Beer Heaven, Warsaw. Nice head with good duration. Color is gilden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, amlt and hops.
Tap @ Piw Paw - Beer Heaven. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 300715

Barwa z?ota, piwo klarowne z bardzo ma?? pian?, znikaj?c? szybko do zera. Przyjemny aromat s?odowo chmielowy. W smaku równie? przyjemna mieszanka s?odu i chmielu. Goryczka przyjemna, ale mog?a by by? troch? wi?ksza. Ogólnie przyjemny i bardzo pijalny pils.

Butelka 0.5l. Piwo klarowne o zlocistej barwie z biala czapa piany, ktora niestety blyskawicznie znika do zera. Aromat swiezy, slodowy, slodkawy z malutka estrowa nuta w tle. W smaku slodowe z goryczka o charakterze ziolowym. Przyzwoite ale spodziewalem sie troche wiecej po pilsie. Piwo jest w miare pelne z wyraznym slodowym cialem przez co brak mu lekkosci choc jest w miare pijalne. Calosc dopelnia fajna goryczka na dosc wysokim poziomie jak na pilsa ale za ta cene to zdecydowanie slaba propozycja.

Podane/Served: Footed Pilzner, 9°C Partia/Batch: 29-04-2015, 0,5l Bottle Etykieta/Label: Uroczo archaiczna. / Cute archaic. Aromat/Aroma: Miękki słodowy; miodowy; dość czysty ziołowy; metaliczny, nie żelazisty. / Soft malts; honey; quite clean herbs; metallic, but no iron is present. Wygląd/Appearance: Jasno złota, klarowna barwa. Piana puszysta, drobna, trwała. Ładne koronkowanie. / Pale golden, clear colour. Head is fluffy, fine, lasting. Nice lacing. Smak/Taste: Porządna, słodka baza słodowa; bardzo spokojna, choć momentami intensywna goryczka; nieco trawiaste; cytrynowa kwaskowość; miodowe nutki. Chmielowa kwiatowość i metaliczność, brak żelaza. / Solid, sweet malt base; very calm, although intense hop bitterness; lemon sourness; honey notes. Flowers and metallic from hops, no iron. Odczucie/Palate: Dość pełne. Średnie wysycenie. / Quite full. Medium carbonation. Ogólnie/Overall: Całkiem przyjemny, prosty lager. / Quite pleasant, simple lager.
Barwa złota, dość kalrowne, piana drobna i średnia. Aromat słodowy, słodkawy, trawasty, estry, zielone jabłłko. Smak słodowy, estrowy, niska krótka goryczka. (Tap / WFP kwiecień 2015)

Slightly hazy warm copper, small skim of off-white head. Full volume, ultra-fresh hops: melon, strawberry, mint. Clean refreshing minty bite, melon, dry finish with just a touch of lingering bready malt. Delicate, clean, full-flavored--all-around good!
Dark copper color with minimal carbonation and faint bubbles in the body. A little floral hops in the nose. Floral and vegetable tasting hop flavor with a kind of bite to the finish.
Tried this at the 2007 Arborfest, it was served on Cask. Great hop aroma, clean start and finish, great pale ale, with a heavy hop twist.

Pale, clear orange/amber look, under a creamy staying head, leaving lace. Nice! Interesting aroma, with orange peel spilling out first, vanilla, cream, lemon zest,...what else? Sweet, slightly spicy, and unlike anything I’ve ever encountered before. Most interesting. Taste: again, sui generis. Clean, hoppy, fairly smooth...brisk, sweet, citrusy flavor. Snappy, crisp, easy to drink...boy, I’ve had these hops in other Euro-brews before, but maybe not in this combination, or with these malts. I can’t get over how unusual this is! Mouthfeel/texture is a bit of a wrangle, though...very odd, takes some getting used to, for sure. Sticky herbal hops cling to the palate, citrus and spice hang on...there’s a long finish, that eventually dries. Drinkability, though, is a breeze...getting over that unique play on the tongue is easier than I thought...so easy to swallow! Dang, this is good!

Amber Color with White Ring. Light Notes of Fresh Fruit and Cereal Grains on the Nose. Light Bodied, with a Crispy Dry Taste...Nice Fruit Notes of Blueberry/Raspberry?... Perhaps a Subtle Mixture...Dry Grains.. Quite Dry on the Aftertaste. The Dryness of the Grains Similuates a Fruity Wheat Beer Quite Well. A Nice Drinker!

Enjoyed at Town Hall on 4/30/07. This is a a break from the usual for Town Hall. The aroma of this beer is fairly light on the hops. There is rotting fruit, and some hops. There is also something here that doesn’t smell so good, but I can’t nail down exactly what it is, but what is more weird is it works with the beer overall. Flavor is bone dry. This is not excessively hopped, but what is there is bitter, and a light flavor of lemongrass enhances this dryness. Overall I like it; I am always happy to see Town Hall do something different. This beer could use some adjustment, but overall it is good.
Cask In Bristol last month. Clear chestnut colour cream head. Good Scottish heavy malt caramel notes.

Gravity cask at the 2019 Bedford Beer Festival. Mahogany and incredibly thin-looking. Flat. Bit nutty, malty scent, hints of spiced orange peel and carbo. Taste carries a gorgeous balance, with the sweetness paired with the sweet/bitter/sour interplay of overripe tangerine, and finishing with a hint of hazelnut. Flat as a pancake, but it was always gonna be. Nice.

Sehr dunkles Rubinrot mit etwas weißem Schaum im Glas. In der Nase gesäuerte Himbeermarmelade, Karamell, Ahornsirup. Im Mund wässrig und süßlich herb, Haselnußsirup mit Gerste, karamellisierter Rohrzucker, dazu eine entfernt fruchtige Bitterkeit, Erdbeer-Rhabarber.
light ruby colour. smell dark fruit. taste is light and fruity. Some cola notes. no bitterness. ok
Cask @ Mitre Bar, Edinburgh. Clear brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dark fruit. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 150419

Cask. Deep amber-brown color with creamy off-white head. Aroma is raisins, chocolate, toffee, fudge. Taste is raisins, chocolate, earthy, toffee, on the fruity side. Oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Quite tasty, nice harmony!
Cask at Crown Bar. Clear garnet with tan head that is small but lingers. Aroma is restrained crystal malt. Mostly a rich malt flavor with a tad too much bitterness offsetting the balance.
Clead reddish amber to mahogny colour, half cm of creamy beige-is off-white head; aroma and taste of roasted nuts, toasted rye bread, some burnt sugar and dried fruits; very smooth ale

Pint from cask at Bow Bar, Edinburgh, with JR and RS 24.10.18. Clear amber copper. Diminishing beige head. Excellently balaced taste, with dark caramel, brittle, dates and soft hops. Appropriately uncarbpnated. Very quaffable.

Cask at Bow Bar. Pours clear deep amber. Aroma is slight caramel and pine needles, also rose petals. Body is full but not heavy, rather sweetly painted over background bitterness. Still malt forward with toasted flavours, all gentle and smooth. Usually characteristics I rather don't like, but here they harmonise perfectly. Dryish palate, but actually developing the full flavour profile only there. Outstanding for a bitter!

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured a red-amber color with a large creamy white head. The aroma was roasty and smoky malts. The flavor was fairly strong roasty and smoky malts with a sugary undertone. The was a vague sugar smack cereal note to this beer.

Aroma is a little fruity if you look for it. Unfiltered hazy light brown with no head. Very mild creamy carbonation. Taste is hoppy but medium hops, not strong. Probably more than my lager lovin taste buds can handle.

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured an orange-amber color with a small tan head. The aroma was tangy with a hint of lemon. The flavor was sweet, tangy and sour with a long tangy malt finish.

column1: John Harvards Imperial Brown Sugar Stout
column5: Certainly not a sweet stout, the alky content is readily apparent. ood stout aroma. Nice black opaque pour, then the head fades. Very little detectable carbonation. Bitter but not really bitter. Does not have a ton of black coffee. Offensive in it’s own personal way. Imp stouts are so ovvensive on the finish.

column1: John Harvards Imperial Brown Sugar Stout
column5: At the Monroeville, PA location. Part of a large sampler. Dark black brown with tan head. Aroma is malt, molasses, anise, coffee. Flavor is molasses, caramel, anise, coffee, oats, chocolate, The best of the sampler, but nothing to write home about.

column1: John Harvards Imperial Brown Sugar Stout
column5: Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured a black color with a small tan head. The aroma was sweet and roasty. The flavor was sweet, roasty, smoky and has a noticeable brown sugar element. The flavor was nicely complex. The finish was long, roasty and a bit smoky.
Cask at Scarborough Arms, Leeds. Pours dark brown, thin beige head. Little going on, aroma-wise. Light cocoa maybe. Taste was much the same, where is the orange? An OK, chocolate stout.
Cask at The Bree Louise Pub, Euston, London. Is this a stout?? Dark amber beer with a offwhite head. Chocolate and orange flavour but it feels artificiall and not nice at all.

Pint pulled at The Bricklayers Arms in Putney (London), a dark amber colour with a white foamy head. Aroma was a light chocolate. To taste, it was very orange chocolate in the finish, but before that it was more light and of caramal, with a little licorice as well. An interesting, complex palate, but a stout?

Bottle dated as 15 months old, so might be slightly past its prime. Pours hazy straw color with a 3-finger white head. Fruity aroma mixed with a pine note. Maybe some earthiness from the yeast. Medium body. Finish is long and dry, maybe a touch of astringency. Piney hops flavor with a touch of resin. Earthy note at the back.

Poured from bottle into a tulip: Pours clear yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, herbal, light resin. Taste moderately sweet, funk, resin, slightly boozy. Medium body, little too boozy.

Thanks altonbrownd for the bottle! Poured into a snifter showing well filtered golden yellow with a finger of quickly dissipating clean white foam. The nose shows strong Belgian yeast influence with light pine hops around the edges. The palate is medium bodied and moderately carbonated. Flavors of Belgian yeasty forwardness and light bready malts ending on a moderate hoppy and tea-like astringent bitterness. Somewhat out of place but it’s alright.

Backlog, Bottle from Canals in Bellmawr, Pours a amber orange with a fluffy but smaller head. Smell and taste are belgian fruits, spices, coriander, wood, yeast and earthy hops. Medium in body with a lasting finish.

Taps clear golden with a fairly thick eggshell head that leaves good lacing. Aroma presents inviting citrus, malty and hoppy tones. Flavor offers resiny hops, citrus, fresh malt, pomme fruit, and subtle banana tones. Very Belgian and very IPA. Mouthfeel features decent body and fine fizz. Hugh should try it.

On tap at Rattle n him in NYC. Poured a yellow body and made a thin white head. Aroma is of citrus, yeast, and light Simcoe hops. Tastes of Belgian candi and a bit of licorice bitterness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour is a cloudy looking yellow with a large white head. Aroma is a nice fruity hop with some esters in the back to let you know this is not a typical IPA. Flavor is more of a fruity hop. Not much of the Belgian yeast shows up in the flavor. More grapefruit hops are left on the tongue as this goes down. Decent IPA I just wish more of the yeast came out to play.

Thought I had rated this before, guess not? Bottled 7.21.16..pours a medium golden yellow color with a slim white filly head atop..nose is really solid with that Belgian yeast essence and some pineapple..bottle neck sums this up well, fruit and pine hop notes balanced with Belgian style yeast esters, a very nice representation of the style, has some alcohol legs to it that are disguised well at first, but linger post sip..

Purchased at Bottles and Cans in Chicago, IL; enjoyed at home while nervously flipping between Bears/Packers and NLCS game 5. This is a good beer to be nervous with. Appearance is pale yellow with a rich frothy white head. Aroma is abundant with citrus, orange peel, grapefruit, lot going on. Taste is equally good, goes down bitter and tart, rich in lemon notes, light ale yeast. Really good one here.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 10-7-16. Bottled on 07/20/16. I’d say 3 months is the cutoff for a typical IPA, so I’m pushing it a bit with this one, but it should be alright. Pours a hazy yellow to dirty gold with a small to moderate amount of creamy, beige head. Not the most attractive appearance but not problematic. The final pour, however, is quite cloudy and produces a large amount of creamy, cream-colored head and pretty good lacing. Ends up looking much better than it did in the initial pour. Fresh smell features scents of melon and lemons. The Belgian-esque esters and hops combine to produce a heavily citric aroma. Lemon peel and grapefruit scents. Tame, subdued, dry flavor. Slightly chemical, although it’s not entirely clear whether that quality derives from the yeast or the hops. Quite dry in the sense of lacking in sweetness but not actively drying in the palate. Disappointingly low in flavor. Lively and frothy in the palate. Medium body. I’ll write something that I didn’t expect at all to write about an Allagash Belgian IPA: Bland!
Bottle. Murky yellow appearance which was not a good start. Bitter but no others flavours present. Not a lot going for this one.

way TOO fizzy, it foamed out of bottle and disturbed ths sediment massivly.THus was very clowdy lumpy. grassy hopnose, fruity bitter hop, with long bitter linger little smokeyness. I could see what it was aiming for so scored that.

Tasted this at the Troon Beer Festival in October 2008. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear dark ruby red in colour with a creamy white head. Soft bramble fruit in the short aroma. Good creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Mixed malts give a strong fruit base with dark plums and ripe bramble evident. Moist earthy notes present in the short hoppy aftertaste. Finish is malty with dry chocolate drinking powder present in the mouth. An eclectic bitter and well recommended.
A deep ruby in colour, with a full malty flavour and sweetness deep syrupy tones

Cask (handpump) at Great British Beer Festival, day 4 on 5 August 2011. Quite a dark coloured bitter - deep copper with a ruby tinge. Some berry fruit in the aroma. More nutty, with a touch of toffee, on the palate. More malt than hops but not too sweet - finishes rather dry in fact. There’s also a slightly tart, vinous quality here. Quite tasty and interesting, especially for the relatively low strength, even if I usually prefer a bit more bite and hop grip in my bitters.

Cask @ GBBF 2011. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. has a fruity malty caramel and dark fruit aroma with hints of toffee. Fruity malty caramel flavor with hints of dark fruit. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Cask at the GBBF. Hazy copper with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel and toffee, bread and nuts, and a vineous dried fruit note. Has a nice little touch of pleasant oxidation. Dry and somewhat thin malty flavour with caramel and toffee
Cask at GBBF 2011, Day 3. Pours cloudy amber with a bubbly head. Toast, ripe fruit aroma. Light to medium in body with fine carbonation. Slight tang. Mild brown sugar in the finish. Decent.
Cask @ Blue Blazer. Orange colour, tan head. Nose is caramel malts, bit of red wine sourness. Flavour is slightly malty, caramel malts, a bit sour. Not too well.
Cask @ The Blue Blazer. Nutty vegetable malt aroma. Medium brown colour, not much head. Sour vegetable flavour. Very sharp & sour. Not nice bitter.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear light dark amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, nutty, malty. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, nutty, licorice. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110802]

Cask (GBBF2011, Friday) Dark muddy and flat. Maple syrup, walnuts, and a slightly savoury aroma. Some booze in the retronasals, shockingly. Sweet sticky roast malts, a bit OTT on the sweetness, Anna highlights it’s maple. As a Led Zep fan, I’m offended by this beer.
Cask at GBBF 2011 - Tuesday. Clear amber/golden - offwhite head. Banana, roasted, fruity, berries, nutty, light chocolate, chocolate banana candy. Wierd.

Cask@GBBF2011. Amber colour, small head. Aroma is fruits, wood, mild herbal notes as well as some raisins and mild ripe fruit. Flavour is caramel, fruits, wood, earth and mild toasted notes. Very old ale like notes.
rbesg07, cask at the standing order, edinburgh. steady amber, decent pine and frozen hop pellet aroma, lightly grassy, moderate bitterness, not too bad

From cask at Standing Order. Pours almost clear and deep golden amber with a small fraqmented white head. Mild butterish and roasted malty aroma. smooth and roasted malty flavoured with a mild acidic fruity note. Bitter and medium dry finish.

Cask at Standing Order, Edinburgh. A golden beer with a dense (due to a sparkler) beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of fruit. The flavor is sweet mlaty and fruity, leading to a lightly bitter finish. It was named Standing Order Red Ale on the pumpclip, so I wonder why it is not red???

Sparkler’s white head. Hazy golden ale of strong posture with more alcohol notes than most and a full, but airy body. Sweet cerealic notes are all over the place, accompanied by muted banana undertones. Floral hop range is kept to a minimum all along, leaving the pureed impression more important. A big bowl of cereals.

Standing Order. Who knows how this place manages to get through so much ale that 2 brewerys make ale for it. Aroma is tart fruit, hints at sourness, yeasty and malty. Taste is similar buttery sourness, really just badly kept beer in all aspects.
Cask at Standing Room, Edinburgh. Deep golden colour. Eggy aroma, with butterscotch. Light citric, with faint maltiness. Green apples and eggs in flavour. Low bitterness.
Cask at Standing Order, Edinburgh. Deep golden. Heavily buttery nose. Sweet and fruity, medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Low bitterness. Quite anonymous, but OK session beer.
A Mes rate: Cask handpull at the Standing Order JDW. Gold colour with a decent head. Malty and sweet, quite German in character. Fruity finish.
Light Ruby, roast sweet malt, lots of juicy fruity malt with a little chocolate in its finnish

On tap @ Maduro, Bells GTMW pre-party 8/10/07. Cloudy light orange golden with a quickly fading white head. Aroma has lots of orange, white pepper, alcohol, and a bit of leather. Flavor had lots of ripe orange pulp an coriander, white pepper, and the leather became more apparent as it warmed. Light carbonation with a medium body--masked the alcohol better than the Right Bank. Good beer--more like an imperial wit?

Bells Left Bank [b]Draft at Maduro’s during GTMW weekend[/b] Cloudy orange gold color. Aroma is very spicy with lots of corriader, some nice yeast, vanilla, and flour. Taste is spicy corriander, vanilla, yeast, light sweet orang. Finish is spicy with lingering orange and spice. Nice mouthfeel.

Draft. Poured a clear light orange color. Head was white and one finger high. A bit of lace was left behind on the glass. Smelled of orange, coriander, a splash of alcohol, and subdued clove. Not unlike the aroma of a strong wit beer.Sweet on the tongue with orange marmalade, clove, and flower blossom flavors. There was also a slight earthy/leathery note and mild hop bitterness. Interesting beer. Similar to some Belgian IPA’s I’ve tried.
tap at maduro. weird note i wrote: have you heard of this. super mint ginger aroma. tastes wonderful. a bit of a tripel.

On tap at Maduro for the GTMW pre party Murky flat yellow with a touch of white head. This is very much a corriander experiment. The nose has a spicy nose with a pinch of citrus. Again in the flavor, tons of spicy citrus flavor. Sort of a lighter body, yet fluffy on the palate. Nice but a touch one dimensional.

On tap at Maduro – GTMW pre-party. Poured hazy medium golden with just a short cap of white head sticking around. Aroma picked up heavy banana, bubblegum, and cloves upfront, with toasty banana and more spices moving outward.. well put-together, strong, and enticing. In the flavor, sweet, lightly-toasted banana and sour wheaty notes abound.. some sharper diacetyl notes make an appearance, especially across the middle.. decent balance between the sweet and sour notes. Little too strong on the palate overall with the diacetyl detracting a bit.. long, warm impression. Tasty stuff!

On tap at Maduro’s Thanks to whomever shared half a pint of this with me. Otherwise there is no way I would have possibly finished my Wedding Ale as well. This is apparently one of the test batches for Batch 8000 so once it is gone I don’t think you should expect to run across it except by sheer luck. If the Batch 8000 is this good though I will savor every bottle. Aroma / Appearance - Creamy orange scents remind me of a Belgian wit ale with a bright open aroma. The yeasty background plays nicely against the fruity characteristics. The body appears to be almost identical to the Right Bank and Batch 8000 pours - dark orange with a minimal head. Flavor / Palate - Orange, wheat and a trace amount of rye bread create a fruity playful mouthfeel. It reminds me of a Belgian wit with more bite than normal. I found it a tad on the rich side but yet still attractive. If I was just going to kick back and not rate anything the rest of the night I would have been content with these.

Tap at Maduro pre-GTMW party. The beer pours to a murky straw orange colored body with no head. The aroma is wheat and oranges with coriander. The flavor is cookie malt, toasted grains, perfume hops, oranges, white pepper, and coriander. A medium sweetness pervades. Subtle bitterness. The body is medium bodied with a dry creamy texture.

On tap at the cafe. Pours clear golden amber color with a smallish off white head. Aroma is clove, green banana, sweet malts, roasty. Flavor is much the same, clove, green banana, sweet malts, roasty. Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, sweet finish. Said belgian strong on the board. I liked it!

On tap at the Eccentric Cafe. The closest fit for this beer appears to be American Wheat; witbier characteristics were absent. Poured a clearish, lifeless orange with no head. Strong clove aroma with sugary malts, toast, and alcohol. Heavy body dominated by clove with light banana, sweet toasts, and caramel. Lingering clove finish with modest alcohol bite. About what I expected from the short description. So-so.

getrunken 2014 in einem tschechischen Supermarkt Ich weiß nicht, ob es das Bier noch gibt, aber damals war es mir eindeutig zu süß. Das Malz lässt dem Hopfen keinen Platz. Auch beim Typ des Halbdunklen gibt/gab es bessere.
tap @ brutal assault festival (jaromer) amber colour, normal body, average carbonated, hoppy, malty, caramel taste, medium sweet aroma, easy to drink
