Reddish brown colour, white head. Caramel aroma. Sweet malty flavour, light burned caramel. Sweet caramel finish. (From draught @ Na Spilce Restaurant, Pilsen Urquell brewery)
On tap. Pours pale amber with small head. A: sweet malty, caramely T: crispy, medium body, shortly caramely malty followed by lingering bitterness.
Pression à Prague. Ambrée col de mousse à bonne tenue et carbo nulle. Arôme malt toasté. Idem en bouche avec pointe alcool. Moyenne

Draft pour at the Pilsner Urquel restaurant. The beer is a clear copper color with a white head of foam. Mild toffee and caramel aroma. Sweet taste and light earthy toffee notes. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Tap at Brutal Assault. Malty aroma, mild chocolate and biscuit. Clear dark golden to amber color with minimal sized white head. Medium to heavy sweetness, caramel and biscuit. Medium body, soft carbonation. Nice caramel finish.
FLes 33cl in Benesov. Hop, citrus, zacht, wat gebrande mout, licht zoet, bitters, drop, complex, goede balans. (7-2014).
355ml Flasche. Bernsteinfarbenes Bier. Malziger Duft. Geschmack malz und etwas wässerig.
Zajímavé pivo s nasládlým aroma, jemným řízem, slabší chutí a hustší pěnou.
Most likely the most complete beer I have tasted (and that’s a few). Strange that SO few place offers it.

Auch dieses Master-Bier habe ich bereits 2014 getrunken. Damals hat mich der süßes EInschlag und das Aroma nach Rumtopf irritiert. So schmeckt kein Dunkles bzw. Schwarzes aus Tschechien. Die Einstufung als übertrieben süßen deutschen Doppelbock kann ich gutheißen -das muss man halt mögen. Ich kenne eigentlich keinen Tschechen, dem so etwas schmeckt, aber es wird wohl einen Markt geben bzw. gegeben haben (ich habe es schon lange in keinem Supermarkt gefunden).
tap @ brutal assault festival (jaromer) brown colour, normal body, average carbonated, hoppy, roasted malty, caramel taste, sweet aroma

Dark brown colour, white head. Aroma of caramel malts and chocolate. Sweet malty flavour, caramel, malt sugars. Quite light carbonation. Finish light yeast, caramel, chocolate and roasted malts. Bought as the nefiltr. version at the Pilsner Urquell brewery. (from 33cL growler bought @ the Pilsner Urquell brewery giftshop)

On tap at Na Parkanu, Plzen. Black! Small off-white to tan head. Aroma is toasty malty, roasty malts, dark caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit. Very nice fruity sweetness, balanced with roasty, even bunrt. Very caramely, slightly too sweet. Soft, sticky. Medium to full body. Sweet finish.
Dark ruby color Aroma: Hop transient in caramel. Taste: Caramel passing into hop bitterness. Good balance between sweetness and bitterness.
Intense chocolate, then caramel, roasted malt, some dark fruit. Light-med bitterness, creamy medium body. Nice.

Caramel and chocolate aroma, bit boozy. Clear (?) dark brown color with minimal sized tan head. Medium to heavy sweetness, caramel chocolate, malt. Medium body, soft carbonation. //tap at Brutal Assault 2017
Fles 33cl in Benesov. Vol, zoet, drop, zoethout, licht maltig, roasted, siroop. (7-2014).

0.3 l on tap at 'Plzenský Prazdroj' (Petržalka). Clear, very dark brown with a medium large, dense, stable, beige head. Sweetish-malty, nutty and a bit fruity aroma of caramel, toasted nuts, some raisins and traces of chocolate. Quite sweet, malty, minimally bitter, a little fruity taste of lots of caramel, toasted nuts, some chocolate and a touch of raisins, followed by a short, moderately bitter, a bit roasty and minimally grassy-spicy finish. Medium to full body, creamy to oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Not overly complex, but very tasty and saturating, sometimes you just want exactly that.

Bishops Arms, Järntorget, Göteborg. Red-golden with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit/apple. The flavour is fruity with light citrus, caramel and the overall impression is light, smooth and quite charming. 2388

(Draught at the Bishops Arms, Järntorget, Göteborg. Named Dugges Sunset Summer) Hazy golden/orange color, creamy yellowish head. Fruity aroma, grapes, apple, pear, quite malty. Fruity, hoppy, citric flavor. A bit thin. Weak fruity finish.

Draught, Dugges brewery. Beautiful off-white cover tops the orangey beach sand coloured hue. Hoppy, spicy and rather woody nose reminds of avenyn, but got sweetish hay-like nuances that I did not find in the former. It feels spicier as well - fuggles, and sweeter, perhaps juicier ultimately, orange earthiness. Made for easy-drinking. Efficient, cleansing carbonation invites to the next sip. Well if I had had that as the University’s staple beer, I’d have spent more time at school.

(Draught) Pours hazy brown orange. Light fruity and spicy aroma with some light notes of roast and caramel. Also some lighter notes of orange, banana and clove. The hops are certainly from the UK. Light roasted flavour with a subtle hop background of oranges. Also some nice maltiness of toffee and caramel. Rather smooth. Light bitter and light dry. Light to medium body.
Draught at the brewery. Hazy amber with a thick, of-white head. Light hoppy and malty aroma Citric flavour with flowery, nutty hoppiness. Late bitterness.
At the Brewery: yellow/ brown- colour,creamy white head. Aroma of flowers,fruity and some, olddust and hay. Flavor is werry flowery,citric,smouth mouth feeling,nice medium finish. Thanks Dugge!

Draught at the brewery. Dark hazy amber with an orange touch. Creamy, longlasting off-white head. Fruity malt aroma, with apricots, and grassy and piney hops. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Good balance, quite bitter aftertaste.

On draught at the brewery. Dark amber colour, light hazy. Good lasting off-white head. Pale malty, with raisins and UK hops in aroma. Bit grassy. Light bodied with vague notes of banana and canned fruits. Good bitter. Very quaffable beer.

(Sampled draught at the brewery) Clear copper color. Thick lasting creamy tan head. Caramel, fruity and grassy scent, some nettles and banana. Sweet a bit roasted and fruity taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Rather dry aftertaste.

Draught at the brewpub in Atiye Sokak, Istanbu. The waiter told me it’s 7% ABV, but I guess he was wrong Dark amber color. Nothing special, like the Red Ale, but with a light roasted malt touch in addition.

Draft - served in their lager glass. An unclear dark golden beer with a thin white head - wonder how to get that small a head on a Weizen. The aroma has light notes of wheat and cloves. The flavor is sweet with notes of wheat and dusty hops as well as lighter notes of cloves, leading to a dry wheaty finish. Boring.

Draft @ brewpub. Pale, bright hazy yellow. White foamy head is pretty long-lasting. Aroma is distinctly rotting fruit, smells like a garbage disposal. Low carbonation, thin palate. Tastes better than it smells. Lots of citrus and the tartness is inoffensive. If it weren’t for the aroma this would not be a bad beer.
Cloudy yellow. Banana aroma but with footy off-notes. Sweet, watery body with light pedio taste. Slight tartness in the finish.
Cloudy colour with nice head. Taste of nice fruitness, some banana, some vanilla. Clear finish and smooth taste. Nice wheat beer.
cereal taste, citrus, cloudy surprisingly very refreshing on a hot istanbul night. i suspect some sort of german influence.

Draught at the brewpub: cloudy yellow like a german hefeweissen. Light wheat taste, and slightly heavier lemon taste. Very refreshing and drinkable. So far this is by far the best beer I have had in Istanbul.
Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy yellow, minimal head.Some light banana up front, then malt sweetness battle with citric acid. Light bodied. Refreshing, but way too lemony.

Draught at the brewery in Istanbul Muddy blond color. Aroma of wheat, banana. Good body strength, malt flavor, wheat character, sweetness, banana fruitness, drier at the end, spicy; good bitterness for a Weissbier. Well brewed.

Draugha at the brewpub as Pilsener. Yellow/pale golden coloured, small white head that went away slowly, light malty nose. Grainy, light bready and watery with pretty strong stale acidic finish and aftertaste. 4€ for nothing.
Gold / yellow pour. Mild hop and mild bread aroma. Mild hop and mild bread taste. Not much going on.

Draft. A dark golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt and lighter notes of Bamberg smoke. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of smoke - which comes as a bit surprise to me, when it was listed as a Pilsener on the board, but it also has malty notes, leading to a dry smokey finish. A good thirstquencher. I asked the bartender and he told me they did use smoked malt for this beer.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden colour, sparkling. Small stable white head. Fizzy mouthfeel and mildly grainy flavour. Very bland. Does not taste microbrewed at all, more like macro swill.
White foamy head, clear yellow body, faint citrus aroma, hoppy smooth finish. A very standard and boring beer

Draft @ brewpub. Hazy yellow-gold with nice white head. Decent head retention. Sour aroma is not all bad, just fruit tang. Low carbonation, is nearly flat. Lots of fruity flavors, esp citrus. Drinks easily enough for not being a very good beer.
Hazy straw colour. Footy-funky aroma. Relatively flat. Light straw taste, probably too much acidity. Goes down easy, though.

On tap at the brewpub in Istanbul. Pours a hazy, glowing golden yellow color with a small, foamy white head. The foam is quickly fleeting, and soapy lacing mostly rejoins the body. The nose is heavy on bready yeast, with a pungent, sourdough type note. Floral hops are weak to hardly distinguishable, with just a hint of a spice note. Flavors follow suit, with pungent grains and yeast balanced by faint floral hops. Moderate in both body and carbonation. This beer doesn’t leave much of an impression on me, it’s just kind of "blah".

Draught at the brewpub. Hazy yellow, small head. Medium bodied with rounded, spritzy mouthfeel. Grainy with very light spicy hops. Quite mellow with low bitterness. A quite messy beer without much pilsener characteristics.

[i] 50cl glass from the Balans Brau brewery tap 21-01-07 taken from travel diary notes [/i] I added this brewpub to places on the 24th January and I’m pleased to see that its had a couple more visitors since and that the beers that I had have been added. These were my last two beers of the night and of my time in Turkey my notes read ’soft, easy drinking, cloudy yellow unfiltered beer’ (amusingly for both beers)The reason I didn’t rate this at the time was I was unsure whether the beers I had were one and the same (see notes on place) and I had to write the type of the beer down in Turkish I had written Special and Kristal for each one as thats what I was told they were, but hoped that someone else in a less wobbly state could add them better than I did.
Caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel, caramel
Very slight caramel aroma, clear amber brown color, tan frothy head, slightly sweet, medium body, medium long finish. Definitely better than their Pilsner.

Draft @ brewpub. Dark amber/reddish brown. Nice head. Nice tan head and lacing. Aroma has some nice dark malts. Is dry, husky with distinct caramel notes on top of it all. Smells like malt candy. Low carbonation. Smooth. Bready flavors. Has some sourdough tang but is also sweet. Smooth and drinkable. The only one of the bunch that I actually enjoyed drinking and would again if in the area.
Golden-brown colour. Chocolate and toasty aroma. Light, toasty character with a fairly dry finish. Light body but otherwise an ok dunkel.

This beer is the worst of all beers in blans brau. Well very sweet but swetness makes your mouthfeel awful for some later. Dark brown and sweety finish. Well i actually don’t like when i do not feel malt and hops this is one of these kind.
Draught at the brewery in Istanbul Hazy dark brown color. Some malt aroma. Caramel taste, soft, sweet, not enough bitter.
served warm in a plastic cup, pilsen square markets. dark brown with slight reddish tinge; aroma of icing sugar and marzipan; very sweet but mellow with hints of baklava. pretty good
Bottle @Theis - bottle from Pivni Galerie. Dark brown coloured with no head. Dark burnt syrup, honey, berries - kinda sweet and dry with sherry notes.
Pours brown with no head. Sweet with aromas of red berries and port and cherries. Deep sweetness of raisins. Alcohol with a hint of dryness in the finish. Thanks Theis + Mette.
theis’ bottle (bought at Pivni Galerie) tasted at his home. dark color. kinda like sirup texture. sweet and xmassy. quite pleasant.

Bottle (bought at Pivni Galerie) tasted at home. Dark red/brown - no head. Dark fruits, raisins, licorice, dark bread, chokolate, sweetness, honey, syrup, light light alcoholic, light superclue aroma, smooth. Very nice !!
Bottle at yespr. Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of hops and solvents. Malty flavour of hops, grass and solvents. Hoppy finish.
clear yellow ,smooth white head. malty and strong caramelly aroma. flavor is caramelly, malty, prettty lousy pils, but drinkable belgian caramelly brew.
Bottled. A golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of fruits and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of over ripe straw and malt, leading to a dry finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.
Bottle @ yespr tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, bread, notes of yeast and hops. Medium body and soft carbonation.
33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity, light citric. Mild cornish. Bitter, light grassy and vague metallic. Ends dry and light malty.
Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours golden with a lacing off-white head. Malty nose with a skunky edge. Medium body, old stale maltiness, distinctly fusty. Subtle bitterness. 230212

23/I/2012 33cl bottle from Sint Canarus @ home - BB: 15/III/12 (2012-72) Dark blond beer, big frothy white head, very stable, adhesive. Aroma: quote some canabis upon opening, bit of citrus, fresh cut grass, bit metallic. MF: good carbon, light to medium body. Taste: nice bitter start, some citrus, bit grassy, more bitterness. Aftertaste: good bitter crisp ending, bit of metal afterwards.

Bottle 33cl. @ home. Clear sparkling light to medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, fruit acidic, corn notes. Flavor is moderate sweet, light light acidic and light bitter with a average to long duration. Fresh. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. Very much like a german micro pilsener. [20090315]
33cl, exclusive brew, from De Bierloods Adegem, not complex brew, yet refreshing, balanced, clear, rocky head, simpel brew

(Bottled) Slightly hazy yellow-golden with a small, frothy and lacy head. Herby-honeyish hops and buttery, pale malt in the aroma. Pale-alty, slightly cardboardy flavor with hints of buttery diacetyl and herby hops. Medium body with pretty soft carbonation. Quite surprising to see this kind of beer from Sint Canarus. This one didn’t have a BBE date, but calculating from the amount of dust in the bottle, it wasn’t the freshest sample. Drinkable, but not something you’d want to have while in Belgium.

This is a backlog rating from 2009 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are bready, grains, citrus, mild funk, light yeast, one of my least favorite from them.

old rating from a notebook i found. orange yellow turbid body that is extremely carbed up. light citrus nose that is just a touch dirty in a good way. very light drinkable flavor. quenching orange zest like notes mix well with the malt. enjoyable and would be better on a summer day

6/4/12. 22oz bomber that has some age. Clear golden pour with a small khaki head. Minty and papery oxidation in the aroma with touches of spice and a hint of honey and sugars. Slightly sweet malty flavor with bits of spice and sugars. Not terrible.

Bottle @ chriso. Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Sweetish malty fruity bitter yeasty flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty finish.

Bottle at Chriso’s Fullers-Gales tasting, thanks to Leighton. It pours cloudy orange-amber, with a thick beige head. The nose is sweet orangey fruit - apricot, mango and ripe orange, as well as gingerbread. The taste is sweet orange, mango, apricot, grapefruit, metal, hay, straw and dough. Light-medium body and moderate carbonation. Too thin and a bit too much sweetness. Balance is not great either...

Bottle at chriso Vintage Tasting. Pours cloudy gold with a foamy head. Odd nose, some sweet bready malts. Light to medium sweet flavor, some bread and light caramel, faint tang. Medium in body with fine to average carbonation. Sweet and bready finish, with some age on the malts. Pretty weak overall.
Bottle at Chriso FullersGales tasting. Cloudy dirty brown colour white head. Lots of hop. Not a good beer. Mess of styles. Its terrible

A: Dark orange body, with a minimal head that all but disappears within a few moments. No lacing. S: Candy orange. Caramel. No Spice. No Funk. No BelgianYeast notes. T: More of the same. Out of style. But not bad tasting. M: Smooth. Light to medium body. Good carbonation levels. Lacking any crispness or bite to the finish. O: Ehh. I’ll pass on this most likely.

Cloudy amber/ orange pour with thin white head. A musty yeasty smell common in saison. A moderate belgian spice and bread flavor that starts out sweet , but finishes bitter. A hint of toasted malts and wheat. Interesting.

murky, thin white head. Lightly wheat, dusty nose, fair amount of fruit. Sugary flavor, bit of pear and green grape skin, lightly yeasty, bit of bubblegum, astringent papery finish. Thin, lightly hit and dry, and relatively low alcohol for Weyerbacher.

Où, Quand, Comment : Dégustée en fût au Vices & Versa à Montréal (printemps 2007). Visuel : Couleur : dorée. Apparence : voilée. Arôme : Fruitée légèrement sûre (framboises, notes d’agrumes), léger de céréales, notes de houblon herbeux. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Goût fruité très légèrement sûr (framboises, notes d’agrumes) Un léger support de grains de malt pâle est également présent avec des notes de houblon herbeux et des traces de miel. En bouche : Corps : moyen. Effervescence : moyenne. Texture : légèrement crémeuse. Finale : moyenne et aux notes sèches, composée d’une faible aigreur fruitée avec de faibles notes amères de houblon herbeux.
Draught at brewpub. Light body, fresh raspberry, wheat, grape, sour finish. Not the most rich raspberry brew in the region but a fine summer fruit beer.

"glad i got to try all 3 hopfenstark brews. if i’d only had one, this would have been it, and it was BY FAR the least impressive of the 3. not really working well as a sour or a fruit beer. the raspberry is understated, as is the sourness. it’s kinda like Fort without the abv and the body. not was i was hoping for. a bit muddled, but still decent, just not in comparison to their other brews or to others in this style."

750 ml bottle at Volo. Pours a hazy pinkish orange with white head (maybe a hint pf pink) and tiny floaties. Aroma is dry, tart raspberries, light sour tree fruit and wheat. Flavour is dry, tart raspberries, effervescent white wine character and wheat. Tart raspberries in finish. Lively carbonation. Quite refreshing and nice.

Bottle at Barvolo. 5.5%. Pours a pale, golden/peach with a thin, white head. Aroma is a nice, semi-sweet raspberry. Taste is very slightly bitter/tart with smooth notes of raspberry. Medium body with a medium-high carbonation. Dry finish. Overall a really nice fruit beer. Smooth raspberry for sure.

Elle est blonde-rosée et limpide ayant un mince voile à sa surface. Des arômes de papier mouillé et de framboises qui semblent trop mûres. En bouche, c’est acidulé et suret sur les bords. Des épices mêlées à une effervescence prononcée semblent brouiller les cartes. Par moment, une impression de blé courtise les papilles. Légère déception quand même.(860-181013)

Plutôt pâle, couleur or blanc, elle laisse échapper des notes assez puissantes de framboises, tel que prévu. Douce en bouche malgré une petite pointe acidulée, elle n'envahit pas avec ses fruits, et si elle a un petit côté aqueux, elle emploie bien ce fait en étant désaltérante. Pas mal du tout pour uke fruitée, mais elle ne soulève pas les passions.

750 ml bottle. Pours a pinkish whitish orange with a short lasting white head. Aroma is sugar, field berry, but mostly, raspberry. Flavor is raspberry, tropical fruits (pineapple, oranges), but generally feels like a regular witbier...Some tartness, unripe, wild fruit flavor, with a touch of herbal bitterness. Light body, watery mouthfeel, weak to medium carbonation. Okay, I guess.
Light head. Notes of yeast and cereal medium fruitiness. Really nice light body. Solid summer beer.

Part of the easter Hopfenstark cellar purge since im visiting quebec very soon. Blonde pour, pink hues. Decent carbonation despite sitting in the basement for a while. Sour raspberry in the aroma, barnyard funk, yeast. Lots of funk up front, hints of fresh raspberry, wheat, fairly tart. Refreshing, lighter body. Age did this one some favours. Very drinkable.

Draft: Penetrable black. Jagged, big-bubbled grayish foam quickly diminishes. Fairly attractive nose of cocoa-dusted raspberries, black licorice, dark chocolate, and raisins. Briskly prickly carbonic sting. Rounded fruit-derived acidity gently puckers the palate and is softened by moist hints of tobacco. Velvety chocolate and gritty char deepen the fruitiness. Pungently earthy roast stop just short of becoming grainy. Metallic zing of malt enhances the bright acidity of the fruit. Finishes bittersweet and softly chocolaty, yet slightly crunchy with char and black chocolate. A straightforward rendition but well-structured and surprisingly vibrantly fruity.
Golden, clear, piney resin in aroma and taste. Some sweet lemon. Tangy and a touch sour.
On cask @ GRAF 2016 clear golden beer with creamy white head aroma is citrus fruit and slightly floral flavour is grapefruit and lemon crisp dry with good level of bitterness
Cask at holyrood 9a. Pours pale amber, nose is citrus, taste is a bit thin/watery, light fruity bitterness.
9th July 2009 Draft. Very slightly hazy gold beer. Light palate, a little dry and crispy. Very nicely judged hops. Grassy grapefruit and orange. Refreshing with a mildly bitter grapefruit aftertaste.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Dark orange colour, white head. Aroma is pine hops, citrus, bit of pencil dust. Flavour is pine hops, followed by dry biscuit. Fruity and juicy. Fairly dry finish. Good drinkable!

Bottle from the Scottish Real Ale Shop. Acidic malty aroma. Golden brown colour, no head, lot of bits floating about in it. Tastes like malt vinegar and sour apples with bitter aftertaste. I wonder if this one was off?

1. Cask Handpump at the GBBF Earl’s Court, London 08/08/2008 Very hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity with a crisp and slightly bitter finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 21/01/2009 Hop aroma. Small white head. Golden coloured and hoppy with grapefruit and citrus flavours. Crisp and creamy on the palate with a little dryness in a bitter malt finish.

Cask at the Guilford, Edinburgh, 20-03-09 on Craig’s crawl of Edinburgh’s finest establishments. Pours light amber with a white head. Taste is stringy hops at first then I realise that in actual fact the hops really dominate. Soft maltiness and a dry bitterness, really tasty beer in a very popular pub. A7 A5 F7 P4 OV15 3.8

Cask at Smithfield Hotel, Manchester. A pale golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet and very hoppy to start off with - lending it notes of grass and elderflowers, then comes notes of malt and caramel. The mouthfeel is nicely smooth.

Bottle @ Dave’s. Hazy gold with a white head. Cheesy, floral hop, some fruit and yeast in the nose. Taste is much the same with slight bitterness and the same cheesy note in the finish. Wow, how am I the only one to rate this from a bottle? Even the foreigners have had cask, lol...Funny thing is I prolly do have a cask rate in one of my notebooks :p
Cask Handpump at the Gardener’s Rest, Sheffield 22/12/2002 Amber coloured with an acidic taste and a hint of dryness in the finish.
Bottle. Nice golden appearance and as usual with this brewery poured very flat. Slight vinegar background-perhaps not as well bottled as it should have been.
an Orange coloured ale, orangey nose, light fruity ale with a bitter finish to it.

Bottle. More body than some of their beers. Poured with a medium head and had a bitter mouth feel that lingered for some time.As all their beers it was lacking in carbonation that made it easy to drink.A nice bottle conditioned ale which is probably very hard to find.
A red coloured ale with a strong hoppy arroma, and a fairly plain fruit malt flavour.
Bottle from Alexandra Wines in Coventry Golden and poured with a medium head. No carbonation and no lacing which is normal for this brewery. No real body either,just a trace of citrus
And amber coloured brew, with an orangy nose,, a flat start to flavour building to a light medicinal malt.
Peachy, lemon great bitterness in the finish, hop resin at times, super drinkable, probably the best iv had from cairngorm by far.

Date: 04/29/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub cloudy yellow, dense creamy bright white head, thick lace, sweet malt aroma with lots of spicy character, creamy body, rich malt flavor, lots of spicy character, lots of sweetness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

Pint at BB - Aroma of sweet pale malts with some yeastiness and a touch of lemon. Pours cloudy yellow with cascading bubbles, a medium head and decent lacing. Flavor matches aroma. Palate is clean and refreshing. Easy drinking, smooth and tast, just nothing special.

On draft @ Brugge. Pours hazy gold with fluffy bright white head. The light aroma is sweet with sugary malts, sweet ripe bananas and a slight tart citrus note. Wow. The flavor is nice. Great hot weather brew. Starts off sweet from malts and sugar (possibly) as well as a very light mix of spices. Near midway the yeasty banana note comes to the surface to marry up with the other flavors including a vaguely citrus tartness.

Moderately hazy, beautiful rich yellow. Nice head, dies quickly. A bit of a corn nose, otherwise hay. Too sweet, really sugary sweet, grainy, DMS. Wanted this to be a good accompaniment to the mussels but wasn’t dry enough. I was very excited about it too.

On tap at Cider Tap with Sarah. Pours a clear pale gold with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has sweet apples with a hint of wood and leaves. Flavor has a nice sweet apple note that is matched by a bit of a woody note.
Bottle. Pale golden colour with some white bubbles. Aroma is apple, yeast. Flavour is sweet, apple, yeast, sourness, alcohol. Medium body. OK cider.

Cask@Cider Tap, London. Pale yellowish golden colour with a minor head, that vanishes quickly. Aroma is fruity apples, some herbs, yeast and mild vanilla. Flavour is sweet juicy apples with some yeast, herbs and mild vanilla.
Bottle at DBF2012. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma heavy of apples. Flavor sweet of apples, notes of vanilla. Medium body. Refrehing.
DØE. Clear golden without head. Aroma is sweet apples and acidic apples. Flavor is medium sweet. Dry finish. 100512
Bottle. Pours straw yellow with a small white head. Aroma of apples, caramel and fruitiness. Flavor is sweet apples with a dry fruity finish. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 500ml @ gunnfryd Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma has notes of sweet apples, oak and vanilla. Taste is medium sweet and light sour. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. A clear, pale golden cider with some white bubbles on top. Sweetish apple aroma with some hints of apple cores. It’s drier in the mouth than expected from the aroma, it’s not very tart, with a touch of apple cores and cold autumn grass. A nice cider indeed, but I think it’s a bit on the sweet side. Could easily drink more of it though, maybe with pork chops and sauerkraut. 120405
Bottle. Dark clear yellow cider. Powerfull nice applearoma with some barnyard notes. Moderate nice apple flavor. Light sweet and dry. Not acetic. Average nice finish. Oily palate. Nice cider.
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is red apples and light sulfur. Flavour is red apples, sulfur and quite dry.

column1: Fountain City Irish Valley Spring Bock
column5: On tap only at the Monarch Tavern in Fountain City, Wisconsin. Straight from the tap, this brew pours a hazy dark amber brew with a white head. Dissolves quickly and leaves behind a nice lacing. Aroma contains some grassy scents, citrus, vanilla, grape brandy, caramel and a touch of semi-sweet apples. Taste is tangy caramel with citrus after taste.

column1: Fountain City Irish Valley Spring Bock
column5: Lot of carmel on the nose of this brown beer. Body has a similar caramel taste with a roasted character. One of the best brews on tap at the Monarch.

column1: Fountain City Prairie Moon Red Ale
column5: On tap only at the Monarch Tavern in Fountain City, Wisconsin. Straight from the tap, this brew pours a dark caramel with an ivory head that stays around for a few minutes. Aroma of citrus and ripe apples. Taste of malt barley, a touch of rye and apples. Smooth yet a dry finish.

column1: Fountain City Prairie Moon Red Ale
column5: On tap at the Monarch Pub. Nice fesh smell with good lacing on this ruby red beer. Carmel body with a crisp finish.
Pours a clear deep amber with thin white head. Aroma is pleasantly Malthus and sweet. Flavor is nice and balanced.

On tap only at the Monarch Tavern in Fountain City, Wisconsin. Straight from the tap, this brew pours a dark caramel red brew with an ivory head that stays around for a few minutes. Aroma of citrus and caramel. Taste of malt barley, a touch of rye and some sweet apples. Smooth yet a dry finish.
On tap at the Monarch pub. Nice pale red color with a grainy smell (rye?). Hint of carob on the dry finish.
Ikke meget hvede over denne øl. Er det mon en forkert etiket, som er kommet på en pilsner.

Can (backlog). Hazy golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is bready malts, some wheat, mild dusty and rubbery notes. Flavour is wheat, some artificial citrus notes along with some some rubbery and mild earthy notes.

(on bottle) Hazy, yellow, white head. Odd brew and not to the good side. Has a strange sour, pea-like aroma, along with the wheat esters of rotten bananas. High carbonated and a rather irritating, soapy finish.
Bottle. Quite thin aroma of nothing else than nothing. Is this a wheatbeer? I did not notice it, but could be good for someone in the heat today.
33 cl can. Hazy yellow, medium white head. Citric, wheat and some bitterness.

Can. Creamy white excellent mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. very yeasty which is a surprise because its only 8% wheat malt. Light bitter nice yeasty flavor. Short finish. Watery palate. I kind of like this.
Can. Slightly hazy yellow colour with a medium white head and a fair lacing. aroma and taste of wheat and citrus. Quite odd finish.
Can. Medium head with medium duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma and taste are wheat malt, yeast and some hops.
Can. Hazy yellow colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of fruit, malt and wheat.
Hazy yellow colour with a white head.Aroma of wheat and banana fresh summer beer light body and short finish.
Pours a cloudy gold color. Thin white head. Flowery and honey smell to it. Slightly bitter hops. Tart and flowery as well. Honey notes in there. Light bodied. Pretty good.

Cask at GBBF 2007. An unclear light golden beer with a small white head. The aroma is very unrefined with powerful notes of grapefruit - too gross for me. The flavor is sweet mlaty with notes of citrus, leading to a slightly bitter finish. A weird combination - nothing for me.

on tap-pours a white head that bubbles and gold color. Aroma is spicy hops, clove, secondary honey. Taste is spicy hops, clove, secondary honey. OK but doesn’t quite balance. OK effervescence. Occasional.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Sweet malty honey aroma with some hints of hops. Sweet malty and slightly fruity flavor with some hints of honey. Sweet malty ans slightly spicy aftertaste.

Flat hazy golden pour that remains completely headless. Powerful honey nose, thus sugary and tartish. At the same time, its hops are rather floral and it makes a weird mix with the acidity. It never grows more complex than that and the lazy attenuation ensures the residual sugariness in high enough levels to leave a stale film in the mouth as you swallow. Poor.
Cask-GBBF. Hazy yellow with a small white head. Pine, herbs (sage) aroma, somewhat unpleasant - I’m not a fan of the fermented honey herbal aroma. Dry and herbal, quite boring flavour.
Cask at GBBF 2007. Poured a hazy golden colour and no head. Their was plenty of honey in the aroma. The beer was sweet,, with a spicy aftertaste.

Cask gravity @ GBBF 2007, London. Hazy light yellow orange color with virtually none head. Aroma is honey honey and honey, notes of wood. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.

Cask@GBBF2007. Hazy yellow pale golden colour with small white head. Aroma is really strong honey along with wood and fruity hops. Also a lot of flowery hops. Flavour is is honey, wood and some sweet citrusfruity notes. Aftertaste is lemony and quite spicy.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - GBBF 2007. A very hazy yellow coloured beer with some patches of whitish head. The aroma is a bit sweet and sour, but no obvious honey. Honey in the flavour though together with some yeastiness. Not very pleasant and has an infected hint to it.

column1: Rock Bottom Arrowhead Bourbon Barrel Aged Brown Ale
column5: Pours deep brown w/ a good head. Residual lacing is lasting. Aromas of celery and raw coconut. Medium nectar w/ mellow residual effers. This tastes more like rum than bourbon. Molases, cocoa, celery w/ a mild touch of sweetness. The finish is bittered w/ an acidic component and leaves a lingering rummy flavor. Overall: a little overwhelming with the bourbon but interesting indeed. The aroma was not enjoyable at all.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Bottle. Very sweet honey aroma. Clear golden colour. The flavour has OK sweet honey notes. Decent, but needs more flavour.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Golden of color, no head. A rancid aroma with honey notes, some bitterness. A nice flavor of apples and honey with a bitter finish.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Sample from 75 cL bottle. Pours golden yellow. Aroma is very strong honey and quite bitter/edgy spicy. Flavour is strong honey, spicy and alchol. Ends strong spicy with a finish of alcohols.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Bottle at ØLbaren - thanks to Jacob. Clear dark golden/amber - no head. Aroma: Honey, flowery. Taste: Honey, flowery, sweetness, raisins, light alcoholic. Thin body and finish.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Bottled. A golden mead. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of honey and light notes of rosehips, and beeswax. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of beeswax and lighter notes of honey, leading to a very dry and slightly acidic end.

column2: Plau am See - Quetzin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany
column5: Bottled. Deep golden coloured. Aroma of honey, flowers and some melons. Sweet honey flavour with interesting notes of parsley, coriander and other herbs. The rather dry finish gives the mead a good balance between sweetness and dryness.
Bottle from brewery in Ribe. Golden colour, with a small white head. Fruity nose. Sweet malty flavour with an rich grassy aftertaste.
Golden with a small white head. Fruity aroma with a hint of juniper. Sweet malty and fruity flavour
Bottle at Chris o Shindig Aug 08. Murky pale appearance - a warm and pleasant beer, but a little vague.

Bottle @ chriso’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Hasa fruity malty caramel aroma with some grassy hoppy hints. Sweetish malty fruity caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty fruity finish with some hopy hints.

Bottle 50cl Clear light to medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, fruity, coriander - junipeer berry notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and sour with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (020808)
Bottled. Amber colour, small beige head. aroma is fruits, some nectar, mild alcohol as well as some mild grassyness. Flavour is very much the same. A bit watery, but yet balanced.
Bottle at Chris_o Pre GBBF Shindig 08. Clear copper, thin beige head. A little musty on aroma. It’s a little empty and plain. Some citrus hop fruit on end.
Clear golden with medium white head. Sweet and sourish aroma with fruity notes. Sourish flavor with fruity and caramel notes.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Grassy notes. Light bitter flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate. Nice but a little boring.
50cl bottle. Pours hazy gold with a off white bubbly head. Aroma has hops, fruit (apple & orange) & spices. Quite sweet taste - weak body as well. Very short end. So forgettable!

Cask handpump at the Old manor (JDW), Bracknell. Slightly cloudy, chestnut witha creamy head; fresh orange aroma; fruity orange flavour too, smooth and creamy; with a sharp bitter finish. Very refreshing.

On tap at Nimbus - Pours a hazy golden color with a thin white head. Very little lacing. Aroma is esters and very light yeast. Flavor is much of the same. Medium body. I’m not a big Belgium ale fan, but this was pretty good. A good, new beer from Nimbus.

This beer sits in my pint glass with a fully hazy, straw-gold color and is topped by a wispy, off-white colored head that barely covers the beer. This beer has an aroma that is predominantly made up of fruit aromatics and an earthy spiciness, which makes me think of the Chimay yeast strain. There is a fair amount of sweetness in the flavor, though it is not enough to keep this from being light and quaffable. The sweetness accentuates some fruit notes of pear and a touch of green apple. There is also a light, lemon-like zestiness to the flavor as well as an unrelated, yet accentuating, touch of tartness. There is some malt sweetness that leans towards simple grain accents, but there is something else (definitely fermentation derived) that seems to be upping the sweetness here; it works here and seems to be almost saccharine like in some ways. The mouthfeel has a certain fullness to it, which somehow works in a beer of this gravity. There are some grassy grain flavors here, and I would bet that the hops also add to these flavors. A definite underlying earthy note and a low level of spicing are just perceptible as well. This has really hit the spicing almost perfectly; there is nothing that hits you over the head with its obviousness. This is actually quite nice, and I am much more impressed than I was expecting.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: Cask at the Walsall CAMRA Beer Festival 2014. Poured a crystal clear straw colour with a bubbly white head. The aroma is citrus malt and surprisingly very light chocolate. Not sure where that comes from. The flavour is medium to light bitter with a watery malt light hop fruit palate. Light bodied with soft carbonation.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: Dark golden colour, small off-white head. Aroma has caramel malts. Flavour has sweet caramel malts, with a touch of fruits. Easy bitter finish.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: Market Porter The bottled version of this beer was the very first one I ever rated, back in 1998 or 1999 on Oxford Bottled Beer Database. I rated it with a friend of mine, Robert, and we said "Very sweet caramel nose - not for the toffee nosed!" I have drunk it a couple of times since in the bottle, but this is the first time I’ve tried it in the cask. It was bought for me by aceofhearts on a quick visit to London. The beer is comforting and syrupy and fruity. Rather average really.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: 1. Cask Stillage at the Mill At The Pier, Wigan 09/03/2001 Sweet on the palate and easy drinking. 2. Cask Handpump at the Freemasons Arms, Northwich 29/06/2001 Amber coloured with a fruity aroma. Dry hop finish.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: Cask. Dark golden colour with white head that quickly disappears. Friuty flavour with slight cider edge, a bit rough. Some hops but they do not dominate.

column1: Wyre Piddle Piddle in the Hole (Cask)
column5: Sampled cask conditioned at Prince of Wales, Foxfield, Cumbria. Pale amber. Neutral aroma. Sweetish and fruity with decent maltiness. Lighty hoppy and enjoyable finish. Good, but not exceptional.

Ceramic bottle, 18%. Quite cloudy orange colour, the bottom of the bottle. Good vinous aroma, sweet honey, wax and alcohol. Smells and tasted stronger than the noted ABV. Quite alcoholic flavour, some honey, though not too sweet. Citric aftertaste along with some bitterness and plenty of alcohol.

Bottle. [thank you, Yespr] Pours a hazy yellow with no head. Aroma is alcoholic and sweet honey with light cinnamon. Oily mouthfeel with no carbonation. Flavour is sweet, sticky, very vinious and light spicyness. Not me, far too sweet and cloying.
[Courtesy of yespr, session @ yespr] Dark amber with tiny head. Sweet aroma with port and cinnamon notes. Flavor is sweet with alcohol, cinnamon and caramel.

Bottle. A light hazy dark golden Mead, with no head. The aroma and taste is heavy on the honey side, fruity, dried fruits and some spices. Medium body with a sweet light alcoholic finish. It is a bit thin.
Cloudy deep golden colour with no head. Malty, honey sweet aroma with fruity and floral notes. Malty, honey sweet flavor with notes of the alcohol.

Bottle. [Courtesy of yespr, quality tasting @ Papsoe] Spare to no head. Oily see-through like lacework. Light cloudy orange color. Hospital like aroma, nutty, fruity, raisin, honey, and mix of dried fruity notes. Full bodied with an alcoholic texture and a soft carbonation. Heavy sweet flavor, not much bitterness. Heavy sweet warming and lingering finish. 28-09-2007

(Ceramic bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of yespr. Pours a hazy, pale amber - no head. Spicy, alcoholic nose. Very full-bodied and rather acidic fruit notes combined with pleasant honey notes. That tartness is really somewhat unusual but quite interesting. 180907

Cloudy golden color. Aroma of glue, ethanol, cherries in brandy, hence a bit fruity. Medium sweetness (for a Mead), with a very nice touch of sweet herbs (like the Alpine herbs), a bit spicy and fruity. At the end the alcohol is very warming. It reminds me some Alpine herbs liquors, a bit more honeyish. Very good.
Bottle. Pours am deep orange colour. sweet honey spiced fruitish alco aroma. The flavour is sweet with honey, spices, alcohol and alcohol. Spiced sweet finish. Quite a pleasant mead. Tak Jesper.
Jarred. Hazy amber coloured with nno head. Spicey with notes of stable, hay, citrus, honey, orange and flowers. A bit sharp.

Heavily carbonated, fizzy with a thin white head. Fairly standard hazy golden color. Fruity, bubble-gum aroma. Sweet and fruity candy-like flavors. Not too much depth or complexity. Decent, but not very interesting. Light, slightly sticky mouthfeel. An alright white ale, but nothing special.

It pours a light gold with a soapy head of white foam. It has a really fragrant floral, peppery & lightly grainy aroma. Really summery. Round raspy carbonation with a fairly soft light body. The taste is very crisp, light malts, bright green noble hops - this is a really nice lager-ish the beer.

Bottle from the brewery. Smells very sweet and is reminiscent of a japanese macro beer. Guess that’s the rice thing. Bit fruity too. Taste is alright. Honey, sweetness, light grassy hop bitterness, bit grainy. I’d rather drink it than most of the macros, but that’s not really saying so much.

Bottle, mail order from the brewery. Malty, fruity nose. Honey, bread, rice, sweet orange, light apricots. Deep gold with a low, fine head. Sweet, fruity flavor. Bready and grainy, with biscuit, orange, peach, honey. Cereals come though but not particularly rice. There is a slight Belgian spiciness coming from the yeast. Not bad at all. Cleanly made and drinkable, though less than exciting.

Slightly hazy golden brown color, white diminishing head. Aroma of barley, rice, and a slight bready sweetness. Rice-dominated flavors along with barley malt, hops, and a caramel-like sweetness. Crisp and light palate, finishes very dry. Interesting but nothing special.

Bouteille verte, avec bouchon de plastique, de 750 ml reçu en cadeau de la part de mes parents. Arôme: Très légère odeur de pomme. Apparence: La couleur est presque translucide avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Saveur: Léger goût de pomme verte. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #2187)

750 ml bottle. Dark golden colour with a fully diminishing fizzy white head. Sweet brown sugar, caramel, and apple aroma. Caramelized but not overly sweet apple flavour with a lightly woody background character. Medium bodied, lively carbonation but very refreshing. Surprising complexity for a 5% abv cider - almost has some ice cider character.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of tan colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated dark orange colored body. The almost non-existant aroma was malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of malt hops cherry and semi-sweet. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

Tap at MABC in FW, In. Off-whte small head that was mostly lasting with a fair amount of lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and an orange-golden hue. Nose was semi-sweet, cherries and a hint of malt. Flavor was semi-sweet, cherries and dry. Smooth, dry mouthfeel. Light body. Too one-dimensional IMO and lacks character.

On tap in FTW: Deep golden hue with a small fading head and okay lace. The aroma has a light cherry juice character along with biscuity and grainy malt and a hint of dusty yeast esters. The taste a very faint hit of cherry but more basic sweet and toffee malts with no bitterness or acidic bite. The mouth feel is initially sharp but fades to a thin nothingness followed by a weird medical aftertaste. WHERE ARE THE CHERRIES? An udder disappointment to say the least.

Tap at MA. Strong cherry aroma on the artificial side. Reddish amber with a small head. Strong sweet-tart cherry flavor - slighly cloying. Light hops and artificial cherry finish. Liked the tartness of the beer but didn’t like the artificial cherry.

tap at the brewpub - Pours an orange-ish color with a minimal head. The aroma is very mild and sweet. It tastes of sweet maltiness and a subdued cherry flavor. The body is thin to medium. It’s not a bad quaff by any means, but I would have liked more of... something. This is the right time of year for a sweet, easy drinking brew though, and it’s always nice to see MA roll out another new one.
Sample at Atlantic Beer Festival Moncton. Clear amber color, medium white head. Aroma of vanilla and caramel. Taste is malt forward with a bit of vanilla. Not bad.

Clear amber/brown pour with a fairly minimal head that has a bit of retention. The nose on this has more brown sugar than maple with some underlying grainy character. The grain stands out more on the palate and then leads into a lightly brown sugar and maple note with a bittersweet finish. Very unremarkable, but at least it’s not as sweet as a lot of these maple beers tend to be.
Amber pour with a thin head. Strong maple aroma. Very sweet, almost too sickly. Really get the maple from this but you can?t have everything.
I love maple. I’m the biggest maple fan I know so I’m probably overrating this by a large margin. It’s not over the top maple but it’s there and it is nice.

Location: Draft at a restaurant in Saint John, 7/6/13 Aroma: The nose is malty, with some maple notes, and a bit of hops as well Appearance: The pour is an amber color, on the darker side, with a tan head to it Flavor: The taste is medium sweet, but it keeps clear of getting past that, and light bitter Palate: The body is medium, it has a mild stickiness, and solid mouthfeel Overall Impression: I was expecting an over-the-top sweet beer, but this one turned out to be surprisingly tasty. This exceeded my expectations.

341 ml bottle from ABNL. Pours a nearly clear orange/amber with small whiteish head. Aroma is maple, caramel, wood and grains. Flavour is moderately sweet maple, toasty caramel, vanillaish wood and bready grains. Soft mouthfeel. I’ve often thought these maple beers are a bit of a gimmick but this strikes a nice balance between actually delivering some maple flavour and being sickly sweet.

341ml bottle. Pours the colour of light maple syrup, moderate, slightly tan head. Filtered. Aroma is faintly maple with some toffee and bread. Taste is pretty much the same, medium bodied. Overall, this was a solid amber ale with a hint of maple sweetness added. Glad they didn’t go overboard and make it sickeningly sweet. Probably the best of the Atlantic Canadian maple beers I’ve had.

Pours a brown amber color with a white lacing head. Aroma of maple and brown sugar with a bit of hops. Mouthfeel is pretty hoppy with some definate sugar sweetness. Finish is also very sweet. Overall pretty decent

Had on tap at the brewpub in Moncton. nose is maple syrup and malts brownish color with some white lacing. flavor is maple but not overpowering maple. some malt some toffee. reading other ratings i am betting they changed the recipe for the better.

Tap at Vices & Versa. Cloudy brown body with a very small beige head. Some berries in the aroma along with dirty wet cloth, also evoking kitty litter. Taste is certainly not what I expected from a maple beer. A weird mix of brown cake, butterscotch, white grapes (?!?) along some unidentified rotten fruits. As much as I was trying to relate to usual beer flavours I could only come-up with unusual flavours. I even thought the beer was a bit meaty in a sea-fish kind of way. Not as bad as I make it sound to be but not a whole lot better either. Maybe it was a bad keg. The pint I had was about as recommendable as a piranha blowjob.
Their Kent hop . Lacey with noticeable head, some hops in there. Malty. OK cask beer. Floral and herby hops, and some sticky candy there.

Growler, courtesy of LordMaynard. Thanks, Russ! Even after two+ weeks in the growler, this pours beautifully: a clear, golden-orange color; fluffy, off-white head with great retention and lacing that coats the inside of the glass. Plenty of citrusy bitterness in the aroma; English-style bittering with some candy sugar malt underneath. Medium mouthfeel: citrus and English-style hops upfront; lively carbonation; well-balanced with a candy sugar and maple syrup maltiness. Very drinkable and tasty, like a hopped-up ESB. Nice, dry dose of floral and citrus hops on the finish.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Draft at Tyler’s taproom Raleigh. Pouts orange and muddled with a thin head that disappears quickly. Nice orange aroma. A tad sweet on the tongue but that’s just the orange coming through. Finishes clean. A real easy drinker that hides it alcohol well. Certainly the best Big Boss I’ve tried so far.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: very nice on Tap at the Marriott downtown. Like a session beer but clearly Belgian oily sweet, hints of spice, slightly cloudy light amber with no head but pleasant odor.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Pint @ Tyler’s Apex. Good aroma, sweet & sour, spice too. Yeasty, seltzer kind of sharpness , little corniness about it, hints of orange and/or grapefruit. Touch of haze, golden yellow, cleared as it sat. Ok head, minor to no lace. Bittersweet flavor still a yeasty streak, banana kicks in, though I’m still getting some corn about it. Thick body, creamy oily mouthfeel, bitter sweet finish, Little rough around the finish. Tasty, though I wasn’t diggin the corn I got out of aroma, didn’t effect flavor as much. Didn’t stand out for me.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Draught at Tylers in Durham. Pours a hazy golden color with a frothy white head. Great notes of sweet wheat. Aroma is quite good as well. Tastes of cotton candy. Finishes with a great sweet taste, yet not to sugary.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Rating #1800, growler, sampled at the 1st Annual Shenandoah Beer Throwdown, courtesy of wilkie. Thanks, Chris! Fittingly enough, this was my final rating of the weekend. Pours a hazy, golden-orange hue; white head with fine-bubbled lacing. Lots of cloves, bananas, and breadiness in the aroma; solid witte nose. Lively carbonation; medium mouthfeel: lots of bananas, caramelized sugar, and cloves, with some warming alcohol / roughness coming through; some astringency. Medium finish: bananas, brown sugar, and toasted malts.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Poured at Milltown. Pours a soft yellow gold with a one finger white head. Doesn’t look like a Belgian White, filtered maybe? The nose is a little sweet, some citrus, alcohol, a little bit of wheat and yeast imprint. Not as big as I would like it to be. The flavor is similar, a little warm, some orange, sweet, not much yeast or wheat flavor. Tastey.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Wow... awesome beer. Also had this at the brewpub, with Ryan and Chris, while playing photohunt. We didn’t know you could get the adult version until we were done. Bogus.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Draught at woodys in downtown raleigh--a while ago...found this on a machine washed receipt) Pours golden, hazy, with small white head. Aroma is yeasty, with citrus and spice, orange peel? lemon? Flavor is earthy, yeasty, and a little pepper in malt. Slight alcohol in aftertaste, but not too much.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Growler thanks to Turdferguson. Thanks Sam! This was surprising for a double wit. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a thin lasting head- but lower carbonation that it should have since it was a growler. Aroma is actually very similar to a saison- im curious as to what yeast strain they used. Lots of spicy phenolics, pepper, dandelion tea, orange and lemon in the very background. More green pepper flavor, lgith doughy yeast, cream of wheat, light phenols, some vanilla and a whispy doughy finihs. Nice double white for sure, but I wanna say if they used some kind of saison yeast, this falls more into a saison than a double wit. Would be interested to try fresh on tap with a high carbonation.

column1: Big Boss Belle Wringer Double Wit
column5: Hazy yellow-gold color with a minimal head. Aroma is big, sweet, & spicy - lots of orange peel, coriander, and assorted spices. Flavor is sweet with citrus, banana, pepper, wheat, and earthy spice. Nice tingle as it goes down. Unique - I would put this one above Southampton’s Double White

120z bottle from Willow Ben (Tampa, FL). Pours a hazy lemon color with clearly visible chunky particulates and a creamy foamy white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of citrus, lemon, honey, yeast, grain, orange, tangerine, light caramel, floral esters. Flavor is essentially the same with some stronger honey and fruity notes. Light to medium body with a floral finish.

Spanish Peaks Brewing Company, Ltd.--White Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV (2.75 / 5.0) Wit--Very light cloudy color. Orange peel, coriander, and pepper spiced. Spice is not overdone. More malt body would enrich spice.
Bottle. Pours a hazy golden body. Lemon grass, wheat with a light citrus note and a clove and grain y finish. Decent.

(bottle). Pours a cloudy yellow color with particles floating. Medium white head which is mostly diminishing. Wheaty aroma. Wheat flavor with light citrus. Avg duration. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

To use an semi-old term. This stuff is da bomb. Pours a cloudy yellow with particles in the liquid looking suspended in air. Best part is the great, smooth taste. I was leery of this beer for no reason..turned out to be a super choice.

Bottle. Pours like a wheat that is a little past its prime. Kind of a gush of fizz somewhere in the middle of the pour and then it dies back quickly. I’m a little concerned as I look at the highly carbonated pale liquid, but aromas don’t seem too offensive, so I take a sip. My buddy from Bozeman insists that this was a right of passage when growing up... so how bad can it be, even after the brewery sold out or whatever the deal was? Aromas are fairly nondescript: a little bit of wheat, grass, spice and maybe even citrus. Flavor is about the same. The carbonation is a little obnoxious, but I can’t deduct since it is probably my fault for delaying on a "summer wheat" until the snow flies in November. The flavor doesn’t seem to have deteriorated at all... it’s just not that interesting.

Phenolic wheaty lemon aroma. Thin small head on pale straw colored beer, small dark chunks of yeast floating. Mmmm citrus lemon flavors up front with lingering dry sour (in a good way) phenolic wheat finish. Clove flavors remain in the background and lemon not orange dominates. Nice mouth feel spritzie well carbed, too style. Overall very drinkable, big bonus for all biers in my opinion, balanced but tart. Just what you’re expecting from a Belgian style witbier. Note: This is one of the better bottled witbiers I’ve had. I suspect I got fresh bottles of this, as Hoegardden is a favorite, but it’s really suffering by the time it reaches my supermarket shelf!

Bottle, from total wine. Pours a gold color with a fair head. Pretty average white beer. Aromas of fruit, yeast, biscuit. Flavor is typical of the style and not anytihng amazing. But easy to drink for sure.
More or less true to style, slightly spicier than expected. Metallic notes a bit stronger than desired, taste is a little thin, lame head. Flawed but far from a pour-out, would not recommend.

The Spanish Peaks Summer White is a culinary experiment in brewing, taking on many of the qualities of pub grub rather than the actual pub’s beer. The regular, well bubbled white head takes up a medium volume, with the melted butter golden brown beer sitting peacefully below. Likewise, the aroma effuses with the smell of butter in the pan, along with a pinch of black pepper, a squeeze of lemon juice, the delicious oils of white fish, frying batter and even some friend corn chips. Really, there’s a lot of gustatory flavors present. The taste is, to my delight, a perfect match of the aroma, exhibiting all the tastes of a good buttered up and fried dish. Very French and Southern. The only negative is a very busy palate which blockades rather than assists the flavors. But still, this is a wonderfully different white beer, and one that could be a daily staple for your friend food fanatics.

Pours a dull dark brown-grey with a foamy head. Aroma is sharp and wheaty with clove and vanilla. Taste is all the typical d-weizen elements: clove, banana, vanilla, sweet wheat, light pepper. Taste of unsweetened cocoa or chocolate malt is strong, possibly more than I’d prefer. Gets cloying toward the end. Mouthfeel is thick and heavy, typical wheat texture. Overall, in the range of a Franziskaner Dunkel.
Bottle @ Gotha. Pours clear golden with a white head. Straw, grass and slight marzipan. Smooth and soft with a short bitter herbal finish. Okay
Golden im Glas, cremiger Schaum. In der Nase maischig, geschmacklich fast wie Sekt, leichte Bitternoten. Hintenweg etwas flach, wässrig.

Bottle thanks to ErlangerNick. Prost my friend. Clear pale gold colour lasting white head. Lemon hop aroma. Tastes a bit like an export beer. Yes quite light but some sweetness from the abv. Nettle lemon hoppy beer. Rather light and refreshing. A little harsh maybe. Bit too carbonated. Decent.
50 cl bottle at Fristo Nuremberg. Golden colour with medium head. Medium to light body with medium carbo. Bread and sweet malts. Too sweet and boring

0,5 NRW-Flasche aus einem lokalen Getränkemarkt. Hellgoldene Farbe, eher wenig Kohlensäure und eine sehr kleine cremige Schaumschicht. Riecht sehr malzig, leicht würzig. Schmeckt malzig, süßlich und wird dann würzig, leicht bitter.
bottle, from the fridge at klub malych pivovaru in pilsen. plain, pale clear golden with a shortlived head; aroma of hay and wet cardboard; faint bitterness, cleaning products, pretty bland

Bottle. Deep gold in colour, with a slight, white, head and limited carbonation. Sweetish malts, slightly honeyed edge, followed by some sweetness in the finish. Very easy drinking for the ABV and OK.
A truly beautiful beer with an average aroma that tastes very good. This beer has a very good herbal note and is tasty in a prestigious way. This is indeed a good premium beer.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig, leicht fruchtig, getreidig, minimal herb.

Goldgelbes Helles mit feinporiger Blume. Ein frischwürziges Aroma mit fruchtigen Anklängen nach Apfel ist vernehmbar. Vollmundig im Antrunk. Blumiger Malzgeschmack gepaart mit harzigem Hopfen sorgen für ein süffiges Trinkvergnügen. Überdurchschnittliches Helles.
Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 25/05/2001 Light coloured and hoppy with a bitter finish.

Draught (St. Urho’s, Helsinki) Light yellow, light head. Odd savoury aroma, some yeastiness, some apples and some oddness. Taste is similar, but without the apples. Some odd brown mush of flavours, dominated by the bitterness which leaves an unpleasant 1-dimensional bitter aftertaste. Hop Back can do far better.
Cask@Black Door Pale yellow color, small steady white head. Honeyish-hoppy aroma, some homemade booze notes (old cask?). Light palate. Honeyish flavor, touch of hops in the finish. Thirst-quencher.
Cask@Ealing BF. Very light. Texture is grainy and thin, with some lightly earthy citric hops in the finish. Not much happening to be honest, but i guess its drinkable. If a bit boring.
Cask @ "The Wharf", Aalborg. Golden in colour with a white head. Clear. The aroma is of spicy hop and a bit of yeast. The flavor is of bitter hops and malt that lingers.
A Mes rate: Gravicask. Golden colour with lots of floaters. Slight sulphur in the nose. Citric and wheaty flavour that has reasonable balance. Boring.

Half pint gravity fed from the cask at the Ealing Beer Festival, a slight haze to the golden colour with a white bubbly head. A pungent malt aroma with a hint of fruit. The palate was smooth with a bitter finish that was a little tart. There wasn’t much flavour, just a basic ale - but did get better through the glass.
Cask conditioned @ Waterloo Arms, Soton. Golden. Drinkable but lacking in flavour. Moderately dry with a bit of bitterness. Fine but uninteresting.
yes cherry and some sweet vanilla taste. maybe a stout. on tap at the source.very sweet. cloying.

On-tap at Dancing Camel Florentin. Pours deep brown almost black with a nice tan head. Strong vanilla aroma that overshadows everything else. Taste of cherries, vanilla and coffee, kind of liquid vanilla-berries cake, mild roasty bitterness in aftertaste. Medium-bodied, relatively strong carbonation. Decent.

Draught sample at Dancing Camel Florentin, Tel Aviv. Opaque black with small brown head. Intense vanilla aroma, milk chocolate notes. Basically most of the aroma is vanilla. Flavor of sweetish vanilla, cherry liqueur, faint chocolate notes. Medium carbonation, Medium-bodied.
On tap at the brewery. black, opaque liquid with minimal head. Smells like vanilla and espresso. Rich flavours - jelly doughnut like. Full body, softly carbonated with thick texture. Long finish.

Poured at the Friday Farmer’s Market - Tel Aviv Port, deep black with a small beige head, aroma of coffee and some roasted malt with some almond tones, flavor is rather sweet with coffee, roasted malt, liquirice, and notes of sour cherries, bitter pleasant finish, good body, well-balanced with a nice Hanuka twist.

Draught at the brewery. Black with beige head. Rich vanilla aroma that makes you expect something unbalanced. Upon tasting I find that cherries lies behind a thin curtain of vanilla and coffee. Honey rounds off possible edges is the mid sized body. Piney bitterness creeps out late and I realize that my fears of lack of balance were unfounded. This is a good, unusual beer!

On tap at "pre-passover keg party": a lot is going on with this beer, cherry jam, some artificial sweetness, vanilla, mocha like ice cream, some notes of roasted/burnt barley, the different flavors are are integrated in wierd way which is not so good but overall a nice and interasting beer.

Draught. Dark brown, almost opaque. wonderfull aromas of roasted coffee, cocoa, vanila and moca which lingered in the glass long after the beer was gone. some vanila, cherry and faint coffee flavours. Body is quite light and the aftertaste is short. Not bad.

Re-rate 4/16/08: Draught at the "Pre-Pesach Keg Party" 2008. Black-colored with a small light brown head. Strong vanilla aroma with coffee notes and faint cherry hints. Flavor of vanilla, coffee with milk, some roasted malt and unfortunately no hints of cherries. Medium-bodied. Could be great for vanilla lovers, just not for me. 6/4/6/3/12=3.1 Draught at the "Pre-Pesach Keg Party" 2007. Black with a brown head. Aroma of vanilla, cream, a bit of roastiness. Flavor with roastiness, cherry, coffee and vanilla. A medium to full body. A very interesting beer, but not exactly my type of beer, since I don’t really like vanilla. Very nice anyway. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Cask (handpump) @ Smithfield Hotel & Bar, Manchester M4, UK. Clear medium to dark orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, grain, sweet. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. (180108)
Bottle.Gold in colour with a nice head,smells of summer fruit and hops,taste is fresh and fruity.

Bottled. Cloudy golden, rich firm head. Orangey nose. Medium sweet and medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Fruity and orangey with loads of tangerines and some bread. Low bitterness. Juicy and freshly hoppy.

Cask hand-pump at the Hobgoblin, Reading. Brilliantly clear copper colour with a trace of a beige head, an excellent looking pint; floral and citrus aromas; an immediate citrus bite when first tasted, with sweet orange and grapefruit flavours; then a refreshing lightly bitter finish. A great beer for early summer.

Bottle shared by JMFG on 12/27/07: Transparent orange bronze with a wispy-lacing small froth of white head. Aroma of rich earthy oaky bourbon and some sweet caramel. Body starts thinner, effervescent and semi-sweet with a touch of mild light fruity tartness and bourbon oak character toward a warming finish. Needs a fuller body and more balance, but has a nice aroma.

On tap at the brewery...Listed as a bourbon stong ale. Poured into a snifter, not much head. Dark red in color. Nice aroma of tobbaco, light touch of smoke. Taste is close to the nose, lots of malt, light tobbacco, smoke. Low carbonation level. Overall a solid sipping beer.

22oz. Bottle: Aroma of whiskey, bourbon, alcohol, vanilla, wood, cherries, and yeast. Poured light brown with some amber in color and a medium-sized, loose, fizzy, off-white head that disappeared very quickly. Hazy. Very sparkling. A few large, and many tiny, particles. Light to medium sweet flavor. Tastes heavily of bourbon, whiskey, vanilla, alcohol, a hint of tobacco, and wood. Very heavy on boozy flavors. Medium body. Oily texture. Average carbonation. Sweet, boozy, bourbon finish.

May 2007 - Pours mahogany brown color, with smallish head and lacing. Extremely strong aroma of bourbon. I like Stewarts beers, but their barrel aged beers often tend to taste more like bourbon than beer. Strong flavor of bourbon and wood, almost losing the beer underneath. Hints of vanilla, caramel and something sour that almost tastes off. Very sweet.

Courtesy Santa (DocLock). Slightly cloudy brown color with a thin broken off-white head. Tannic oaky bourbon on the nose and not much else. The taste is severly bitterly tannic to the point of being unappealing. The sour twang keeps on through the finish and dominates the beer. Overboard with the bourbon, very astringent.

Bottle... O-Town Christmas Gathering ‘07... Cloudy, dark, Longhorn-orange ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Notes of sour mash, resin, oak and toffee amount to the aroma. Full-bodied and biting with restrained carbonation. Mostly sweet and malty, the flavor provides rich essences of vanilla, caramel and bourbon. Moderately acidic. Mid-length, lightly tangy, very drying finish. Vastly underrated. Thanks to jayg for bringing this beer along to share!

Courtesy jayMFg. The body is a hazy, dark caramel brown. A small, foamy, off-white head leaves behind some sudsy lacing that mostly rejoins the body. The aroma shows darkly toasted caramel malts, light bourbon, vanilla, and a touch of ripe cherries. This one smells really nice, with a touch of cream smoothing out the light booziness from the bourbon. The flavor mostly follows suit, though things are a bit more muddled. The cherries aren’t as pronounced on the palate, moving more towards a non-descript, general fruity component. Medium bodied and fairly smooth. Short finish. This is a pretty solid brew. Surprised to see that it’s 9% ABV. I would have guessed lower.
Copper colored with some head and lacing. Aroma is yeasty with a hint of sourness. Flavor is yeasty with a spicy sourness.

Courtesy jayMFg. Pours a copper color, with a small off white head. smells of bready yeast, dark malt, and some light bourbon, but not too overpowering. Theflavor was fairly fruity and sweet, alot of apples, malt, and the light bourbon as well. The body is a little bit thinner than I had hoped for. very sweet, almost too much, which took away from it a bit. seemed like it had not enough bourbon in it.

Enjoyed at SLLs secret, especial, members only, totally secret friday nights beer tasting with Robert, eaglefan and an un-named BA member. Thin offwhite head that settled out quickly, little lace. Deep brown with some red edging. HELLO WHISKY! Plenty in the nose along with some dark fruitiness, definate lumber and alcohol. Body is med/full, slick on the palate. Plenty of Bourbon flavor, really dominant with dark fruity notes, wood, alcohol and maybe some toffeeish, caramel notes as well. Finish is fairly dry, whiskyish but clean. Guess i,ve turned into a BB aged whore as i seem to be diggin most of them any more. Thanks to eaglefan for sharing, thanks Brian!!

On tap at brewery. Dark brown in color with tan head. Aroma is mostly bread and malt. Taste is caramel malt with good sweetness. Little bitterness. Nice body. Above average for style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This dark amber beer comes with a small but fairly durable head that leaves a little splotchy lacing. Very good clarity. The flavor profile is a bit unusual for style, probably due to the use of "domestic Perle hops", but I found only a little harm in this. Medium body with good, medium carbonation. Smooth. O: Interesting version of this style.

A growler from the brewpub, served in a dimpled mug. Pours a deep copper with red hints and a small, tan head that quickly fades. Decent lacing. Heavy carmel malt aroma with subtle hints of coffee. Full, creamy mouthfeel with slightly more effervescence than is typical of the style. Sweet, malty flavor, but without much depth or complexity. Nonetheless, a decent representative doppelbock. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for the Daystrom M-5

Draft sample at the brewpub. Poured dark brown color with a creamy light brown head that was mostky lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet malty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Solid sweet malty toasted flavor with an average smooth finish of short duration. My expectations where met.
on tap-pours a tan head and hazy copper color. Aroma is caramel-medium malt, some spice hops. Taste is caramel-medium malt, some spice/earthy hops.

Served at a cooler cellar temperature in a pint glass. Poured a nice looking crayon brown with a small foamy head that settled into a thin lacing, minimal amount of sticking. The cascade hops immediately hit your nose, floral and citric, with a light backing of nuts and chocolate. Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, dryish, velvety smooth medium bodied mouthfeel. Cascade hops are the first thing you notice in the taste, they have a good citrus fruitiness, juicy, not too sour and a little sweet, a light grainy nuttiness, dry chocolate malty, and a dry fruity, malty finish. Just a well brewed American Brown Ale, tasty and balanced, another good effort from Mark at Rhodell’s.
[CASK: The Salisbury Ale House, Manchester 05/10/06] A very pleasant tasting brew and a great example of Britsh Ale. Quite dark and full bodied! Recommended.

On tap at the Pizza Schmizza Pub & Grub in Beaverton, OR. Not quite clear red pour with a big sticky head that dissipates quickly and leaves a ring of residue down the glass. Fruity caramel aroma and taste with a marked bitterness and medium mouthfeel. Bitter finish.
Draft at PreFunk. Dark amber, clear, scant head. Sharp malty aroma, Band-Aids. Taste is also malt centric, leaves, tobacco . Slightly dry, cough drops.

Bottle shared with Ladi at Bad Flash on the last day of his tenure. Drank alongside the ’Hop Lava’. Both beers were disappointingly not hop forward. Nice malt profile and smooth and easy going. This one had more depth of flavour, more hops and was slightly more enjoyable.
The apearence of this bottle and beer is pretty normal but the taste us great. Not super heavy red but definitely hop. In the bottle drank with the neighbor lesbos. Good times.
On tap at Hop City. The yeast gave it a banana and clove finish that I want expecting, nice malt body.

Pours dark amber, slightly hazy with a nice off-white head. The aroma is caramel, malanoidin malts, some tropical fruit, ripe apple and pear. The taste is sweet, lots of caramel, hard candy. The bitterness is moderate, grassy and piney, long-lasting. The beer’s ok, I guess, but way too hard candy sweet for my taste and the bitterness doesn’t balance out the sweetness in a very pleasant way.

On tap at St. Augustine with Ash during Double Mountain tap takeover. Pours a slightly hazy copper with a beige head. Aroma is caramel malt, some tropical fruits. Taste and aftertaste is the same with piney bitterness notes. Quite good.

Appearance: slightly hazy medium amber with two fingers of rocky ivory head diminishing quickly to a thin skim, moderate lacing. (4/5) Aroma: caramel, pithy grapefruit and orange peel, cedar, tropical fruit. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate-high bitter. (7/10) Medium slightly oily body, moderate carbonation, off-dry medium duration slightly spicy finish. (3/5) A little elderly, perhaps, but the slightly higher ABV seems to have provided some measure of protection. The intention here is pretty clear: marry the characteristics of sweet malty red ales with those of IPAs. The execution is… slightly less clear. Although bitter and sweet are not necessarily antagonistic, they can be tough to balance - one or the other seems to always win out. In this case, malt is clearly dominant. On the plus side, the SImcoe hops don’t taste skunk or catty, so there’s that. (14/20)
Cannery Row Beer Club tastes this for $4 out of 1 pt .9 fl oz. from Uptown Market in Lake Oswego, Oregon. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle purchased and consumed near th brewery in Oregon. 65 IBU A fine looking ale with a brilliant copper colored body and beige head. Malty and hoppy aroma precedes a solidly hoppy flavor with a faint malt in the background. Medium body, carbonation and (for an IPA) bitterness.

draught at the brewpub on a very hot and moist day, after carrying 25 bottles of beer from Wine of Dreams through Warsaw, with Schroppfy. Hazy pale golden yellow, no head at all. Light and refreshing, citrusy with shy hints of spices, very light, quite watery. I didn’t mind so much because I was incredibly thirsty, but it was very watery indeed.
On tap at the brewpub. Cloudy, pale yellow with a creamy white head. Coriander and fruity nose and flavours with some notes of banana. A standard weizen.

Looks the part, smells weak, tastes even weaker. What the hell is with these Polish brewpubs, even established ones like this, putting out such shitty beer? Jeez. This is like witbier for children, a watered down mess of clove and coriander for children. The color is nice.
On tap at both Chetek and Eau Claire brewpub locations. Pale copper colory with foarmy head. Floral hop nose. Crisp light carbonated beer with faint hop character.

On tap at both Chetek and Eau Claire brewpub locations. The tap marker at both brewpubs do not have any special brand name except the three letters I P A. So... I’ll just call this Northwoods IPA. This brew pours a semi-hazy light golden color with a light fast dissolving white head. Aroma has the piney hops, grapefruit, some lime peel, and some cornish/barley malt. Taste is light body, medium carbonation and a watery finish. Not much hop bite in the aftertaste. Too clean finish. 5/8/07 - The brewpub just sent me the actual name of the product: Northwoods Sawmill IPA
Pale yellow-orange with a nicely lacing head. Aroma of sweet honey and some balancing German hops. I’m really enjoying this.
aroma of malt, citrus, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is very good.. Effervescent, malty, grassy. Very good.

On tap at brewpub. Poured a deep golden color with a small white head. Aroma of mostly sweet malts with a slight hoppy undertone. Flavor had a bitter up front hop presence that was mellowed out nicely by a sweet fruity malt base. Medium bodied with higher carbonation, that was well balanced and highly drinkable.

Draught at the BrewPub (at 7.6%ABV): Malt, slight noble hops, and yeast. Poured yellow/gold in color with a a tiny white head around the edges only. Clear. Not sparkling. Flavor is lightly sweet and slightly bitter. Tastes of malt, lager yeast, light dried leafs. and a hint of hops. Medium body. Dry texture. Average carbonation. Malt, yeast, and slight hop finish is dry.
