Bottle from Mane Liquor. Not bad quaffing ginger beer. It leaves that touch of a bite at the back of the throat which is always nice I suppose

330ml bottle. Murky and cloudy with a colour that resembles dirty dishwater, complete with a scattering of soapy looking bubbles that pop and disappear. Very strong earthy ginger aroma and a strong ginger flavour to match. It leaves a burning aftertaste in the mouth and throat.

Bottle (330ml). Poured a muddy yellowed brown (resembling bore water) with a small, fizzy, off-white head which was fully diminishing. A spicy aroma with powdered ginger dominating, earthy/tree root notes, 5 spice powder and a dash of lemon juice. Flavor was equally spicy with freshly chopped ginger, gingerbread, a light bitterness, some earthy/bark notes and weeds in the finish. Light bodied with medium carbonation, a slightly thick/syrupy texture and an average finish

Big beaded head which told me it probably wouldn’t last too long but it just managed to hang around. Murky, dull straw coloured body. Taste is fairly sweet and mainly ginger but is there a hint of pear and or apple in there. Body is just above medium and on the finish just a bit of a bite. One of the better Gluten free beers that I have tried though one was enough.

Gluten-free beer now available mainstream at a few places in and around Perth. Mine, a bottle from the Beer Store Morley. Into a shallow chalice fresh chilled from the fridge. I let it known I love Ginger root anyway, so a bias goes towards anything made with it include. It pours an opaque, sandy yellow. A few reluctant bubbles grip the side of the glass, the others, conditioned and well trained, trace a silent path to the top, releasing up to a short, loose, bubbly pad of white that manages to stick around for dessert. Aroma of Fresh ginger is seemingly mulled, and plentifully spicy, ripe, woody and sweet. There is an extra spice there in the aroma hinting at Caraway seeds, rather fragrant. Quite sweet in the mouth as I expected. The ginger has a tough battle but pulls it off, this is very sweet, tangy and juicy but fairs clear of becoming cloying. Big spice of ginger in back , very woody and quite drawing with a long, sweet, equally woody ginger flavoured swallow and aftertaste. The carbonation is quite soft, the body firm and in charge. Quite refreshing I must say. Sessionable? I reckon it would pass at that too!!! (33cL, 1324)
Tap (rating from notes 5/23/07). Cloudy dark amber orange color with an off-white head. Vinous, rye, hoppy, and orange aroma. Smooth and bitter with a clean slightly sweet finish.

Draft. murkey caramel color with a thin off-hite head. Low citrus aroma. Grapefruit, citrus, slight pine flavor with earthy/spice/caramel backing. LIngering grapefruit and pine. Decent bitterness. Medium body. I’ve had this a number of times and the beer has been all over the place with some kegs being much better (Toronado was the worst).

Draught at the Toronado. Beer is hazy, light/medium caramel with a small, white, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.Malty with a light note of toasted grain, trace of caramel; Hoppy with a heavy note of resin/pine, light note of lemon/orange zest; Lightly yeasty note of attic, trace of sweat.Lightly sweet, moderately bitter, moderately acidic with a long, lightly/moderately bitter, lightly acidic, lightly sweet lingering finish.The body is medium, the texture is watery/velvety and the carbonation is soft/lively.Utterly fogetable.

Draught at Toronado. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is light to medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately to heavily hoppy (grapefruit, resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with a note of butter/diacetyl. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Found it amusing after having the El Toro Deuce and thinking "here we go again." Diacetyl and yeast once more, and similarly pretty much just a hop bomb with little else of interest (for a non-hophead). Very lean, stark.

Draft at brew pub. Murky, dark copper pour with an ivory head. Piney and floral hop aroma with an obvious rye note. I couldn’t help but think what a great name this beer has has I drank it...Bid rye notes line the malt sweetness with the hop flavor and aroma of a west-coast IPA. Very dry and bitter- a great, and very different, IPA.

On tap @ E J Phair poured a clear copper with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness, pine and grapefruit. Palate was medium bodied crisp and dry. Flavors of rye, earthiness, carmel, pine and grapefruit rind witrh a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

At NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. Aroma of piney hop with hints of grapefruit. Light amber color with little head. Starts with firm mouth feel and over the top pine. Perhaps some underlying grapefruit residue. Great long bitter finish.

Tasted on tap at the 2007 Bistro Hop Rhizome Festival. This IPA pours a medium amber color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is mild, but kind of bready and floral. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. Hops are grapefruity and floral. There is a touch of spiciness from the rye. Good carbonation. A medium bitter IPA, the hop flavors are about in the middle of the scale. Mouthfeel is perhaps a touch thin, but not every sip. Which is kind of strange. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is bitter with a touch of alcohol bite.
ON tap at Freddy’s brewpub. Solid middle-of-the-road offering with just enough nutty, toasted character to be keep things interesting.
On tap at Freddy’s, pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of bready malts, light caramel, and grass. Pretty ordinary but well-enough made. Decent stuff.
Draft - Light malts and a hit of toffee. Clear amber with a rich white head. Grains, light caramel and a watery finish. A very light drinking amber, almost like a British Mild.

Draught at the brewpub Darkish amber color, clean; creamy head. Very light aroma and flavor of caramelly malts, with ordinary bitterness, an inpression of chlorine (bad tap) water, and a slightly metallic finish. Boring.

1 of a 6-variety sample tasted on 03/10/2011. Colour: Maple syrup. Nose: Butterscotch, olive, maple syrup. Taste: Light sweet, light bitter, light sour. Hazelnuts, almond paste, grassy but very light overall.
Amber body with no head. Faint malt aroma. Caramel sweet in flavour with not very much hop presence to tame the sweetness. Finishes a little sweet and simple.

I actually don’t know if this is a lager or ale. It could go either way. Fairly standard-looking amber colour. It was served rather cold for much aroma to escape, a bit caramelly, maybe grainy. Flavourwise is tended towards a mild sweetness, with subtle caramel and fresh malt notes. Very clean - hence why I’m not sure of the yeast. Typical of Freddy’s brews in that it’s well made but not terribly flavourful.
Tap@ Panther Room. Cloudy orange pour, white head and medium lace. Citrus hops from nose to finish, light-medium body, not very complex. A typical PNW IPA.

9/28/08 On draught at the Panther Room, Seattle, Wa. Aroma is caramel malt infused with grassy citrus flora. Appearance is hazy orange with a well maintained white head. Flavor is a bit harsh with a very starchy resin, low sweetness and somewhat sour bittering. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a moderate carb texture and dry finish. Overall, interesting, but not easy drinking enough.

This brew is made and served exclusively for the Cyclops bar in Belltown, Seattle. Was told they add an extra bag of hops (dry hopping?) to there regular IPA (which is sensational) to create this brew. Gorgeous sunset color, with a nose full of cascades! Wonderful cascade hope flavor, possibly rounded out by crystal. Just enough bitterness to give it backbone. Quite a tasty IPA.

Clear golden color. Green apples and cloves in the nose. Not tart, but green apples, wheat, cinammon and funky yeasty character in the mouth. Rich apple brandy toasted malt finish. The aftertaste just sits there and lingers. Very interesting, but not really a hefe.

My Bottom Line: This off-the-wall wheat beer does not set its foundations into any known style (not surprising, this is a Hakusekikan beer after all), yet even if it throws you off, it should eventually conquer you with its sweet apple fruitiness, honeyed maltiness, and enlightening tartness. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circles the deep gold. -This is not a Weizen at all in the nose, barely showing a few cereals. -The lean body, frothy effervescence, and fruity tartness recalled quite cidery. -After reading the other guys’ ratings, I wonder if our glass was on its way down...in any case, it was definitely far from the usual style characteristics when paired side-by-side with the Fujizakura and Hidatakayama Weizens. On tap at Popeye’s.

Draught at Popeye’s. Hazy golden with a smallish head. Banana, wheat, spice, yeast and sweet malts in the aroma. Flavor is fruity - citrus with strong banana notes, wheat, yeast, and some spice. Light, refreshing body. Nothing out of the ordinary but light and refreshing on a warm summers eve.

On tap at Popeye’s in Tokyo. Slightly hazy golden color with a thin white head that disappeared very quickly. Aroma of sweet citrus fruits, wheat, and a certain sugariness. Rich fruity flavors (banana, citrus), with spices and a bready yeast base. Decent carbonation and a crisp refreshing mouthfeel make this a very good hefeweizen.

draught. taps a medium amber with a white head. smells very sweet and somewhat like a sorghum beer. flavor is sweet and has some indescribable flavor. pleasant though. drinkable but not a head turner.

Tap at the brewery. Clear orange amber colored body, no head really at all. Weird smelly, sugary fruit cocktail nose, but not really smelling of hops, the hemp smells more like sweaty fruit, but not any hop. Sweet and syrupy, low carbonation. Sweet fruity pears and marachino cherries tasted, altogethor it tastes like a spoiled.
Brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, light vanilla. Taste of strong caramel, faint roast, sweet on the finish.

Pours a nice clear ruby with a thin tan head. Aroma has light fruity notes...almost a black cherry note but not sweet. Flavor has nice dark fruit and earthy hops to balance. Mouthfeel is full and silky with a nice balanced fruity/earthy finish.

Tap. Pours clear dark amber with a small, frothy off-white head, short retention with good lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malt with dates and plum esters and light earthy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops, bitterness, and fruity esters and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Tap. Pours clear light brown with ruby highlights and thin, creamy off-white head; decent retention and spare lacing. Aroma is fairly mute with notes of cookie and caramel malts, mixed berries, floral hops, figs, and light vanilla. Flavor is dried fruit, lightly sweet bready malts, light floral hops, and faint vanilla; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

tapped a deep amber with a dense nitro-looking head. sweet smelling and tasting it is lacking a bit in complexity, but more than makes up for it in drinkability. very smooth for the supposed 5.9 % abv, I polished off 2 pints before my food even arrived.

Draft, Bube’s. Pours a bright, cherry-amber color; headless. Very minimal aroma: some dried fruit and caramel, at most. Average carbonation. Medium mouthfeel: chewy dried fruits, cherries, and caramel at the core; decent weight and viscosity in the mouth; on the sweet side, but good density at the center and mild mineral bitterness; medium, dried red fruit and caramel in the finish; well-balanced throughout.
On tap at the Bubes Brew Pub. Poured a deeper amber color with a very small sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, earthy, and grainy. Tastes of lighter earthiness, nutty, toffee and caramel.

Pours a reddish/orange/amber with a smaller bubbly/creamy off white head. Aroma of malty sweet grains, toffee, nuts, some floral and caramel notes. Flavor of nuts, malty sweet grains, some citrus, molasses and toasted malts.
I wasn’t too impressed with this brew. Body was kinda thin, taste was lacking, maybe it wasn’t fermented long enough or it got tainted, but this just didn’t taste all that great.

Tap at the brewery. Clear copper color, small head. Very faint nose, light-to-medium bitterness, tinny grains and light coarse maple... not sweet at all. Very plain, so much so I couldn’t really write anything down about this beer.
Aroma:verry spicy,orange anmd fruity... Appearance:Light hazy gold,light head... Flavor:Very spicy,fruity,orange and citrus...
Robe blonde paille voilée surmontée d’une mousse blanche en dentelle. Arômes d’agrumes et de céréales. Saveurs de malt, d’oranges et d’épices.

Bottled (5.5 %, old backlog). Golden colour, no head. Aroma is apples, some resin and mild earthy notes. Flavour is similar, with also some yeasty notes to it. Mild sulphury notes become evident as it warms up a bit.
Bottle.Clear colour with no head.Aroma of rotten apples and applejuice,feels dry and mild lively mouthfeels and sweet with hint of wood and apples.
Bottle. Aroma of wood, apples and yeast. golden yellow colour. Dry flavour with distinct aplle taste. Low carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a clear, pale yellow/golden with a faint greenish glow. No head. Dry, sour apple aroma. Flavour is sweet and a bit dry. Earthy notes. Dryish and mildly bitter finish with a sour note. 02-03-08.

Københavnske Øldage 07. Bottle. Papsoe, thanks for sharing. The color is very light straw and the aroma is sweet and very like an apple juice. The flavour is watery, sweet and is a bit like apple juice. It’s boring.
Bottled. Pale golden coloured. Apples and vanilla in the aroma. Sweet apple flavour. Moderately dry finish. Medium carbonation.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and slight pale yellow and with a diminished white head. Slight dry woody apple aroma. Slight sweet and acidic apple flavoured. Ends dry and with a mild acidity. Nice.

Bottled. A light golden cider with a thin fast disappearing white head. The aroma is sweet and dominated by apples, while the flavor is sweet with notes of apples as well as wood, leading to a dry woody finish.
Bottle. No head. Pale yellow nice colour. Powerfull nice aplle aroma and flavor. Very dry. Oily palate. Nice cider.
Clear pale yellow colour. Aroma of pear with a little sweetness. The flavour is rather thin with some pear and sourness. Dry bit sweet finish.
on tap at west seattle location. aroma is somehow enhanced from the original. caramel vanilla and chocolate aroma. chocolate and caramel tastes with a lingering alcohol finish. quality

draft at the brewery. jet black with a towering moussy dark tan head. loose stringy lace coming down the side of the glass. sweet, almost tangy chocolate nose. plenty of cheap coffee there as well, maybe a little basement to boot. creamy thick body. chocolate, coffee, and char on the mid palate. lingering char finish. big and tasty and fun to drink, could stand some subtlety and complexity. no clue on the vintage here.

Nose is full of sweet chocolate, some roast, caramel, and a little dark fruit. Pours almost black, brownish undertones, no head or lace. Sweet and chocolatey with some dark fruity notes. Light roasted malt shows up, but this is a chocolatey impy stout. Some noticeable alcohol with an almost viscous body. Creamy and almost smooth.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Coffee roast aroma. Small beige head. Black strong in alcohol and hoppy with a crisp and bitter coffee roast finish.

Draft. Fudge black color. No head, but subtle tan rim around the edges. Raisins, chocolatey, with hint of apple. Thin, syrupy-like flavoring with soda consistency and body. Not much beyond initial punch to recommend it - though high alcohol content does make an appearance in the deep recesses of the throat. Ok, but really a disappointment given how much richness an imperial stout style affords the brewer. Seemed flat and unimaginative.

On tap at the 2007 GABF: Barely transparent dark mahogany pour has a tan ring of head. Aroma of lightly sweet dark caramel malt with a hint of pear and dark chocolate. Body is fairly thick with a sticky caramel malty sweetness and some tart light fruity notes toward a doughy finish. Needs a little more balance.

Date: 10/13/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, GABF black, creamy tan head, dark chocolate aroma with a touch of roasted and vanilla sweetness, creamy body, rich chocolate flavor, dark caramel sweetness, roasted keeps the sweetness in check, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

GABF 2007: Poured a deep brown with a tan head. The beer had an alcohol nose. Also notes of old coffee and some roasted malt. The flavor was also of old coffee and a touch of tartness. The finish leaves coffee in the mouth. Very dry. Medium to full bodied with a silk mouthfeel.
Black with good head. Chocolate aroma with decent roasted grains. Too sweet for my liking...doesn’t taste, or feel, like 9%.
On tap at Brewpub Seattle. Pours out a almost black topped with a tan head. A nice burnt malt aroma and tast. A little think for an Imperial Stout. 9% on this one.

THIS BEER IS RETIRED, please see the "Weiss" entry for the 2008 version, thanks: This rating from the growler but I had two of these earlier at the brewpub, I served this in my Wiehenstephen weizen glass which makes sense! Pours mostly clean since the yeast is at the bottom of the bright tank, topped by a huge fluffy white head and excellent lace. Looks all the part of a classic hefeweizen. Onward towards to nose where I found a fresh banana and clove ester, mild grassy notes and a classic bubblegum overtone. Smells the part of a classic hefeweizen. The taste is mildly fruity and malty and quite refreshing minus a hit of soapy aftertaste. Mild spice and flowery qualities also found within. What I like about this is you can notice the wheat bill without a struggle unlike many American made versions. The mouth feel is softer than the German original is is dryer than many hefes as well. A fine effort from Back Road, Kudos! Worth a try for anyone looking for a solid summer brew.
Fruity aroma. Clear golden colour with poor head. Standard stale flavor, no real hop or malt profile. Light body with mediumcarbonation.

BB 02MAY14. Poured a clear golden amber with a one-finger white foamy head that diminished fast to a collar that laced OK. Carbonation low with rare small bubbles. Aroma subtly of light malt is quite pleasant but typical of a lager; no hops. Taste of slight sweetness and a very slight bitterness if anything at all. Light body. Smooth crisp refreshing but another run-of-the-mill macro brewed lager.
On Tap- very dissapointing beer. Just a watered down VB. Not worth detailing. Reminds me of Coors Light and that is not a good thing.
Only ever got to shot gun this through the can after losing a bet at work. Was shit then, still shit now
Bottle - pours light orange with a loose head. Not much of an aroma. Some malt on the taste and dry finish. Pretty straight forward, think I prefer it to full strength VB!
same crap as normal VB. only difference is it is a mid strength. still tastes like cat piss

375ml stubby. Clear gold with a negligible white head. Faint malt aromas and little else. Light sweet malts on the tongue. No hop presence. Light bodied with a thin watery mouthfeel and abrupt finnish. Actually tastes a little less "chemical" than a full strength VB. Still awful.

375ml bottle. Bland to look at when poured with a taste to match. Thin and watery with no head, small white bubbles only. Skunky aroma with a heavy hop mixture. Bland taste and texture, not flavoursome at all.

Can @ home You would have to drink this to find out how bad it really is, but that is not something that I would recommend. This ’brew’ tastes phenomenally bad; I never poured it from the can so I can’t comment on the appearance but it had a rancid aroma and a nasty watery texture and metallic taste. Totally unpalatable. I imagine rust would taste much like this does.

Another rather thin and watery, mass-produced Australian beer. This is the sort of stuff you buy a case of for a house party, not something you buy to savor and compare tasting notes. But you could do worse. A cold VB on a hot Australian day can work wonders.

yeah...pretty much duclaw’s version of a corona. not too much to it...a little sweeter than your typical light lager...pretty drinkable. i’m content to just have it the one time a while back...just getting to adding some of my old tasting notes.

20090707 Tap at Bel Air location. Meaty and malty with light vegetal flavors. Mostly reminds of white sandwich bread. Metallic aromas. Little to no hop presence. Husky. I swore it seemed adjuncty, but the folks behind the bar swore it was all malt so...okay. With beers like this on tap, I don’t get why the brewpub has to stock something like Miller Lite, yet they do.

Lets just put it this way.. this beer is made for the brewery to make money off of people who think Corona is the nectar of the gods. I can’t blame them for trying to make money. And yes, this beer blows

Draft at the 2009 MD Spring Fest. Light yellow with a hint of green. Super filtered. Refreshing middle-of-the-road Helles. Well balanced, with a hoppy crispness. Some doughy yeast. All around a good straight forward session beer.
Thought this was pretty good for a crappy light beer. If you compare it to other pale lagers, its nice. Sweet, grainy, good flavor. Most of all, its clean with no skunk.
on tap-pours a white head and pale yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain, continental hops (Hallertau?). Taste is sweet grain-honey, continental hops (Hallertau?)-lemon. Mild carbonation.
Draft @ Bel Air location. Boring, watery lager. Seems odd that a brewpub would make a Corona clone - that’s basically what this is. Drinkable, but not DuClaw’s best offering.

On tap @ Arundel Mills. Golden yellow color w/a moderate white head. Aroma of corn & bread dough. Kind of a basic, easy drinking, light, summer brew. This will never be confused w/a classic, world class brew, but it’s not trying to be. It’s just a beer you can knock a few back & enjoy w/o thinking about it too much. Some flavors of bread dough & hay, maybe a little corn. Very slight hop bite. Decent mouthfeel, not too thin. Plesent finish.

Sparkling gold, fizzy white head. Soft cornbread and faint earthy citrus aromas. Flavor is corn and lightly sweetened citrus throughout. Well balanced and refreshing. Light bodied with light carbonation. This would be easy to put a growler down on a typical MD summer afternoon...

An average Cerveza. Enjoyed as a part of the sampler from the Arundel Mills location. Threw a lemon in the glass and it ended up tasting like lemon. Very Corona-like and nothing more, except maybe a fuller body. That’s it.

From Jul 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with Lofgrep. Thanks Peter! This pours a clear copper colour with a 1 finger head of foam. It has some lacing and though the foam shrinks a lot, there's still some there at the end of the session. Overall, a very nice looking brew in my glass. The smell has some caramel malt in it but the hops dominate with citrus and some grass. The taste at first sip is on the sweetish side with good caramel notes and some grain but the hops follow very closely with some nice citrus and a touch of grass that adds some good bitterness. I think there's some other fruitiness here but I'm not all sure which one(s) I'm tasting. The finish is definitely hop oriented with a nice bitter citrus flavour that is fairly long lasting. Good close to medium mouthfeel and this brew is working for me. I'm glad it came in a 22oz bottle because it sure is easy enough to drink. Well done Flat Earth! I'd be glad to drink this during the hot days of summer, which it currently is. ;^)

On tap at Black Sheep. Pours a clear gold with an orange hue and a near white head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has a good amount of sweet grains supported by graham cracker and a hint of grass. Flavor starts with sweet grain and bread but has a hint of grass growing.
Bomber. Dark amber with minimal head. Malty, light caramel, grassy hops. Taste is very mildly bitter. Medium to lighter body with a soapy feel. Simple beer, would be a good summer beer.

Pour on tap at APN 2013, clear yellow pour with white head, aroma brought notes of grass biscuit, hints of spice, slight cracker notes as well, pretty clean. Taste is a mix of cracker, biscuit, some grass, hints of spice, finishing slightly grassy, grainy.
Steamy steam beer on tap. Lighter far but still some good elements. Hops are lingering.
Bomber. Golden/amber pour - very clear. Small foamy white head. Aroma is crackers and mild toffee, with a highly carbonated palate. Taste is a little dry on the finish.
Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a light brown color with white head. Caramel, toffee flavors with a dry, lingering finish. Good California Common.

Bottle @ Brad’s house Minneapolis picked up at Zipps. Pours a clear, dark orange appearance with a bubbly, khaki head. Somewhat nutty, herbal/grassy, somewhat toasty caramel malty aroma. Somewhat bitter, earthy/herbal hoppy, toasty cracker, biscuity, light caramel flavor. Ok.

Dark copper and clear with moderate carbonation and foamy head. Aroma of Yeasts, pale malts, barley, cider and caramel. Flavors of Yeasts, cider, malts and slight hoppy aftertaste. Body is light and moderately carbonated. Good tasting beer overall that finishes well.
On cask at Firkin Fest. Easy drinking and refreshing, this hit the spot on a hot afternoon. But only good for sessions.

The color is very reddish brown, slightly hazy. The foam is somewhat thin and evanescent. However, left little spontaneous foam residues on top. It smells very clear and pleasant of fresh apples with a slightly sweet malt aroma. The tart and familiar taste of a ripe apple is the first impression tasting and a little later appears the sweet hint of malt. The taste is also cinnamon and banana, and lead into a soft and not too sweet final. The tangy and sweet combined really well in this beer.

Bottle. Best before ’08. Pours a Clear amber color with a small longlasting off-white head. Has a fruity spicy chocolate and weak apple aroma. Fruity malty slightly acid apple flavor. Fruity spicy slightly acid apple finish with hints of caramel.

Bottle shared by Theis. Poured hazy amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is aplle vinegar, caramel, spices, acid and sweet fruit. The flavour is light balsamico, caramel, acid, sweet fruit and sweet apples. Long sweet/sour finish. Quite good actually.
Old notes from DØE Valby 07. Cloudy amber with orange notes. No head. Aroma and flavour is malt and apple.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2007, Valby. Pours a hazy orange beer with almost no head. The aroma is fruits (apple) with sourness. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is dry with a little sweetness. Overall an average beer.

Bottle. Hazy reddish-brown with a nice off white head. Aroma of apples and grape along with a fruity sweetness and some malt ditto. Flavour is initially slightly sour with notes of apple, but then becomes sweet and more malty with spices showing themselves and ending in a dry lemonish bitterness. Gets better with every sip, so this is a beer that deserves more than a just a quick 3 mouthfull rating.

Bottled. A slightly hazy dark-amber with traces of brown in it with a bubbly light tan head. The aroma is sweet with notes of fresh apples mixing in with notes of wheat, making it a very refreshing aroma - reminding me of spring. The flavor is sweet with apples hitting first with the slight acidity of a fresh green apple - or a medium cider, then comes the malt and wheat and gives it some body, before the refreshing acidity comes back. The finish is dry and wheaty with a slight note of the apples lingering.

Bottle, 6.5%. Hazy orange/brown colour, looks thick when poured. Small head. Acidic aroma with a hint of green apple. The flavour is quite acidic, cidery with some apple juice and wild yeast notes. Some sweetness to balance. Strange and perhaps infected, but not bad.
Bought at Nørrebro Br.Hazy brown colour with small head.Taste of sour appels and vinegar,feels more like cider a really bad taste.

Bottle at NB (Launchday). Unclear dark amber – nice tight light amber head. Apple, sweetness, light dusty, salt and vinegar (sour/bitter – almost like lambic acid, but very nice and delicious) - (5/4/6/315)..... ReRate: Clear dark reddish/ brown - white head. Light apples, vineous, light oxidation - green walnuts, light balsamic, light acid, red berries, nice light flamish sour like !!!

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Piwo koloru ciemnej miedzi z rubinowymi refleksami, pianka w postaci obrączki. W aromacie słodko i bourbonowo. Czuć suszone owoce, karmel, dębina, kokos, wanilia, nuty ciemnych owoców, alkohol niewyczuwalny. W smaku świetnie ułożone, dobry balans między słodyczą a wytrawnością. Czuć karmel, suszone owoce, dużo wanilii i kokosa, lekka kwiatowość, mokre drewno, nuty tostowe i nawet delikatna orzechowość. Alkohol lekko rozgrzewa podniebienie. Sporo ciała, niskie nasycenie (praktycznie go nie ma). Mega dostojne, eleganckie i degustacyjne piwo, swietnie zbalansowane i smaczne. Najlepszy barley wine BA jaki do tej pory piłem.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 2013 375mL bottle drunk 10/12/18. Dark mahogany with cola tints. Good clarity. Beige head fades steadily to a ring. Oh ya, lovely bourbon and oak mix with toffee and molasses, very lightly warming alcohol and soft vanilla. Spicy and full with light chocolate and raisin lingering. In the mouth, it's soft, slippery, spicy and full of a good mix of oak and bourbon. Everything has aged incredibly well, with little/no oxidation and great malt and wood integration. Super low but tight carbonation with chocolate and vanilla longering alongside fruity esters and warming alcohol. Thins out on the very end with very spicy bourbon and vanilla lingering. Goid attenuation. Lightly sticky at times but not sugary or syrupy in the least.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Thick, sweet, and syrupy, with an unrelenting booziness bordering on overpowering. Not that this is a bad thing: BBA Angels Share is malt pushed to its indulgent extremes, a celebration of fermentation with nary a care as to balance or restraint. Waves of caramel, toffee, date, and fig fade into a booze-fueled bourbon extravaganza on the finish, wood and vanilla and a mild hop bitterness trying in vain to offset the liquor flood. Good, but I'd be hard-pressed to finish a pint; eight ounces are plenty.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle at home. Hazy copper brown with a brief, beige head. Massive aroma and taste of vanilla, caramel, bourbon and toffee. Quite sweet, yet the light roast is balancing it out elegantly. Great sipper!

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Barwa brunatna. Aromat intensywny, suszone owoce (rodzynki, daktyle), melasa, nuty palonego karmelu i b. intensywna beczka: wanilia, kokos, migdały. W smaku słodkie, pełne i bogate: suszone owoce, karmel, bardzo wyraźna beczka, dużo wanilii i kokosa. Finisz lekko taninowy, nieco alkoholowy, rozgrzewający.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 180417 bottle. [backlog] Beer to celebrate the birth of our twins! Delicious. Great end to an unforgettable day. Pours hazy brown, not really any carbonation there. Soft toffee nose, sweet milk chocolate, not really roasted, more like going into molasses direction. Taste has lots of sweetness, dried brown fruits, figs, some plums and lots and lots of molasses.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Alluring aroma in an inky black pour. Massive semi-sweet chocolate flavor with hints of liquorice, aniseed, coffee, and vanilla (amongst others). An excellent example of the style - albeit dangerously delicious.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle at puttetjes. Brown with no head. Sweet roasted malts, caramel, overripe strawberries, leathery, grainy bourbon, tutti fruity and massive vanilla smoothness. Big sweet and moderate bitter. Full body and soft carbonation.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle shared thanks to sjogro. Hazy dark brown with small short lasting beige head. Massive bourbon, sweet vanilla, toffee, fudge, brandy, light alcohol, raisins, brown sugar, creamy vanilla pudding. Quite sweet and medium bitter. Full bodied with slick feel, soft carbonation and some booze. Lovely.

column1: Lost Abbey The Angels Share - Bourbon Barrel
column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle 375ml at home. Bourbon 2012. From Bierkompass. Pours dark brown, no head. Unfortynately this one is not so well aged. Dried fruits, brown sugar, bourbon barrel, alcohol, licorice, malty bitterness. Full oily body, flat carbonation, rounded mouthfeel. Original rating 10-4-9-4-17. Sample from bottle at SBWF 12 2012-10-04.

Draught at the brewpub. Poured a dark rd clour with a slightly off white head. Light nose of dark malts, yoghurt and coffee. Roasty, kina creamy taste. Ok, kinda nice balanced dark ale, didn’t notice the spicces though and it seems to have improved.
Draught at Perho´s march 2008. Dark ruby color, no head. Nose of roasted malts and dung (?). Lactoses, no hops but malty sweetness. Sour & dry finish, not very pleasant.

Draught (Helsinki Beer Festival 2004) Reddy brown, small head. Sweetness came over more as a sticky banana than honey. Sweet and a bit alcoholic, but not offensively so. Should re-rate, presume a duff batch, as Perho can do better.

Draught @ravintola perho. Dark rubyish brown colour with small beige head. Aroma is sweet and acidic vinegary. The flavour is also a very sour thing. I didn’t find anything of the honey and coriander in it, just a weird sweetish sourness along with some malts and hops. Not very pleasant brew...
Cask in the Kings Head in Bishop's Castle. A standard toasty bitter with citrus notes.

9/2/2019. Bottle from Beer Dock, Crewe. Pours pale amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of biscuit, malt, hop, fruit and resin. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily and watery texture, above average carbonation.
Bottle from Beer Dock, Crewe. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are grain, bread, malt and hops. Grainy bready finish.
Bottle from Beer Dock, Crewe. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, toffee and labre larver. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. 090219

Cask ale, half-pint shared with Finn at Salopian Bar. Off-white head leaving clingy lacing down the glass. Clear amber body. Moderate smell of toffee and dough. Taste is rather sweet, coconuts and toffee. Doughy end. Drinkable but rather empty mouth feel. (Shrewsbury 05.10.2018).
Fra cask på Salopian, Shrewsbury. Delt med Rune. Mørk gylden. Lavt skum. Smørmaltaroma. Smaken det samme. På overtid? Spor av frukt i ettersmaken.

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! A clear amber beer with a huge most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramelish malt, nuts, reddish malt. Taste of dry caramelish malt, nuts, spicy hops, toffee, medium bitterness, soft carbonation.

Many thanks to Minutemat for this bottel! Malty nose. The beer starts very dry, malty. Moderate bitter, very dry but rich and full-bodied. Nice but a bit dry aftertaste, sessionable, dry malty in the aftertaste with a nice bitterness. Hazelnuts with hints of roast.

Bottle at Beerdock Leek. Pours a clear amber colour with a thin off white head. Aroma of toasted malts, tea, slight caramel, some orange, a little pine and subtle spicy hops. Taste of caramel, some fruit, some tea, a little toast, subtle orange and slight spicy, woody hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A short, dryish, spicy and woody hop bitterness in the finish. A hoppy bitter but that’s about it. Was expecting more from the aroma. Ok though.

Cask at the Three Fishes, Shrewsbury - pours a clear amber colour with a small off white head that quickly disappeared. Aroma is caramel malt and a similar caramel malt taste. A mild bitterness in the finish. Average in every respect.

Butelka 500ml.jasnozlote lekko metnawe. Piana biala obfita utrzymuje sie dlugo. Aromat raczej delikatny. Banany i lekki koleander w tle. W smaku podobnie mozna dodac jeszcze cytrynowy posmak na finiszu. Nie jest zle jednak zbyt plytkie w smaku i zapachu jak na pszeniczniaka. MarcinG

Bottle from Moonshine and Fuggles at Ironbridge. Slightly hazy gold with a middling white. Lemon and lime up front give a pleasant and refreshing light sourness to the beer. Mild bitterness in the finish. Quite pleasant.

Sampled from a bottle, a gift from Shropshire (thanks, Rachel). Golden colour with a really high white head. Aromas of spices, lemon and banana. The taste is quite light, but with intriguing flavours of banana, coriander and lemon. Slightly sour. Not really true to the Belgian style of Witbier, as it is a little thin and sour, but very nice and highly drinkable.

Bottle at Home. Light Amber ale with a thick white frothy head. Slight carbonation but not too bad. Aroma of bubblegum, fruit and sweet sugars, taste of how a wheat beer should be, again light fruit, and a sweet taste on the palate. Quite pleasant and refreshing.

9th November 2014 Hazy gold beer, big pale cream colour head. Palate is light, semi dry and minerally crisp. Airy malts, trace of creamy sweetness. A sourish lemony floralness, touch of herb. Light semi dry finish. Interesting!
500ml bottle. Pours pale gold with a large, frothy head. Aroma is coriander, basil and a little lemon. Taste has a little coriander to start and a strong coriander and basil finish.
Cask @ Old Harker Arms, Chester. Golden with a thick creamy head. It’s mild tasting with a floral aroma and taste but a higher sweetness in its nose.
Cask @ Shrewsbury Beer Festival. Nice and tasty vanilla sweet wheat, a little silkier than the grainy wheats but lovely stuff nonetheless. A nice mid-fest beer.

Bottled, 500ml from The Spar Shop in Chirk, Wales. Hazed gold with white head. This had a floral, fresh character from the start, perhaps a little thinnish, but there was a lemon note along with a hint of pear drop. I didn’t get the herbs to come through, but all in all a reasonable Wheat Ale.

50cl bottle from the Spar at Rhos on Sea. There’s definitely the expected tang of unmalted wheat in here and the lemon zest added, increases this aroma and and taste. It’s fairly true to the style, but I’d really have liked something of a bit more intensity - maybe orangey and a bit more creamy. It could do with just a little more body though I generally do like this style, so still enjoyable.
@Cloisters, Edinburgh. Golden/straw colour. Dull aroma, with maybe some pedio. Light, watery with light malt and pedio. Overall, quite uneventful.
cask at cloisters ... gold#n amber ... thin white head ... light fruit hop ... dull soft creamy hop ... non descript
Cask@Babington Arms, Derby. Pale beer with a strong head. The aroma and flavour are lighlty dry. Overall an average beer.

Cask, The Babington Arms, Derby. Golden with a dense white head. Aromas are dry hay and biscuit with sharp citrus and some spices. Flavours are dry with sharp lemon. Fairly citric with some creamy malts. Dry biscuit. OK.

Cask, Kingdom of Fife Beer Festival. Cloudy dark straw colour with no head. Nose is sweet malty, very interesting and complex, something really familiar, but can’t quite put my finger on what it is. Malty mouth, bready, slightly yeasty, quite an organic taste, with something slightly balsamic about it. Very nice, very drinkable. Best of festival for me.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Bouteille 341ml. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt rôti avec des notes de chocolat noir, de café, de levures fruitées (raisins) et de houblon herbeux. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse. Léger goût de levures aux notes fruitées (raisins, traces de cerises noires) accompagné de traces de vanille lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût moyennement amer de malt assez rôti avec des notes de chocolat noir puis en finale l’on retrouve une amertume assez asséchante de houblon herbeux ainsi qu’un léger goût de café et des notes de levures épicées (poivre très doux). Post-goût long-moyen et sec, moyennement amer de rôti, moyen de houblon herbeux et avec des notes de café et de chocolat noir (traces de moût de raisins).

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: 341ml bottle thanks to Glouglouburp given to me at BCTC ’07. One really great looking beer, vigorous pour garnered one HUGE light tan head sitting atop a dark thick abyss of black. Aroma was not so good. Huge nose of dust and mustiness. Hidden in the background is slight touch of malt but that is only noticed after really searching through the old basement mustiness. Full bodied with some large carbonation that was very lively. Flavor is lots of raosted malt with a slight touch of dark bitter chocolate. Looks great, smells bad, tastes average.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, biegaman & Viggo -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a large diminishing foamy light-brown head. Dry aroma of lightly roasted malt, sweet fruit, Belgian yeast, some spices and hops -- quite nice! Flavour of roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee, dark fruit, hops, alcohol and a dry, bitter finish -- surprisingly good. Medium bodied. Another good beer from one of Quebec’s finest breweries.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Bottle (750ml). Shared with blankboy, biegaman and viggo, my bottle via trade with Viper666. Deep black, slick-looking, average light brown creamy head. Light dry spicy hop aroma, mild licorice, vanilla extract - very dark. Taste follows, more bitterness, more dry spicy hops - thicker, too. Thick, silky body, mild carbonation, nice longer bitter deep roast malt finish. Very, very good.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Medium brown head. Opaque black body. Roasty, malty pine needle aroma. Dry musty roasty licorice taste with light hoppy background. Notes of chocolate. Kind of sweetish. Dry musty aftertaste. (0.75l bottle from glouglouburp.)

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Very dark brown body, chunks of yeast and a small tan head. Malt profile really feels like generic over-baked “black-cake”. Dusty yeast, some raisins distant back grapes, a little robber here and there. An overall dirty and dusty and the roatiness had this ashes feeling to it. A week later I shared a big bottle with some friends and the result was even more disappointing. It’s a good beer but I much prefer the original D’Ham Noire (without the “extra malt” label). Although to be fair “extra malt” can in fact translate to “unnecessary malt”.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: Verre de dégustation, provenant d’une bouteille de 750 ml. Souper "Bières & Francofolies" chez Glouglouburp. Arôme: Odeur de malts rôtis. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence d’un moyen col beige mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe de cacao. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Légère présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #1167)

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Noire Extra Malt
column5: My Bottom Line: Roastiness reigns on this frothy and dry Belgian Dark Ale, scarcely helped by coffee beans. A straightforward quaffer this is, overshadowed by its more complex and livelier brother, d’Ham Noire. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam covers the brown-sleeved black. -There may be more malt in the recipe than their regular Noire, but it does not contribute more body; it’s just very dry and roasty. -The back end is just more roastiness, and perhaps a smidge of supporting hoppiness if you’re really looking for it. -As is usual with Brasseurs du Hameau beers, the body is light and carbonation big-bubbled, providing the typically quaffable Belgian Ale character. Bottle.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: drank at quebec city beerfest. clear pale blond, small white head, ok-retention and lacing. honeyed malts, light but present grassy-citrusy hopping. lively, light body.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle: Poured a cloudy light beige color ale with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of nice solid malt backbone with light hoppy notes. Taste is very refreshing with some solid malt backbone with notes of floral hops and light citrus finish. Body is fuller then average with good carbonation. Not the most complex beer out there but very well done nonetheless.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: [2089-20090410] 375mL bottle. Floral egg noodles aroma with mild plastic pasta notes. Hazy, light orange brown body with a long-lasting creamy white head. More light floral yeast in the flavour with mostly pasta water and some candy red Twizzlers and a long aftertaste. Light-medium body is mildly dry. Average. (w/ GregClow, jerc)

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: 2009-04-10. Hazy orange amber body with a good foamy off-white head, large chunks from the bottom of the bottle. Yeasty grainy aroma, touch of cardboard/oxidation. Lightly bitter flavour, underlying pale malts, dry caramel and a dry finish. Yeast lingers in the aftertaste. Average palate is well carbonated. Meh. Bottle from shop in Montreal

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: A hazy golden ale witha super thick egg white head. A very grainy malt aroma, with mineral notes. In mouth, a crisp malt with lots of mineral qualities, light german hops, very lager like. Medium bodied Overall, a decent beer.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: Bouteille de 341 ml. La bière se présente avec une robe cuivrée-dorée surmontée d’une mousse imposante. Au nez on découvre des arômes de grain, de fleurs, de raisins secs avec une présence de houblon floral. En bouche le corps est moyen avec une effervescence moyenne. On goute des saveurs de grain suivit rapidement par une bonne amertume.

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: Bouteille 341ml. De couleur ambrée-dorée et voilée. Nez malté de grains de céréales, de houblon herbeux (herbe fraîche) et légèrement floral, léger de miel, de caramel doux et de levures fruitées (agrumes) ainsi que des notes de pain. Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et un peu croustillant ainsi qu’une texture très légèrement crémeuse. Moyen goût de levures fruitées (agrumes, traces de pêche) avec de petites notes de grains de malt pâle lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un léger goût de céréales avec des notes de biscuits au miel, de pain et de caramel doux. Parallèlement, l’on retrouve un moyen goût amer et légèrement asséchant de houblon herbeux (herbe fraîche) et un peu floral (ainsi que de petites notes terreuses) jusqu’en finale, où l’on retrouve également des notes de levures épicées (poivre). Post-goût moyen et un peu sec, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux et aux notes florales et terreuses ainsi qu’un léger goût fruité (zest d’agrumes).

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: Bouteille de 341 ml, acheté le 13/3/08 au Marché des Saveurs (Montréal), bu ce soir. Brune grise vaseuse, bon collet. Arome de blé malté un peu épicé, légèrement amère. Goût assez sec et amère, saveur de blé brute faible. Quelle sorte de bière c’est ça? Blonde sur lie, belge? Extra pale ale, anglaise? Non, bâtard!

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: En fût. Verre de 12 oz dégusté chez Brouhaha. (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Légère odeur de malt et d’houblons. Apparence: La couleur est orangée voilée. Présence d’un large col mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de malt légèrement fruité avce une pointe d’épices. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement houblonné. (Rating #1489)

column1: Les Brasseurs du Hameau dHam Sud (Blonde Extra Pale Ale)
column5: My Bottom Line: An adorable balance of spicy, leafy hops and homely honeyed cereals resides in this modest and highly convenient quaffer of a Golden Ale. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sticky ring of foam circles the hazy peach golden. -The malts have that personality intrinsic to the Frontenac maltsters; that farmy, grainy greenness is definitely detectable. -The finish lengthens the leafy side of the chosen hops and adds some grassiness too. -A subtle tropical fruitiness can be found in the nosem blending in perfectly with the malt and hop profiles. -Although it’s name might have you expect an English style, du Hameau’s house yeast is definitely Belgian... -I get the impression the tap version was a tad better integrated than the bottles. On tap at Brouhaha.

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle, best before April 2021. Almost clear, golden with a white head. Sweetish, fairly artificial and slightly fruity aroma of passion fruit and some lemonade. Sweetish, slightly sourish, gently artificial and quite fruity taste of passion fruit and lemonade, followed by a short, slightly tart finish. Thin to medium body, slightly astringent and gently effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Okay, way more pleasant than the mango one.
Süß-säuerlicher, fruchtig saftiger Beginn. Keine Spur von Bier, steigende Säure, erfrischend. Trinkbar. 8/6/7/6/9/7
skunky, bubblegum, orange, red, hazy, minimal head, white foam, heavy cloying sweetness, heavily sour, lightly bitter, light body, fizzy, astringent,
From a bottle in an Ethiopean place in Frankfurt. I thought it was African, well, lesson learned. It's beer with passion fruit sirup, not even bad, but not really a banger.
0,33l bottle from beerbottle.eu. I dont like the taste of passion fruit, therefore this is the worst Dju Dju juice imo. Dont call it a beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours hazy orange with a white head. Some artificial passion fruit aroma. Flavor is sweet with a sticky end.
300ml Flasche. Leicht trüb, bernsteinfarben. Mittlere Schaumkrone. Pappsüss, leicht säuerlich. Überhaupt kein Biergeschmack.
Lys brun klar med lavt hvitt skum. Eple, ananas og pasjonsfruktlukt. Smaker søt pasjonsfruktlukt. Lett syrlig.
Lys brun med tynt hvitt skum. Lukter selvfølgelig pasjonsfrukt. Syrlig og fruktig i smak. Søtsyrlig avslutning.

# 3518 ersma: ist ja spannend, das wird in belgien für eine firma in ghana gebraut. ist das dann ein bier aus ghana oder aus belgien? orange mit leichtem rotstich. recht schaumbefreit. der geruch ist intensiv nach passionsfrucht, etwas zu intensiv. abert sind ja auch natürliche aromen drin. der antrunk ist süßlich bis süß, auch hier passionsfrucht, die baer in ihrer übertriebenheit gekünstelt wirkt. dahinter säuerlichkeit und ein hauch hopfen. zur mitte wird es marginal herber und vor allem weniger süß. auch das gekünstelte aroma nimmt ab. der abgang birngt nichts neues, das bier verblasst einfach. die flasche ist noch das beste am ganzen. fazit: tut nicht not. 8,6,5,6,10,6 - 6,25 28/9/14

5/01/2007: The Cincinnati version of the Rock Bottom Vienna has a slight Mexican flare to it... Color is clear, reddish amber. It has a thin frothy head that is off-white in color. Weak malt is present in the aroma. The flavor has a bit more malt (medium level), but is comparable to that of a Mexican "Vienna" Lager rather than that of a more full true German Vienna. The malt presence is toasty in character. Medium-light body with ample carbonation. This beer is easy to drink, but is lacking depth and excitement. 20 oz draught (mug) at Rock Bottom Cincinnati complements of Tmoney99. Thanks Tom!

Draft at brewpub at Mug Club Tapping. Poured clear dark amber with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate nuts and malty aroma. Medium body. Medium toasted balanced flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. This is an upgrade of a standard Rock Bottom brew.

Bottle. Reddish Brown in colour. Malty; caramel, lightly toasted malts. Fruity; light citrus, raisins. Hoppy; lightly hopped. Sweet malty fruity with a slight bitter hoppy edge. Disappointing. (2009-09)

Bottled. Goldeny orange colour with a small white slightly off-white creamy head. Aroma is caramel malts, some toffee, mild floral and citrusy notes along with some wood and slight spicyness. Flavour is ripe fruits, berries, some sweet malts, fudge and mild toasted notes.
Slightly hoppy in its aroma, not a lot of character elsewhere, but drinkable.
Csk by handpump at Camperdown Place, Glasgow (17 Mar 12) - clear amber ale, good off-white head, slightly cold, lightly hopped, well balanced, slight soapiness, easy to drink

14th March 2012 Liberty Bell Spoons. Clear amber beer. Small off white head. Light palate. Very mild fine carbonation. Tangy but mild lemon hops underpinned by mild malt. Dry finish. Not bad, goes down easy.

Hand-pulled pint in my local Spoon’s during the March 2012 Beerfestival. I have enjoyed all the beers I’ve had from Wolf and this was no exception. Clean looking: chestnut red and almost bright in appearance: an off-white crown of creamy textured head sat on top. The aroma was of mildly toasted malts sprinkled with some citrus esters, pleasant without being over-powering or heavy. The taste was a fine blend of beery things: malty yet not sweet, hoppy yet not bitter or too citrusy. The alcohol was well concealled within the flavours: this is an easy drinking beer and a pleasure to sip.

Cask (Pint): Some sweet malts and a faint touch of caramel along with some more earthly malts and possibly some dried fruits. Amber to copper colours with a fairly small, foamy white head at the top of the beer. Faint malts and caramel or perhaps toffee to begin with, but again like the smell the taste is also very weak and light. There is some bitter hops and malts with the bitterness staying around for a while. Slightly chewy with a medium body and a very bitter finish that is slightly dry. Carbonation on this one is very low and as is normally the case with a cask ale, it taste a little flat with a sightly warm feel. This one was like every other cask ale I can remember, the nose was fairly weak and light with the taste not much better. The feel was a slightly warm, flat one. 1001 Beers Blog:
Cask. The Punch Bowl (JDW), York. Thin white gold. Caramel, butterscotch. Sweet. Dirty aftertaste.
[Cask at the Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading] Amber, fruit and vanilla, a slight dusty bitterness but predominantly sweet. This gets tiresome quite quickly.

Cask at The Crosse Keys, JDW, London. Pours clear, rich gold with a creamy, foamy head. Sweet caramel and toast aroma. Medium sweet flavor with light caramel and toffee, light leafy bitters, faint ripe fruits. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Mildly sweet finish with bread, toffee, faint tangy fruits and light leaves. Fair.
Draft at the source. Clear yellow color. Aroma of light fruit. Taste is lightly funky fruit.

Clear orange body, medium sized white head and soapy lacing. Orange, other citrus, toffee and sweet grainy malts. Too malt forward for my liking. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a rounded finish.
From the tap poured a amber color with a good amount of head. Hoppy flavor with a lasting finish.

A golden ale with a thin a thin white head. Nice classy c-hops in aroma, lightly pinhey and smooth, over biscuitty malts. In mouth, a clean crisp american pale ale with good biscuitty malts, floral hops, grapefruits, classic. On tap at PA Flavor, April 9th, 2011.

On tap. Pours a clear and light amber with a average-sized white head. Aroma is grassy/floral hops and some matly notes. Flavor is much the same - the hops are slightly bitter. Very nice drinking. Tasty. This was probably my favorite of the sampler.
on tap, pours carmel amber with a thin off white head. Tons of hop aromas, very pleasant, flavors the same with nice bitterness offset by some toasted malt. Solid.

On draft and on cask at the brewpub. Light amber color topped by a fluffy white head. Smells of earthy, grassy hops, faint citrus. Taste is very similar with a touch of caramel. Somewhat on the dry side for a pale ale but that is how I like my hoppy beers. I think this was the best one that I tried during my visit to the Barrel Works.
On tap at the brewery...pours amber color, slight white head...scent had hints of floral citrus wiht some earthiness too it...taste was clean, grassy, some citrus and hops...decent.

On draught at brewer. Huge Goldings nose! Hazy amber pour with lots of soapy lace. Pale malts, biscuits and flour notes grace the tongue, with a nicely clean dry-hopped finish. Cleanses the palate decently. Dry citrus notes come in at the back of the pull, still bittered. A bit reminiscent of an American take on the English ESB.

Moderate amber-bronze color with an easy hop aroma of cascade and honey. Mild English Hop (Kent Golding) flavor with a moderate raw hop finish. Decent, English style Pale Ale, albeit one with some PNW hops.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark gold with a small off white head. Slight citric aroma, possibly grapefruit. Thick heavy oily citric taste, again with hints of grapefruit, and a sweet background maltiness. Mid bitter finish. Didn’t much like this, to be honest.

Bottle.. Amber with a small foam. Aromas are toffee and citrus with lots of spices. Burnt toast with grapefruit. Flavours are sweet malts with herbal notes. Spicy, peppery, nutty and quite fruity. Nice.
Bottle. Pours hazy red amber with almost no head. Good fruity aroma, folled by spicy fruity toffee flavours. Good dry finish. Flat. Decent.

[CASK: The Lass-O-Gowry, Manchester 01/12/06] A very festive fruity ale and a great taste. Good % makes it a perfect Christmas pint. I’m sure Santa wouldn’t get far on Xmas Eve after a few of these...bet he looks forward to a few once he’s finished his round though!
Keg at the Black Isle Bar, Inverness in 2016. Clear light amber with a white head. Aroma of citrus, dusty grain and bready malt. Fairly crisp. Nice gentle hoppy bitterness with fruity notes.
Cloudy amber colour. Light carbonation. Light sweet malted barley taste, bergamot and orange zest back taste.

330mml. bottle. @home, 03/10/2019. Clean orange colour with a medium white head. Good retention. Beautiful. Aroma is medium malty, citrusy and soft bready. Taste is orange citrusy, clean caramellized malts andand soft dried fruits leading to a medium bitter and dry finish. Next one please!
On tap at Salt Horse. Pours orange brown. Honey, cereal, pear, stone fruit, bread. Medium body. Decent.

06Jul2019 Bitter citrus fruits, creamy tangerine peel, creamy bitter malts. Clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More bitter citrus fruits, orange and lemon peel, tangerine, wet straw, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Very nice. Draft at Black Isle Bar and Rooms, Inverness.
Can from Cotteridge Wines; hazy amber pour with a bubbly beige head, aroma has sharp citrus and sweet malts, taste has caramel malts , tangerine an ipa from 2010 which is ok.
Orange, brownish clear appearance with a thin head. Smell of new furniture and fishy taste. Weird stuff. In the end I think the beer was off I've got served.

June 2019 330ml bottle, unfiltered, from a £10 Beer52 promotional pack. Hazy orange. Citric flavours above a reasonably rustic pale beer make. The crystal malt gives it a bit of charater and flavour. I'm not appalled by this, even if it does come from Beer52.
33cl bottle from Pastures Discount Foods. Medium creamy white head. Very hazy golden pour. light bitterness

33cl bottle on 19-Apr-2019, enjoyed in a snifter. Hazy orangiah amber colour with a small white head. Aroma of malt, citrus and pine. Medium body and carbonation. Taste of sweet malt, caramel, orange, grapefruit and floral pine. Hoppy, fruity and bitter.

Cask Stillage from the Outside Marquee at the Prince Of Wales, Foxfield 07/11/2009 Floral aroma. Copper coloured rich on the palate and fruity with a little dryness in a crisp bitter and floral full malt finish.

Cask conditioned at The Lamb & Flag, Oxford. Dark brown, ruby with cream head. A sweet malty beer, not sure whether this is a Stout, lacks the bitter dark roast notes, but in its own right it has a decent fullish body with a fruity, blackberry note. Reasonable.
[CASK: The Salisbury Ale House, Manchester 17/12/06] A OKish winter ale, not very high in % for a winter ale but a good flavour. Overal reasonable.

Hand bottled, thanks jeverszeuge! Muddy amber,rich creamy head. Aroma of banana with some careful smoke underneath. Medium sweet with rounded mouthfeel. Evident flavour of wheat malt and yeast induced bubblegum esters - the smoke stays in a distance and adds complexity. A good and refreshing, welll balanced smoked wheat beer.

Tap at the brewpub. Crisp hop nose, lemony, herbal. Peppery flavor, very bitter finish. Starkly bitter, actually, crisp and stark hop finish balances and then slightly overwhelms the rich, yeasty malts. Interesting.

On tap at the brewery. Slightly hazy straw color with white head. Aroma has a young beer character, quite yeasty but still fresh. Taste starts slightly sweet and malty, a bit of yeast character in the middle and finish is slightly hoppy and bitter. Medium body and carbonation. Not your regular pils but overall it’s a decent beer.

- trüb-gelbe Farbe mit guter Schaumbildung - schöne leichte Aromen nach Zitrone, Gras und Hopfenbitternis - perfekte Carbonisierung - geschmacklich dominiert der Hopfen das Bier mit einer fantastischen Herbe, welche nie unangenehm wird - ein guter kräftiger Körper mit einer fordernden Süffigkeit - selbst der Abgang bleibt immer voll und ohne jegliche Wässrigkeit Fazit: Das mit Abstand beste Gastronomiebrauerei-Pils

On tap the at the brewpub in Derlach. 22/07/2015 Three days after the Etape du Tour. Translucent bright yellow coloured pour with a lasting sticky white head. Aroma is nice grainstore, spicy hop, little wort, dry yeasty. Flavour is Crisp grainy, pils grains, straw, asssertive spicy bittering hop, earthy, grainy. Palate is crisp and drying in the finish, highish carbonation.

Vom Fass im Brauhaus in Durlach. 5,1% Alkohol und 12,5% Stammwürze. Gelbe trübe Farbe, fester heller Schaum. Duft nach Hefe, Grass, Heu und Hopfen. Hefe im Antrunk, grassig. Kräftig bitter im Abgang. Lang anhaltend. Viel Kohlensäure. Eher ein Kellerpils.

On tap at the brewpub. Cloudy golden color, good foam. Medium light aroma intensity; some fruitiness, light honey, malt and a little cardboard. Medium body & complexity. Good bitterness, ok balance. Pretty ok beer
Trübes goldgelb mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Hopfig, etwas Malz, der Hopfen dominiert, angenehm bitter.
Draft at the source. Slightly hazy golden color, ice cream cone head. Aroma of white pepper and hay. Taste is peppery straw. Not bad.
Tap. Color hazy golden with big white head. Aroma sweet, grass, hoppy. Taste sweet, fruits, grass, hoppy, bitter finish. Nice pils.
On tap at the Brewpub. Trübes goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr getreidig, malzig, noch zu junges Bier. Geschmack getreidig, bitter hopfig, grasig.

- wunderschöne braun-rote Farbe mit guter Schaumbildung - Aromen nach Malz, Honig und etwas Pflaume - perfekte Carbonisierung für diesen Biertyp - der Antrunk ist weich, herb und intensiv malzig - im weiteren Verlauf gewinnt eine angenehme Hopfenbitternis die Oberhand - das Bier behält bis in den Abgang eine hohe Drinkability Fazit: Einfach das perfekte Rotbier

Hand bottled (gezwickelt), thanks jeverszeuge! Hazy amber, average head. Fruity apricot aroma. Medium sweet, fruity and medium bodied with chewy mouthfeel. Some grasy hops mixes with canteloupe. Lingering dusty bitter finish. Peculiar and complex. I’ve never tasted anything like it before.
Dark brown. Aroma is woody, vinous. Rich smooth texture. It’s dry, woody and malty.
Cask at NWAF, 2011. Reddish-amber pour with a white head. Aromas of toffee, caramel, red apples. Flavours of caramel, malts, butter scotch. Quite a sweet finish.

Cask at NWAF 2009. A chestnut colored beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt, alcohol, and vegetables. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, vegetables, alcohol, and caramel, leading to a dry and lightly alcoholic finish.
Cask Stillage at the Town Hall, Stockport 01/06/2001 A strong old ale, almost wine like with fruitiness and a pronounced finish.

Cask @ National Winter Ales Festival 2009, Manchester. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty caramel aroma with some hoppy hints. Slightly roasted malty caramel and toffee flavor. Has a slightly sweetish malty caramel finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
cask at cloisters edinburgh ... copper ... sweet toffee and vanilla nose ... again the same tones in flavour ... ligth bitterness ... quite rich

Cask at The Friendship, Fallowfield, Manchester. Dark amber with white head. Fruit and malt in aroma. Mostly malt in flavour with undercurrents of berries. Decent initial dry finish, yet sweetness prevails. Surprisingly complex beer and bloody strong, too.

Cask (handpump) @ The National Winter Ales Festival 2008, Manchester, UK. Clear medium amber color with a small, fizzy - virtually none appearance, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, sweet, light hoppy, perfume. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily - syrupy, carbonation is flat. (170108)

[CASK: Victoria Hotel, Withington, Manchester 04/02/07] I totally agree with the description of this ale... Seriously strong and definatly high strength. A beautiful winter ale and wow what a taste. You must try!
[CASK: The Lass-O-Gowry, Manchester 05/02/07] A bad tasting ale that was difficult to drink. A poor ale. Not recommended.
Hefig herb säuerlicher, leider auch wässriger Antrunk. Das Ganze wird im Mittelteil unerträglich da die vorher vorhandenen Aromen sich komplett verabschieden. Schlecht. 13/7/4/5/8/5

Vielen Dank an kevnic2008 für diese Flasche! Milchig trübes goldenes Weizen mit ordentlicher weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr hefig, leicht fruchtig, getreidig, banannig. Geschmack bananig fruchtig, hefig, reife Früchte, phenolisch, getreidig.

Thanks to kevnic2008 for that one! Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Fruity aroma. Starts mild, malty-yeasty, more and more fruity with notes of banana. Finish more dry, less fruity. Okay.

Many thanks to Kevnic2008 for this bottle. The beer starts sweetish-mild. Very soft in carbonation - unlike sparkling wine. Easy drinkable - even from the bottle. Sweetish-smooth beer, clove but no banana, hints of bitterness in the end, yeasty aftertaste. Interesting.
Yellow coloured and unclear. Has a white head, medium duration. Spicy aroma, coriander, light bitter finish.
Bottled. Cloudy yellow. Sweet aroma of banana, almods and vanilla. Fruity and light-bodied of banana, nectarines and vanilla with notes of cloves and soap in the mild finish.

Bottled, thanks jeverszeuge Muddy pale yellow, brief head. Fruity citric nose. Fairly sweet and medium bodied with rounded spritzy mouthfeel. Some bubblegum and vanilla, but the use of champagne yeast has given this wheat beer completely different flavour and mouthfeel than an ordinary hefeweizen. Some of the gain in terms of unusual complex flavour is lost on the drinkability.

- orange-gelbe Farbe mit leichter Schaumbildung - Aromen nach Malz, Karamell, Honig, Banane, Hefe sowie etwas Koriander und Ingwer - gute, zurückhaltende Carbonisierung - der Antrunk ist überraschenderweise von einer sehr starken Bitternis geprägt - erst im Mittelteil schwingt eine zart-süße Honignote im Hintergrund mit - welche im weiteren Verlauf dann leider schnell wieder das Weite sucht Fazit: Einfach der „Bitternis“ etwas zu viel

On tap at the brewpub. Trübes dunkel goldenes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch würzig, kräftig malzig, hefig, Kräuter. Geschmack süß kräftig malzig, hefig, Kräuter, leicht alkoholisch.
10,3% alc. Pours yellow. Aroma us sweet bread and fruit with some floral earthy and spicy hop character. Slightly spicy and bitter end.
Heller, würzig bananiger Antrunk mit erkennbaren Alkohol. Die Hefigkeit bleibt vorhanden, hell, süß, zum Ende leicht bitter. Spritziges vollmundiges Bier, gut! 9/10/9/10//10
Fruity malty aroma. Hazy yellow to orange color, low white head. Flavor is full bodied, malty, alcohol, fruity, rum. Sharp bitter and alcoholic finish. A bit unbalanced.

My Bottom Line : An important doughy yeast presence attempts to slowly down the soaring alcohol heat while light banana esters and bubblegummy phenols politely express themselves. Further Personal Perceptions : -A veil of foam sits atop the dull, cloudy blond. -This remains a decent Belgian-style Strong Ale for a German brewer, but it would be second or even third tier in Belgium. But kudos to this brewer for trying something different! -The flavor profile is simple throughout. -The mouthfeel is almost elegant; well carbonated and not too sweet . -Herbal, spicy hop bitterness makes an appearance alongside the alcohol heat. Bottle. Thx Alex!

Bottle at the brauhaus in Durlach Muddy orange color, thin creamy head. Mild aroma; the flavor is malty, yeasty and quite Belgian, with a pleasant fruity touch; moderate residual sweetness; strong bitterness. Some alcohol warmth. Good

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as a touch of alcohol. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of caramel as well as medium notes of malt and light notes of alcohol.

Bottle 750ml. [ Courtesy of fiulijn ]. Light unclear medium yellow orange color with a small, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hay, moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long to average duration, peel bitter, overripped fruit, yeasty, light sour malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110223]
Bottle at Papsø’s - Thanks. Clear golden - white head. Sweetness, light yeasty, haym straw, light guldøl med belgisk gær, light fruity, wierd.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Incredible blend of an IPA and a porter. Aromas of chocolate and floral citrus. The flavor is bold and ends bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: On tap @ Ballast Point in Little Italy. Deep mahogany, beige head. Berry fruit and dark caramel, fruity body with a bitter finish.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Draught @ Ballast Point Little Italy, San Diego, CA Pours pitch black with a smooth head. Aroma of roasty malts, coffee, cocoa and hops. Taste is smooth, slightly roasty and hoppy with some grass and hints of coffee and licorice. Finish is smooth and slightly roasty with some hops and grass. Okay black IPA.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Draft. Pours amber brown with a beige head. Mild fruity hops, faint toasted malts, a good dose of bitterness, very light roast (if any), and a nice fruity hoppy finish. This occupies the space somewhere between "Hoppy Amber/Brown" and "Black IPA." Brown IPA, maybe? Kind of. Whatever it is, it’s well balanced and quite drinkable.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Nice black color, some hops but plenty of malt also overall it isn’t that heavy a pretty decent beer

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: On tap at the source. Pours a dark brown with a thin mocha head. Aroma is a balance between malty caramel and roast. Flavor leans toward the roast. Nice beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Keg at the Ballast Point taproom - San Diego. Pours deep brown with a foamy beige head. Good balance, some toasty bread, light mocha, dirt. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with soft roast, more bread, a bit of oily pine, baking cocoa. Good stuff.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Deep brown in color with a nice off-white head. Dry piney-hop aroma. Nice moderate roast character with strong dry piney hop notes.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: Keg at BP Little Italy, 12/11/14 . Dark mahogany brown with a decent tan covering. Nose is bitter roast, earthy hops, light charr, pine needles, red berry snappage. Taste comprises earthy hops, bitter tropical fruit infusion, light smoke, hint of cocoa, pine. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a bitter hop wash. Solid CDA.

column1: Ballast Point Black Eye Blended Ale
column5: [ Keg ][ 4oz ][ Ballast Point Little Italy ][ $1.50-2 ][ Stemmed Tulip Flute ][ 11.6.14 ] >> Deep, clear red pour with good foam. Excellent Black IPA nose, grilled lemon and orange. Tremendously rich with light roast, vanilla, and big hops. Taste is solid Black IPA with low roast, mild soil, but ultimately it is spot on and excellent all around- extremely hop forward, mild roast, great mouthfeel. Really good, I guess this is the secret to good Black IPA :O

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin lazing beige head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of over ripe fruits. The flavor issweet malty with primary notes of fruit, but also a slight alcohol burn, even though the body is thin.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: (Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Hazy, amber golden with a tall and very lively, rough, off-white head. Lightly tart, fruity nose. Medium body, sweetish fruity with a strangely alcoholic finish. No real bitterness. Quite unusual. 180907

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: 12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a huge white head. Malty aroma. Slight spiced. Sweet flavour with a minor spice note, slight malty. Ends mellow flavoured. Nice.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: Hazy golden color; creamy head; nice lace. The aroma is light, but what I discover underneath is not very good: vegetables; later a very light note of grape juice comes out. Round mouthfeel, but with all my goodwill I can’t like the flavor: iron, vegetables…. It’s not bad, but also not interesting.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: Bottled. Cloudy golden with lots of sediment and rocky head. Aroma of sweet malt with a touch of red wine. Sweet and lightly toffeeish, rather fruity. Solidly malty and mild flavoured, some almondy yeast character. Soft and warming. Interesting and quite tasty beer, but I’d like to see the flavours more developed.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: Bottled (Thanks Bov). Hazy orange colour, big white head. Aroma is lots of fruits, yeast , and some slight alcohol. Flavour is fruits, yeast and some slight acidic notes. Pleasant thing! Not much aftertaste.

column1: Brasserie de la Côte la Cabernet Sauvignon
column5: hazy reddish-amber colour with a big creamy foam; fresh fruity aroma (raisin) with notes of yeast; highly carbonated, sweet and tart/acidic; some astringence, no bitterness; the finish is soft and short with more fruity and yeasty notes

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: 330ml bottle served in a pint glass. A: Pours a slightly hazy orange color forming a nice big light yellow creamy and soapy head. Good retention and tons of lacings formed and left in the glass. S: Strong caramel in the nose. Caramel malts, excellent flowery and citrus hops. T: Pretty much as the nose. Slightly sweet upfront. Strong notes of caramel and crystal malts. some notes of roasted malts too. Good hoppy sting. Good bitterness level too. Hops profile is very grassy and a bit citrus. M: Medium body. A bit molasses. Good carbonation. Caramel and grassy hops bitterness in the aftertaste. O: Great drinkability. Excellent session APA. Indeed, a strong "American" character conduced mainly by the outstanding hops profile. [ BA Review @ 8/8/2010 ]

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Orangene Farbe, angenehm hopfig-herber Geruch. Der Antrunk ist angenehm herb-fruchtig, aber etwas flach-metallisch wirkend. Im Hauptteil ist das Bier vollmundiger, leicht hefig-mild mit angenehm herber Hopfennote, die aber in einen ganz leicht süße Würzigkeit mild eingebettet ist. Der Nachgeschmack ist lang anhaltend, angenehm herb-frisch und würzig-hefig mit ganz leicht süßlicher Note. --> interessantes Bier! Test vom 18.11.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,12,12,12,12,13 - 12,40

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Backlog - May 13, 2010. My 330ml bottle shared with blankboy and garthicus. Near-gusher on opening. Very hazy pale gold with a huge and lasting fluffy white head. Aroma of paint, avocado and weak resin (hey, that’s what my notes say). Dry, nutty and stale leafy flavour - a bit aggressive, but not quite to the point of harshness. Thick mouthfeel, solid carbonation, a bit astringent and quite quick-finishing. I guess it was a tad old when we drank it - fresh, I am betting this would have been pretty damned interesting.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: 12 ounce bottle shared by footbalm. Pours a very opaque yellow color with a large white head, some gushing out of the bottle. A sweet nose of honey and rich herbal malts and hops. Sweet flavors of herbal hops, grass, light honey, almost like a saison. Some dry oranges and pear. The bottle has the abv at 4.8% not 5.4. Best by Nov. 2009. Seems fine to me.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: (Old BA rate - bottle) Pours with a thinner slightly off-white head that’s pretty small; burnt orange hue that leans clearer rather than hazy. Aroma has notes of citrus, some apply, pineapple, and a light malt sweetness. Taste follows suit with some tartness on top of the passion fruit hoppiness.
