Leans a little too sweet for my taste in the style, and the hops are definitely overshadowed by the maltiness. Lingering bit of flowers and candy in the aftertaste, and doesn’t stand up to the better ones in the range. MF is almost medium with a very soft carbonation. Little sticky at points. OK drinking as I would have looked for something hoppier, cleaner, and more refreshing. Not a bad try but not quite there.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Bottle [330ml] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy gold with a spare diminishing foamy white head. Aroma: This might be a tad old, it’s a bit stale, with some light hops, pale malt, light sweetness and some fruit. Flavour of grain, pale malt, light hops, herbs, sweet fruit and a light bitter finish. Finish is a bit harsh and it’s overly carbonated. Medium bodied. Good, not great.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: 33cl bottle from Au Grain d’Orge, Switzerland. pours hazy golden, white head. aromas, lemon, hoppy with light floral scents and yeasty nose. flavors, fizzy/bubbly with high carbonation taking away much of anything enjoyable about tis beer. some mild citrus hops leaving a nice palate, pale malts. Decent APA but sadly dampened by the high carbonation.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: cloudy rusty orange with a small snow white head. Aroma: caramel, a little cranberry, bran, spicy too. A little alcohol in there too. Flavour: Super carbonated, slightly bitter on the tongue, banana skin, do I taste quinine? Sour finish.

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Pours creamy beige body, and after gushing - a foamy beige head. Mild hop aroma, pleasant enough. While the mouthfeel is mildly creamy-buttery, it feels watered down. Before expirey date. Drinkable, though not a great example of an American pale.Bottle sent me from members of the "Importations Privées Bièropholie" buying club

column1: Trois Dames Pacific North West Pale Ale
column5: Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Légère odeur d’agrumes et de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est orangée voilée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de zestes d’oranges avec une pointe de caramel. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence d’agrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #2921)

Bottled. Pale golden, minimal head. Unpleasant artificial lemon nose. Sweet, simplistic and industrial with a cloying artificial flavour, sort of like urinoir stones. Syrupy metallic finish. Thanks Carlsberg!
Bottled. Pale yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is hay and some vegetables. Flavour is mainly something like maize, very sweet notes. Not very pleasant.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a pale yellow beer with a quite fast diminishing average sized white head. Unpleasant nose of stale hops and lemonade. The taste is of the same, the lemonade really doesn’ t work out well at all with the beer, an awful shandy. A very poor combination. Fairly tart and a lot to sweet. A hint of bitterness. The finish is quite enjoyable though: Some citrussy elements combine with a pleasant biscuitty crispness. Despite the finish, it wasn’t a pleasant beer at all, I could hardly finish the bottle! One to forget...

flavoured with herbs - translucid pale yellow colour with a poor head retention; the nose is herbal and slightly oily; medium-bodied, fresh with some tartness due to a solid carbonation; some bitterness and an effervescent herbal finish with some residual sweetness - not bad at all
Bottled. Clear golden. Light vegetable aroma. Sweet and fruity with notes of compost heap. Lifeless and Carlsberg-y, clumsy and dull.

(33cl bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Clear, deep golden to light-amber colour with a dense and persistent slightly off-white foamy head. Shy aroma: slightly sweet, light-grainy cara-malty nose. Moderately sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonated mouthfeel. Malt-accented taste, light herbal background; rather slim malty, slightly bitter finish with faint hoppy notes. Average.

Bottle (Dank an Stefan !): deep golden coloured, small foamy layer, sourish-grainy, a bit papery nose, toasted malt and bitterness detectable; crisp bitter sweet flavour, light bodied; fizzy malty-bitter finish. Not really bad, but kind of bland, anyway.....
bottle. Golden colour, nearly amber, creamy and persistent head. Full-bodied malty flavour with hints of roasted malt and fruit. Also hints of caramel. Hoppy in the finish.

Bottled (thanks Bov!). Deep golden colour, small, but longlasting white head, which leaves lace. Aroma is butter and some hops. Flafvour is just bitter hops along with some buttery and caramellish hints. Not very exciting, but indeed refreshing.
clear bronze colour with a solid white foam; a hint of caramel and butter in the nose; sweet and medium-bodied; no bitterness; more caramelish notes in the finish - deeply uninteresting

10/3/18. 12oz bottle from Piggly Wiggly. Dark brown pour with a small khaki head. Light roasty aroma, reminds me of chocolate brownies, weirdly enough. Light roasty flavor, brownies, touches of caramel, ash. Tasty enough!
On tap at Titletown's restaurant in the old train station. Solid chocolate, ok. Not real deep, but reasonably tasty. GorjusGirl says best there. 13.4
Nice smooth sweet roasted flavor. Classic musty aroma and a nice lacing and color
pours opaque dark brown with a medium tan head. Dark roasted malt aroma. Creamy mouth feel. Rich malty taste with notes of black coffee. mild bittersweet finish and linger. Really good!

12 ounce bottle from Flanagan’s Appleton. Dark brown, large foamy tan head, decent retention. Aroma of strong roasted malt and a bit of smoke. The taste is roasted malts, dark chocolate, a bit of plum. Thin, mild lingering bitterness. Solid.
Bottle. Black with off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt with notes of chocolate.
Nose is roast, some dark chocolate. Taste corresponds. Nice dark roast flavor. Almost coffee like. Slightly bitter, smooth mouthfeel. Very nice beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at The Old Fashioned. Opaque black tan head. Light roasty and spiced aroma. Lots of roast in the taste with almost cinnamon hints in the finish. Medium bodied

Dark brown body with a tall, lasting light beige head. Scents of roasted malt and just a hint of biscuit and herbal hops. Flavors follow scents. Thinner flavors in the finish that I’m not sure if I want more or less.
Draft. Hazy brown color, tan head. Aroma of coffee, toffee, dark fruit. Taste has cocoa, coffee, plums. Not bad.

(330cc bottle) Pours a dark murky brown (near black) with a medium beige head. Aroma of roasted/burnt grain, ash, caramel, and cocoa. Flavor of roasted malt, dry baking cocoa, peat, caramel, and light ash.
On bottle from Jumbo Bilbao, Santiago. Dark brown color, ok foam. Aromas of malt, dried fruits Medium body & complexity. Light immediate sweetness, Then good bitterness- good balance. Enjoyable

Fairly dark amber body with tight beaded, light tan head. Hops on the aroma at first then sweet choc malt , vague hints of caramel in the taste also a little peaty malt taste that was a little harsh at first.
Clear dark amber color, nutty aroma with some caramel and toffee. It has a constant bittersweet flavor, always with the nuttiness and toasted malt. Not my favorite type of beer, but this was nice.

Has a clear brown color. The average head, rather dark. It is very rapid. The aroma is well hoppy, probably he me reminds green apples. There is the sweet and sour good enough, with touches of caramel. The finish is weak, poor.

Appearance: dark amber with reddish tones. Little head, beige color and low persistence. Aroma: candy, tonic and yeasty. Floral and herbal presence from hops. Reminiscences of honey. Sourness and fruitiness of grapefruit. Flavor: low complexity, Herbal and floral hoppiness. Low to medium bitterness, citric-fruit reminiscences of peel lemon and grapefruit. Candy and toasty aftertaste. Palate: Light body with watery texture. Low carbonation. Mediocre beer, far from of the Tübinator beer. (sorry for my english)

Bottled at Sicosis Pours a clear flat brown color with a medium off-white head. It diminishes quickly into a minimal lacing. Aroma is herbal, grassy, like its Red Ale sibling. Mild english and german hops, very simple with notes of apples, herbs, some wood and a slight toasted hint. Flavor is bittersweet herbal with underlying toastiness. Notes of green apples, tea, herbs, wood and a touch of caramel. Light, refreshing body. No alcoholic presence at all. Simple, straight forward and very similar to the Red Ale with a touch of toastiness. Medium carbonation. Weak finish and aftertaste. Unadventurous.
Lager malts, fruity, grassy hops, good bitterness, decent session ale.......

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Lovely dark barrel aged Belgian-style ale from Lost Abbey. Dark deep brown colour with a strong aroma of chocolate, raisins and dark fruit. Taste is equally strong with notes of dark fruits, honey, raisins, chocolate and some funk. The body of the beer is thick amd heavy, but spot on for this type of beer. A really good example of a Belgian dark ale with the whole nine yards.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 0,75l bottle. Pours near black with beige head. Aroma of raisin, rosemary, quite a lot of dark fruits, licorice, somewhat earthy. Taste is sweet, raisin, rosemary, dried fruit, dark fruit, some alcohol, christmas cake. Very good, but a little too sweet.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Poured dark brown. Aroma of raisins and prunes. Raisins and dried fruits on the tongue..Another solid offering from the Lost Abbey.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle.black colour with no head.Aroma of rasins and prune and even more dry fruits nice warming mouthfeels and sweet vinious finish.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Brown pour, small tan head. Aroma of raisin, prune, cherry, red wine, and nuts. Taste follows, very raisiny for sure, with Belgian yeast, candied sugar... a bit sweet.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 2015 vintage poured into my teku glass. Dark brownish red with thin dissipating head. Aroma of honey, baking spices, dark fruit, and alcohol. Tasty af. Honey, cinnamon, raisin, malts. High carbonation. Very good sipper at 12 percent

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle Aroma-raisin, dark fruits Appearance-brown, clear, tan foam, Taste-medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, Palate-full body, sticky, lively, long finish, Overall-very good

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 750ml bottle from Tavour, 2013 vintage. Rating #6800! Pours out a deep brown, opaque, small foamy head subsides to ring around the glass. Aroma is raisins, fruitcake, cherries, honey. Sweet and rich. Taste matches the smell, sweet, raisins, figs, a big goiey morning sweet roll of a beer. Not that boozy. Thick bodied. Not too much of a Belgian presence. Really superb!

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle. Figgy, rich, with lots of alcohol, soft molasses, sweet sugars, beautiful soft fruits. Yum.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Pici, nem túl tartós hab, fekete szín. Csokis, kakaós, aszalt gyümölcsös illat, némi mézes beütéssel. Csokis, kávés, kakaós, mézes ízek, aszalt gyümölcsös aromákkal. A rozmaringot nem igazán érzem benne. Testes, enyhén szénsavas, enyhén keserű és egy hajszálnyit édeskés. Finom, jó arányokkal rendelkező sör.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Copenhagen 12/7 2019. 75 cl bottle from Best of Beers Web-shop. Very idyllic painting of a farm and a tractor on the label. Lost Abbeys usual label design. Pours unclear orange with a medium-sized white head. Settles as 0,5 cm thick layer of creamy foam covering the surface of the beer. Substantial lacing. Aroma is sweet, yeasty and with fairly strong sour notes. Sweet malts, grains and bread, hints of clammy, humid basement. Caramel and toffee. Light sharp noes of citrus. Light carbonation. Slightly thick, oily, lightly tingling texture. Flavor is fairly sweet followed by a medium strong, dry bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter with lighter sweet undercurrent. Lingering. Finish is sharp, citric and dry. Fine Belgian inspired brew with a bitter American touch.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: On tap (half-pint) at the Mission Ave Bar & Grill, Oceanside, 25th March 2019. Light haze to the golden body, lasting white crown on top. Yeast, malts and fruits in both the aroma and taste, nice blend with a Belgian like twist. Liked it.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Restrained funky aroma in a goldenpour. Laid back funky fruit flavor profile is a complex yet subtle take in the saison style.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle from Beer Republic. Aroma is grainy and yeasty with grassy and spicy notes, peppery estery yeast, fruity notes, touch of grassy hops, light floral, some banana and apricot. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet and mildly bitter. Body is medium. Solid Belgian Ale with that typical Lost Abbey balance carrying it way above the average.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bread, leather, earthy, and cheesy aromas. Flavor is very distinct. Barnyardy and earthy with toast and vanilla. Full bodied with a moderate to low amount of carbonation. Frothy white head lasted moderately. Belgian yeast flavor and fruit of banana and apple dominate the middle and finish. It seems like a brew with 6% abv Also slightly oily on the tongue in the finish with notes of hay. More malty in its presence. Not my favorite brew I've had from Lost abbey, but I could see pairing it nicely with some cheeses.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: I wrote a full review on this nkt sure why it’s gone. Golden pour frothy head. Pairs great with mussels. Banana, clove, apple and bubblegum. That all I remember now. Damn you.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bottle 12fl.oz. @home poured into a shaker.Hazy medium golden, small frothy off-white head, dissipates slowly, thin layer remains, fair lacing; aroma toasted malts, yeast, caramel, overripe peach; taste medium sweet and bitter, malty, light toffee, prominent spices (pepper, nutmeg, cloves); malty sweetbitter aftertaste, earthy and spicy notes, light straw and citrus pith in the finish; medium body, oily teaxture, average carbonation; average, nice aroma but tastewise disappointing, overall decent tripel.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: With Lost Abbey's Devotion the California brewers bring the typical standard of excellence and, well, devotion to Belgian brewing methods. Devotion has a yellow-gold color and a lively, somewhat hazy body. The yeast esters impart a somewhat chemical-like earthy aroma. While the flavor is largely malt-driven, there's a pleasantly complex spiciness. Notes of nutmeg, white pepper, and clove. Feel is soft but crisp. There's grassy and mildly bitter finishing hops and gorgeous lacing is left behind on the glass. In all, it's a mostly traditional Belgian Blond, though the hops are a welcome addition.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Good Belgian blonde ale, with a subtle sweetness offset by uber-dry noble hops and a lingering grassy finish. Mild spiciness on the back end rounds out the subtle fruit notes, while hints of clove and straw add complexity. Lingering hoppy bitterness on the fade almost seems pilsner-ish, but yeast and an underlying sweetness provide balance. Nose seems lacking in much Belgian goodness; not much else to fault. Not my favorite, but the pint seemed to disappear rather quickly.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Aus der Flasche beim Berlin Beer Week 2015 - Closing Event auf der Baustelle der Stone Brewing Berlin 2015-07 getrunken. Diese trübe Ale hat eine schöne Hefenote und ein recht leichten Körper. Nicht schlecht!

column1: River City The Grinch (Bourbon Barrel Aged)
column5: Draught at the Parkville Micro Fest. Aroma is massively powerful, richly malty and sweet, dark, and earthy with plenty of bourbon character and spun sugar, combined with raisin, date and plummy fruitiness, also seeing some lighter spicy, citric hop tones and wafts of peppery alcohol. Properly deep, murky mahogany-amber color, head is creamy and lasting. Flavor profile is equally huge but showing surprisingly good balance between the aspects of malt sweetness, dark, dried fruits, hop bitterness and flavor, and the ever-present kiss of bourbon. Attributes include plenty of dark malt sugars and carob, along with some tannic oak, vanilla, charred toast, toffee, some herbal, leafy, citric hop character and plenty of alcohol. Palate is chewy, thick and slightly sticky, body is simply huge. Pretty impressive. Went back for as many samples of this as I could, totalling roughly 20 oz. over the course of the afternoon.

column1: River City The Grinch (Bourbon Barrel Aged)
column5: On tap at the Parkville Microbrew Festival. I feel that this was my beer of the show. The first thing that hits you is the strong aroma of vanilla and bourbon. It is an extremely dark beer- dark reddish orangey brown. Has a thin, but cantankerous yellowy beige head. The intense orange flavor stays on the tongue a long time. A thick and chewy beer with a big orange sweetness to the flavor. There seems to be lots of cane sugar sweetness to this. If you try, you might even discern a bit of coconut.

column1: River City The Grinch (Bourbon Barrel Aged)
column5: Sampled at the Parkville Microbrewers Festival. Murky brown with some creamy tan head. Lots of bourbony vanilla aromas. Faint oak. The flavor came off a touch sweet, but the warm bourbon character was really nice. Not boozy at all. Rich palate. One of the best on that day.

On tap in NYC-- Pours cloudy yellow with thin white head. Nose is white flowers and peach. Aromas are grass, straws, fruits and citrus. Sour, citric acidity. Lively carbonation, low body. Long sour finish. Correct saison. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This Saison is ok, it has a pale flavor that has a bit of honey highlights. Nothing exciting

Comes out of the tap a pretty clear golden with a fine-bubbled white head. Strong fruity and woody aroma has a firm malty tone and hints of pear and banana. Lip-smacking malty flavor has oak and banan tones and a hint of grass. Texture is smooth, slightly slimy (but not nasty at all!) and rather fizzy.

330ml bottle. Golden, reasonably clearwith a decent lacy head. Floral aroma with almost fruit apricot stones. Flavours slightly peppery with some sourness. too malt dominant and lacks sourness, bite and carbonation

Tasted at the Brewery, 3/29/07. Nice golden beer with a nice white head. Aroma is slightly fruity and hoppy. Taste is subtly fruity, but overall this beer was too watery. Sam Adams should stick with Germanic beers and steer FAR AWAY from the Belgians.

Tasted 03/05/2007. 12oz bottle, shared amongst 4 of us, after a BJCP study group. Hazy pale-medium gold, reasonable white head stands. Fruity hops on the nose at first, mostly orange. Caramel malts, possibly munich, come to dominate the nose with some spices later that aren’t all that pleasant. Caramel malts and medium bitterness up front in the mouth, with strong unpleasant vinyl and clove note in the finish. Too malty, under-attenuated and under-carbonated for the style. Not all that pleasant to drink either! I’m not surprised this failed to medal at the NZ Beer Awards. Sam Adams seem to struggle with beers that are not meant to be richly malty.

On tap @ Bullfrog. Hazy light amber with a whitish head and some lacing. Mellow citrus aroma with some caramel malt and a dry hop scent. Medium to light body with mellow carbonation and a slightly water mouth feel.

Draft at Bullfrog. Poured medium gold with white head. Nose was pale malt and hopcitrus. Tasted fairly rich and smooth, with pale malt, resiny hops, and some late floral and tropical fruit flavor hints.

On tap at the brewpub. Gummy, juicy hop fragrant aroma. Citrus and pine heavy. Pours a middle orange-golden, lightly hazed, with a just past white head, lacing. Flavor was a bit muddled and malt messy, but then opened up slowly into some rich, raw, unbridled hop flavors. I want a little more bitterness for balance, as the hop flavor doesn’t feel counter-weighted. Finishes a little dirty and a bit thin. Nothing crazy.

Draft @ Bullfrog. Pours a clear, slightly dulled golden-orange color; off-white head with fine-bubbled lacing. Very light, slightly bland aroma, showing minimal hops, some sugar, and cardboard-y malts; light and generally inoffensive. Medium mouthfeel: stronger show of hoppy bitterness in the mouth: citrus and soft earthy / floral hops upfront, solid levels of bitterness, and fairly drinkable and pleasant overall; much better than the nose; solid pale ale after the initial impression. Medium finish: toasty malts, mineral and citrus bitterness, and sugar.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours golden honey color with thin white head. The aroma is herbal hops with slight tangerine and white bread. The flavor is herbal with very mild citric bitterness. a bit of toast comes out toward the finish. Thinner-bodied than I would like.
Light but drinkable. Not at all what one expects when they order an APA. I honestly thought there would be more hop and more malt ... well, I guess I thought there would be more taste.
A good pale ale. Hops are everywhere. This beer was crisp with a dry finish. A very good pale ale. A winner from Bullfrog
On tap at the brew pub. Some new tweaking of a pale, Light yellow with lace. Cheese aroma. Above carbonated. Some hops, so some relation to a pale.

On tap at the brewery. Orange colour with above average carbonation, a little more taste though light mouthfeel, than the rest of the lineup. Malty with the addition of what seemed like Juniper berries. Nothing special.
Gedronken in café Antwerpen. Licht zurige afsmaak, amberkleurig, 5% alcohol.
Almost no head, amber colour. Didn’t really stick to it’s promise of a bitter finish. Rather blend speciale

Light malty, light brown sugar, touch woody, hopless. Bit kolsch like. A very odd style and this is a typical if not quite clean example. I enjoyed it still, but not going to rock your world. (On tap at the brewpub)
Bottle shared. Clear amber with an off white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, some fruity hops and peach. Flavour is light to ligt moderate sweet and bitter. Above light bodied with light carbonation.
25cl bottle shared with kermis. Thin white head. Clear amber pour. Average.
From tap at Taphouse. Clear amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, fruit, yeast, bitter and watery.

Tap@Taphouse, Copenhagen - Amber pour with off white head. Sweet malty aroma and taste, some caramel, treacle, light subdued dried fruit, overall a little watery and weak for a Belgo ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at Taphouse. Clear amber colored with a medium sized white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, hay and spices. Sweet and fruity flavor of caramel and spices with notes of hops and soap. Spicy finish

On tap at Old Shades Whitehall. Clear mid brown amber colour lasting beige head. Some apple peach ester on aroma. Very light Belgian ale. Some fizzy carbonation. Not much hop. OK but distinctly average.

25cl draft at Het Verdronken Land, Ghent (18 II 2016). This special belge is a red brown looking ale with a notable grain and malt nose. The collar is small beige coloured. The taste itself is rather flat, coming from the low carbonation and the thin watery body. Some flavours really are too subtle. There are some pleasant almost soury hints in the beer as well. Classic special belge... with a faint palate though, I’m afraid.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A hazy straw coloured beer with some white head and lacing. The aroma is thin and a little yeasty. The taste has sour overtones and yeasty home brew notes. Acceptable.

(bottle 0,75l @ Biancofarina (Bari)) Overall: Very nice, refreshing. Aroma: Fresh, coriander, malty, sweet. Appearance: Hazy yellow. Medium, white head. Taste: Medium sweet, malty, spicy, fresh, peel, light bitter. Palate: Light-medium body. Dry, light bitter finish.

Bottle at Erzbierschof Monday Club. Pours cloudy yellow with a little head. Aroma is banana, herbs, cough syrup, medicine. Light body with a crisp carbonation, still fruity, but rather short again. The carbonation drowns the flavours. Palate is short and sparkly. Nice.

Bottle @ Basilico Bianco Gallarate. giallo paglierino opalescente, schiuma bianca fine persistente. Aroma non molto intenso ma fine, coriandolo, agrumi (scorza d’arancia e citrico), leggermente erbaceo, cereali (frumento). Gusto abboccato, acidulo, citrico, speziato. Poco corposa, carbonatazione intensa, debole calore alcolico, equilibrata ed armonica.

750ml crown-capped bottle with plastic-cork come with a free screwed pin bought at CitySuper in Harbour City, Tsim Sha Tsui. Looks: Translucent light golden honey colour with a ring of dirt-like yeastsediments; One finger head and soapy white foam which last for 90 seconds; Minimal lacing and very fizzy carbonation. Aroma: Fragrant malt, with strong wheat and tartness, strong coriander, strong orange peels, banana, faint pineapple, faint dark fruits, bread, strong yeast, lemon and thin grass. Taste: Mid to light sweet light malt, with strong wheaty tartness, spelt, orange peels, coriander, sugar, strong spices, earth, dry biscuits , strong yeast, lemon, moderate bitter hops and strong grass. Body: Close to light body. Slick and crisp palate. Mouth Feel: Fair malt in a slick background. Strong tart wheat and quite coarse spelt presence. This coarseness raise the effect of orange peels and coriander, which make the palate a lots livelier. Sweeter than usual Belgian White, with strong spices and yeast. Good lemon to round. Good! Hoppiness: Lemon and thin grass in nose, a lot stronger in taste. Bitterness is fairly strong for a lasting, mid-to-high astringent sweet-bitter finish. After Taste: Quite dry. Sweet, wheaty and bitter to mouth. Comments: Like most of 32’s line-ups, this Witbier is bold and expressive in wheaty aroma, orangey / spicy taste with a strong hoopinness. I think the spelt factor jack up its taste to another level without being unpleasant like most spelt beers do. Only the strong sweetness tilts its balance off a bit. Otherwise this is a good one to enjoy with friends!
Spicca al naso la nota di agrumi tipo limone, pompelmo, birra molto dissetante di grande pulizia e piacevolezza al palato e di ottima salivation.

Tipico colore da witbier, molto velata, schiuma bianca che svanisce al secondo battito di palpebre. Al naso pepe bianco e frutta gialla tropicale, piccante del farro che ritrovi in bocca immerso in un corpo medio e sapore lievemente dolce e acidulo. Il finale è rapido e non da sussulti. I luppoli si avvertono solo in un tenue sentore citrico, mentre i lieviti coprono la lingua con una sorta di stuoia vellutata.
Loaded with fresh n fruity favours, it offers an outstanding complexity you won’t expect in such pure n light products.
Giallo opalescente, molto torbida, con sentori di pepe, coriandolo e lievito. Molto carbonata.

Bottiglia @ Simei 2015, Milano. L’intensità olfattiva è conforme alla media e la persistenza olfattiva è sensata. La schiuma è costituita da bollicine fini. Un liquido opalescente ha colore giallo torbido. Il corpo è pieno. Alla lingua arriva un dolce medio, un amaro moderato, un acido leggero ed una traccia di umami. L’intensità gustativa è normale e la persistenza gustativa è buona. Il gusto è piacevole. Il finale è felpato, secco e pulito.

Gialla pallida, schiuma bianca di media persistenza. Aroma citrico e pepato, coriandolo, leggero frumento. Al palato sempre citrica e pepata con coda erbacea e di frumento, leggermente astringente. Molto carbonata, corpo leggero.
Tap at Titletown. Pour is clear golden/amber. Floral hops, honey, and fruit on the nose. Taste is sweet and grainy. Medium bodied. Well done Maibock.

Excellent beer. Balanced out just about right. For my tastes it could be a smidge sweeter or maybe more A touch more Munich, But great just the way it is. One of the best on the menu right now ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap. Pours a light hazy golden color with thin of white head. Aroma is of sweet bread, grassy hops and sweet malt. Taste is of sweet malt, light sugar, grassy hops, and sweet bread. The palate is a bit thick and the alcohol, although not presente in warmth, is there. Still, good stuff.

Pours a crisp light amber color with a thin off-white head which fades quickly and leaves a few streaks of lacing. Aroma is floral, honey, and candied figs. Taste is honey, candied figs, with some toasted grains. Good stuff.

On draught at the Titletown brewpub in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden amber colored brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a thin film top and no lacing. Aroma of floral hops, some honey, fruit, and a touch of cotton candy. Taste is full bodied, with flavors of rich sweet golden grain malt, some cotton candy, a hint of candi sugar and honey. Finish is semi-sweet with a continuing honey and golden grain aftertaste. One of the fullest bodied maibocks I’ve tried.
Another winner from Ttown. Pours a dark, copper colour with a full fluffy tan head. nice and creamy with a touch of hops mid palate. fruity in the finish.

My second favorite at the brewpub. Dark amber color. Smell of malt, brown sugar, fruit, caramel, strawberries, and minor citurs. Taste of sweet malt, brown sugar, dark fruit, some citrus peal, nuts a little honey. Very smooth and I liked the sweet malt flavor.
Cask. A golden beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a dry finish where the caramel note lingers.

Cask (handpump) @ Rat & Ratchet (Ossett), 40 Chapel Hill, West Yorkshire, Huddersfield Road, HD1 3EB. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, nutty, overripped apple, earthy - damp stain notes, anis notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100119]
Cask. Clear dark amber golden with a creamy beige head. Nutty nose. Light body, flat, nuts and burned caramel with a lightly bitter finish. 190110

Pint pulled at the Hart’s Head Hotel in Giggleswick (Yorkshire), took a long time to settle to its clear brown colour body with a large off-white foamy head. A strong malty aroma with caramal and a strong presense of hops as well. I found the palate a little watery, but it did have an interesting sweet malt flavour that became mroe earthy through the swallow. A good bitterness all the way through as well.

A Sim rate (cask up the Junction): Flavour is chocolate and coffee and a little like a porter. Appearance is ruby red with little lacing. Nice and subtle flavour. Slightly bitter finish but nice overall.

From Jul 2008 I got this can in a trade with Lofgrep. Thanks Peter! Another adventure into Surly-land. It pours from the 16oz can(it says 4%abv) into my New Belgium Imperial Pint glass a hazy orange gold. There's about a 1" head of foam(which doesn't last very long) and there's some good lacing. The smell is very fruity. I get a lot of citrus but there's also a sweet fruity nose there as well. It's nice. The taste hits me with some caramel malt sweetness balanced by a good, but not over the top, hoppiness....definitely mostly pine but also some citrus with the grapefruit. The sweet fruit aspect that I mentioned in the nose is more subdued in the taste, darn it, but for a low abv brew, it *is* power packed with flavour and is *very* easy drinking. If I had something like this on tap at a local bar, I could easily session on it all night! No kidding. It's close enough to medium bodied that I'd call it medium bodied, carbonation is on the very light side of medium, and it finishes piney and very dry. Sometimes dry doesn't work for me but in this case, it's right up my alley. ;^) Bottom line: I really like this "English Bitter" though purists would probably say it's too bitter. I agree, basically, but it in no way impedes me from enjoying this brew. This is yet another winner from Surly!

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #57. Draught pint (in a Surly glass) at Café 28 (RIP) in Minneapolis, August 2008. Translucent, slightly cloudy amber-brown with a lasting bit of off-white fine-bubbled foam...fruity, resinous, somewhat earthy aroma, touches of dried hops...dry and earthy in the body, lightly peppery, some sweeter, juicier touches show up with time though it remains just a touch too dry for me...notes say "toasted bread but no marmalade" what the hell? anyway, strong tingly carbonation is a bit strong also...this was served too cold and improved quite a bit over a long tasting with some warmth; I look forward to trying it again now that I can get the commoner Surlys pretty easily.
Pours hazy yellow with a huge rocky white head. Nose is yeasty and spicy. Taste is toasty malt, spicy and floral hops, black pepper. Finishes dry and bitter. Definitely an a-typical bitter.
Pale yellow but a bit hazy pour. Thin white head. Citrus, pineapple, almost candied citrus on the nose. Flavor is orangey/grapefruit. A bit odd. Not what I was expecting.
Light opaque dark yellow, fluffy white foam head. Hoppy aroma and strong bitter taste. Some citrus ntes. Like this. (Velp, 201512)
16oz can to tulip. Pours clear straw/gold, white sticky head. Aroma of pine, grapefruit and peppercorn. Taste is the same. As advertised...less malt backbone, but great beer.

Can. Hazy, light orange body with an inch plus of white head. Aromas of citrus, earthy hops, pine, alcohol. Bitter indeed. Resinous, earthy hops. Light, even thin, bodied with aggressive bitterness, peaking mid to late palate. Not the easy drinking, session beer renowned in England.

16oz can. Pale yellow pour with a big soapy head of huge bubbles. The head diminishes like the frothy on a milkshake; around the edges first and leaves a lumpy residue. Bitter hop aroma that is very attractive. Flavors are bright, clean, refreshing bitterness. Delicious. I love the low alcohol content. Easy to drink. Well deserved reputation.

Can at home, pours a hazy yellow with thick head and average retention. Leaves a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma is citrusy hops, lightly fruity. Taste is orange, light tropical fruit, clean, but extremely bitter. Pretty enjoyable. Lots of flavor from a low ABV beer.
Yet another disappointment from Surly. The flavor actually isn’t awful - kind of a sour pineapple - but aftertaste is wretchedly bitter.

Cask (handpump) @ Marble Arch Inn, 73 Rochdale Rd, Manchester, Greater Manchester England M4 4HY. Clear dark black red - brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, dusty, moderate hoppy, grass, citrus, dusty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, hoppy, dry. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100425]

Pours dark brown with fluffy tanned head. Roasted malts, coffe and dark chocolate arma. Crisp and à bit sweet malty and hoppy flavor. À bit flat but pleasantly malty on palate. Finishes with flat dry hoppy aftertaste.
Cask Stillage at Edgeley Park, Stockport 02/06/2007 (Also as Half Cut Mild at 4.0%) Rich chocolaty aroma. Dark smooth fruity and hoppy with a chocolaty slight roast finish.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. I had this down as Marble Half Cut Mild at 4.0%. Ginger aroma. Fairly light in body, but it is definitely gingery. Light mild with ginger.

Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Light flavours. Spicy some choc and coffee and grainy malts. Dry with some bitterness and slight tartness. I was unimpressed by this. I just had spice down in my notes but after the suggestion of ginger I could see that.
A Sim rate (cask at Reading BF): Very gingery and quite hoppy aroma. Similar flavour with slight liquorice. Really enjoyed this one.
[Gravity cask at Chippenham Beer Festival] Dark brown. Liquorice dominates, with a bit of cough mixture. Sweet with odd sour hints. Not really my cup of tea. Or my pint of beer for that matter.

Bottle @ Chris O. Pours a brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel flavor with some weak hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty caramel finish.
31st July 2010. ChrisO’s ’Raise The Roof’ tasting. Clear dark brown beer with a little tan head. Sourish malt and sourish fruit. Finish is a little bit dry. Okay.
From the Bottle at Chris O’s pre GBBF tasting, Kensal Rise 31/07/2010 Slightly sour fruit aroma. Amber mid brown coloured and fruity with a hint of dryness in a malt finish.

Bottle from Drink of Fulham, drunk at ChrisO’s "Raise the Roof" tasting, 31st July 2010. Deep mid brown, beige head. Sour nose. Quite lively palate. Feels like this bottle is off/infected. Not pleasant.

Bottle 50cl. @ ChrisOs Pre-GBBF Shindig 2010. [ Raise The Roof Tasting ]. Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, light beigge head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, sour malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light berry acidic with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100731]

Bottled@The Chriso rock the roof down pre-GBBF tasting. Slightly hazy brown colour with small head. Aroma is fruits, wood, mild toast as well as some mild spices. Flavour is fruits, earth, wood and some mild hops in the finish.
Bottled. A brown beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of sulphur and roasted malt. The flavor is acidic with notes of roasted malt and sulphur. Not good.
Bottle at chriso’s pre-GBBF ’Raise the Roof’ Shindig ’10. Brown with a small off white head. Faint aroma. Sour taste and a sharp bitter finish.
Bottle.Dark chestnut with a big head,aroma of old wine,wood,rum and blackcurrant.taste of dark choc,wood,light sourness,leather with blackberry tartness,apple,light dry finish.

Cask (gravity) @ The 16th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2010, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, light toffee, apple notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100430]
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2010. Deep gold, thin white head. Fairly tasty bitter. OK biscuit. Very drinkable session bitter.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Malty caramel and fruit with mild hop finish. Drinkable standard bitter.
A Sim rate (cask @ Reading BF): Fruity berry aroma with obvious pear. Nice golden amber colour. Sweet flavour with malt, pear, berries and a slightly bitter finish.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Good malt flavours. Woody toffee and pleasant hop. Growing tangy hop bitterness well complemented by malt sweetness. Not bad.
A Sim rate (cask @ Reading BF): Very slightly hoppy aroma but not much to it. Slightly nutty. Flavour is bizarre... almost smokey, but nutty and overly alcoholic. Not very nice at all.
Cask Handpump at the Community Centre, Frodsham 12/05/2007 Thick white head. Golden coloured hoppy and citrus fruit flavoured with a crisp bitter and grainy dry finish.

Cask @ New Oxford, Salford. Mayday Weekend Beer Festival (Saturday) Not had this one before, and its not on Northerns website. So must have been a special brew maybe for the New Oxford. The pint was a pale straw colour, with a off white head. Aroma was of popcorn and sugar. And flavour was also sugary popcorn, a very moreish brew. One of the best I have tasted!

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: 500ml bottle from Favourite Beers, Cheltenham. Pours a clear golden colour with a very thin white head dissipating immediately. Aroma is malty, earthy, vegetal. The flavour is malty, light roast hints, with a rather weak hoppy bitterness at the end. Not what I expect from an IPA, it’s just a bitter, but otherwise a nice beer, though nothing special - average.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle from Gloucester services M5. Deep gold colour, with thin head. Aroma and Taste is malty caramel.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Typiske engelsk bitter. Noget ordinær. God smag af humle. Pæn farve og ikke meget skum.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle at Östersunds maltfestival cons 2015-02-28 Östersund AR: dry caramel AP: clear bronz, wee transparent white head F: malt bread, brown sugar, very dry

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle at Craig’s. Pours clear golden amber, nose is floral, vegetal, taste is similar.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Sample at SBWF 2014. Fruity and flowery smell. Similar taste. Easy to drink. Felt very brittish, or rather it really brought me back to England.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottled at SBWF. Hazy pale amber, small head. Hay and bread. Mid dry with medium body and rounded mouthfeel. Grains, spices, butter and hay. Mid bitter finish.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Flaska. Klar orange med ett vitt skum. Dofter av säd, majs, trä och äppeljuice. Smakinslag av säd, omogna äpplen och trä. Besk avslutning. Medelkolsyra. sträv munkänsla.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle. Pours clear orange with a small, frothy off-white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is toast and grain malt, earthy and woody hops with light apple esters. Flavor is toast and nutty malt, earthy hops and medium bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column1: Battledown Special (Cheltenham SPA Special Pale Ale)
column5: Bottle at Craig’s. Pours clear golden amber, white head. Aromas of caramel and something vegetal. Taste has more toffee sweetness, done light fruits, thin and bitter finish. Ok.
A Sim rate (cask @ Reading BF): Sweet yet sour flavour. Lemon and grapefruit with a tangy finish. Aroma is grapefruit again.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Some diacetyl. Bit of brazil nut maybe. Not wonderful, the walnut is pretty good if unintended. Light roastiness.

A Sim rate (cask @ Reading BF): Smokey, oaky and very buttery aroma. Flavour has a bit of chocolate, a bit of honey and coffee. Its stings at the start and leaves with a coffee finish. Slightly eggy / sulphur aroma. Appearance is classic dark ruby black. Looks like a gorgeous espresso.
Cask in the Crown in Bishops Castle. A warm malty mess that give English beer a bad name

11/2/2019. Bottle from Tuffins Supermarket, Craven Arms. Poured amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, hops, fruit and nut. Medium sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, fruits and hops. Sweet finish.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 110219
Has a very minimal aroma. OKay appearance, dark brown, some head. Flavour is soft nut, some malt. Good on the mouth. Just okay, really - and rating 2300 on such an average brew!!!
Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 7/1/2016. Amber with a decent, off-white head. Malty beer, with a slightly earthy edge, some hedgerow fruits and a decent, bitter finish. Good.

Bottle from Appleyards Deli. Appearance - golden amber with a decent thin head. Nose - light biscuits, orange. Taste - more orange biscuits. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - solid if unexciting.
Bottle at ash’s. Pours clear amber, nose is toffee, floral, nutty, taste is similar, light sweetness.
Bottle at Ashton McCobb’s. Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aromas of demerara sugar. Taste is sweet, light mineral note. Nutty finish. Last wee tasting of the summer

23rd October 2014 Almost clear gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and minerally crisp. Semi dry. Light dry pale malts, grainy sweetness. Little lactose and a light tang. Very mild floral citrus on the backend. Dry finish. Grainy sweetness dominates here. Meh!

Cask conditioned at The white Lion, Upton upon Severn, Worcs. Pale amber with white head. Quite a light bitter, biscuit malt, dry, crisp but lacking a little depth. Thin and bitter on the finish with a herby note (thyme at a guess).
Cask at the Rose & Crown, Sandhurst. Dark amber with a scummy cream head; malty aroma with a touch of spice; rathn thin in the mouth with a caramelly malt taste; and a malty finish.
Sold as "Stag Ale" at The Stag in Warrington. ----- Light brown colour. Has a woody aroma. It’s a plain, malty bitter with a nice soft texture but a slightly unpleasant sharp edge.
Medium bodied tasty ale with an excellent, but not overstated fruity flavour.
Cask Stillage at the Paradise Brewery Bar, Wrenbury 04/07/2003 Amber coloured a little rich on the palate and fruity with a slightly dry full malt finish.
Pretty ordinary session beer. As previous drinkers have noted it has a slightly fruity flavour.
Cask in Henglers Circus, Glasgow. Alround rating: A sweet malty bitter, thin but quite drinkable.

A Mes rate. Cask at Baker St. ’Sporks. Golden brown with a thin off white head. Berry fruit accents to the nose. Full of bready malt with a little cardboard in the flavour. Maybe a touch of caramel in the finish. Not a showstopper by any means.

Cask at ’Spoons, Milton Keynes. Copper amber with an off white head. Engaging buttery malt aroma. Smooth oily malt taste with wet dog and earth. Mid bitter finish. Liked it. 8.1.11 Cask at Wellington Arms, bedford. Not much going on.Faint malt aroma. Gentle MDF taste with some sweetness. Slight bitterness. Rating:4,4,6,3,11:2.8

Cask handpull at Westgate, JDW, Canterbury. It’s a brown bitter. Some decent malt and raspberry type fruit on the aroma, some decent caramel malt in the mouth and flavour, good condition, some hoppy bite on the finish. As I said, a bitter.

Cask - Glasshouse (Wetherspoons), Norwich. Copper coloured with a white head of no real longevity. Minimal aroma - perhaps a slight toffee quality. Thin and flat generic malt flavours without an ounce of bitterness to speak of. No finish whatsoever. Ends before it ever gets started. In a word: weak.

Sampler at RAM, Schaumburg. A lot of coffee, kind of a syrupy, almost Kahlua texture. Taste is a quite warming coffee roast, with some cacao nibs. I’m catching a bit of alcohol and a touch of vanilla. This could be something amazing if it were allowed to sit in a barrell for a while.

Tap in Schaumburg. Pours black with a medium, frothy light tan head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (toast, chocolate, coffee), no hops, and notes of prunes, dates, and wood. Flavor is heavy malt with roast bitterness. Medium body and carbonation, low warmth and a dry finish.

Pour is black with a thin brown head...smell is roasty and sweet with a lot of chocolatey notes...roasty sweet chocolate flavor...fairly chewy and velvety mouthfeel...hints of bitterness in the finish...

(Ram Restaurant and Brewery, Schaumburg, IL) Draft... DLD’08... Clear black ale with a mid-sized, creamy, light brown head. Wafts of nutty, dark roast coffee and cocoa send my olfactory system into an ascending spin. Medium-bodied with bristly carbonation. Chocolaty with medium sweetness. Balanced decently by charcoal malts and moderately bitter, herbal lupulin. Chocolaty, coffee-dry finish. Surprisingly spot-on stout!

This draft brew from the brewery in Chicago poured a medium sized head of foamy tan colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a semi-opaque dark ruby red brown colored body and a fair lacing. The almost non-existant aroma was malty. The semi-thick mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of malt hops and roasted malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

On tap at Ram - Schaumburg. This was a very pleasant surprise! Poured a beautiful deep brown with a thick, creamy cap of caramel head. Aroma was of deeply-roasted cocoa, coffee, and faint hints of herbal.. full and quite enticing! Flavor had a couple really nice levels of roasted chocolate.. first cocoa, then some darker chocolate.. coffee and faint grassy bitterness was quite complementary.. some dark fruits emerge at the back-end, and were quite welcome. Medium-bodied with nice depth of flavor.. very good mouthfeel.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark amber with a creamy off-white head. Buttery malt aroma with a hint of honey. Sweet taste full of grainy golden syrup: like an all-butter flapjack. A little bitterness. This is Zodiac themed beer for the month of the star sign Taurus, described as one of their ’Mystic Brews’. While deploring the tacky marketing ploy, I enjoyed the beer.
Cask (handpump) at the Lass O Gowrie, Manchester. Amber, thin white head. Dry malt with touches of earthy hop. Standard UK bitter.

A simple clear golden hue topped by a small, but lacy white head. Bready and almost toasty malt nature quickly take their leave in favour of the considerable spicy and flowery dryness. Low bitterness though, but a hoppy and fun, refreshing ale. Efficient and highly drinkable. Low on the carbonation and fresh tasting.
[CASK: The Lass-O-Gowry, Manchester 17/04/07] Not a bad brew easy drinking and fairly tasty. An ale that can be drunk all night.
50cl bottle. A murky deep golden beer with a small white head. Aroma of spicy wheat malt and clove. Taste of mild sweet wheat malt, clove, yeast.
bottle from the brewery. Cloudy pale brownish yellow, mid-sized white head. Wheaty and yeasty, slightly fruity. Well balanced and very smooth.
bottled. poured a murky golden with an appreciable off-white head; simple aromas of musk and vanilla; dense mouthfeel; hints of mustiness and porridge; overall felt a little flat

Bottle. An unclear, orange beer with a nice, off-white head leaving some lacings. The aroma is bubblegum dominated, some wheat and cloves in the back. Nice flavor, bubblegum, banana, cloves, some wheat and lemon. Medium body, nicely carbonated. The finish is tasteful, bubblegum, banana, lemon, cloves and pale malts well combined. A pleasant one indeed, well crafted, tasteful and quenching. 100813

Bottle 500ml. Hazy medium matt orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, grain, paper, moderate yeasty, fruity, paper. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20100813]
Bottle, 5.2%. Subtle banana aroma. Cloudy yellow colour. The flavour is quite sweet, sugary even. Some banana. Low to medium bitterness.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of MiP/KimJohansen. Pours a cloudy golden with a small off-white head. Sweet banana aroma. Medium body, sweet banana and yeast. Absolutely no bitterness. One of the sweeter Hefes. 130810
Hazy orange with a medium off white head. Sweet and yeasty aroma with wheat and banana. Flavor had yeast, banana and wheat. Finished sweet.

Bottle. Sweet banana, orange, clove, and wheat malt. Cloudy yellow-tan color with moderate head. Slight sweet banana, moderately strong clove and wheat malt flavor. Body on the light side. Decent - not great.

Bottled (BB 03/2010) Courtesy of bierkoning, ty Edo! Hazy orange color, huge cloudy head. Aroma of wheat and orange marmalade, some grainy notes. Flavor is slightly sour. Banana, some citrusy notes in the flavor. Body is on the lighter side. Probably better when it is fresh. Now just ok.

Bottle. Another old Big rock rating. Yellow gold pour with a thin white bubbly head that soon dissipates. Light malt aroma. Taste has some light fruit notes and decent hopping. However its still overall rather thin and lackluster.

Pours a clear pale straw color with a frothy white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of soft sweet person malts, dme and a light bit of green apple. Taste is sweet pale malts and dme. Easy drinking lager.

341mL bottle poured clear pale golden color with white head diminishing quickly to virtually no lace. Aromas are muted grains. Taste is mildly sweet and bitter finish which is just off the mark. A little below average as far as lagers go.
Hazy pale golden pour. White head. The aroma is fairly sweet with lots of DMS present up front. Fairly slick, almost greasy palate. I think that about says it all - down the drain with this beast.

Appearance is golden yellow with almost no head. Very little smell except for a hint of grain and fruits. Taste is very light with a hint of malt and a slight hint of fruit, nothing to interesting. Very little carbonation and no body. After taste is very watery and smooth, just like water. Overall, this beer is very bland offering nothing unique.

Bought this one at The Beer Store in a variety 12-pack. XO, giving the impression of aged (like cognac), but not really. Talks about this on back label but does not mention anything about how long (so not really important and credible). Small white head, not lasting long, with a few wet spots of lace. Golden colour with little carbonation. Smells like wet hay and pee. Wet mouthfeel, wishing it was at least crisp (for a lager). Nope. A little bit of grass is felt to save the day, in the taste. Other than that, not much else. Short finish and overly boring.
Straight from the can, no glass involved! Nice fresh hoppy aroma. Taste is ok, mild bitterness on the roof of the mouth. Very clean finish.
341ml bottle from The Beer Store. Pours light yellow. No real aroma. Not a lot of flavour, but nothing innoffensive either. Should be caled "OK Lager".
I enjoy most of what Big Rock puts out, and even though I’m not a pilsner fan this one was surprisingly tasty and easy on the taste buds. Go Big Rock
can. Poured clear straw coloured with a thin white head. Citrusy hop nose. Bready malt flavour with a lemon citrus undertone. Finish is crisp, a bit grainy, but not bad.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Pours cloudy golden with a tiny white head. Aroma og weak caramel and fruits. Taste is rather weak as well, thin and watery palate, flat carbonation. Middle of the road in all departments.
Bottle. Golden-orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hop. Flavour is fruit, malt, hop, citerus. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium amber orange color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, malty, metalic, horse blanket - leather. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20110319]

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, dark golden beer with a finger-thick off-white head. Fruity on the nose, some maltyness too. The flavor is quite bitter, especially towards the end. Fruity and slightly malty. Medium body, dry. Bitter finish. A pleasant and easy drinkable beer that neither impresses nor disappoints. Certainly a beer that I could drink a few of. 110319

Bottle@Ulfborg tasting.Pours golden with a white head.Aroma of malt ,fruitiness and a little citrus.Flavor is sweet and somewhat bitter with some floral and citrus notes.Medium body, average carbonation.
Bottle @ Denmark/Norway Tasting @ Ulfborg 2011. Courtesy of Fonefan. Pours cloudy golden with a creamy egg white head. Bitter and fruity hoppy. Rubber and citrus. Very dry and bitter hoppy flavor.

50cl bottle from the Home Brew Shop, Aldershot. Amber with a thin white head; has a pleasant aroma I can’t quite place; flavour is fruity and slightly sour, with some caramel malts; and a pleasantly light bitterness to finish. Very drinkable.

Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Fruity slightly astringent. Odd yeasty nut finish. I wasnt too keen on this. I’ve found a similar odd flavour in some of their bottled beers which I’d assumed to be a bottling problem rather than house character.

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Not the best way to start the festival but what I wanted had sold our already (thanks Ian) and this was near by. Has the looks of cold tea. Tea in the aroma also but backed up with some hops. Thank god the tea is missing from the flavour and it’s much better for it. Malty up front and then some nice citric hops to finish.
Small white lace. Thinn yellow color. A litle opaque. The aroma is small with some sulphur. Big bitterness but only small hop taste balanced by a too big sweetness for such a low alcohol beer.

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’09. Gold with white head. Light and a little thin, but with a sweetish malt and flowery hop, lemony and a decent bite. An enjoyable start to the Festival for me.
Cask at Fox and Crown, Nottingham. Pale gold, white head. Sulphurous aroma. Biscuity malt taste. Sharp bitterness. Huge flavour for a 3.6%. But not very good.
Yellow with a small white head. Lemon, grass and herbal aroma. Dry and hoppy flavour with an off-wnote of chloride.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Gold, lasting whtie head. Farty aroma. Haddonsman described it as Eau de Tramp and I wouldn’t disagree. Crap blond beer.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Sweaty with sweat malt. Not too much to say as I didnt examine it too closely but doesnt drink to badly.

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Sorry guys but this was awful. Eggy sulphuric aroma. Looks like it hasn’t settled properly. Golden body filled with some very very fine floaters. Flavour of bleach and swimming pools with just a lick of malt at the finish being its only saving grace. Very poor.
355ml Dose. Klar und golden mit minimaler Schaumkrone. Leicht getreidig, sonst keinerlei Aroma oder Geschmack.

Aroma: caramel, bread, sweet Appearance: golden, clear, minimal head, white foam, Taste: medium sweetness, cereal flavor, refreshing, metallic, no bitter Palate: light body, thin feel, lively carbonation,
Can - Almost no nose to speak of. Clear gold with a thin head. Very sweet grains and honey notes. Bleh.

Can thanks to Joe! Pours a clear pale straw yellow with a fizzy white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of stale bread with some corn and sweet grains. Flavor has a combination of straw and stale bread with a bit of corn underlying.

Smells of rotting bread. Has a decent head and an okay lager-type body.As for flavour, it’s all wet bread with an overarching hint of caramel. Watery mouthfeel. Another big fail in the non-alcohol department.

Can of 355 ml. There are so many Sol beers out there lately and one seems to be worse than the other, let’s see how this one is doing.  Pours a golden yellow colour with a one finger head, good retention although it looks quite soapy. A light aroma of corn which it wouldn’t be that bad, only it reminds of corn flakes in milk. Taste is like you’ re drinking that milk, aweful!  As for mouthfeel, watery and no carbonation at all.  This one tastes and smells and feels so skunked, It’s like they invented a can that allows sunlight to get through it and spoil your beer.
Cannette bue à Playa Del Carmen. Pas vraiment d’arôme, peu de goût et arrière goût un peu désagréable.
355ml can. I had to try this seeing as though I was in Mexico. Pale looking with little aroma and no flavour.
Color amarillo brillante, poca espuma, aroma desagradable y sabor muy sin chiste, mejor tomar agua natural.
35.5 cL can. Pours clear and golden yellow with a huge white head. Aroma is cornish if anything, Cornish and wet cardboard flavoured. Flat. Watery finish.

column1: Otokoyama (Mans Mountain) Naturally Pure Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: Served at Sanraku japanese restaurant in san francisco. This has been my go to sake for many years and is hard to find. Beautifully clear. Slightly sweet aroma. Delicate floral notes. Perfection.

column1: Otokoyama (Mans Mountain) Naturally Pure Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: Bottle thanks to my dad who apparently regularly gets this stuff...news to me...Pours as clear as water with strong legs. Aroma is on the sweetish side with berries, marzipan, and honeydew. Complex yet a bit light. Taste is very sweet and amazingly smooth, perfectly balanced with absolutely no alcohol presence what-so-ever. Very, very well balanced. Smooth, full mouthfeel, amazing stuff!

column1: Otokoyama (Mans Mountain) Naturally Pure Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: $185 750mL bottle split with a friend and Oishii in Boston! From first sniff to the first sip, I was in love. My first daiginjo, so take this rating with a grain of salt, but I must admit, I was quite shocked. I was expecting daiginjos to be the austere, conservative, flawless/perfectly executed type, but perhaps lacking a bit in some funky character. Nope, not this one anyways. Legs and all, with as clear and clean an appearance as I’ve seen. Fruity notes abound and it almost seems to have as much body and substance to it as a nigori. But yet, the liquid never seems heavy nor does drinking the stuff get fatiguing. Rich, but yet spritzy and playful, with tangerines, apricots, peaches and rosehips. Wow. Sensory overload and truly divine. Worth the price tag, in my mind. The flavor somewhat outdid the aroma in sheer complexity.

column1: Otokoyama (Mans Mountain) Naturally Pure Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: My tongue is tingling while I’m walking through the parking lot towards Rangetsu, my favorite restaurant. I approach the bar and as I’m sitting down I order a bottle of this. "Are you sure?" asks the bartender. "Definitely." This isn’t my first encounter with this sake, nor will it be my last. "Well, the manager keeps it locked up in a refrigerator in the office, I’ll be right back." Shortly thereafter a wooden box is presented to me in the same fashion a rare diamond might be carefully handed over to someone who has no means to procure it. The manager, the bartender and the others at the bar are silent. All eyes on the fool who just ordered the $250 bottle of sake. I produce a crystal glass from my pocket and begin to pour. Suddenly, I am alone. The experience, from the first twist of the cap, to the last drop disappearing from the glass, is always surreal, transcendent. The liquid pours out in a silken fashion, crystal clear and quiet. It’s like staring through a window, one that just had a foggy mist wiped from it. On the other side is a lush green mountainside, and a look into the distant future. The whole event brings with it a keen sense of meditation and contemplation. The nose is very light but sufficiently aromatic. White flowers parade forward with stunning delicacy. Rainwater and hints of pear and Kaffir lime coalesce and disperse across my tongue, giving each sip a sense of divinity. The flavor is as soft and pure as glacial water. Notes of exotic soft-skinned tree fruits balance a graceful employment of earthiness. Tea leaves and very mild acidity dice through minimal sweetness like razor wire. Slight hints of melon are imparted with a gentle caress. The mouthfeel is as soft as a cloud, ultimately light-bodied. Alcohol is never noticeable, even in the enduring finish. So many years. So many sakes. To find one that crushes everything in its complexity, destroys all competition with its truthful purity, is such a rewarding experience. Divine Droplets are these, a regal nectar that gleefully thwarts any futile attempt at toppling its elegance from the aforementioned brand, or any other unworthy contender. This is the absolute, unequivocal benchmark for sake. Almost perfect.

Aroma: raspberry seeds/hairs/skins, slight tartness--like the kriek Appearance: reddish brown, small white head Flavor: nice tartness, some chocolate, some raspberry seeds/hairs/stems Palate: little lite, chcolate covered raspberry aftertaste

Draft at the brewpub. Purple and brown colored body with little to no head. Fruit syrup nose of plum, black cherry and mostly raspberries, with only a light porter presence. Flavor is more of this syrupy fruit flavoring, moderately thick, very lightly tart and punchy - overall very tasty and easy to drink, but not a runaway winner. Too syrupy, artificial tasting, floral, etc, with minimal porter character.
Chestnut brown pour, thick white head. Dried apricot molasses and malt. I wouldn’t describe this as a Weizen Bock, but still a tasty ale.

Sampled from a bottle, this beer had a dark brown pour into the glass and gave a small off-white cover that receded to a small ring and a few islands of bubbles, it was a dark red at the edges of the glass when held up to a lamp, the nose had aromas of raisin and date with a prominent dark fruit sweetness, toasted bread and bread crust, melanoidins, some hints of chocolate here and there, the flavors were bread with some dark fruit (though not as much dark fruit as I thought it would be based on the nose), some melanoidins, a little spice and some bread sweetness, the mouth feel was medium to full, it layered on the tongue, it felt creamy and had average carbonation, the nose was pretty good and big, the flavor was not as big as I thought it would be from the nose, it was sweeter on the nose than the flavor, it was an ok drink.

12 oz bottle. Pours a red brown with a very off-white head. Intense banana toffee and some strawberry in the aroma. Toffee flavor with some wheat and some weizen yeast. A touch of an off flavor as well. Not enough to make it unpleasant by any means. Decent beer.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass; no bottle dating, but is a recent release. Pours crystal clear deep reddish brown color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of raisin, plum, banana, caramel, toast, brown sugar, brown bread, light clove/nuttiness, slight chocolate, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt notes; with solid strength. Taste of raisin, plum, banana, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, brown bread, light clove/nuttiness, slight chocolate, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Light herbal bitterness/yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, banana, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, brown bread, light nuttiness, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice robustness and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; with a nice malt/yeast balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, creamy, and slightly slick/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very good weizenbock style. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth to drink for the ABV. A nicely enjoyable offering.

21-Feb-11 (12-oz sample bottle: Free bottle for stewarding the 2008 World Beer Cup in San Diego, CA) This beer pours dark ruddy-brown with half an inch of tan head that fizzles away to a wide ring and dusting. The nose is very fruity, with raisin, banana, apple, and fig, plus brown sugar and cola. The fruitiness continues on the palate, again with the raisin, apple, and brown sugar, but the sweetness is sugary, the darker malts are vague, and the yeast character is barely noticeable. Medium-plus in weight, though much of that is from residual sugar, and the carbonation is medium-high and distracting. Not bad, but too much emphasis on the fruity character, and not enough on malt or yeast.

Nitro… RBSG 2010… Clear, beautiful copper ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Lengthy retention. Caramel and toffee dominate the bouquet, but a rumor of banana works its way into the mix. Full-bodied and creamy with tame carbonation. The sweet flavor renders caramel and banana with a whisper of clove. Low bitterness. Not a lot of chocolate. The flavor eventually fades to a sticky-sweet wet dream.

4-30-08 on tap. Brown minimal beige head. Aroma very faint combo of banana and caramel. Flavor is pretty much spot on. Banana, prune, raisin, clove. Slightly boozy, thins it out a tad too much. Other than the lack of aroma, this is pretty solid.

MBG Winterfest 2010. Poured hazy dark brown color with a large off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate spicy toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet and small alcohol bite finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew.

MiBG Winter Fest 2010: Ruby brown with a very good creamy off-white head. The aroma has the expected banana, clove and bubblegum esters along with some red wheat, walnut and roasted malt character. The taste is twangy fruits and light yeasty spice in play along with the wheat and roasted malt tones. Light alcohol presence towards the end. The mouth feel is lively and chalky. An okay example of the style.

Beer #36 of 42 at GTMW, 8-8-09. I wanted to try one of their meads, but all out! So I’ve got this treat instead. It is a dark, weizenbock appearance, a thin but foamy head. Good beer smell, rich in malts. Good bock taste, like dark wheat bread. Very slight bit of estery fruitiness.

From bottle on board Stavangerfjord 11.07.17. Almost colourless. No head. Unpleasant and artificial aroma of pears and wine gum. Similar taste, also with apples. Bitterness of wine gum and artificial sweeteners.
Klar nesten fargeløs med flotte bobler. Lukt av pære. Smak av søt pære. Syrlig ettersmak. supermarked.
God søtlig duft av pære. Sprudlende friskt hvitt skum som forsvinner raskt. Lys klar farge. Frisk smak av pære, noe for søtlig ettersmak.
Flaske fra Prix, konsumert under matlaging: lett og frisk og faktisk ikke for søt. En enkel men helt ok aperitif ved kjøkkenbenken. Trekk for det korte bruseskummet.
18.10.2012, 0,33l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting: Sødmerik fruktig lukt med preg av hermetiske pærer, sukker. Sødmerik kunstig smak med preg av sukker, sure epler, hermetiske pærer. Kjedelig.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC and courtesy of Gunnar, thanks man! :-) Super water-like body. Almost no color, whatsoever. What? I know perries can be faint-hued, but this is ridiculous. Aroma is pear-like candy tones; not very inviting at all. Taste is watery pear juice, of which I the only favorable thing I have to say is that it’s not too sweet. Watery palate. Neext please.
Very light coloured, no head. Sweet pear aroma and taste. Light and fizzy on the palate.

0.33l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. Yupp, totally pale, clear and almost transparent in the looks, well actually it looks just like water this, and it has a small quickly completely gone top. Don’t know what it looked like.. Sweet with apples and some canned pear on the nose. Not much more really. Average on the carbonation and light sticky in the mouthfeel. It actually taste a bit of pear this. Not only apples, but they are definitely also present. A bit to sweet and artificial to be classified as easy drinking’, but also this one was possible to finish the glass. Yeah, thanks Gunnar! 18.10.2012

Biggish coarse white head quickly disappears entirely with a soft, crackling sound. Clear very pale greenish yellow body. Strong pear jam aroma with perfumy floral notes. Unusual. Sweet sugary pear jam taste with vaguely earthy, herbal notes. Mid-bodied. Sweet honey and pear aftertaste with faint cinnamon notes. Well, for a cider it isn’t bad at all. Very clean, but too sweet, and lacking in freshness. (0.5l can, Meny Ringnes Park, Oslo.)
I cider that is the symbol of drunken teens. Way too sweet and candyish for me. The flavour doesn’t feel natural, there are something wrong here.

Aus der Flasche im 2019-09 auf eine Fjordline Fähre getrunken. Dieses Cider hat eine sehr gute Balance zwischen Säure und das Aroma von übereifen Äpfeln bzw. Bratäpfeln was ich so noch nicht hatte. Dabei kommt auch keine Süße auf was es für mich es spannend macht. Der Körper ist recht leicht was es fast süffig macht. Lecker!
From bottle on board Stavangerfjord 11.07.17. Very pale hay colour. Clear. No head. Aroma of ripe yellow apples and wine gum. Silimar taste, with bitterness reminiscent of artificial sweetener.
Klar lys strågul farve med lyst skum som avtar raskt. Lukt av eple. Smak av eple. Søt og noe syrlig. Supermarked,
Søtlig duft av epler. Fin lys gyllen farge. Nesten ingen skum. God smak av epler med en litt syrlig ettersmak.

Flaske fra Berentsens utsalg i Egersund, som aperitif før middag: lett, frisk og søt med litt fruktsyrlighet, men en noe kunstig eplesmak. Tynn munnfølelse og kort ettersmak. Kanskje bedre på en varm somlerdag i hagen? Foreløpig foretrekker jeg pærecideren.
Bottle. Old rating. Yellow colour. Light apple aroma. Light sweet apple flavor. Short finish. Watery palate.
18.10.2012, 0,33l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting: Frisk fruktig lukt med preg av søte gule epler, sukker. Sødmerik smak med preg av sukker, søte gule epler. Kjedelig.
Pours a pale green colour. Aroma of aples and a quite sweet smell. The taste is mostly artificial sweetness, and it makes this cider almost undrinkable. Not good at all.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC, courtesy of Gunnar - thanks! :-) Pours a light dishwashing-water-like color, not looking good. Aroma is sugary apple juice and candy tones. Meh. Taste is sugary apple candy tones, as well. Not too good, but barely passable I guess. Body is thin and watery. No, on second thought: this is pretty much like the other "ciders" out there in the Norwegian grocery store segment - not good (real apples or not).

0.33l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. It’s definitely what you can call clear and pale in the color. Perhaps a swiff of something sea-green and the head is bubbly and transparent. Oh, the aroma takes me back to my youth. Sweet and apply with a gummy bear candy touch as well. Not much more going on here. Oh, it’s aggressive on the carbonation and thin and sticky-sweet mouthfeel. The taste has tons of sugary sweet yellow apples. Tastes a bit like the juice on canned pears. I have no problems finishing my glass, but I think that’s about my limit. Thanks Gunnar! 18.10.2012

Cask Handpump at the Kelham Island Tavern, Sheffield 07/04/2007 Hoppy aroma. Small white head. Golden coloured with some alcohol present. Hoppy. Spicy coriander flavour. Pale and fruity. Orange tasting. Bitter lasting finish.

Cask conditioned at The Golden Lion, York. Served at correct temperature. ABV was 5.5%. Deep golden colour, creamy head. Pleasant malty aroma, hints of malt vinegar and fruity hops. Fairly rich and smooth flavour, well balanced between the malts and hops.
Cask@Reading BF. Some barley sweetness comes through to start, then some fruity, citric (orange) hop notes. Some floral hop ntes in both the aroma and flavour. Sweetish.

Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. First beer of the Reading BF on Thursday with Duff and Chris_O. Gold colour with bubbly white head. Good grapefruity hoppy astringent aroma. Very pleasant, great sharp grapefruit. Really very good. Quite dry. Very good condition.

50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via The Dram Shop. Slightly hazy amber gold colour. Aroma of sweet cereal malt and some fruity bubblegum. Light body, a little oily, with a slightly off taste on the finish.
Bottle. Golden and clear with some hops and citrus. Well bottled which is an improvement of some of their other beers. The best i have tried from this brewery.

Cask (handpump) @ Harlequin, Sheffield, Bedfordshire England S3 8GG. On RateBeer Sheffield "Valley of beer" Crawl 2008. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average to large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, fruity, moderate hoppy, flowers, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet amd moderate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (260708)
Cask at the Harlequin, Sheffield, on RateBeer Valley of Beer Crawl ’08 ...amber,water hop, light fruity hop, little caramel

A Mes rate: Cask at the Harlequin. An attractive golden brown with a good white head. Creamy and sweet aroma. Tea, malt and slight peat in the flavour with some slight bitterness in the finish. Rather dull.

Suspect this is the beer described in the database as ’Spire IPA’. It definitely now boasts the name ’Sovereign’ on pumpclip and website. Cask at the Harlequin, Sheffield, on RateBeer Valley of Beer Crawl ’08. Gold with a small white head. Hoppy aroma. Slight oiliness in the mouthfeel, but the overall impression is rather watery for a 5.2%. Some rather horsey grain, but little bitterness to follow.
Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Fairly toasty malty flavours. Mild hops with a little dustiness and hints of more interesting fruit flavours somewhere. Not great but drinkable.

Cask@Reading IPA. Malty- quite gristing and grainy malt notes. Hops are citric/earthy and dry. Quite light in the hops department, and probably not an IPA, which it claims to be. Just a stronger bitter. Above average.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Hazy copper colour with thin beige head. Slightly syrupy aroma. Doesn’t drink its strength. Quite dry on finish. Not much of an IPA to be honest.

Cask-conditioned at the Gardener’s Rest, Sheffield, 2/12/2014. Golden in colour, with a slight, white, head. Easy drinking pale ale, with crisp malts, a touch of citrus fruit, and decent, bitter, finish. Good.
On cask at Gardeners Rest, Sheffield. Pours golden with white head. Smooth yet rather light on taste. It’s an Ok session ale.
Hand pulled at The Gardeners Rest, Sheffield. Hoppy dry bitter with no duration to the finish. Disappointing.

Cask @ The Rutland Arms, Sheffield. The pour’s a light gold color with a small white head. The nose is of fart, some grain, a bit of cake batter. The taste is pretty underwhelming. More fart, pale malt. Sour apricot on the finish. Light body, thin and of little consequence. Overall, I really didn’t like this one.

Cask at Gardener’s Rest, Sheffield on 19th January 2013. Gold with lasting laceless white head. Hoppy and mildly yeasty aroma. Floral and fruity in-mouth, suggestions of smoke. Delicately hoppy and fruity finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Pleasant, drinkable pint.
Cask at Rutland Arms, Holmesfield - a slight lemony nose, and mild hops. Taste to match, not much body. Bland.
