Cask conditioned handpump Gardeners Rest Sheffield 21/06/12. A straw coloured beer with a white head. There are lemony hops in this but otherwise there are rubber and fart notes. Must be shallowing, but it should be in prime condition in this pub.
Cask @ Bon Accord. Clear golden colour, whtie ehad. Aroma is soft malty, bit of biscuit. Flavour is malty, bit hoppy and some dry biscuit. Smooth and well drinkable.

Cask. A light golden beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of citrus fruits and elderflowers as well as lighter notes of sulphur. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and citrus fruits, leading to a dry and bitter finish where the elderflower notes lingers.

From cask at University Arms. Pours almost clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma is cornish and slight grassy hops. Fruity, mild citrusy and light spiced hoppy. Simple and easy. Ends slight bitter and mild fruity.
Cask at Bow bar ... golden yellow ... thin white head ... soft lemon hop nose ... wishy washy light fruit hop ...
Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Chester 15/05/2003 Clear golden coloured and fruity. Creamy on the palate with a lasting hop finish.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 20/5/08. Deep, clear gold in colour with a decent, white head. Aroma of elderflowers and grapefruit. with a touch of sweet malt. Hoppy flavours, with some citrus fruit and pepper leading to a decent dry finish. Very good.
Cask@Reading BF. Quite light, with some soft citric hop notes, some lightly sweet, earthy malt notes. The flavour dissapears quite quickly and its too light in body for me.

Cask at Fannies Ale and Cider House, Saltaire, West Yorks’ 04-05-07. Poured warm golden colour with white busy head. Hops and Grapefruit dominated the aroma and were most noticeable in taste dept’. I marginally preferred the Durham White Velvet that I tried alongside this, but this was very drinkable.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Pale copper/gold with bubbly off white head. Very hoppy aroma, dry spice. Very citrusy. Very very dry (or was that the dust?) Bit floral, but v. drinkable.

Bottle at home picked up from Sainsbury's. As Sainsbury's taste the difference english vintage cider 6.8% A clear yellow golden coloured pour with a fine white fizz. Aroma is semi sweet, clean apple, plastic, juicy apple. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, apple juice, clean, hides the abv well. Hint of tang in the finish. Palate is semi sweet, fine mellow carbonation. Decent clean drinking boost.
50cl bottle shared at my birthday tasting. Thin white head. Hazy golden pour. A bit sweet.

750ml bottle from Sainsbury's Darlington. 2016 vintage. Golden colour, no lasting head and aroma of apple, fruity. Taste is sweet sugary, fruity apple with light woody oak notes. Light to medium bodied, low carbonation, semi-dry slightly tannic finish. Quite OK.
(Sainsbury’s) 750 ml bottle @home,bb 07/2019. 2016 vintage. Golden,clear. Apple and apple skin aroma. The same taste. No carbonation - big downside.

bought as sainsbury’s English vintage cider (2014) , 750ml bottle, sainsbury’s morecambe. Served chilled in straight glass. Nice bitter sweet apple with subtle oaked flavor, with smoky under tones. No head ( it is cider after all ), but nice gold colour. Fresh apple aroma, nicely sparkling .

Bottle from sainsburys. Pale yellow cider, carbonated. Aroma of musty apples and some Apple skin. Taste is mild tannin, Apple pulp, some wood and a moderate dry finish. A touch of oil on the palate. Good stuff.

Bottle from local Sainsbury’s in Eastbourne. Pours out in a clear light golden colour with medium body. Aroma of crisp apples. Taste of medium ripe red apples, green apples, leaves and light caramel. Acid-thin finish. Refreshing and not that bad.

Bottle from M and S in Eastbourne shared with McTapps. Not really big into aromas but a well balanced one with a good mitxure of sweet and sour moments. Apples all the way with some lemons. Heavily drinkable, balanced carbo - decent cider.

Bottle at chriso’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2013 - London. Vintage 2010. Pours clear, very pale yellow with note head, really. Sweet but not cloying, with light tang and moderate ripe apple character. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with mellow dryness and lingering tangy quench. Good stuff.

’Sainsbury’s English Vintage Cider’. Tulip from a 750ml screwtop. Headless gold with an edge of halo. Asti, strawberry and champagne aroma. Warming, drying and somewhat industrial with hints of calamine and mild acidic interest. OK but not going to be guzzling down the remaining 500ml any time soon.

Rafraîchissante, dégustée directement à la pression après une longue route. Une bière ambrée, plutôt claire, quasi sans mousse. Son nez est plutôt caramélisé et sa bouche assez limpide, maltée également.

Robe ambrée, limpide, mousse faible. Nez très floral. En bouche, un peu de malt, et surtout bcp de fleurs, du corps, mais pas trop sucré. Un goût de céréales soutenu par le sucre. Rafraichissant, se boit sans peine, malgré le sucre. Doux, sans prétention, agréable.

Bottle shared thanks to Pierre. Clear light amber with small white head and big bubbles rising, looks like amber cola. Sweet malts, light cardboard, orange, some funny candy, hop extract, light herbs. Medium sweet and light bitter. Medium bodied. I’m not sure what the artificial aromas in this are supposed to be, but overall it’s a messy and weird beer that still somewhat drinkeable.

Pression 25 ccl service pro. Mousse crémeuse, dense et persistante. Nez florale, arôme houblonné présent sans toutefois être porté sur l'amertume. Bière plaisir et gourmande idéal en accompagnent de charcuterie salée et fromage léger. (PPC, PPNC).
Forbavset! Denne øl ville jeg tro var en tynd omgang øl, men jeg blev forbavset. Den er meget frugagtig øg sødlig i det.
25cl bottle purchased @ Leclerc. Lager bien rafraichissante avec une belle note de raisin muscat. Très fruitée.

Bue à la pression. Nez un peu caramel, pas mal floral, mousse qui fini sur un col durable, bonne limpidité. En bouche c’est légèrement caramel et herbacé avec une bonne amertume en fin de bouche. Notes métalliques en toute fin de bouche. Bière industrielle un peu moins classique que d’ordinaire mais rien de bien dingo.

25cl bouteillette, heureusement.- An alsatian Märzen of sorts, filtered through an age of industrial brewing into harsh spring barley metallics and vegetable stalk bitterness. Aroma of starchy grape sugars, packaged vanilla dust. Minimal barley caramel, green tea, then sweetish like a faceless Maibock light, too shy to become gluey. This is not a beer from an era/dispositif culturel that believes beer can "do" taste independently.
Bière dorée ambrée avec belle mousse blanche. Au nez on retrouve direct l’odeur d’une bière industriel. Un peu maltée, épicée et douce.

750ml bottle from Carrefour, Calais, France.Amber coloured with a thick white head of foam. It has a sweet fruity and gentle grassy flavour with gentle floral and malt notes on the creamy, warming finish. Ok.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: 50 cl bottle from the Home Brew shop, Aldershot. Bottle Conditioned. Poured a hazy golden amber with a billowing white head and heavy carbonation; aroma of cider apples; slightly sour, cidery taste; then a dry finish. - I strongly suspect that this was actually Hopped Up Cyder.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle at DSG 2011. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is sour, malt, hop. Flavour is sour, malt, hop, fruit. Infected.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, Ulfborg 2011. Very murky amber with no head. Malty aroma and taste, very tart, cardboard soem caramel and hops. Def infected

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle 500ml. ABV: 3.8%. Clear medium amber colour with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, leather - berry. Flavour is moderate sweet, light acidic and light moderate bitter with a long duration, berry tart. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110819]

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Hazy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of dried fruit, malt and barnyard. Dry and tart fruity flavour

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: botella. Unclear amber brown colour. Malty toasty bit fruity aroma, lightly sour. Flavour is sweet and malty with caramel, sourish fruity bit.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. It pous an unclear, amber body with some sediments and a dense, small, beige head. The aroma is sourish and fruity, surely infected. The same goes for the flavor, sourish, lemony and fruity, with a chalky touch. Not very good in any way. 110819

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are vinegar, caramel, fruits and hops.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle @ FOneFan. Hazy brown/orange with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, little sour, brett, caramel, fruit, hops and a little sweet.

column1: Fallen Angel Englishmans Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, Ulfborg 2011. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Bitter , tart and fruity, dry flavor. A bit thin palate. Orange, dust and tartness.
Old notes from DØE Valby 07. Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and liquorish. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee and liqourish. Light alcohol.

A special treat from the brewers private cellar. Thanks alot for the chance to taste this black X. The pour is realy black and almost oily with s very dark brown head. I dont recal I have seen a darker head than this. The nose is packed with laqurice, brown sugar and alcohol mixed up with a vinoes and sweet side. There is some vanilla, som oak and something that reminds me of oil from a ferrys machineroom. The taste is enourmous - so huge that it fills up every little part of your mouth. There are some sweet chocolate, cinamon, burned malts, coffee and dried fruits. The palate is picking and sticky. In the finish therede is a balanced sweetness and bitterness with notes of cherrys.. Excelent. Thanks M

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2007, Valby. Pours a black beer with a beige/lightbrown head. The aroma is roasted with licorice, port and prunes. The flavor is sweet and roasted with chocolate, licorice, port and dried fruits. The palate is roasted. Really nice and drinkable Imperial Stout.

Tasted at the WLV tasting. I agree with 17th that this was a wonderful and delicious treat. Perhaps I was a bit toasty by the time this one came out, but I definately found to be better than what the rest of the chi-town crew are giving it. So it goes I suppose. Deep black pour with very little in the way of head. Aromas were very unusual. Chocolate, coffee, soy sauce, some very herbacious notes, licorice. I could keep my nose over this all day. Flavors folow suite, roasty, chocolate, soy, some other elements that are hard to define... especially cause I lost my notes from that day :*( I agree that there wasnt a strong or rather identifiable brett character, though I’m not sure what it would be like in a 15% stout anyway. In any case I am very glad to have been able to try this rare treat and am very much looking forwarf to trying the barrel aged version this summer ;)

Shared at WLV liquors... Thank you Ted for keeping this one for so long! Out of the 30 beers we tasted this day this one stood out the most... and in a good way regardless of what these others say on here =p shame shame. Strong varnish aroma, spicy, nutty and some plums. Pours very dark brown. Sweet raisin, plum and cherry flavors, some chocolate and soy as well.

huge thanks to the folks at wlv who shared this rare gem. . a dark brown our almost black with no head whatsoever.... ghastly aroma of sour, spoiled vegetables and soy which i couldn’t quite stand.... flavors didn’t help out at all either. sweet, sour, chocolate, seaweed, spoiled vegetables which was difficult to keep down.....this one garnered a wide variety of reactions. some liked it and found it very unique. i thought that it was pretty different in a bad way. my facial reaction really showed it all. i’m glad i don’t have a picture of it. i’m hoping that i can attribute this to a poorly mishandled bottle.

bottle. pours black with no head. an odd aroma, extremely vegetal, soy, and some chemical i can’t put my finger on, there seems to be some cherry notes in there as well. flavors are chocolatey, soy, and herbs. perhaps this has aged horribly. i didn’t get any brett either. alcohol was pretty well hidden for 15% but this is just a mess of a beer. in the end pantanap’s face and the instant almost depressive episode afterwards gave the best review of this beer. cheer up bud, you’ll be drinking M soon I thought.

Sampled by bottle at West Lake View Tasting. So I was really excited the good people at WLV decided to open this one up for this generous tasting. But I was blown away (in the opposite direction) by this one. Pours brown black with no head. This nose says this beer had bottling problems or was seriously abused by heat. Vegetables, soy sauce, and fresh hops before they are even thrown in the boil. Sweet flavors. Chocolate, roasted malts, and booze. Full chunky body. Touch of alcohol with a harsh and nearly unbearable soy sauce. What’s goin on here? No brett detected and its kinda the let down of the year. Terrible.

Draught at Copenhagen Beerfestival 2007. Pitch black colour with a white head. Aroma of sweetness, roastedness and vanilla. Also flavour of roastedness, vanilla, chocolate, sweetness and with a strong alcoholic finish. I would like to taste this beer again after cellered a couple of years.

Motor oil looks, headless. A very intense, port-wine like nose with hugely concentrated sugars immediately reminiscent of brown sugar. Fortunately, it has this grapey vinous character that saves it from being an unjustified sugar fest. It is dense dark fruits, admittedly complex malts from the beginning until the end. Blackberries, ink, tar, oil… Not very beery in the end. Hugely alcoholic and syrupy with the limited carbonation. Pure sugary experiment, playing with desserts, molasses intensity. A bum with a citric character. Obviously aiming at pushing the boundaries of craft brewing further. It is appreciated, I enjoy the end, but the means, not completely.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4 &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Dark(5) : 3 &nbsp Ruby : XX &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 2 &nbsp White(1)->Tan(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 1 &nbsp Lacing : 1 Aroma: Intensity : 3 &nbsp Yeast : 3 &nbsp Bread : XX &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Esters : XX &nbsp Banana : XX &nbsp Phenols : XX &nbsp Leather : 2 &nbsp Perfume : XX &nbsp DMS : XX &nbsp Diacetyl : XX Malt : 2 &nbsp Biscuity : XX &nbsp Toast : XX &nbsp Caramel : 2 &nbsp Toffee : XX &nbsp Maple : XX &nbsp Molasses : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Candy : 4 &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : 3 &nbsp Fruits : 5 &nbsp Chocolate : 3 &nbsp Coffee : 2 &nbsp Vanilla : 2 &nbsp Grapes : 2 &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Dates : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX &nbsp Plums : XX &nbsp Figs : XX Hops : 1 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Spicy : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : XX &nbsp Wood : 3 &nbsp Cloves : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Pepper : 3 &nbsp Ginger : 4 &nbsp Peach/Pear/Apricot : XX &nbsp Candi Sugar : 2 &nbsp Anise : XX &nbsp Vinous : 2 Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 5 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 5 &nbsp Sourness : 2 &nbsp Bitterness : 1 &nbsp Complex : 2 &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 4 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 5 &nbsp Clean : 3 &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : XX &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : 3 &nbsp Mineral : 2 &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : 1 Comments: I did not enjoy this one as much as I expected. First it is nicely woody and its raspberry flavours are very well extracted, but the palate did not protrude as much sourness as I would have hoped and the result feels extremely sweet to the point of being sticky despite the very high carbonation. The alcohol is also well upfront. Raspberry waffled with ginger and soaked in rum.

[Another century celebrated with a Mikkeller beer - this time 8900] Draft. A deep red-brown beer with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is sweet malty combined with strong notes of raspberries and wood. The flavor is a mixture of sweet and acidic with notes of raspberries and wood. For a lover of Flemish Sour beers this is lovely.

Draught at Københavnske Øldage 2007 Dark chestnut color; thin creamy head. The fruity-sour aroma of Oud Bruin beers is strong. Powerful flavor too, full malty, a bit vinous, fruity, chemicals… I love so much this!
Dark and cloudy ruby with a small white head. Really big and perfumed raspberry aroma. Sweet flavour with notes of raspberry and molasses.
On tap. Dark brown coloured with a tan head. Bit sour with notes of dark fruit, caramel, raspberries and alcohol.
Draught at Københavnske øldage 07. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, raspberry, sour. Flavour is alcohol, raspberry, malt, caramel,sour, dried fruits. Nice beer.

Draught at Københavnske Øldage. Deep mahogany color, clear, and without head. Really a juiced-up flamish sour ale, with a good dash of alcohol, but a decent level of sourness. Quite sweet flavor, yet very sour, with dried fruits as well. A bit astringent mouthfeel, as it should be. The finish is both sweet and acidic. (070511)

Hazy brown, oily poure and small light coloured head. Aroma a bready, candi like and has tons of stuffed rasperries, red berries, eau de vie de framboise but also touches of medicinale sirups, chalk pouder (Johnson & Johnson), tar, solfer, pipe tobacco. Taste is another storry. Its is rich, with nice mouthfilling breadyness (Milkbread) nuts, frangipan (almond cake) vanilla and a very nice ballans between the sweet sugars and the sour (slight tart) raspberrie and other berries. No medicinale accents in the taste here. Thanks Mikkel for filling up the only bottle ever made of this stuff. I realy loved the the brown sugars and the fruits.
Draught at KØ07. Dark brown colour, small head. Very sweet pruney flavour. Some port and prune notes. A little sourness, but not enough.
Deep reddish, brown colour with a tan head. Malty, raspberry fruity aroma with a light sweetness. Wellbalanced raspberry fruity flavor with sugar sweet notes and a light dry and tart finish.
Copenhagen beerfestival 2007. Complex hop aroma: Herbal, almost sulphury, pine, green apples. Cloudy amber creamy head. Metallic bitterness, orangepeel, pine, grass. Light body. Very silly.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2007, Valby. Pours a muddy amber beer with a white head. The aroma is (surprise!) hops. The flavor is (surprise again) hops. The palate is bitter, almost burning. And overall a very hoppy beer.
This beer is undrinkable, there are no harmoni between the hops and malt. The periment is funny, and is was fun to try, but thats all to say about that.
The hoppies brew ever... per Urbain at Struisse. Very 1 dimensional... not that it should be a surprise, comes off very astringent and almost acidic.. has some sweetness but lacks balance.
Tap. Amber with white head. Aroma is hops with notes of hops and after that some more hops. Taste is very hoppy and very bitter. Funny experiment.

Draught at Copenhagen Beerfestival 2007. Hazy amber colour with a very nice hoppy aroma. Very very hoppy and bitter flavour, a little bit to much sharp bitter nad hops flavour, the flavour also have some caramel, but need some balance. A very interresting beer.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body:   Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4     Golden(1)->Dark brown(5) : 2     Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 3 Head:   None(1)->Large(5) : 2   White(1)->Tan(5) : 2   Lasting: 2   Lacing : 2 Aroma: Intensity : 4   Yeast : 2   Bread : 2   Tropical Fruits : XX   Soap : XX   Diacetyl : XX Sulfur : XX   Fusel : 3   Malt : 2   Biscuity : XX   Hay : XX   Toasty : 2   Caramel : XX   Fruity : XX   Nutty : XX   Honey : XX   Maple : XX   Molasses : XX   Cereals : XX   Grainy : XX Hops : 5   Noble(1)->American(5) : 4   Leafy : 5   Spicy : 5   Floral : 3   Lemon/Lime : XX   Grapefruit : XX Orange : 4   Herbal : 5   Grassy : XX   Pine/Spruce/Resin : 5   Notes :   Peach/Apricot : 2   Earth : 2   Mint : 2   Butterscotch : XX   Smoke : 2   Dates : XX   Bourbon : XX   Bubblegum : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 1   Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 1   Sourness : XX   Bitterness : 5   Complex : 2   Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3   Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2   Clean : XX   Sharp : XX   Watery : XX   Oily : 2   Chalk : XX   Astringent : 4   Alcohol : XX   Mineral : XX   Oxidation : XX   Metallic : XX Comments: Precisely what it tries to be: the hoppiest beer I’ve ever tried. Extremely harsh and like licking a hop sack, leafy, resinous, bitter and astringent, but someone had to do it!

[Another century celebrated with a Mikkeller beer - this time 9200] An unclear orange beer with a beige head. The aroma is extremely hoppy with notes of grapefruit and grass - just hops nothing else is evident to me. The flavor is even more extreme just being hops and being extremely bitter - some notes of grapefruit and grass - but mainly just bitter. I’m an admitted hophead - but this is just too much for me.
Unclear orange with a small white head. Intense hop aroma, mostly of the citrus kind. Extremely bitter, with a long lasting, wonderfully painful lingering bitterness.
A funny Xperiment, but not a good beer. There is No harmoni in it. Normally I really enjoy beer with lots of hop in it. But is shall still taste like a beer, in this beer there is only hop taste.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: 03.05.2014, tap @ CBC: Small brown creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is very mild and balanced, almost too balanced, sweet coffee liquor, mocha, vanilla, dark sugar, espresso, caramel. Taste is sweet roasted, chocolate milk, lactose, burnt coffee, burnt caramel, cereal, roasted grain, vanilla, grass, hay. Medium bitterness, very dry dusty mouthfeel. Fair enough, a little disappointing.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: From tap at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014. Black color with brown head. Roasted malty aroma, chocolate, cocoa, caramel, coffee, cookies. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: Draught at CBC 2014. Opaque black liquid with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, licorice, raw sugar, chocolate and syrup. Taste is light to medium sweet and medium bitter with notes of coffee and licorice. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Good.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: Tap at CBC 2014. Beer in the glass deep black, small head. Malty smokey aroma. Starts heavy malty, smokey, notes of strong coffee, bitter background. Finish milder, malty-smokey. Nice!

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: Keg at the Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014, red session. 03/05/2014. Deep black, viscous pour with a lasting rich tan head. Aroma is really earthy coffee beans, vanilla, creamy caramel. Flavour is really dirty, earthy, rough coffee, light veg. Really dirty and rough, coffee beans. Dark harsh roast. Palate is full body, butty on the tongue. Overall this is way too raw.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: Draught at CBC 2014. Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and bitterness.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: On tap at CBC 2014. Black with brown head. Aroma and taste of coffee, slight acidic, milky, chocolate, more coffee with a silky mouthfeel. Nice

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: CBC. Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, heavy chocolate and coffee. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 030514

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: 3rd May 2014 CBC Session 3. Muddy looking dark brown beer, short lived dark tan head. Palate starts smooth but has a light crispness on the backend. Dry coffee and well buried burned malt. Whisper of malt cream. Dry finish. All round - quite mellow.

column1: Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast (Pooh Coffee Cask Festival Edition)
column5: Draught sample at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014. 3rd Session. Pours black with a nice head, aroma of chocolate, coffee, honey, caramel, flavor is bitter with chocolate, coffee and some acidity, medium to full bodied, Great.
330ml bottle at home. Poured dark gold with white head. Aroma is hoppy citrus pine. Taste is malt pine citrus hoppy bitter finish
Pours mid tan, white but thinning head. Good bitterness but the cascade hops don't shine through, remains rather overly malty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice. Lovely rust colour, slightly cloudy. You can feel the American in it. Very drinkable.

I like to see an English brewer trying a US style beer. Slightly hazy gold, medium head. Armoa of vanilla cream, bit of fruit. Flavour has a hint of vanilla but some medicinal herby notes. Mildish bitter finish. Not sure about this, will have again if I ever see it.

Bottle Conditioned. Pours a golden orange colour with a huge white head. Real citrus aroma with more than a hint of grapefruit. The taste is very a sticky citrus, with plenty of malt with a long dry finish.

Bottled at RBESG 2008. An unclear golden beer with a huge orangey head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and strong notes of fruit among them peaches. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of fruits again peaches being strongest, as well as medium notes of malt and dusty hops, leading to a bitter finish.
RBESG 08. Hazy orange with a lasting white head. Aroma is perfumed floral with some hay. Fruity sweet flavour with a drying, grapefruit hoppy finish.

Bottle 50cl. @ home. Clear medium amber copper color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, caramel, moderate to light light heavy hoppy, flowers, citrus, moderate grapefruit - soap. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (120808)
Bottle. Very bitter and is it really an America pale ale? More like a bland British bitter. The bitterness put me off.

Bottle. Hazy amber with a medium off-white head. Citric fruit aroma. Citric flavours, quite dry with good underlying bitterness. Apples flavours. Well-carbonated. Despite suspicion of some infection problems, it is still quite drinkable with its solid bitterness.

Draft: Poured a clear dirty brown color ale with small foamy head. Aroma of dry wheat malt notes with some woody and vanilla notes is quite pleasant. Taste is dominated by dry wheat malt notes with some caramelized malt notes and a woody and vanilla finish with plenty of bourbon notes. Body is about average with good carbonation and light warming alcohol notes. Interesting beer thought I would not drink large quantities in one sitting.
3rd of flight of 4 @ clybourn. hazy orange-bronze. filled my mouth with flavor, intense, malty, a little boozy, sweet, luscious.

Draft at Goose Island. It’s finally back and not from a barrel!. Pours a lightly hazed bronze with fluffy white head. Nose is actually citrusy and fruity, hints of tart wheat, restrained yeast character and noted ethanol. On tasting, medium-high bitterness, much lighter body than expected. Was anticipating more of a barleywine character. Alcohol is definitely noted, but not all bad. Fruity and lightly sweet but balanced. The citrusy notes are definitely welcome.

On tap at Goose Island - Clybourn in August 2009. A: Pours a dark bronze with a nice white head. S: Sweet caramel malt, fruits, wheat, some tartness, and a wee bit of alcohol. T: Similar to the nose but with a more pronounced spiciness from the yeast, and a bit more of an alcohol kick. M: Medium bodied with good carbonation. D: Pretty good--a little heavy and sweet to be really drinkable, but quite good all around. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-04-2009
Tap at Clybourn brewpub, Chicago. Golden pour with white head. Sweet aroma. Tastes sweet, wheaty, fruity, malty. No distinct taste in this one. Unremarkable.

Small sample &#40thankfully&#41 at Goose Island Clark. Pours a clear glowing viscous yellow golden with a fine white froth. Aroma is very strong bubble-gum and super sweet extra ripe banana, sweet fermenting fruits, fermenting banana. Flavor is very cloying overripe fermenting banana and bubblegum, massive banana liquor. Doughy chewy very viscous, light fizzy carbonation. Glad I got a free sample. This belongs mixed into a tropical drink.

Tap at the Clybourne location. Pale golden pour. The nose is intensely sweet with a lot of candyish and cotton candy aroma. Very sugary palate with a real tooth-aching sweetness. A little bit of peach and rotted fruit. Vegetal and DMS laden. Herbal hoppiness but nothing could even come close to balancing all of the unfermented, underattenuated malt sugars in here. Gak!

On tap at GI Clybourn served in a snifter. Slightly hazed copper pour with a thin head of lasting tan foam. Okay lacing. The aroma was a little dull for a beer this big. Some toasted wheat followed by some faint caramel notes. The flavor had creamy, lightly toasted wheat, caramel, a hint of fruit skins, and a very mild alcohol warmth. Full-bodied and lightly carbonated. The bourbon-aged version blows this away. Bland and almost a chore to drink.

On tap at gi clybourn... Pours a darker reddish amber brown hue with a soapy film of milk white head... Banana in the aroma with lighter fruit playing a backing role. Sweeter overall... Flavors are sticky and sugary sweet. Tasted like an extreme take on a wheat beer with a little bitter astringency in the finish. Semi-warming but holds the abv in check to some degree.

Goblet poured draft at the Clybourne brewpub (Chicago, IL). Pours an orangey amber! Light haze, moderate offwhite head that sticks around and laces pretty damn well. Aromas are wheaty malts, cereal with some toffee sweetness, a touch fruity with some darker bits and a bit of booziness. Some grapefruit citrus, caramel come in stronger as it warms a bit. Initial is warming booziness, an imperial wheat throws some bigger but smooth sweetness, toffee and graininess. Hops come in fairly strong but taper down. Citrusy grapefruit and a bit of other fruitiness comes (Pear? Apricot?) In with some warming booziness. Lighter on the palate, delicate with pretty good sweetness and decent hop balance. Finish is warming, sweet, with ok hoppy balance.

On tap at the Cumberland brewpub as Dorkmonster. Hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of noble hops, lemon, wheat and pale malt. Taste of lemon, pale malt, noble hops and mild rye. Slightly sour.

Draft. Not much to sytle, but a good drinking beer on its own. Hazy, unflitered gold/orange body below a frothy white head. Hoppy, citrusy nose with some notes of toast and bread. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Light acidity. Light taste of orange juice. Light to medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Reminded me somewhat of an American wheat, especially Bells Oberron.

I had this last night under the title "Dorkmonster" - they still tagged it as a dry hopped dortmunder, so I am guessing it is the same brew. Really hazy yellow with a lingering foamy white head. (all of cumberlands brews are hazy, do they not have a bright tank?). Aroma of citrus, wheat, and floral hops. Awesome refreshing citrus wheaty hoppy flavor. NOT to style reallt, but quite pleasing. Medium to lite body with medium carbonation. Overall: great summer brew.
some serious hops on this one. coupled with some pretty heavy bitterness made it pretty intense. enjoyable but a bit much for me.

Labeled as Dry-hopped Dortmunder at the brewpub. Comes out blazing with an unfiltered gold body and nose full of American hops. Had a robusty bready character, though was overly bitter and hopped for a Dort, still a very nice beer.

Draft at brewpub. Poured a hazy amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus hoppy aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Drinkable brew.

clear yellow. white head. funky malty dirty skunky german lager aroma light hops......i wish i had a better vocabulary for this style of beer......sorry i will work on that. the flavor is quite bitter and hoppy with light sweet toasted malt undertones. bitter lasting hop finish. light body. lively carbonation. decent for the style.

Very dark, reddish-black pour at the brewpub in Boulder Creek. Thin tan head. Sparse lacing. Nose is malty. Taste is sweet and malty. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Solid porter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Toasty. Cocoa and chocolate. Espresso. Creamy. Weak overall but the creaminess is redeeming.

Sample at the brewpub, 28/10/13. Good as pitch with a slim but lacy tan collar. Roasted nose with filter coffee stirred into Ribena. Blackcurrant swirls beneath well done sausage and yam skin. Excellent mellow cigar and chipotle linger. Growlerworthy.
Tap at the brewery. Pours black, tan head. Aroma of roast malt, taste of same. Pleasing enough.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours black with a lasting tan head. Aroma is sweet and roasty chocolate and espresso, with some earthy hops. Flavor is the same. A bit creamy mouthfeel. A solid porter, on the sweet and moderately hoppy, but still very easy-drinking side.

I am a big fan of porters. But their porter missed the mark to me. Nice deep dark color and great lacing, but way too hoppy for a porter. The chocolate malt was masked by the bitterness, which should not happen in a porter, for me.

Brown, nice white head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits, spices, raisins - belgian notes. Taste of caramel, spices, dark fruits. Boring Belgium. Medium body, well hidden alco. Medium carbonation. Correct one.
Bevuta in bottiglia. Birra stile belgian ale scura. Non particolari profumi. Comunque molto buona.
gyllenbrun, svisker, tørket frukt, karamell litt tynn,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,

Dark caramel Amber foamy head. Aromas olve, Candi sugar slight banana, slight yeast. Flavors toffee, slight banana ester, caramel, slight bread, slight yeast. Medium to high sweetness. Not that complex for an abt quad, but tasty. Not the kind of quad I look for.

Dark and sublte red pour with a decent tan head. Nice pleasant aroma with a fine intensity in this one. Quite ok to sniff on for a while. Also a fine balanced sweetness for a beer like this. And a mellow carbonation level that made it easy to drink. Boozy, but no sticky alcohol. Dried fruits, toffee, brown sugar and a bit vinous flavor. [Bottle from Mikkeller in Copenhagen, Denmark]

Can shared at a tasting at Max's place. Brown with a frothy beige head. Mildly nutty, a little alcoholic aroma, sweet, a little nutty, some cocoa and a little alcoholic in the mouth. Full body, fizzy, long, bitter and alcoholic finish.
At Max Place, pours black with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, fruits, flavor of chocolate, fruits, sugar, medium bodied
På flaska, lagrad några år i källaren. Smak och doft av karamell, torkad mörk frukt, brunt socker, stor alkoholsötma, bra balans och beska. Gott!

16 February 2019. At Struise Shop, Bruges. Shared with Anke. Cask: vintage 2015. Pours hazy brown with a lasting, small, unstable, frothy, yellowish tan head; lots of lacing. Strong aroma of pear syrup, Turkish delight, candied plum, earth, roasted peanut, milk chocolate, herbal liqueur, green tea. Taste is medium to heavy malty sweet, pure candied plum & Turkish delight with a caramelly edge & a dash of pear syrup; light herbal bitter middle offers balance, notes of cookie spices, green tea, bit roasted, chocolatey & nutty. Dryish, herbal & peppery hoppy finish, lingering caramel, plum & nuts, and a firm dash of warming herbal liqueur alcohol. Medium to full body, oily-syrupy texture, soft carbonation. Funny to discover this is inspired by Rochefort and the likes, with Mikkeller making an over-the-top version of it.

Pression 25cl le 13/02/2019. Mousse : Marron, bulles moyennes, bonne tenue. Liquide : Brun foncé. Nez : Caramel, sucre, pruneaux, pomme caramélisée, fruit noir/rouge/confit, malt torréfié. Bouche : Caramel, sucre, pruneaux, raisin sec, fruit noir/rouge/confit, malt torréfié, pomme/poire caramelisée, fruits secs, doux, bonne amertume. Palais : Carbonatation faible à moyenne, très bonne longueur en bouche. Excellent !
On draft at the Grizzly Paw Brewery tasting room. Labeled 20th Springbock. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Malty nose. Flavors of toffee and caramel. Light bitter finish. 3

So as not to add another springbock to this brewery I will add this review here. This latest one is called Axis and Allies Maibock. Anyways, pint on tap at the brewery pours a clear golden color with a small white head that leaves very little if any lacing on the glass. Aroma is grass and grains. Taste is a grass hop bitterness with a grassy malt sweetness. Light to medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, this brew is average at best for the style.

Draft at the brewpub; bright golden and quite still. Light malty aroma. Smooth drinker. Sharp and biting flavor with a big cerealy malt undertow; little to this distinguishes it from a common American lager. Where’s it’s warming aspect you’d want from a Maibock? Bland. (#2882, 5/14/2007)

The new seasonal, and quite a disappointment. Bright, clear straw yellow with a thin white head. Very faint aroma, grainy and wet hair (dirty lines?). Quite light, quite carbonated, and quite featureless unfortunately. The bartender reassures me that there is "a mild hop presence", but I can’t find it. It may be because I had this after the IPA.
rbesg07, cask at the cask and barrel in edinburgh. golden with some nice lacing. generic grainy aroma, firm-bodied with a modest grassy bitterness
Cask at The Cask and Barrel, Edinburgh. A golden beer with a thin dense lazing off-white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of caramel - and so is the flavor.

Strong sparkler white foam covers the golden body veiled by a light haze. Well hopped this! Highly flowery, lightly lemony and brightly extracted. Firm bitterness in the finish. Really drinkable, but perhaps a bit too grainy in its maltiness that does not really follow any other discipline. I found it to be a very impressive and tasty low ABV ale, perhaps one of the nicest cask ale I’ve had in Scotland and I’m afraid to say that unsurprisingly, it is not Scottish.
Cask at The Cask & Barrel, Edinburgh. Amber colour. Red and green apples in flavour. Bit eggy. Soft mouthfeel. Low bitterness.

Cask conditioned at The Cask & Barrel, Edinburgh. Served too warm. Amber colour, creamy head. Very nice aroma of fruity and zesty hops, hints of blackcurrants and maybe some balsamic vinegar. The flavour did not take advantage of the beer being served too warm. Biscuity flavour with tolerable hops, but not very exciting.
Cask, Cask and Barrel, Edinburgh, RBESG 07. Coppery, thin off-white head. Nose is quite malty, some fruit. Mouth malty, some fresh summer fruit, a little lemongrass too. Little bit dry. Alright

Cask at Cask and Barrel, Edinburgh. Golden colour, creamyhead. Strong grassy aroma. Sweet and fruity with soft mouthfilling maltiness. Caramelly malt flavours are folllowed by flowery, salty bitterness.
(RBESG 2007, Cask at "Cask and Barrel", Edinburgh) Golden color, white head. Hoppy and somewhat spicy aroma. Hoppy, grassy flavor with hay and pepper. A bit dry.
Cask handpull at Cask & Barrel, Edinburgh. Gold, some hop, easy drinking light bitter, some tingle form rubbery hop on end.
Aroma is honey sweetness off the malt and grassy and trying to be peppery hops. Taste is similar again the hops are trying but not coming through.
On tap at the Auld Brig, Irvine. Lovely looking pint with a nice white head. Quite hoppy, green apples, floral. Very nice and easy to drink on a hot day.

On tap at the Malt Shovel. Appearance - amber with a decent head. Nose - apples and toffee. Taste - more toffee apple with a dry ginger biscuit finish. Palate - medium bodied with a crunchy texture and a dry finish. Overall - a solid citizen.
Poured clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of light citrus and moderate malt. Light to medium body, flavour of pine, light lemon and caramel, bitter finish.
Cask by handpump at Pot Still, Glasgow - pours pale clear golden with a white head, bit cold, sweet, fruity, smooth, pleasant, no prolonged aftertaste

Cask at The Bree Louise, London. Pours clear gold with a few bubbles for a head. Bready malt aroma with some ripe citrus hops. Medium sweet flavor with a nice fruit character. Some crunchy grains, also grapes, oranges and dull cherries. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation. Mild sweet finish, some fruit jam, toast. Very enjoyable stuff. (3.7) Gravity cask at The Duchess of Cambridge, London. Pours clear, rich gold with a tight, light cream head. Nose of light dough, yeast, citrus, flowers, bubblegum and straw. Light sweet flavor, fruity with some citrus and berries and light hay bitterness. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Light sweet and light bitter finish with mild hay, fruit and faint grain. A tad bland but a very basic, easy bitter. (3.1)

Cask@The Bree Louise, London. Golden colour, small off-white head. Aroma is nutty, mildly fruity, wooden caramelly and sweet malty. Flavour is honey, sweet malts, resin and some nice floral notes. Finishes in a pleasant wooden and floral toffeeish balance.

First tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in August 1997. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale amber in colour with a thick white head. Light aroma of meadowsweet and dusty hay. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a light digestive biscuit note with fruity citric flavours of gooseberry and kiwi. Dusty hop resins give an aromatic dry bitter aftertaste. Good malt and hop balance in the well rounded finish. A good session ale for hot summer days.
Cask @ The State. Golden colour, white head. Aroma is light malted and fruity. Flavour is malty, fruity and light sour finish.
Cask @ The State Bar. Toffee apple aroma, rich golden colour. Mixed fruit flavour. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Not bad.

Cask, handpull at the Malt and Hops?, Edinburgh, with Craig, Jan, Charlotte & Loz, 29.10.10 Pours amber with a big white fluffy head. The aroma isn’t up too much. Taste is low-med bitterness, bit too much confectionary going on here for me, too sweet lacking bite and identity. A6 A5 T6 P3 Ov12 3.2

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours out in a slightly hazy bronze colour with a low low white head. Aroma of hay, red apples, metal and cookies. Light-bodied. Apple-skins, grass and vanilla in the flavour. Medium-bitter long finish of grass and hay.

Draught (Live & Let Live, Cambridge) Orange, no head. Sweet malty aroma, hints at mild spices, perhaps hops. In the mouth it first gives apples, then fills out to a malty bitterness. After swallowing, count to 5, and then a wonderful wave of slightly doughy malt will hit you. The finish is also very bitter, later it becomes zesty orange. Everything you could ask for in a bitter. Very caramelly too.

Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Golden with a thin white head; fresh, slightly citrus aroma; some citrus and honey flavours and a rounded bitter finish. An extremely refreshing pint for a summer lunchtime.
A Sim rate (Cask at Reading Beer Festival): Amber copper colour. Smells like biscuits, vanilla and pudding. Tastes even more of vanilla and sponge. Spicy. Butterscotch.

Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Deep Golden. Full sweet malt light biscuits and bread. Mild leafy hops. Enough bitterness to keep it drinkable but the pale malt flavours dont really provide enough interest over a pint.
Keg at The Euston Tap East Lodge in 2017. Deep amber with an offwhite head. Burnt sugar, caramel and herbal hop aroma. Lightly toasted malt flavour. Good body and residual grassy hop bitterness.

Moor confidence Cask at southampton arms Bright amber color short bubbly white head with poor persistence, no lacing. Flavors pf flowers, ginger and roasted malts, toffee, caramel and a mineral note.  Soft to flat carbonation quite solid body and sugary, sweet with a distinct bitter balance. Finish is very smooth with a leftover of orange, ginger,  boiled vegetables anf a sublte smoky note. Very nice 8 3 8 4 17

Review based on the BJCP2015 guidelines (style 15A). Can 33 cl - Batch 38 (BBF 21/11/19). AROMA: medium-low citrusy hop aroma starting to show oxidation (low). background of slightly caramelly malt. APPEARANCE: red amber colour and very slightly hazy. medium-low ivory head with average retention. TASTE: similar to the aroma with initial medium-low hop flavor (pine-like and slight citrus), followed by a slight caramelly malt background. medium to medium-high bitterness with a dry and slightly bitter finish. PALATE: medium-light to light body with medium-low carbonation. OVERALL: a red ale with added hops starting to show oxidation and a bit more bitter than usual.

Wow ! Amazing discovery! Pours very cloudy brown. Aroma of a malty IPA: caramel and orange. Aroma of caramel, and nice dry bitter fusing of orange peel. Can't get enough ! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Craft Room Zagreb. Darker amber coloured, medium sized off-white head, caramel and light toffee in the nose. Moderate malty, toasted, light caramel and toffee with notes of herbal hops. Dry sweetish finish. Not bad but rather ordinary brew.
On tap at Opatovina beer fest. Pours amber with off white head. Malty, caramel, toasted, some fruity notes, dry. Medium sweetness with bitterish finish. Medium bodied.

Tap at Makarska Connexion@Opatovina. Misty red-brown body, beige creamy head. Sweetish-dry dark cherry and earthy notes in the aroma. Similar taste, mild aroma hops breaking through the earthy maltiness, mild cherry notes, ends a bit dry again. Nice beer, though not the most exciting style-wise!

Sweet caramel aroma, candy, toffee, touch of rye. Cloudy deep amber to light brown color with medium sized tan head. Taste follows aroma completely. Caramel, toffee, light toasty, sweet and bit roasted. Thin to medium body, average to high carbonation. //tap at Opatovina Connexion

Keg at The Canal house Nottingham. Pours red amber with frothy off white lacing. Aroma has caramelized malts and fruity hops below. Taste is medium sweet to bitter with a juicy tang. Palate is medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation and a soft fruit finish. I can imagine a session of this although today it's over chilled.

33cl can from Abeervinum, Rimini, Italy. Pours unattractive hazy brown with medium grain white foam, some residue. Aroma is a nice aromatic citrus, some caramel, malty. Body is average with moderate carbonation. Taste is quite bitter for a red ale, with moderate sweetness, maybe less. Finish is kind of short.

Cask@Reading Beer Festival 2012. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, mild yeastyness as welkl as some leathery notes. Flavour is perfumed soap, mild grains, some rubber and mild earthyness.

Cask at Hillary Step, Manchester. Gold with off-white head. Aroma of citrus, malt, something floral. There’s a lot going on in the taste of this beer... chocolate and coffee in the malt, a bit sweet, but also a strong dry hops kick with grapefruit, lemon, pineapple. Nice balance, a bit malty for my taste but one of the best bitters I’ve had.

Cask (handpump) @ The KIT (Kelham Island Tavern), 62 Russell Street, Sheffield, South Yorkshire, England S3 8RW. Clear medium to dark yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, fruity, dusty, light roasted, moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090419]

Cask, The Queens Arms in Corton Denham. Gold with a bronze tinge, very good looking, thin persistent white head. Aromas of pungent hops - spice, orange, peach and slight floral; malt in background. Zingy hops in the mouth, full malt flavour with biscuit, chocolate & toffee, loads of citrus and a long bitter, drying finish. Really well brewed and balanced.

Cask conditioned at Far from the Madding Crowd, Oxford. Gold copper with white head. My sort of beer, tangy, hoppy dry bitter with plenty of citric grapefruit flavours, Zesty and flavouful, I want more of this.

A mid copper brown coloured beer with a weak white head. A Light, malty nose, a bit biscuity and sweet. The taste is dry and bitter, biscuity malt followed by a tangy grapefruit and orange citrus fruit flavour that lasts through to the finish. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

Cask half-pint at NERAX on 5/3/07 Frothy white head is small, but provides messy lacing. Body is not completely bright and a very brassy-golden color. Sulphur, though very faint, is detectable in the nose (as it was in their other beer this year, the Welsh Pale Ale). Very fruity, ripe yellow fruit esters, with hard water-like minerals and a creamy, wheat-like nuttiness. Some hop bitterness is noted, but surprisingly very little aroma. Maybe these are the last of this hop for a good reason? Don’t know, but the stuff, even discounting the sulphur, seemed very underwhelming, as did the Welsh Pale this year, the Golden Valley and Fan Dance last year. Not any significant character, and a weak strength of aroma at that. Still a trace of sulphur in the flavor, with light saltiness and grainy malts. Some fruity, citrusy hops help bolster the overall flavor and some herbal tanginess is contributed from the hop as well, but the malts only show a pinch of sweet pale maltiness at best, and mostly range from nutty to grainy and are quite bland through and through. Other than the fruitiness and hop bitterness, I don’t find a single interesting character in this beer. Lots of hard mineral character as well. Medium-light to light-bodied, slight wateriness, but appropriate for style. No alcohol noted, no flaws but for the light sulphur. This hop taste like a mix of Northern Brewer, Tettnang and Amarillo. Interesting and very weird.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Copper/gold. Not much condition. Bit farty, bit minerally in mouth, bit of tangerine maybe. Some dryness on finish, slightly juicy in mouth.

Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Golden. A little pungent yeast and slightly herby hops. A little astringent bitterness. Quite nice on the whole but let down a bit by the yeasty nose and its a bit sticky ion the end.

Cask (gravity) @ The 17th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium orange colour with a small average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, fruity, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110430]

Direct from the brewery. Golden amber with a ring of translucent head; sweet and earthy aroma; the taste has some earthy malts and light honey; before a crisp, biscuity finish. A really nice straightforward bitter.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Copper, bit of a haze, lasting bubbly off white head. Farty yeast aroma, alright bitter. Enough hopo on end to be slightly bitter, but an undemanding bitter.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Golden copper. Light bitter. Mild yeast and a little bit of fruity dusty hops. Not too bad.

Bottle from Björn, thanks. This was one of the best beers Björn brought back from Wales in this beer sampling. The only thing negative was that it lacked a fine foam. The aroma was nice fruity. The taste had a fine malt taste with a perfect bitterness for a bitter. Highly enoyable and big drinkabillity.
Bottled. Hazy amber, minimal head. Spicy pear aroma. Dry and dense with light body and soft doughy malt. Long spicy bitterness. Tasty bottled bitter.
Cask-conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 28/8/07. Dark amber with a slight white head. Fruity malt aroma followed by a slightly sweet flavour and bitter finish. Ok.

Cask Handpump from the Outside Bar at the Star Inn, Huddersfield 31/03/2007 Very hoppy and floral aromas. Thick white head. Amber coloured smooth on the palate and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish. A little thin and watery.

A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Thanks Alex for doing the research mate! Amber coloured. Slight alcohol notes to an otherwise malty nose. Flavour still has the slight alcohol but the malt is replaced with hops. Nothing amazing, but a drinkable mellow ale.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Badged as Heart of Wales Heart of Wales. Fruity malts with pleasant earthy hop. Flavours aren’t especially forward or characterful but are mildly pleasant.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Arrrrgh! it’s that tea hint again. I just cant do it. A bit of a strange one, almost mild like in the mouth but... tea... just no.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Dark brown. Fruity toffeeish malt and toasty. Dry with hints of chocolate and mild bitterness in the finish. Quite good.

On gravity at the Tuckers Maltings Beer festival, Newton Abbot 23/04/10. Dark copper in colour with no head. Malty aroma with some plum fruit. Flavour had bready malts, dark fruit and a hint of roastiness, leading to a moderately bitter finish. Ok.

[Gravity cask at Chippenham Beer Festival 2009] I’ve been getting quite excited by stouts and porters of late, to the extent that I’ve been wondering about updating my favourite beer style. As a result, at the Chippenham beer festival it was the stouts and porters I hit first, which were unconvincing. Returning to milds, I was reminded of how great this style is - my doubts are over, milds reamin as my favourite style! This one is slightly smokey with a hint of coffee and a bit of toffee. Finishes with sweet malts and goes down a treat. Good stuff!
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. It’s a mild, fine, but not very exciting. Some choc/coffee.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Low socre but not for anuthing out of oder it was just too bland. Slightly sweet and burnt sugar. Muddy appearance. Watery palate. Dull.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Fesitval 07. Sweet and grainy with toffee. Pleasant and unexciting.
Sweet fruity aroma. Clear golden colour with ok head. Very hoppy with hints of malt and honey, nice finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Dull orangey golden body with a short lasting head. Light hops on the nose with similar in the taste. Not very impressive but what light beers are?
Bottle from Hopology, Nottingham. Aroma citrus, and herby fresh. taste light sweet, to mid bitter. nice fresh brew.

Cask at Chesterfield Rail Ale Jolly with RB crew; clear golden amber pour with zero head, aroma has some big tropical hop and caramel, taste has sweet caramel, sticky tinned fruits of the peach variety, some pine

[Waterloo Beer Festival, Liverpool, 2014] - Amber Ales Imperial IPA, 6.5%, bernsteinfarben trüb, etwas Schaum. Aroma nach Fichtennadeln, Zitrus und Kräutern. Nicht sehr schwer, etwas olig, nicht mehr wässrig. Im Antrunk neben reifen Orangen und Kräutern eben jene Fichtennadeln, die ein Bier zum American IPA machen. In der Mitte v.a fruchtig herb, wie Bitter Orange, ebenso in den Abgang hinein. Selbiger immer noch deutlich fruchtig, leicht herb, mittellang. Sehr gutes IPA.

Bottle consumed at home Monday 27th August 2012 brought along by dad ’cheers dad!’Hazy orange amber with off white head. Quite soft, some warmth from alcohol, not as bitter as expected but very decent IPA. Light & sweet citrus shine, good beer. A6 A3 T8 P4 Ov14 3.5

Cask @ Euston Tap, 190 Euston Road, London, Greater London, England NW1 2EF. Clear medium amber colour with a small, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, toasted, caramel, moderate hoppy, citrus, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110806]

Cask@Euston Tap, London. Amber colour, small slightly off-white head. Aroma is berries, some wood, fruity and floral notes along with some sweet maltyness. Flavour is crystal malts, some caramel and some fruity, floral, wooden and berryish notes.
Cask at the NWAF, 2012. Amber pour with a white head. Honey and caramel nose. Quite smooth. Pear, honey, peach and baked apple flavour. Dry-fruit finish. Quite liked this one.

On cask at the 2012 NWAF, Manchester. Pours a dark golden colour with a decent beige head. Aroma doesn’t suggest imperial ipa with alcohol, caramel and yeast. Very sweet flavour of candy sugar, caramel, biscuity malt and apple seed. Quite a dry finish but not hoppy enough to be an imperial ipa. Mild carbonation with a long sweet finish and a warming alcohol hum.
Cask @ Euston Tap, Euston NW1. Pours a clear pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter finish.
Dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of pear fruit, grassy hops and biscuit malt. Sweet fruity flavour with grassy hops and medium bitterness

Cask conditioned at The Crown & Trumpet, Broadway, Worcs. Amber with white head. Bright hoppy beer, dry fruity bitterness mixed with a hop leaf character. Cracking condition, I admit to having several across the weekend.
Cask gravity at Reading BF 2007. Copper. No condition. Buttery, dull English bitter. Some hop.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Hoppy session bitter with some malty sweetness to finish. Very sinkable.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Thin caramel and sweetish malts. Good level of hoppiness. Alright.

500ml bottle at home on 19 June 2011, best before December 2008. Silvery colour. Musky, spicy and rubbery aroma. Reasonably dry with some tannin. More spicy notes on the palate. Quite firm mouthfeel. Not showing too much sign of age. A pretty decent drop.

Bottle 500ml. Clear light yellow colour almost cristal white with a fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy pear, vanilla notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light light acidic with a average to long duration, pear, tart, dry, vinegar notes. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. [20110619]
Bottled. Yellowish golden colour, no head. Aroma is mild pear, some mild vinegar, earth and vanilla. Flavour is pear, vanilla, some wood and mild earthyness.

500ml bottle bought at Corks, Bristol as ’dry still perry’ at 6.4% ABV. Pale, slightly hazy, yellow in colour, with almost no carbonation. Tart, spicy aroma, with some fruit in the background. Complex flavour, with some pear fruit, tartness, wood and even a hint of vinegar, as mentioned below. Rather surprisingly, the finish was rather mellow with pears to the fore. Good stuff.
Blackfriers. Aroma has hint at pear drop, but mainly a good over ripe fruit vinigar. Taste is a similar bag of tricks, alcohol only 6.4%, however increadibly well hidden, super drinkable.
Edinburgh beer fest 07 ... very very pale yellow ... tiny cider nose ... sour sharp very little pear ... no real body
Bag in a box at Reading BF. Pale gold/silver. Acetone on aroma. Decent dry perry. Not overly exciting. Some soft fruit. Not harsh. Not overly dry, good acetone underlying it though.
A Mes rate: Barrel at Reading Beer Festival. Very watery appearance. Dryish nose with clear alcohol. Exactly like fruit juice in the mouth. Nothing much going on at all but it’s still pretty tasty.
Barrel @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Quite clear. Thin slightly sweet with mild acidity. A bit bland but pleasant enough.

Tasted at Southampton Beer Festival June ’10. Thin head, little fizz. Very dark ebony colour with a hint of red. Aroma quite smoky - slightly burnt toast.. Flavours of coffee, wood smoke and dark chocolate. A slight bitterness, easy to drink though

Cask (Southampton Beer Festival 2010) - Very dark brown, with some red tinges when held to the light. Fruity and slightly roasted aroma with hints of dried fruit and marzipan. Malty, fruity and slightly roasted taste with notes of caramel, chocolate and a hint of roasted malt in the finish.

Cask handpump @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium amber brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, thin coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (020508)

[i] [b] Cask, gravity at the Flowerpots brewpub, Cheriton, Hampshire 6th June 2008 [/i] [/b] Pours very dark brown fading to a mid brown towards the edges. Nose was quite nice and very traditional methinks, with some good solid roasty and woody notes. Tasted very traditional and whilst it initially impressed I felt that it started to lack little as I go down it but interestingly aside from the gentle roasted flavours there was a slightly sour edge and I think that this was intentional with also some nice gentle hoppy flavours coming through, not bad.
Cask gravity at Reading BF. Decent condtion. OK for a 3.2% mild. It was good, nice mild.

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Muddy brown colour. Chocolate malt nose let down by a little sulphur. Nice mellow and downable with most of the standard mild attributes. Run of the mill but certainly drinkable.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Brown. Sweetish malty caramel and a little toastiness almost buttery toffee. Mild hop. Unimpressive but drinkable mild

On tap at the brewpub. An odd hefe, for me at least, in that it smells not just better than average for style, but a bit better than it tastes. The feel may be the low point as this is thin to the point of watery, partly doe to a somewhat low carbonation level. Mild for style, with a rather bready aftertaste rather than just bananas and clove.

Comes out of the tap hazy hay-golden with a fairly thick eggshell head. Strong, wheaty aroma has firm citrus and yeasty undertones plus a hint of malt. Flavor trots wheat, citrus and malt notes across the palate, with malt and a bit of hops in the background. Texture is fairly firm, smooth yet lively. You don’t have to know much to appreciate a good Hefe.
Great, estery banana aroma. Cloudy tannish gold. Paper and spice flavor. Alcohol is not well-hidden. Medium-light body. Under-carbonated. Bittering starts to show through at the very end.
On tap at brewpub. A cloudy golden with a decent size head. Aroma is light banana and clove. Light sweet flavor, a bit bland.

Appearance: Cloudy, golden body with a small, white head. Smell: Wheaty aroma with all of the accompanying notes of banana and spices. Taste: Malted wheat with a sharp tanginess but only a light sweetness. Strong flavors of banana, clove, and coriander. Spicy Noble hops, lightly bitter. Finishes dry with a lingering taste of toasted bananas. Mouthfeel: Medium-low body. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: Oh, it’s a hefe alright!

Tap @ 5 North. Poured a hazy yellow color with a large white head. Clove and light banana with a hint of lemon make up the aroma. The flavor was malty with banana and lemony wheat notes. Mild clove on the finish with a light body.

Name: Sgt. Schultz’s Hefeweizen Date: 05/03/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: opaque light orange, huge dense white head, lots of lace Aroma: spicy clove aroma with a hint of sweet banana Body: light body Flavor: mostly dry, good spicy clove character, light banana, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Sgt. Schultz’s Hefeweizen Date: 05/31/2007 Mode: draft Vintage: batch 2 Score: 2.9 to 3.2 bigger body and more sweetness, the extra sweetness brings out more of the banana to balance the clove, even a bit more banana in the aroma creates the needed balance there, overall a very nice improvement over the original batch -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Sgt. Schultz’s Hefeweizen Date: 08/20/2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub very much like the second batch in 2007 with the big banana sweetness, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Sgt. Schultz’s Hefeweizen Date: 08/28/2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Score: 3.2 to 3.4 clove is getting a bit more assertive with the banana sweetness coming later, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

On tap at the brewpub in Alpharetta - cloudy, murky medium golden pour with a crisp, yet fluffy white head. Clean, fragrant estery aroma, cloves, bubblegu - there are in there. Flavor of bananas, but not contrived - nice and natural. Extremely thick mouthfeel for a Hefe. Overall, an excellent Hefe - the North branch seems to be on the same high level as their original.

I wish this had more head, but that could be a sympton of the sample pour. The full hefeweizen glass pour that I saw after making my rating certainly had plenty of head and it lasted. Cloudy yellow. Great banana aroma. Good wheat underneath. The only problem I had with the beer is the flavor is almost too sweet.
This is the Haziest Hefe I think I’ve ever seen. Hazy golden orange, Very unfiltered. Aroma of citrus, lemons/oranges, wheat, bananas. Malty finish. Medium Bodied. Good Stuff!

Taps barely translucent chocolate brown with a fair buff head. Aroma offers caramel, toasted malt, wheat and banana notes. Flavor ups the banana and wheat character, but retains the malt and downplays the caramel. Body is about average, while tingle has some good life. Ask for a prescription.

Tap at 5 seasons North. Pours a deep dark woody brown with a good beige head- fades a bit over time. Aroma is banana and clove-typical hefe yeast, with some spritzy and spicy phenolics - peppery and zesty with earth and a good doughy deep caramel and nutty malt character. Flavor is initially sweet with caramel malts, toast, and bread with more banana and clove and a doughy light chocolate nutty hint. Very smooth overall with a slight salty slick kick that I get from a few dunkels- nice. Pretty good for a dunkelweizen.

Appearance: Dark brown, near black body with some slight garnet-hued edges and a smallish, off-white head. Smell: Aroma smelling of chocolate bars and caramel-covered wheat with only a faint note of banana. Taste: Roasty wheat flavor with tastes of chocolate and weak coffee. Bits of dark caramel sweetness on-hand. As it warms a bit, a more apparent wheat tanginess develops. Very light banana fruitiness. A drying nuttiness emerges even as the chocolate persists. Vague spicy hop character, though almost no bitterness. Finishes dry with an earthy taste of wheat and chocolate. Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: Quite nice! More out-and-out chocolate flavor than I find in most dunkelweizens. It makes for a nice surprise, like finding a piece of chocolate on a hotel pillow. That was a piece of chocolate on the hotel pillow, right?

Name: Doctor Moran’s Dunkelweizen Date: July 05, 2007 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Vintage: last pint of batch one Aroma: picking up some pepper in the aroma Flavor: banana flavor and sweetness has faded leaving a lot of rich chocolate behind Name: Doctor Moran’s Dunkelweizen Date: May 03, 2007 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewpub Vintage: 2007 Appearance: opaque muddy brown, big creamy beige head, lots of drippy lace Aroma: toasted and dry chocolate malt aroma Body: creamy body Flavor: rich chocolate malt flavor, touch of sweet banana, a bit of astrengent bitterness shows halfway through the second pint, a bit too dry but still quite tasty Name: Doctor Moran’s Dunkelweizen Date: May 06, 2007 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Vintage: 2007 Appearance: same muddy brown, fine beige head Aroma: rich chocolate and sweet banana aroma Flavor: the chocolate flavor is a bit richer but still quite dry with only a bit of sweet banana in the finish, nice toasted malt coming through Name: Doctor Moran’s Dunkelweizen Date: August 28, 2008 Mode: cask Source: brewpub Vintage: 2008 Score: 3.2 to 3.6 Appearance: muddy brown, wispy tan head Aroma: sweet chocolate and banana aroma Body: creamy body Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, light banana sweetness Overall: more of the banana sweetness than last year brings out a richer chocolate and provides better balance overall Name: Doctor Moran’s Dunkelweizen Date: November 20, 2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Vintage:

Dark Brown and Hazy. Looks like a dirty, muddy coke. or a chilled espresso. Very unfiltered. Aroma of roasty malt.. and something?..(unpeeled ripe plaintain AKA Ripe Platanos Maduros) and not necessarily the coffee bean but the whole plant. Flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, finished w/ coffee. medium bodied. My new "5" fave! WORD
Pours a hazy opaque brown with a light brown head. Aroma is malty and yeasty. Flavor is of some roasted malts, with some yeasty banana notes.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Blonde / amber looks. Hoppy grapefruit nose. Very very citric in the mouth. Almost too much. So so.
Gravity Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Strong malt and leafy hop. Quite tasty but finishes slightly sweet for full enjoyment.
Barrel @ Reading Beer Festival 07. Very pale yellow. Good dryish pear with hints of acetic acid and acetone. Fairly standard perry with a slightly more aggressive finish than some.

Canned 500ml. -at gas station near Warszawa. Clear golden coloured, medium sized airy white head, light malty nose. Sweet malty, light caramel and light grainy with notes of alcohol in rather sweet finish. Surprisingly pleasant and drinkable Polish mocne that I’ve rated few minutes before 10 a.m.

Plechovka 500 ml. Aroma je příjemně sladové s jemným květinovým nádechem. Pěna je jasně bílá, jemná, středně vysoká a mizící. Barva samotného piva je zlatá. Chuť je sladová s alkoholovým obalem, nepříliš pestrá a fádní, finiš je velmi slabý, nehořký. V ústech pivo působí vodově a je poměrně těžké, má střední říz. Celkově se jedná o nepříliš chutný silný ležák, který není ani nijak vysoké pitelnosti.
Clear golden colour. Malt and hops in aroma. Sweet taste with some bitterness.
Clear yellow with decent white foam head, lacing. Aroma is good, taste is nice, somewhat stron beer indeed. Aftertaste is short. (Hoek van Holland 201308)
Slightly better polish-style lager. Nothing to complain about, nothing to remember.

Can 500 ml Aroma fresh , fairly light aroma. Hints of herbal hops, sweet balancing malt. Alcohol hidden. Appearance golden with medium frisky top. Shorter lifespan. 2+ Flavor and Palate : Soft, grainy- malty top with noticeable hop accents. Clean .pleasant brew for stronger pale lager. Alcohol only noticeable as it warms up.
Słodkie, mocno gazowane i słabe :(. Amatorom mocnego piwa radzę omijać.
Brewed again, with 6% alcohol content. Very sweet, medium bodied, slight bitterness. Just OK

Hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of cereal grains, wheat, some honey, citrus, and spices. Taste of much of the same, some grass, spices, and a somewhat dry finish.

On tap at Ortino’s Northside. Pours a lightly hazy golden with an average creamy/lacing off white head. Aroma of grainy malts, some citrus and Saison spices. Flavor was up front yeasty, spicy, crisp and dry. Some grainy cereal grains, hints of bitter hops and honey. various spices went well with the spicy chicken dish I had.
Golden Saison with flavor leaning more to pepper and spices than citrus. Hints of Belgian yeast. Manayunk Saison was decent, just not a full blown Saison.

Light & clear golden color with a smaller head. Aroma is light and somewhat musty with hints of raw grain and yeast. Taste is very peppery with some earthy and yeast undertones. Not bad, but I like my Saisons cloudy, complex, and in something other than a standard shaker/pint glass.
Draft at brewpub. Hazy medium gold pour with minimal off-white head. Aroma is spicy and hopcitric, with some funky yeasty and fruity notes in the aroma and flavor. Stays on the dry side throughout.
Brpwnish with a medium white head. Heavy, dark bread malty aroma. Thick, chewy malt & bread flavors create an interesting ESB. Not bad

Amberish pour with minimal off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, slight fruit, tannins, and hops. Tastes malty, with some mild mid-palate tannic and hop notes, and finishing slightly bitter fruity hints.
Pretty tasty porter, but I don’t get a lot of the smoked character. Lots of of chocolate, vanilla, and roastiness. Quite nice.

Bomber at a bottle share/cellar cleaning. Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and bourbon. Taste is roasted malt, bourbon, chocolate, and some faint smoke. Holding up OK.
Bottle at CGBD. Pours deep brown with a thin beige head. Medium whiskey sweetness, hints of vanilla, medium roasted malts, and faint smoke. Solid.

bottle 582 of 2398 .. . i brought this to a rare beer tasting, to cut through the sours and bourbon aged monsters .. . pours a deep tan .. mild foam .. . light mouth .. . light whiskey, sugar, and light smoke .. . easy to drink, but i think i like the original better .. . . jesus, are these someone else’s pants?
Nose of salty smoke oak roasted a little bourbon. Dark brown pour tan head. Flavors of salty smoke oak roasted malts leather light bourbon and salty smoke finish.

Tasted on 3/28/12 from a waxed and capped 650mL bomber bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors, I believe that this is the 2010 bottling, 587/2398. Pours an opaque, dark cola brown with a thin tan head that leaves an average collar of lace. The nose is smoked dark malt, with coffee, dark chocolate, a hint of molasses, and just a touch of maple and vanilla from the very subdued oak treatment. The flavor is fairly subtle, with the smoke really coming through nicely, with some cola, dark chocolate, and then the very subdued oak once again. The body is just lighter than medium with average carbonation and a long cola, dark chocolate, and smoked finish.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a medium sized beige head. The aroma was moderately smoky, roasted malt with moderate whisky barrel notes. The flavor has well blended notes of smoke, whiskey, roasted malts, barrel. Fairly nice flavor and only comes in at 6%.

Black pour from bottle. Minimal head. Body is light. Massive whiskey in the nose with added licorice and maple syrup. Mostly whiskey and wood. Flavor captures a more subtle version of the smell. More subdued in whiskey, but it is still very much in the finish. Very light and quite smokey. Little else comes through in this disappointing beer. Thin and watery.

Bottle poured into a snifter. Pours black with frothy tan head. Aroma of smoke and firewood and oddly, bacon. I don’t get any bourbon barrel at all. Taste is mildly sweet and bitter, a bit medicinal. Mouthfeel is pretty thin and watery, good carbonation. Disappointing that I didn’t get any of the bourbon or vanilla character that I would expect.

Received in trade from jtrockchalk, thanks for the opportunity. Pours a solid dark brown and faint ruby highlights when held to light. Thinnish off white head lingers for a short while and leaves minimal lacing. Smell is bourbon up front and strong. Some smoky peat a bit of chocolate some wood as well. Taste is a bourbony oaky affair with some roast bitterness at the finish. The mouthfeel is oily/watery. I think the underlying porter doesn’t have enough body to stand up to the thinning properties of the bourbon barrel. Carbonation is light. I actually enjoyed this one a lot, but would have loved it with a thicker body.

Draft at the brewpub. A hazy copper colored beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel, but also light notes of bourbon and alcohol. The flavor is very powerful with notes of bourbon, alcohol, and over ripe fruits, leadin to a dry woody finish.

From a tap at Oak’s Bottom and Concordia Alehouse in Portland--Poured a deep mahogany chestnut amber-orange. Tan small fluffy head. Nose of high alcohol heat and musty fruit cough syrup. Thick, resinous piny hops and sweet and cloying malts. Bubblegum and sticky fruit finish with a fleeting buttery texture. Oaky, woody and quite a strange blend of flavors, though most enjoyable.

On tap at Oak’s Bottom. Aroma of maraschino cherries, white toast & a bit of nail polsh. An IIPA without hop aroma?-- maybe under the chemical smell. silky o the tongue, almost hot pin-pricks into the tongue. Dark orange color w/ chino colored head, tin but peristent, hops express in the flavor, though still the solvent presence w/ hints of dired cherry, grapefuit & bubblegum. could be a good English strong if the chemical presence was gone or hidden.
No real aroma. A clear gold color. Somewhat crisp, no malt backbone, very wattery. Actually the flavor profile could say carbonated water with mild hop flavor. Very unimpressive.
This was pretty much the same beer as the Bartlite except it was less wattery. I could taste a little more malt or grain as well. More crisp than the Bartlite. Gold in color. Light in body. Meh.

A nice mild raspberry aroma that smells pretty natural surprisingly. This beer is a clear yellow. The flavor is a very smooth and sweet. Almost tea like. A buddy of mine was asking for more beer flavor and compared it to Nestea or a fruit water. It wasnt bad, just not very beerlike.

murky apricot color with no head. very faint wheat nose. bitingly fizzy and almost flavorless save a little wheat note in the finish and the lager yeast phenols. this place gives you 6 tasters for $6, not bad, even if its crappy brewpub beers.

On draft at brewery, 02/11/08. Yellow with almost no cloudiness (despite the claims of not being filtered). Thin skin of white foam for a head. Aroma is very sweet, like confectioner’s sugar. Some sweet fruits also present. Still carbonated after quite some time. Wheat flavor present with only the mildest hint of banana. Some vague sweetness. No hop character I could discern. Due to mixup with taster, I thought this was the blonde lager at first: not a good mark on this beer’s flavor profile.
On tap at RAXX. Clear yellow with no head. Banana aroma. Orange and clove taste with a disappointing palate and finish.
