A sweet wheat aroma with a slight fruitiness. Faint, faint banana. It is a nice bright yellowish orange color. Probably their best looking beer. Flavor is a slight clovey sweetness. Pretty carbonated. I could see this being good on a hot day. One of their better beers, but that does not say too much.

A little hops in the aroma. Both some citrus and some earth. The beer is a dark amber/red color. The flavor is somewhat watery, but it is smooth and hoppy. Although somewhere in there is an unclean earthy grainyness. No real sweetness. It was pretty smooth despite the shortcomings. Crisp and hoppy on the palate, but not too full bodied or resiny. There really is something going on here with the water or the lines because alot of the beers have this wierd ass uncleanliness to them

hazed orange, no settling head diacytl and hops in both nose and flavor and strong tongue scraping astringency in the finish. hops are somewhat floral but theres butterscotch and nut skins getting stuck to the roof of my mouth. palate fail.
On draft at brewery, 02/11/08. Clear yellow, lots of carbonation. No detectable aroma. Subtle sweet maltiness up front, a little grapefruit hoppiness at the end. Unexceptional.
On tap at RAXX. Clear golden amber with creamy white head. Malty aroma witha a sweet taste a good bitter bite with citrus notes and a bready finish.

A mild hoppy and grainy aroma. Somewhat bready as well. This beer had the best head retention of them all and was a nice orange golden color. A nice piney flavor. It is pleasantly crisp and hoppy. Not alot of malt backbone, definitley more so in the nose. A dry mouthfeel as well. A nice beer.

Bottle (leftover judging beer from 2006 GABF labeled Brazen Hussy Oatmeal Stout) poured a translucent brownish black with a minimal tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee, bakers cocoa and a hint of vanilla. Palate was light bodied, crisp and slightly tart. Flavors of coffee, roasted malt and a hint of cocoa with a lingering bitter finish.
On tap at RAXX. Reddish brown with a creamy tan head. Sweet aroma with roasty, grainy, and chocolate notes. Medium bodied palate. Sweet roasty taste, milk chocolate, and a cereal taste to the finish.

This was on a nirtro tap. It had a really pleasant sweet malt aroma. A little bit of hoppy chocolate. Poured black with a tan velvetty head. The flavor is mocha and coffee with a nice dash of crisp citrus hops, but not overpowering or unbalanced at all. Mostly on the backend do the hops come through. The mouthfeel is dry and roasty. Somewhat full bodied. One of their best beers by far.

The aroma is mildew and some malt. WOW, probably one of the worst smelling beers I have ever encountered. Black in color with no real head. Flavor is sweatsocks, malt, and mildew. Not good at all. Obviously not the flavor the brewmaster was going for. It was light bodied for how dark it was if that can be a plus.
On tap at RAXX. Clear orange amber with a creamy white head. Aroma of caramel, grapefruit, and yeast. Thick sticky palate. Citrus and pine taste, some caramel sweetness, and a slightly bitter finish.

Some citrus aroma, but not overwhelming. Some sweet malt as well. Beer is a muddy orange red color, and looks as if it is unfiltered. Initial flavor is pine and citrus hops balanced by some sweet caramel malts. It is a pretty balanced DIPA, but pretty underwhelming actually. Not very impressive, but not bad. There is also alot of alcohol in the flavor which is pretty strange being that it is so balanced by hops and malt. Full bodied with some dry resiny hops and tons of alcohol.
Tap. Toasty, raisiny, caramelly, earthy. Gritty earth. Quite German. Didn’t write much down about it, but it’s my favorite JH brew to date.

On tap at JH. Pours a deep red with a very small white head. Aroma is pretty sweet, with rhubarb and light fruits, and some light wheaty lager malt. Flavor of sweet and light malts, some buttery popcorn. A little bland but not bad overall.

Tap at the Lake Grove location: Pours a deep brown/amber color with good clarity, topped by a creamy tan head. Aroma is sweetly malty and appetizing; toasty caramel. Has a nice creamy texture with velvety carbonation. Roasty malt flavors give off chocolate-like hints, and almost a maple-ish sweetness. There are also hazelnut flavors in the background with a balancing toasty dry finish. A solid Dunkel.

Clear dark amber with pretty much zero head - somewhat light, fruity aroma (some touches of cherry, mostly) - the flavor up front is dominated by caramel sweetness, and some hints of roasted nuts - however, this gets washed away quickly by a clean, almost watery, far too sudden finish - it’s like the beer doesn’t know if it wants to be full and flavorful, or light and quaffable - decent flavor, but a little uninteresting.

The last batch of this beer (the first by the current brewer [Dave?]) was really good. Unfortunately, I am rating the newest batch which is not as good. Tap at brewpub, dark amber color, clear beer but dark enough that you cannot see through it. Some light streaks at the bottom of the pint glass. Aroma is light lagered fruitiness as well as light prototypical German maltiness (very clean). Taste is again a very clean malt, well lagered. Light bitterness at the end of it all. A very good replication of a style that has a lot more potential. A decent thirst quencher but not worth a return visit, unless I get a caramel bomb like the first batch.
On tap at the Bethlehem location. Poured a medium yellow color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of citrus, grains, and some spices. Tastes follow suit.
Straw yellow color with a white head. Grainy citrus-lemon flavor with earthy aroma. At 7.8% ABV, easily the most powerful pilsner I’ve ever had. Nice beer and not my style.

on tap-pours a white head and yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain, citrus-lemon, faint spicy/clove. Taste is sweet grain/malt, faint secondary spicy, clove earthy-hops, faint citrus-lemon. Crisp. OK/mild carbonation.
Draft. Yellow with creamy head. Nice dry flavors. Some sweetness. Very smooth and dry with lots of lacing.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a mostly clear deep reddish amber with a very thin off-white head that quickly disappeared and left very little lace. Mild aroma of malt and not much else. The flavor is straightforward malt with just a bit of sweetness. Mild bitterness at the finish. Very easy to drink. No problems.

Deep copper coloured beer. Lovely sweet malty nose. Very clean and well-integrated. Soft fresh bready/crackery nose and a nice fresh light noble/spicy hoppiness. Crisp and crackery and very quaffable. A pretty solid brew.

Tap at JH. Aroma of some light berries with sweet, crackery malt. Flavor mostly crackery malt with some other grain complexity. A very light sprinkling of leafy hops, VERY light. Nothing outstanding, but also pleasing in its simplicity.

On tap at JH. Pours a clear amber with a small white head. Aroma of sweet malt. Flavor is sweet initially with some wheat and crackery malt notes and a fruity finish. The malt backbone is very nice. Super fresh and crisp. A surprising beer, especially considering that oktoberfest/marzen is not one of my favorite styles. 7/4/7/4/14 (3.6/5)

Tap at the Lake Grove location: Deep orange pour with a fading head. The aroma shows some grainy, cereal like hints with a caramel touch. Grainy malt flavors are evident, with a light toffeeish hint. Also has a oat-like cereal character and a earthy touch. A straight forward, simple example.

Tap at brewpub, amber colored, good clarity - can see through it pretty well. Color is slight orange/red in direct light. Aroma is a bit unexpectedly hoppy for the style, which is an effervescent earthiness. This is all mixed up with a clean maltiness. Taste is similar with a hoppy aftertaste. Its not that the hops are strong they just stand out in this beer. A decent thirst quencher.

Sampler perched at the bar of the brewpub, 31/08/12, scribbling notes like a lunatic in retractable pencil on a scrap of paper. Had 15mins to sink (and describe) 6 beers; "Good shrubby honey hop showing through peppery booze quite balanced veering into palinka as it warms slim haloed bronze good shrub on afters negligible cherry and shrub on the nose blue cheese?" You get the picture.
Tap - not much head, light copper color, sweet malt aroma and flavor, very mild hop taste - light and refreshing, would be good on a hot day
Draft. Rich amber beer with a low cream colored head. Malt and mineral aroma with honey. Honey and malt flavor with light berries. Medium bodied. malt and light berries linger with honey.

Draught at the brewery. Dark gold to amber, clear, with a small white head. Sweet aroma of caramel and honey on toast and a faint noble hop touch. Sweet flavor with some darker bready melanoidins but mostly pale malt flavors. Some spicy hops and a light to medium bitterness but finishes sweet. A bit sticky and sugary on the palate. Getting there, but this would hae been much nicer with a lower finishing gravity to dry it out.

On tap. Clear warm amber golden with no head. Sweet aroma of roasted malt. Quite full-bodied with a solid base of caramellish malt. Discreetly bitter. Solid and authentic for the style if somewhat unspectacular. 250709

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with a fully gone head. Aroma is mild fruity and malty aroma. Vague butterish flavoured. Light roasted and malty with a light hoppy bitterness and subdued roasted note. Bitter and dry finish.

Name: Meaghan’s Maibock Date: July 12, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, scant head, streaks of lace Aroma: light sweet caramel malt aroma, touch of candy sweetness Body: big body Flavor: sweet caramel flavor, nice balancing earthyness, touch of malt candy, light bitterness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

Draft at the brewpub. An amber beer with next to no head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, bread, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of malt and caramel as well as medium notes of bread and alcohol, the lattter growing in strength towards the finish.
Very very nice. crisp clean and flavorful. Light hops and body. Satisfying.
Pours dark golden with a thin head. Mild malty aromas. Flavor starts out sweet, but the beer finishes dry and crisp. Easy drinking beer.

This one had sat in my pile of beers to taste for far too long, I thought it was going to be terrible so I’d put off opening it for a good 6 months. Shit knows why I felt the need to open it tonight but here goes... Deep clear ruby brown with a small tan head. Strong chocolate aroma, a bit of sweetness, tobacco, smoke and soft yeasty fruits... not particularly complex but pretty bloody solid. Medium body, light roasty bitterness and slight sweetness. Strong mocha flavour, smoke and something like a box of sultanas thats been kicking around in your school lunchbox on the 45degree day. Small roasty finish. This stuff is pretty good, much better (and different) to Tooheys Old.

Bottle (375ml). Poured a opaque with ruby highlights and a thick, creamy, tanned head which was fully lasting. Aroma was of some burnt malts, coffee, light notes of dark chocolate and some nuts in the back. Taste very similar to aroma but a bit thinner with burnt malts, light coffee and nuts towards the end. Medium bodied with a watery texture, soft carbonation and an average dry finish.
A bad version of Tooheys Old. Bland and tasteless with a flat head. Some metallic notes to round out the dullness.

Dark red tinged brown with a hard earned beige froth. Some bready malts with a little bit of roasted malt and a lashing of nuts. Too sweet, and with a milky taste, it doesn’t really sit too well. As has been pointed out, it’s more like a cola, albeit a bit flat. All in all it’s hard to see why anyone would drink this more than once, unless for some silly reason you bought two bottles of the stuff...

Picked up a 6 pack of 37ml bottles at my local Dan Murphy’s. My old man and his mates have been rambling on about how good this beer was in its prime for ages. Reminds me alot, if not too much, of Tooheys old. Cola and some oaky roasted malts on the nose. Pours a deep bronze body with some dense off-white lace. Thin body to it, some metallic bitterness to it. Some roasted malts with some cola sweetness to it finishing with a woody dryness. Nothing special, definately not worth the hype I heard.

Something old, something new, something borrowed, something bleugh... This Old is new and very similar to Tooheys Old, the brewer of which might be flattered at how much this borrows from the original. It’s a while since my last Tooheys Old but my impressions of this are fairly similar to notes about the former. It’s a thin-looking teak-coloured brew with a spare scattering of suds. The aroma has a light roastiness, strong Cola notes, cardboardy malts and a whiff of tramp pants. It’s softly carbonated, verging on flat. Thin fare indeed. Too sweet and Cola-like, with just the faintest roast maltiness. Nasty sour-milk aftertaste. Dry finish. Won’t be trying this again. (375ml bottle from Randwick Village Cellars)

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2010, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100804]

Cask handpump at The Green Dragon, Cambridge. Very pale; hardly any colour in it at all. Big dense head. Slightly vegetable scent with some lime. Lovely smooth mouthfeel with some carbonation. Moderately bitter, some dryness. Light lemon citrus notes in the mouth, and some grapes int here too. Maybe also a hint of yeast. Little aftertaste. A nice light summer beer.

1. Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 04/08/2010 Hoppy aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with citrus and lime flavours. A hint of dryness and bitterness in a malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Queens Arms JDW, Winsford 08/09/2010 Hoppy aroma. Clear golden coloured hoppy and a little citrus flavoured with a hint of bitterness in a dry finish.

Cask@GBBF2010. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, spices and some mild nectary and grassy notes. Flavour is quite similar with also some mild herbs and the citrus being more evident.
Cask. Fruity malt nose, yellow, with a small white head. Flavour is light malt, fruit is subdued. Light bodied, balanced, refreshing. Good.
Cask @ Three Judges, Glasgow. Clear yellow color, short head. Hoppy, bitter, full bodied, malty. Bitter palate, bit creamy even.
On cask @ Three Judges, Glasgow. Golden colored brew. Fruity aroma. Flavor is weak, malty, mild bitter, citrus.
On cask @ Three Judges, Glasgow. The aroma has some grass. Golden coloured beer with a thin, white head. The taste is clean, floral with a dry finish.

9th April 2009 Vert light ale with just a hint of hop. Refreshing but somewhat insubstantial. Slight sweet finish. 10th September 2010 Hazy pale gold beer. Little white head. Light palate. Low carbonation. Light ornage and lemon citrus. Some dry even malt, dry finish. Inoffensive drinkable beer.

Cask (handpump) at Penderels Oak (JDW), April 2008. Pale gold colour with a thin white head. Good condition. Not a lot of aroma - just a touch of malt, incongruously a little smoky. Light citrus flavour. Dry aftertaste, light mouthfeel. Clean and crisp. Easy drinking but could use more depth in the flavour department.

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #31. Draught pint at the brewpub, late July 2008. Pale gold with a lasting creamy strong snowy head and good lacing...light, pleasing grassy-grainy aroma, not hugely distinctive but fresh and betraying only a little corn presence which is welcome in it’s rather light sweetness... a bit of toasted malt, light spicy hops towards the finish, moderately sweet, clean...very full, moderate and not over-strong carbonation...this is as good as pale lager probably gets, at least in my experience so far, and though my habit is generally to mock the numbers game and pick crappy beers for my "anniversaries" here, I’m pleased to note in this case that this, my 200th pale lager, is also my highest rated to date. A new standard has been set.

On tap at the brewpub, pours a really pale hazy yellow with a thin head, the aroma is of grass and corn, a little bit of skunk thrown in there as well, the flavor is really light and forgettable, some corn and metallic notes, really only worth the sample, wouldn’t drink a pint of this with the other options available.

Draft at carlyle. Pours a clear light gold with a finger of white head. Aroma of corn and grains with a slight herbal hop nose. Taste is light bitter. Herbal and earthy with mostly grains. Light bodied with a thin texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, not bad. Refreshing summer brew.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Pours a clear pale golden with a well-lacing froth of white head. Faint aroma of grainy pale malt and light corn. Body starts with a light malty sweetness and a mild noble bittering hop presence before a thinner, slightly earthy finish. One of the better Mexican-styled lagers I’ve had.

Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark yellow, fine white head, lots of lace, sweet corn aroma, sweet grain flavor with a pleasant grittyness, light balancing bitterness, touch of corn, Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+/4
A very nice light lager with yeast from Mexico City. Very refreshing. Brewed annually for Cinco de Mayo.

Sampler. The beer list I brought home doesn’t list this, but as you might guess, it’s a Mexican-style lager. My co-drinker says it reminds him of draft Tecate. I detect a slight Corona style skunk, perhaps intentional. But a good light pils taste. Kind of low on hops, but a lawnmower type with a dry finish. This is what they serve when asked if they have a "light."

On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Transparent dark golden bronze pour has a thin, well-lacing off-white head. Light sweet caramel malty nose has a good earthy smoky presence. Body starts with a nice mouthfeel and sweet toasted caramel malt and a hint of butterscotch. A good and authentic rauchbier that finishes crisp and smoky.

Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear amber, fine white head, drippy lace, smoked wood aroma with a light munich malt backbone, creamy body, smoked flavor with well balanced with the slightly sweet munich malts, the malt is big enough to stand up to the smoke and the smoke is tempered enough to not overwhelm Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4
Nice smoky malt flavor on tap at Carlyle. A pleasant aroma over a brown ale that grows on you the more you drink it.

On tap at the brewery. Hazy orange-brown body, thick off-white head. Light smoky, bready, toasty aroma. The smoke notes were relatively subtle in the body, but this beer doesn’t have a compelling malt backbone. So, the smoke is not overpowering, but still dominates the palate. Pretty simple and one-dimensional; not one of my favorites during my visit.

Sampler. Wow, with this being tasted right after their Scottish Ale, it’s like Smokin’ in the Boys’ Room here. Yes, it’s plenty smoky here, but that’s mostly confined to the malt, leaving the rest of the beer profile to come through. Kind of a brown ale base, I think. Burnt umber color. Mild and restrained for a style that can get kind of bacony.

Bottled, 500ml, old unlabelled bottle given to me in Devon, cheers. Chestnut brown with cream head. There are sweet chocolate malts to this, perhaps a tad flat but that's unsurprising. Smooth, nutty flavours, hints of boiled vegetable. It's fine given the provenance.

4 pints for 6 pound, bargain. Drank cool but not cold. Muddy brown with a minimal layer of beige suds atop that is fleeting, not much life evident. Aroma of peat, smoke, dusty cocoa, twiggy bark and drift wood, a little sodden earth and fell stone fruit. Thin in body but packed for flavour. A little tickle of carbonation gives it height. Lots of chocolate and smoke on the palate amongst its funky ‘humber’-like nuances. Grape-skin back end, noticeably astringent adds rather than detracts. Swallow is dusty, lots of peat, chocolate and scorched wood. Long linger, a supple sweetness to it otherwise it is dry. This is not bad stuff. Labelled as a Brown Ale, but fitting as a Mild. Love to taste it on cask as I think it would shine a little more than bottle conditioned. (50cL, BBE 01/12, Bridge House Cellars, Exmouth, Devon)

Bottle from Whistle Wines, Exeter. Deep brown in colour with hints of red and a tight, creamy off-white head. Rich, malty aroma of caramel with a hint of fruit. Flavours of chocolate and caramel with an ashy, dry finish. Very good.
Bottle labeled as a brown ale rather than a mild. Not a lot of body and slightly nutty.Well intentioned but it doesn’t come off.Very disappointing.
bottle, labelled Humber Down Brown Ale 3.6%. Hazy brown colour, bubbly head. Medium-bodied, flavours of caramel and toffee, pleasantly hoppy. Lively carbonation.

Bottled. A dark brown coloured beer with a nice tight off-white coloured head. The aroma is roasty and smoky and filled with chocolate malt. More choc in the taste. Very full flavoured for its ABV. Malty and bitter also. A very nice recommended beer.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear light to medium amber brown color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, chocolate. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (030508)

Bottle at home ... dark brown with a light off white head ... Earthy as fin says, some roast sweet malts in nose ... nice mouth feel ... lot of chocolate and sweet malts ... little smokey ... lots of toffee ... I dont recognise most other people desciption of this beer so ive got to assume its an incosistant beer ... however the one i have is lovely , well balanced and packed full of flavour ...

[i] [b] Bottle from the Dodgi’ Deli’ Cowley Road, Oxford [/i] [/b] Pours dark brown with foamy off white head. Aroma bit earthy but also some chocolate (noticed by Loz), taste is slightly sour and if truth be told its ok but very much in the homebrew league, bit caramelly, bit malty bit unimpressive really.
Bottle. Smokey charcoal and chocolate aroma. Dark brown with small head. Light smokey chocolate flavor initially - watery finish. Very light flavor and body.
A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Dark golden colour. Slight ginger and malt in the nose. Flavour is a little acrid. Slightly unpleasant malt and a harsh hoppy finish. Sorry guys...

Bottle from Cellar Door, Four Oaks. Pours medium brown, between 1 and 2 finger off white head. Aroma of caramel, malts, toffee, spices. Taste of initial malts, toffee, caramel, then some spice, light smokiness, dark fruits, subtle hops. Well balanced brew, nice bitter finish, highly recommended!

500ml bottle from Mitchells Wines, Meadowhead - Clear reddy auburn body, pillowy white head, fades a bit quick though. Nose is toffee, caramel, butterscotch, a little spicy. Taste is helped by a nice warming bitterness, the caramel, toffee and spice there again. Medium finish, again warming on the way through. I liked this one quite a bit.

50cl bottle from Brown & Green, Trentham. As soon as I started to pour this I knew I was going to enjoy it - the colour is a rich copper with a golden tint and a thin off-white head - the perfect look for an ESB; the aroma is rather subdued, with some hedgerow fruit; in the mouth, it’s full of malty caramel, with a fresh English hop bitterness; and a satisying, full and rich caramel finish. I approve wholeheartedly of his Lordship’s choice.

Aroma luppolato con una reminescenza di liquirizia. Color rossiccio nel bicchiere. Corpo liscio e beverino. Un qualcosa di dolce che mi ricorda qualcosa ma non so definire (proverò a definirlo la prossima volta che la berrò). Finale mediamente luppolato.

Third beer in a British Beer Tasting Evening at my place, 8th Jan 2011. The second beer I’ve had from the Shugborough Hall Brewhouse which is used by Titanic on a semi-regular basis to brew different beers than their normal stuff. The beer was poured into an ’Abbot Ale’ glass pint tankard. The beer is a light ruby red/brown colour. A good looking off-white head sat on top and produced some heavy lacing. The smell was all malts, caramel and treacle molasses along with a freshly baked biscuits aroma. The taste was semi-sweet, those biscuity thoughts from the smell are there in the mouth too. A hop bitterness arrives and then retreats as the malts dominate again, so mostly malts in the taste. Full bodied, but just lacks some rich or creaminess to rise it above the rest. I enjoyed it.
Bottle from Brown and Greens, Trentham. Pours amber with quick fading head. Toffee, hops, slightly over carbonated, but a cracking bottled ale.
ambrata buona schiuma persitenza diacetile presenza corpo medio note caramellato mallto lievemente tostato discreto luppolo un po pepato

Bottle conditioned from Favourite Beers, Cheltenham. Brown with slight head. Malty and quite nutty body, there is a malty sweetness, then just a hint of leafy hop. Doesn’t quite hit any heights but ok.
4th January 2009 BBE 27.2.08 bottle that has been stored cool and dark. Clear red - brown beer. Malty with an undercurrant of red fruit. Dry finish but not bitter. Low carbonation. Alright.

Cask (handpump) @ The KIT (Kelham Island Tavern), 62 Russell Street, Sheffield, South Yorkshire, England S3 8RW. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, smoke - peat, overriped fruity, light to moderate hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light heavy citrus shell bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090417]

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Hazy gold amber appearance. Ginger spice aroma with some orange cake. Flavour is totally off the wall. One of the strangest beers I have tasted. Germoline, plenty of spicy notes from the coriander and obvious ginger. Something distinctly medicine like also. A very very odd beer with the character of a witbier mixed with a very spicy ale. It’s bonkers. Please let there be someone else on here who has tried this...

Cask ale, half at Bank Statement (JDW). Good looking in the glass with a covering beige head blanketing the glass. Clear mahogany coloured body. Malt-driven smell of earthy malts, hints of dried fruits, Mixed taste of stewed fruits and mid-sweet malts with a chocolate touch. Ends malty and semi sweet. Pretty alright. (Swansea 01.10.2018).
Fra cask på Bank Statement JDW, Swansea. Dyp rødbrun. Lavt skum. Tynn teppelacing. Aroma av nøtter & sherry. Smaken kirsebær. Myk munnfølelse. Tørr portvinsaktig avslutning.
Fresh aroma. Medium brown colour. Fairly reddish. Hardly any head. Fruity, hoppy taste with a pleasant aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very malty nose, not always pleasant, but much less so in its taste. Medium bodied.

(cask) pours a clear copper colour with a ruby tinge and a frothy beige head. aroma of dried fruit and brown sugar, quite sweet and slightly sour, with hints of biscuits and ginger. flavour is dominated by dried fruit, very sweet, with notes of tobacco and ligonberries and a light herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 27/04/2007 Amber coloured and slightly rich on the palate with some alcohol present. A little bitterness in a crisp and floral full malt finish.

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Sorry guys but this was plain awful. One of my least favourite beers of the whole festival. Eggy and sulphuric aroma. Nice amber colour. Tea and unbrewed malt in the flavour. Slightly strange palate. I hate slating something on a first rate but it just didnt work for me.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Puszka 240ml, zakupiona w Magasin Général Kantaoui. Naprawdę okrutnie alkoholowy lubieżnik.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: 240ml can (thanks Juks). Clear golden color. Small size, white head, stays. Poop, glue, sweet, starch in aroma. Sweet, corny, dusty, poop in taste. Nope.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: 240ml can, 7%. Pours clear golden colour, small white fizzy head. Aroma is corny, cardboard, grainy. Taste is malty, grainy, sweet, corny. Light body, fizzy carbonation. Poor brew.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Can pours a clear gold color with a soft white head. Aroma is sweet malt and perfume. Taste is a sweet malt that ends very dry and almost bitter. Palate is almost smooth. Not terrible but nothing to write home about either. Alcohol content is way too high for a Pils.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Puszka wypite w Tunezji w 2011r. Kolor jasnosłomkowy, piana szybko znika. Aromat słodowy, wytrawny. Smak słodki, lekko pikantny. Goryczka słaba.Ogólnie wytrawne.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: a bit of peppry hop with an ivy finish. some sweetness and oil can as well also a bit of fishbowl in there. light body and a slight harshness to the carbonation. a bit of sugar as well as a pharmaceutical tang to it.

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: smells like grandma... it reminds me of the super bock ( portugal) but than less intense ( thank god) looks yellow, no real foam. in fact, wait 5 seconds and it looks like a lager that stood for an hour or so. chugget it, though i’m not a fan of chugging things, i just figured out, that way the torture would have been less long. no real taste in the mouth ( yay it worked ? ) but a pure chemical, filthy, bitter aftertaste witch makes you think, has this beer been drank before and than canned again ??? the filthy tastes stays too long, too...

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Vreemde Red Bull / Energiedrank stijl blik - 240 ml. van de enige (?) Tunesische brouwerij - mogelijk om dronkenschap onmogelijk te maken? - jij kan wel grote flessen wijn kopen maar niemand drink wijn om dronken te worden :) - bedankt aan mijn moeder voor het blik - helder, licht maar niet te licht gouden, witte chemische kraag - walgelijke mais geur, chemische, zoete rottende bladeren, chemische honing - smaakt naar graan, mais extract, zoetstof, chemische bitterheid die gewoon blijft gaan, extracten, synthetische honing,... eigenlijk best wel erg, ik wou dat dit skunked was dat is op zijn minst minder erg - kleverige, walgelijke synthetische mondgevoel, niet bepaald goed en dit is het beste dat Tunesische bier?

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Herb-malziger Antrunk, dabei scheint mir, als läge eine leichte Honignote im Hintergrund. Der Mitteloteil ist würziger, nicht lasch oder wässrig. Dabei wird das Bier süßer, die Würzigkeit bleibt auf selbem Level, im Hintergrund ist hier eine malzige Herbe, die nach und nach mehr in den Vordergrund rückt. Erfrischend, etwas malzig. Das Bier geht in Ordnung und ist Celtia aus der Flasche vorzuzziehen. Test vom 21.7.2007, Gebinde: Dose Noten: 8,9,9,9,5,9

column4: Société Frigorifique et Brasserie de Tunis (SFBT)
column5: Can 240ml. @ home. [ Trade by HenrikSoegaard ]. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, toasted, vegetables, vitamin pill - fruity. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average duration, vitamin pill, fruity sweet malt. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20110204]

Bottle @ home w friends/the chef. Appearance: pours clear red-brown with low to ok beige soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: barley, caramel, light smoke and fruity notes. palette: medium sweet malty aroma, average carbonation, medium body, medium to distinct sweetness, somewhat balanced by a medium bitterness, average duration and an oily texture. Overall: decent barley wine, but nothing special

Small pale brown head. Fruity malty syrupy aroma, quite faint, with roasty alcoholic notes. Sweet roasty malty syrupy taste with vanilla and chocolate notes. Full-bodied. Slightly sharp mouthfeel. Dryish alcoholic vanilla aftertaste with roasty wild berry notes. Interesting and complex, as well as surprisingly subtle. (0.5l bottle, from Salling, Aalborg.)

courtesy of Antonio Rey - hazy dark brown beer with a poor head retention; aroma of caramel, marzipan and plums; hints of soja sauce; full-bodied, very umami and sweet, gently sticky, a long caramelish aftertaste with notes of apples, plums and more soja sauce - not fully convincing

Appearance: Cloudy brown color with a white layer on top. Some lace. Aroma: Bready, malty and fruity. Palate: Medium + body. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Average to soft carbonation. Oily texture Taste: Bready, mild grassy, fruity and malty. Well masked alcohol. Overall impression: Not my cup of barley wine. Personal stats: Bottle from Kolding Vinhandel in Kolding, Denmark.
Brun öl med beige skum. Doft som påminner om lagrad rom. En hel del alkohol men framförallt russin och torkad frukt, malt, trä och läder. Trä, läder, russin, viss kryddighet och alkoholsötma.
Bottle. Dark brown with a small head. Very sweet with malt, dried fruit, some wood, butter, toffee and some notes of alcohol. Drinkable but nothing special.
@basunen: ganska söt doft. Inte någon större smak. Gabska lätt smörton. Annars igen ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mørkebrun farve. Sjov nøddeagtig smag. Speciel eftersmag lidt hengemt kælder. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
191112: Unclear brown with an ok brown foam. Vinous aroma. Sweet malty flavor of prunes and alcohol.
nice light port aroma,dark orange, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, lively, light bitter, long finish,
Godt nok en mild og svag udgave af en amerikansk pale ale. Minder mest om en pilsner med humlesmag tilført.

En typisk øl efter amerikansk forbillede. En meget humlet øl, så man er tør langt nede i halsen. Cascadehumle når det er bedst. Der er en let sødme og citrusagtigt i den også. Den blev faktisk lidt ofr meget i de sidste par slurke. God øl!

Tap @ the source. Pour amber, with a small off white head. Aroma of pine, bitter grass, caramel, citrus. The taste is slightly harsh bitter, with faint sweet notes. Medium bodied, with a flat but tickling carb. This gets a little better as it warms up a bit.
Orange colour with offwhite head. Aroma citrus notes. Taste quite bitter, some malt, bitter finish

Old rating rerated 04.08.2014, tap bottle @ Søgaards Bryghus: Small creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet grassy, leafs, sap, caramel malts, wet hops, dried fruits, grass. Taste is slightly dry grassy, wet grass, leafs, lawn, caramel malts, sap, hay. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Fair enough.

Tap @ Søgaards Bryghus. Deep orange with a small off-white head. Somewhat hazy. Aroma is mild malty with some toffee, some spicy hop aroma. Taste is light fruity and quite bitter. Light body and light carbonation aswell. Crisp, dry finish.
(tap 22/08-2013) very low white head, slightly unclear brown color, light hoppy aroma, sweet caramel taste, hoppy aftertaste, rather smooth, almost no bitterness.

From tap at the brewery. Pours hazy amber with a beige head. Aroma has sweeter honey, sweet caramel malts and some weak hops. A note of oxidation. Taste has weak laid back hops, sweet malts, some citrus and just overall to sweet for me when it comes to "US Pale ale’s".

Bottle, Salling Aalborg. Pours cloudy orange amber with a small off white head leaving small laces. Aroma is sweet malty some caramel and fruits. Flavor is sweet malty fruity and bitter. Finishes malty and bitter.
Unfiltered? amber with nice head. Some hops and some bitterness but nothing extra here but an anonymus danish variant of US pale ale

Tap@Ølfestival København 2018, Copenhagen - fuzzy golden pour with a white head. Fruity and sweet malty, some caramel sweetness, citrus light fruity, some grassy and floral nuances going on, medium body, spiced fruity finish

Copenhagen 1/5 2017. 50 cl bottle from Kvickly in Middelfart. As "Børglum Kloster - Bispens Trippel". Drawing of pictogram of Mary and Jesus on the label. Pours hazy orange with small white head. Settles as very thin almost transparent layer of foam. No lacing. Aroma is sweetish. A touch of lemonade from the Wheat malt, citrus and oranges with a fermented touch and a little sugary. Low carbonation and thick oily palate. Flavor is quite boozy. Medium sweet followed by harsh sourness. Aftertaste is sour bitter and with the alcohol coming clearly through. A bit thin in the flavor - apart from the alcohol. Some tipsy Monks hanging out at the Børglum Monastery.

Bottle from Voldby. (Børglum Kloster, Bispens trippel). Pours golden with an off-white head. Aroma and taste is malt, sweet fruits, caramel, yeast, alcohol. Full body. Soft carbonation. Nice warming finish.

Easy, but nice foam. Good aroma of the fruit. The taste is really good of both coriander, orange, peach and citrus. A very elegant triple. It has a pleasant, slightly sugar-like, sweetness that stands in good contrast to the fruity richness. Pure in flavor and very kind really.

Medium offwhite head. Brilliant clear brown body with carbonation. Fruity spicy herbal aroma with seeds of paradise notes. Clear and clean. Sweet fruity seeds of paradise taste with strawberry and clove notes. Fullish body. Sharpish, slightly hot mouthfeel. Dryish coriander, cloves and fruit aftertaste with herbal banana and licorice notes. Very nice and far too drinkable for 10.5%. (0.5l bottle, from Salling, Aalborg.)
0,5l Flasche. Dunkeloranges Bier mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Riecht leicht malzig und nach trockenen Früchten. Schmeckt ach so!

courtesy of Antonio Rey; under the name BØrglum Kloster Bispens Trippel - murky dark orange beer with a little foam left; solid spicy aroma of cumin, coriander, esters and ripe fruits (peaches, apples); quite soapy; very sweet, full-bodied, lot of residual sugars and long notes of peaches, cloves, bubblegum, alcohol and cumin - good yet too sweet for my liking
Tap @ Taphouse, Copenhagen 141024. Yeasty and spicy (cumin) with fruity notes, sweet, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is dry and bitter with spicy and alcohol notes.
Tap @ Taphouse, Copenhagen 24/10-14. Aroma: Yeasty, fruity, spicy, cumin. Taste: Yeasty, fruity. Body is medium, the finish is dry and spicy with warming alcohol.
25 cl, fad, Taphouse, 18. oktober 2014 Klar væske Gylden Ufiltreret Duft af nelliker, humle God let smag af lakrids/fennikel Svag/let karboneret Næsten ingen smag af alkohol
Mug at brygghus. Golden cloudy drink with malt aroma and citrus and fruit taste notes. Good summer beer. Best enjoyed cold rather than room.
Yellow of color with a white head. An aroma of citrus and spice. A flavor of spice, fruits and citrus.
Bottle at Københavnske øldage 07.. Yellow colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, apple, citrus. Flavour is dry, fruit, apple, hop, yeast, citrus. Ok beer.

Bottle at Københavnske Øldage. Pale yellowish body with a white head. Citrus, coriander and some unpleasant, vomit-like notes in the aroma. The flavor is quite fruity, with citrus and coriander, leading to a hoppy finish with pine and resin. A very refreshing beer, quite dry, and except for the little unpleasantness in the aroma, quite good. (070512)
Hazy yellow colour with a white head. Sweet fruity aroma with citric and hoppy notes. Malty, sweet and citric flavor with hoppy notes.
Draught at KØ07. Hazy golden colour. The flavour is slightly hoppy and citric. A bit like a naturtrüb Helles, but weaker. Light and easily drinkable.

Draft. A hazy light yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet spicy wiht light notes of coriander and yeast. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of straw. Beef up the hop usage, please.
Draught. Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. Sweet malty and fruity floral aroma. Sweet malty fruity flavor with soome hoppy hints. Has a sweet malty finish.
Københavnske Øldage 07. Light golden with a creamy head. The aroma is perfumed, fruity and floral. The flavour is rather light with notes of fruit, citrus and a light, rather dry bitterness. 2186
CBF07 sample from tap. Pours hazy yellow with a white creamy head. Aroma of wheat and citrus. flavour is sweet and sour bitter hops. Wheaty. Slight bitter to sour finish.
Fint humlet efter europæisk forbillede, med smag af bitterhumlen. Ikke en typisk humletype.
Clear amber color with small off-white head. Borring aroma, need hops. Flavor is sweet and bitter.
Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel´and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 120807
Bottle thanks to mes had at mes’s gaff. Alround rating: Malty, caramel, bit gariny malt, hops are fairly grassy, alround just on the sweetside of balanced.
Old notes from DØE Valby 07. Sampled as ’Tall Ships IPA’. Amber with an off-white head. Caramel and nice hops.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2007, Valby. Sampled as ’Tall Ships IPA’. Pours an amber beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malty with notes of hops, toffee and butter. The flavor is sweet with some bitterness, The palate is oily and lacks a good hoppy finish.
Bottle in Trend. Golden with a white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel) and hoppy (grass, citrus). Flavor moderate sweet and bitter. Light body. I also missed more hops.
50cl bottle @ Løvbjerg, Odense. Pours clear copper/amber with a small creamy white head. Floral hops, some peach and quite a lot of caramel and grass. Medium bodied. Pretty solid.
On tap at EBF 08. Attractive clear amber with thin beige head. Syrupy IPA aroma. Lots of caramel malt. Some biting hop. Hint of elderflower. Quite fruity malt. OK, but expected a bit more.
Ok beer, but a tad disappointing. I had hoped for some more bitterness, but it turned out to be slightly watery. Take the ale in stead.

Copenhagen 10/7 2018. 50 cl bottle from Meny. Usual Fur design this tilme with something Deep red, wet and sugary in the background. From the back label I can understand this is actually the Skull from a Turtle. Pours slightly hazy dark amber with small off-white head. Settles as extremely thin layer of bubbly foam. Aroma is surprisingly subdued. Heavy sweet, dark fermented fruit, leather, sugary, unwashed underwear, alcohol, Port wine. Vinous. Soft carbonation. Medium thick, sticky, soft, oily texture. Flavor is heavy sweet. Almost no bitterness present. Aftertaste is sweet and fairly sugary. Lingering sweetness. Nice and inous - event though a little bit one-dimensional.

Aroma: Malty sweet with caramel and brown sugar. Flavour: Malty sweet and brown sugar with dried fruits and alcoholic warmth. Colour: Amber with an offwhite head. From: Bottle @ Ølmesse Voldby Købmandsgård Sept. 2017
Mild and light version of an barley wine. Easy drinkable, with ok body and volume.

Drukket på Fur midt om natten ved et bål. Pours a light copper colour. Smells like a light bock beer or even a red ale. Getting no hops and Nothing really that I expect from a barley wine. Mostly light flavours of hay, toast and light caramel notes. This goes for both smell and taste. Light mouthfeel, light mineral and yeasty aftertaste. Would never have thought this was a barley wine if tasted blind.

Bottle from Foder Engros, Hammel. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma and taste is malt, caramel, dried fruits, brown sugar. Full body. Soft carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Nice bittersweet finish.
så fås der næsten ikke en bedre øl - uhm meget flot farve flot skum rigtig god duft - sødlig smagen er uovertruffen dejlig :):):) den bedste øl jeg har smagt

Medium deep offwhite head. Clear still reddish brown body. Fruity perfumy anise aroma with caramelly notes. Sweet earthy spicy anise taste with fruity notes. Full-bodied. Mild, slightly hot mouthfeel. Sweetish caramelly sugary anise aftertaste with alcoholic raisiny notes. Quite nice, but the fruitiness is a bit overripe, and the anise is too dominant. Lacking in bitterness. (0.5l bottle, from Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

En barley wine er ofte skarp smagen, men den her er helt rund i det. Lugten og til dels også smagen er ligesom denne 2 år gamle øl har ligget på noget træfade. Den har en helt forrygende smag. Velmaltet og lidt humlet. Gad vide om den bliver bedre med alderen.
Bottle - amber coloured pour with beige head. Medium sweet malty aroma and taste, toasty, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dried fruity and nutty, some spices on the palate, medium sweet bitter finish.

Nice frothy, which is unusual for a barley wine. It smells delicious and welcoming of dark grapes and dried fruit. Lovely vinous taste the grapes, plum and fig. It is a barley which is not as intrusive as a whole, and it suits the great good. It has already gotten a little port wine notes, although it is only 2 years old, so even though it is not as brash as many other barleys, it has nevertheless its own little charm that makes it very appealing.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: Golden pour with a little head and no lacing. Smooth flavor with a nice hint of basil and oregano coming through, really giving it a subtle pizza flavor. Unique in many ways, this was more enjoyable than I expected.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: Growler RBSG 07. Yellow pour with a short white head. Aroma of oregano, basil, tomato, light pepper and pale malt. Flavors of basil, light tomato, pale malt, yeast, and oregano. Light body, malty, spicy, pizza-ie. The most interesting brew of that night hands down, I only wish I had a slice of pepperoni at the time for garnish. Major points for originality.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: On tap at the brewpub on 6/20/07: Pours a transparent yellow golden with a full-lacing frothy white head. Aroma of basil, oregano and garlic along with a touch of pale malt, really does smell like pizza. Body starts with some light caramel malty sweetness, a touch of bready yeast, tomato and Italian spice balance. Incredibly unique and strangely enjoyable.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: RBSG 07 Minneapolis Grand Tasting: Hazy gold, no head or lacing. Nose of basil, a little oregano, light tomato, some malt and dough. The flavor is clean, light malts, lots of spices. Interesting beer that really tastes like pizza. Wish I could try a pint.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: (Growler) Pours a lightly cloudy amber body with a small white head. Aroma of basil, oregano, olives, tomato, and sour dough. Somewhat offensive herbal flavor with garlic and tomato. Interesting...

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: Date: 06/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy light yellow, fine white head, bits of lace, aroma of pizza spices with garlic and basil, tastes exactly like pizza with tomato and basil and garlic on a yeasty fresh bread crust, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: Sampled at the GTMW Wierd. Hazed yellow with no head. It smells and tastes like pizza spices. Oregano and garlic seemed to be in the front. Certainly worth trying.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting. Cloudy yellow with no head. Oregano/basil nose and flavor, some breadiness. Weak body detracts from what could have been a pretty interesting beer. I think some flavors are noticed through the power of "pizza suggestion". Still, not bad for what is basically a gimmick beer.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: (Tap @ Brewpub) Pours a hazy light amber color, with little head. Very fragrant, with a strong oregano aroma that can be detected across the table. I personally expected more in the way of tomatoes, but all I really got was the spices (oregano, basil, garlic) and some funk. Garlic is especially notable in the aftertaste. That being said, this is still a very good beer that is certainly worth trying! I could have actually drank a couple more of these.

column1: Americas Tom Seefurth's Mamma Mia Pizza Beer
column5: Sample from growler, RBSG Minneapolis Grand Tasting, June 23 2007. Pale amber with no real head, oily-looking....overpowering basil aroma, hints of tomato creep in, lightly doughy malts, and eventually some smokiness.....the flavor is, actually rather pizza-like, or more precisely, bruschetta: lots of tomato, light Italian spicing, light bready malts....unfortunately it’s too thin, watery, and has almost no carbonation; a better mouthfeel and this would be more than just a novelty, which is what it is in its current state if you ask me. Still, an interesting one and one of my favorite memories from RBSG regardless of the numbers.

column4: OGriffs Irish Pub, Grill and Brew House
column5: From the tap, served at a cooler cellar temperature in a pint glass. Poured a very lightly orange hued golden with a foamy, bubbly white head that settled into a thin lacing. Had a spicy, herbal leafy nose with a soft, clean sweet pilsener maltiness, the hops come on a bit strong, otherwise just fine. Good moderate, tiny bubbly carbonation and a nicely crisp, dry, cleansing brisk, smooth light bodied mouthfeel. More balanced in the taste than in the aroma, spicy hops with a soft herbal bitterness, dry, clean, sweet pilsener malty, a light lemon honey emerges towards the end, and a dry, crisp, clean finish, the finish you want from a pilsener, firm, assertive, cleansing in the palate, not watery. This was a very fresh tasting pilsener, perfect on a hot spring date, easy, quaffable drinkability, another good German style lager from O’Griff’s.

column4: OGriffs Irish Pub, Grill and Brew House
column5: From the tap, served at cellar temperature in a pint glass. Poured a clear, bright reddish orange with a foamy, bubbly topped white head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing. Spicy, herbal hoppy nose with a light fruitiness, apples and green grapes, a backing of sweet malts. Good carbonation and a crisp, dryish, smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel. Pleasant tasting, but I would have liked a more assertive Maibock taste, thin, sweet sugary maltiness, apples and grapes with lemon squeezed over them, the fruitiness mixes with the alcohol to give a mild acidity to the taste, spicy hops that provide a soft bitterness, and a dry fruity, sweet malty finish. I wish this had more of a Maibock/Helles Bock malt profile, the thinness of the malts deceases the drinkability for me, just too sweet overall. Not a bad spring offering, but could be much better.

Draft at brewpub. Poured cloudy golden color with an average fizzy white head that lasted and had good lacing. Moderate fruity citrus wheat aroma. Light body with a smooth texture. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet short finish. Drinkable not my style beer.

tap @ brewpub.....aroma: orange peel, citrus, wheaty with some banana and coriander....appearance: a golden murky yellow elixir with thin white head....taste: very much like its aroma, mildly carbonated, somewhat watery, subdued flavor but generally a drinkable sessionable beer.

Nothing spectacular, but worth the try. Smells like Froot Loops, looks like heavily salted water with a tiny head. Does taste like blue moon belgian white, with the fruity white ale flavor. Orange peel / coriander , lemon peel, etc.

On tap @ Founders. The name makes me think they really didn’t care too much about this one. It was OK for a wheat, but nothing all that great. Very light golden in color. A little citrus in the nose, a little watery.

On tap at Founders. This beer had little character. Light, spicy wheat, grain, and soapy notes, in addition to a touch of spice. Watery, bland, and peculiar. The uninspired name says it all. Of course, most beers would pale in comparison to the Kentucky Breakfast Stout and Backwoods Bastard on tap...

on tap at Founders...hazy yellow body with large white head...Blue Moon aroma (light orange peel, wheat, and coriander--with just a touch of honey)...flavor is that of a watered down Blue Moon...thin, watery palate...pretty much a waste of a tap handle
Can: pours deep gold with white head. Aroma is citrus and a hint of pineapple. Taste is a bit bitter, balanced malt backbone, fruitiness. Pretty solid.

PKD 040919. From a can poured a slightly hazy mid amber with 2cm of beige dense foam that retained extremely well and laced very well. Carbonation high, lively and fine to medium. Aroma of sweet citrus, grapefruit and pine with malt undertones; alcohol well hidden. Taste is slightly sweet with orange and tangerine, grapefruit, tropical fruits (pineapple) and hints of pine and caramel malt; moderately strong resinous hoppy bitterness; unpleasant alcohol burn. Medium body. Smooth, crisp and dry with a lingering finish.
Can, TW-SP. Murky orange pour, small frothy off-white head. Aroma is stale hops, licorice, citrus peel, shitty resin. Flavor is stale hops, orange and grapefruit peel, resin. Tastes old.

Can. Pours hazy golden, large fluffy white head, good lacing. Aroma is pine, grass, oranges. Smells a lot like an old west coast IPA, which isnt surprising considering the March 2019 brewed on date on the bottom of the can. I am sure its past its prime, but it is for sale; and that is on MBC for not policing their clients better. Medium body.

30-Jun-17 (12-oz can, Canned 31-May-17: Purchased 30-Jun-17 for $3.49 at Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) This Imperial IPA pours a very hazy, pale-orange body and half an inch of off-white head that settles to a dusty sheet and creamy ring, leaving some spotty lacing on the glass. The nose is very fruity, with aromas of mango, cantaloupe, orange citrus, and ripe peach, but no malt at all. On the palate, again, it's all ripe, fleshy tropicals, melons, grapefruit and tangerine, lightly sweet actually, with a vague, minimal-impact malt base and light-medium, resiny hop bitterness. The beer is medium-plus in weight, medium in carbonation, and slightly astringent. Overall, this is a pleasant, modern, very fruity IPA. Quite pleasant for the style.

Refrigerated 12 oz. aluminum can poured into a glass. Hazy deep golden with medium/small white head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is herbal hops and some citrus hops.

Fairly clear golden coloured body with a larger, two centimetre tall head with a nice glowing tan body that shows some depth and punch. Light hoppy aroma with more emphasis on the malts, alcohol and yeast - not too strong, but showing some flavours for sure. Medium-bodied; Nice assertive grainy flavours with a lot of alcohol and more subdued hops with some grassy and herbal notes, but no tropical fruits, resin or pine flavours at all - a relatively good balance, but a bit thin, especially for the style and not showing too many hops, compared to all the malts. Aftertaste is more grainy and bitter from the malt and alcohol than anything else - the hops hit relatively softly with a deft cover of grain near the end. Overall, a fairly good beer that shows much less of an Imperial IPA than anything else - but some softer malts, a good mild bitterness from some fruits with little else. I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from the Food Pantry [express] on Kuhio in Waikiki, Honolulu, O'ahu on 26-December-2018 for US$10,88/six pack sampled the a few minutes after arriving to celebrate Christmas here on the Islands, on 26-December-2018.

I’ve had this before I think. Nice piney, citrusy nose. Carbonated nicely in this 350 ml can offering from Maui Brewing. Smooth drinking with the big ABV and it tastes like an 8.5, luckily I like alcohol and I like this one too. Hoppy, laid back malts, what’s not like?

Sampled from the tap at World Of Beer St. Paul. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has bitter pine and citrus rind with a hint of juicy citrus and sweet grains backing. Flavor has citrus and a decent amount of resin with a grain backbone.
Can from Cotteridge Wines; hazy orange pour with a thin off white head, aroma has pine and sweet malts, taste has tangerine, some pine, grapefruit, ok

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: From tap. Pours golden in color with lingering head. Great hop and bread aroma. Taste follows with a great biscuit and fruity hop taste.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: Random bottle I had while visiting North Caroline. This stuff was very simple but very to style and refreshing. Highly sessionable with a great malt body and a much more prevalent hop presence than I was expecting.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Amber in color. This is more like a lager than an ale. The hop flavoring is very harsh and not a smoothly mellow as the Southern Pale Ale.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Small white head on top of a straw colored brew. A touch of hops and straw in the nose. The flavor is a very thin, a bit of hops, but it’s just so perfectly clean tasting and finishes completely balanced. I could have a good time chugging this stuff all night long.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: Had this quickly after the straight Pale Ale and enjoyed this one a bit more. On draft at the brewpub. Nice hop aroma with some pine and pronounced citrus smells. A sort of faint amber color with a short offwhite head. Caramel malt flavors add to the body. Good bubblegum hop flavors as well.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: Date: 02/02/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark copper, fine white head, streaks of lace, Aroma: sweet caramel malt aroma with light floral hops, Flavor: light sweet malt flavor, touch of crystal for sweetness, light floral hops for balance, long bitter finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: on tap-pours a dissipating off white head and gold/amber color. Aroma is mild citrus hops, faint medium malt. Taste is citrus hops-some bitterness, very dry, some medium malt, roasty. Good carbonation.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: On Tap. Pours a coppery color with a smallish white head. Aroma is caramel malts, floral hops, citrus. Flavor is caramel, grapefruit, light orange. Palate is medium to light bodied, medium carbonation, finished lightly bitter. Decent.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: Nice amber pour with a huge eggshell head that coated the glass all the way. There is a lot of sweetbread in the bouquet... almost like toffee meets dough.... interesting. This starts off with quite a bit of caramel malt, and is immediately contrasted by a pale, biscuit note. Just like their APA, this has a nicely bitter finish, only with bit more residual sugar, accompanied by a tinge of copper. At first, to be honest, I actually thought this was a combo of their APA and amber ales. However, upon further scrutiny, it’s a brew of its own, introducing special biscuit bitters and copper into this recipe. Not bad... the sweetness tends to stay "just" this side of cloying, but it was a nice way to round out the 4th of July.

column1: Natty Greene's Patriot Extra Pale Ale
column5: pours out a nice clean golden yellow color with a nice white head. aroma is very clean and somewhat yeasty. flavor was bland and watered down. i didnt expect much from this beer and that is what i got in return
0,5l bottle Nürnberg - small hazy golden with a white head - aromas of banana yeast and fruits - taste is light and fruity
50cl swing top bottle. Pours hazy dark golden colour with a mid-sized good lasting white head. Aroma of yeast, mild banana and some clove. Taste of banana, sweet fruits, breadish, some clove.

Schöne hefetrübe, helle Farbe, schöner feinpooriger Schaum. Frisch-hefig-weiziger Geruch. Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-hefig-mild, schön weich. Der Hauptteil ist mild-weizig, hefig. Schön rund. Der Nachgeschmack ist mittellang, schön mild-weizig. Zum letzten Teil des Nachgeschmacks wird das Bier ganz leicht herb, und der Nachgeschmack fällt relativ schnell ab. Trotzdem ein schönes, rundes Weizen. Test vom 24.11.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,12,12,9,12,10 - 10,75

It’s unclear golden with a creamy, huge and white head. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit, light banana included and wheat. The sweet flavor has notes of yeast, fruit including banana, wheat, and the finish is slightly spicy.
Hazy golden color. Aroma is: cloves, wheat, refreshing fruit, banana. Flavor is refreshing, sour fruit, wheat, bit yeasty.

Bottle 50cl. w. swing top @ home. Unclear hazy medium orange color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate yeasty, banana, rubber notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090830]

(swing top bottle) Cloudy, orange colour with a big but not very persistent foamy white head. Sourish and slightly sweet fruity nose of overripe citrus and a touch of banana, accompanied by clovy spice. Light-sweet and sourish flavour, light bodied with a lively carbonation. Moderately wheaty and citrus fruity taste; a rising bitterness and clovy spices become a bit harsh towards the finish (02.XI.08).

Bøgelverschlußflaše:Deep golden, cloudy, mid-sized fluffy head, that slowly diminishes, moderate sweetish-fruity nose (mainly bananas, some lemons, too) with wheaty spots; moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, maybe with a light bitterness, light to medium bodied; sweetish wheaty-fruity finish with a light, late tartness. Decent,noz exciting............

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body:   Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 4     Pale Yellow(1)->Copper(5) : 1     Still(1)->Volcanic Sparkling(5) : 3 Head:   None(1)->Large(5) : 4     Lasting: 4     Lacing : 4 Aroma: Intensity : 3   Yeast : 4   Bread : XX   Dough : 2   Esters : XX   Phenols : 2   Dusty : XX   Spicy : XX   Apple : XX   Banana : 2   Tropical Fruits : XX   Brett : XX   Barnyard : XX   Leather : XX   Wood : XX   Vinous : XX   Cheese : XX   DMS : XX   Diacetyl : 2 Sulfur : XX Malt : 3   Pilsner : XX   Pale : XX   Vienna : XX   Biscuity : XX   Toasty : XX   Hay : XX   Caramel : XX   Honey : XX   Cereals : XX   Grainy : XX   Wheat : 3 Hops : 1   Noble(1)->American(5) : 1   Leafy : XX   Perfume : XX   Orange : XX   Floral : XX   Lemon/Lime : XX   Herbal : XX   Grassy : XX   Piney : XX Notes : Pepper : XX   Cloves : XX   Coriander : XX   Ginger : XX   Orange : XX   Earth : XX   Vanilla : XX   Oxidation : XX   Bubblegum : 3 Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3   Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 3   Sourness : 2   Acetic : XX   Lactic : XX   Bitterness : XX   Farmy : XX   Complex : XX   Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 3   Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 4   Clean : XX   Sharp : XX   Watery : XX   Oily : 2   Chalk : XX   Astringent : XX   Alcohol : XX   Mineral : XX Comments: A juicy, bubblegummy weizen with little complexity.

Bottled. A hazy orange beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet wheaty with strong notes of banana and lesser notes of spices. The flavor is sweet and very wheaty combined with notes of straw, yeast, and banana.
Bottle at Oliver Twist - shared with Mette. Clear red/brown/cobber - white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Grassy, pine, citrus, grape, light sweetness, spicy, medium malty. Very lovely !!

Tap. Beautiful red brown colour. Nice off white head. Very fresh fruity aroma, I can especially smell celery, that’s new for me! Heavy fruity flavour, mostly peach. Extremely fresh. Strong and bitter finish, with some fruitiness still going strong. (Glenfiddich Warehouse Stockholm, 24.07.07)

Draught @ Bishop’s Arms, Malmö. Pours a clear amber color with a smalloff-white head. Fruity malty floral hoppy aroma. Sweet malty hoppy flavor with some piney hints. Sweet malty hoppy finish with a bitter aftertaste.

Draught at Warehouse 68, Stockholm. Very balanced IPA with fair amount of hops and a great malty backbone. It is quite refreshing and while it is not packed with flavor, it is still inviting. Nice enjoyable afternoon beer.

Draught at Bishop’s Arms, Malmö Beautiful hazy amber color; thin persistent head. The aroma is well hoppy, a lot aromatic, hop fruitness too. The flavor is less malty than many others, the body is not too strong, but the hopping is really bold, hoppy, resiny, aromatic, wondeful, Very good beer.
Fully golden colour with an off white head. Hoppy, fruity and piney bitter aroma. Light malty and sweet flavor with a clear hoppy citric note. Long dry and piney finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a clear, amber golden with a creamy, yellowish head. Fat, hoppy aroma. Medium body with dry, nutty accents, fat, hoppy citrus notes and a dry, hoppy finish. This is dry as a bone and way too dry for my palate - there’s fundamentally some residual sweetness lacking here. 160607

Draught at Akkurat. Amber with thick creamy head. Powerful hoppy aroma.. can’t recall any brew as having a fresher hop aroma than this! Fair bit of bittering hops too.. Not very balanced, but with hops like this.. who cares?

Draught, Mackinlay’s Inn Cloudy, rather opaque dark amber pour. Strongly hoppy, resiny one with pontent orange notes. Slight earthy, orange, mango peaks - remaining a citrus oriented product, with only shy malts supporting it. Fruity, light exotic notes, minimal, not even toasty, but rather grainy support foundations. Fair medium body with average carbonation. A bit ordinary for Dugges, their usual malt complexity lacks to me.

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours out in a hazy amber colour with a lot’s of yrast sediments in the bortom. Rich tan-coloured foam. Dryish hop-aroma of floders, grapefruit, pine-needlses, pepper and spices with notes of caramel. Dryish, almost dusty flavour all the way through of grapefruit, spices, wormwood, grass and pine-needles. Dryish and really bitter finish
Igazi, a magyar urtyp, igazi széna szalma vagy valamelyik aromákkal. Istálló, barnyard jut még eszembe

Draught at Pedro Sörörsö, the brewpub. Clear golden colour with a thin white head. Sweet aroma with pale malts, grasses and sweet fruits. Taste is light sweet. Medium body with a creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes slightly dry with pale malts and fruits. Nice Lager that comes from the brewery just behind the restaurant. Freshness is essential.
Draught at Lake Balaton. Dark yellow beer with light Co2 and minimal foam. But the taste is quite correct: malty, and the finish is a little bitter. Just a cheap-yeast aroma makes wrong it.
Light and creamy lager. Goes down smooth with a nice dry and slightly bitter finish. Sadly has a bit of that macrolager stale malt flavor too though. The other beers available from them are better.
How: Draught. Where: Főzdefeszt IX, Budapest. Appearance: Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Malt, some bread. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, some hops.
1l bottle. Clear golden body, white head. Aroma of bready malts and a hint of fruity hops. Taste of bread, grains with some metallic tones and a little grassy hop bitterness. It’s an OK beer.

The beer available at only the brewery on tap or in a 1-liter-bottle to take away. Clear golden body, nice white lacing head. Sourish yeast aroma, some floral hop and sandly: diacetil. In the flavor is some diacetil too, but not too strong. Hay, sunflower and malt in the medium body, grassy hop taste, bitter aftertaste. One more week in the cellar and the beer would be better.

The best thing about the Cabin Boy is the look in the glass - all cloudy gold and lots of bubbles. The aroma is marshmallow, boiled lollies, lots of dirty socks and a little grapefruit and lemon. The taste is incredibly sour, almost like you’re sucking on a warhead but I must say that the taste kind of grew on me - not an easy drinker, but worth a go.

With sediment poured a cloudy light gold colour and developed a one-finger white foamy head that collapsed quickly. Spotty lacing. High carbonation - lots of fine bubble trails. Aroma strongly of sour malt with a note of spices. Taste sour. Light body. Finish very sour. (Batch Number looks like L2002)
Out of the bottle at the brewhouse. Very light in colour for a wit. Very soft, subtle nose and same comes through in the tast. Lightly spiced. Good for summer if you a very light wit

It look fantastic, with the dark and full presence with a mocha head but this as not reflected in the taste. Very poor, had some chocolate and mocha aftertastes but had an overwhelming unpleasant zing too it. Didn’t finish the beer.

Tap at the brewhouse. Watery brown pour with a small white head. Nose is charred chocolate. Taste is heavy to medium bitter chocolate with a solid belgian influence. Not too bad. Light bitterness on the finish. Better than most of their beers

330ml bottle. Highly carbonated with a crackling coffee coloured foam that immediiately fills the glass. Deep burnt brown to black colour with roasted malt and bitter dark chocolate in the aroma. Lively in the mouth with some zing to it. Bitterness and roast flavours come in later.

This only scored as high as this because it looked like a stout but this beer went down the drain after two sips. Very thin palate with a sour taste that was unpalatable. One of the worst beers I’ve had unfortunately.
On tap at Kutztown Tavern. Poured a murky brown with thin cream head. Light roasted aroma with minimal vanilla. Med light carb with light bod. Taste of malt caramel and min bourbon.

On tap, at brewery. This was not good. It took their very nice Onyx stout and basically ruined it. I didn’t notice any bourbon at all. There was some vanilla, and a cough medicine/cough drop flavor that was very off putting.

On tap in the Kutztown local. Very dark ruby with dark tan cream head. Creamy malt with powder cocoa nose, vanilla texture. Malt happy and drinking this down was a pleasure. Aroma of light sweet Hershey cocoa and muddled cask conditioned roast was very nice. Liking this!

Nice bold flavor. A very sweet stout that packs a punch. Caramel and vanilla are strong, even overpowering, but slight bitterness and dark stout flavor helps to temper it. The brewery will not let you take growlers of this home! I voiced my dissatisfaction.

Dark body, small medium tan head. Nose is pure vanilla extract syrup. Taste is pasty and sweet, turns basically into a vanilla soda over the middle, finishing with some roasted vanilla beans and cola. Weird. No stout in there at all, and no bourbon whatsoever, just vanilla, vanilla and more vanilla.

Rating #700, woohoo! Draft @ Golden Avalanche, pre-BCTC beerventure. Pours a dark cola color; medium tan head with fine-bubbled lacing. Vanilla extract and light chocolate in the aroma. Overly sweet, marshmallow and cheap vanilla extract upfront; more of a cola character than any sort of legitimate bourbon, with some warm chocolate and no show of alcohol. Doesn’t seem to be much bourbon or stout in here, just vanilla cola. Still drinkable, but not good. Only ABV info I could find was "it’s probably above 7%, because it’s a big beer."
on tap-pours a thin light tan head and dark brown color. Aroma is cherry, vanilla, malt, chocolate. Taste is more Jack Daniel-like than the aroma and not quite as good as the aroma. A bit thin.
Brown Color with Orange Hue and Sandy Head. Dark Malt/Bread Aroma. Light to Medium Moutfheel, Although Session Drinkability. Rasin, Dark Breads..Dry Malt...Crisp, Dry and Enjoyable.

Densely bodied, dark, pale brown color with a slight dark orange cast to the edges. Soft, finger high head of lighty sandy browned white, firmly creamed foam. Tons of lacing decorates the glass in broken sheeting. Aroma is very light and soft; clean, crisp, and rounded with a pale grassy, whole grain maltyness that would seem like what a Pilsner should smell like. Just not very aromatic in any fashion. Flavors are very nice and pleasantly rounded on the palate. Crisp, full, wholesome, clean pale malt profile and Pils malt taste. Kinda bready, tender with a touch of toasted grassyness and a very tiny puff of roast and cocoa. Clean favorable finish that is only a titch dry and has a late, light grassy pinch. Nice. Body is about medium with a smooth, yet tense carbonation grab thats well-balanced, firm, and holds a nice tone the whole way through. Drinkabilty is outstanding! A nearly perfect Pils. A great job by Great Waters "Bob" on this one. A summer drinker keeper! Yum!

A dark pilsner? Hmm... Dark brown color with a medium head. Has the aroma of Noble hops and some residual graininess. The taste is a bit more barley-like than, say, Pilsner Urquell. Also some roasted malt. Not enough to turn me off to it, but just enough to say "hey there, I’m not normal!" Interesting and solid effort.

column1: Lost Duck Simply The Blues Bock
column5: Brewed especially for the May "Simply The Blues" music festival in Fort Madison. From the tap, served at cellar temperature in a pint glass. Poured a clear reddish orange hued copper with a slightly off-white head, decent retention, settled into a thin lacing, minimal amount of sticking. A nice Maibock aroma, toasted grains and caramel, apples with a light lemon, spicy with a very soft scent of herbal hops, and a gentle whiff of alcohol. Good even, steady carbonation and a crisp, dry, velvety smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel, pretty close to perfect for a Maibock. This is a straightforward Maibock/Helles Bock, but well brewed, balanced and delicious tasting, toasted grainy and sugary with a nice touch of caramel, fresh green apple slices with a light amount of lemon squeezed over them, the fruitiness mixes with the alcohol to give a mild amount of acidity to the taste, spicy hops that turn lightly herbal in the finish, and a dry, toasted grainy finish. I know the Lost Duck can do a good job with pale lagers, even their lite lager is first rate, but for me, everything else is hit or miss, mainly a big miss, but I was stunned, floored by this bock, absolutely first rate, upon the first sip, taste in my palate I knew that I would spend the rest of the night with this, a beautiful beer, I can’t praise it enough, I wish the Duck put this kind of effort into all of their beers.
This is just completely terrible and undrinkable. I can’t believe it was put on the market.

At the Heritage Brew Festival on tap. Pale amber pour with a decent small bead head. Light texture with a pleasant malt taste and sweetness; light hop character. This is quite good. Of course, AB is 5 miles away and brings their stuff in fresh for the festivals. If AB products tasted this fresh and good at an average pub nationwide, they’d completely control the market.

Sample at the Heritage Festival. Only got to try three of the seven St. Louis Dark Lager styles. Or a least only jotted some notes for three. Given that this one took the silver according to my notes. Filtered and amber hued. Layer of thick off-white head. Light bready with a touch floral aroma. Toasty caramel flavor. Easy drinking.

Also sampled at the Brewfest. I was proud of AB for sponsoring this event and tried to sample several of their offerings. However, I was disappointed by this one. The aftertaste was disagreeable and the flavor a bit harsh.
(tap at the brewfest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor. I thought this was one of the two best tries of the festival beer.
(tap at the brewfest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor. Medium bodied. Middle of the pack at the brewfest.

Sampled at the Heritage Festival. Second sample of the Festival beers and got the bronze, only because I only notes three. Filtered and amber hued. Moldy off-white head. Caramel and woody notes in the aroma. Light bready and dry. One dimensional. Mildly more bitter than AB’s
(tap at the brewfest) Medium brown. Mild malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor. Medium bodied. Middle of the pack at the brewfest.
